webTitle: Javed takes the reins for Pakistan

fields.headline: Javed takes the reins for Pakistan
fields.trailText: Javed Miandad, following the resignation of Intikhab Alam, has taken over as Pakistan's coach for the third and final Test against Sri Lanka starting tomorrow in Karachi.
fields.body:
Javed Miandad, following the resignation of Intikhab Alam, has taken over as Pakistan's coach for the third and final Test against Sri Lanka starting tomorrow in Karachi.

"He [Miandad] has been appointed with immediate effect until July 13," said Yawar Saeed, the Pakistan Cricket Board's director of operations.

During the second Test in Peshawar the board announced that Miandad would replace Intikhab at the end of the series. Sri Lanka lead 2-0.

"I have had enough. I have been removed unceremoniously, which I don't deserve," a disgruntled Intikhab said.

Miandad commented: "Intikhab was unlucky that Pakistan lost two close matches and it is an honour for me to replace him since he was my coach in 1992. It's just a matter of one victory, and I am sure things will fall into place."

Australia recalled Colin Miller and Damien Martyn as the three-Test series against New Zealand got under way this morning in Auckland. It is Martyn's first Test in some six years, with Ricky Ponting's ankle injury possibly keeping him out for six months. Miller replaces the injured fast bowler Damien Fleming.

fields.headline: Redknapp cheers 'panto villain' Di Canio
fields.trailText: Paolo di Canio must expect a few one-finger salutes this afternoon, and not from behind people's backs. The West Ham striker returns to Hillsborough for the first time since he pushed over Paul Alcock.
fields.body:
Paolo di Canio must expect a few one-finger salutes this afternoon, and not from behind people's backs. The West Ham striker returns to Hillsborough for the first time since he pushed over Paul Alcock.

"Paolo knows what is coming," said West Ham's manager Harry Redknapp. "He knows he is going to get some stick and that he just has to get on and deal with it."

That Di Canio will get a rough ride is beyond dispute. The Alcock incident 18 months ago proved his last contribution in Wednesday colours as he declined to return from Italy on medical grounds after completing his 11-match ban.

The 31-year-old hardly helped matters by insisting the club had not supported him. And some fans were unimpressed when he refused to return the trophy they awarded him as player of the year. There were even threats to sue him for its £85 cost.

Redknapp, though, sympathises with the man who went from hero to zero. "I think Paolo felt he never got the backing of the club after he pushed the referee," he said. "It wasn't the supporters who were a problem. He thought the fans were great."

What worries Redknapp more about today is the effect the "pantomime" anti-Di Canio atmosphere might have on the referee and his assistants. He hopes Peter Jones "doesn't get caught up in the swing of it". With Di Canio, it is usually the shove of it.

"Linesmen sometimes enjoy putting their flag up to give the home side an offside decision because the crowd all cheer," Redknapp said, "and the home fans will cheer any mistake Paolo makes.

"I'm not saying it to try to get an edge, it is a genuine fear. It is easy for the officials to go along with the sway of the crowd. It is almost pantomime-like with all boos and cheers, so I can see it happening."

Wednesday desperately need a win to have any hope of avoiding the drop, and there was ominous news for one of their struggling counterparts Derby, who visit Old Trafford.

Manchester United have not been at their best of late but Sir Alex Ferguson warned yesterday: "Someone is going to suffer. Someone is going to get a walloping from us and the sooner the better really. A good result would put us on the road, I think. We're just missing a few too many chances."

Ferguson's assistant, Steve McClaren, will enjoy a more low-key reunion with a former club than Di Canio. He spent four years as assistant to Jim Smith at Derby - "quite an ordeal," he joked - and recalled: "He got me into the tasting of the red wine during many team talks into the early hours."

The reunions continue at Tottenham, where Glenn Hoddle returns to his first club as Southampton manager. One point from the past nine has dragged the Saints back into trouble.

"Glenn is a hero at Tottenham and deservedly so," said the Spurs manager George Graham. "He did for Tottenham what Liam Brady did for Arsenal. They were midfield magicians and it is sad that those type of players have gone from the game and been replaced by all-action players."

Bobby Robson picked up his first manager of the month award at Newcastle yesterday and promptly tried to dampen expectation ahead of today's visit of the bottom club Watford.

In September Newcastle won 8-0 against Sheffield Wednesday, then at the bottom, but Robson said: "Eight-nil drubbings are romantic, not realistic".

Wimbledon's embattled manager Egil Olsen, has spoken to John Hartson to clarify the striker's future. "There is no bad feeling," Olsen said. "John wants to help us stay in the Premiership. I don't need to sell any players and I won't until our position is safe."

webTitle: Real drop Anelka for training snub

fields.headline: Real drop Anelka for training snub
fields.trailText: Real Madrid yesterday dropped Nicolas Anelka from their squad for this evening's home match with Seville after the recalcitrant former Arsenal striker refused to train.
fields.body:
Real Madrid yesterday dropped Nicolas Anelka from their squad for this evening's home match with Seville after the recalcitrant former Arsenal striker refused to train.

The France international, who left Highbury last summer for £23m after a protracted wrangle between Real and Lazio, is understood to be unhappy with the tactics of the coach Vicente del Bosque.

"Nicolas Anelka, as a Real Madrid player, has certain obligations to the club," Del Bosque said. "One of those is to train. I reminded Nicolas that this is not a school playground but a professional club, but he still refused to train... tomorrow he will have to train with the injured players."

However Real are unlikely to do more than fine their expensive investment and he is expected to be available for selection for next Tuesday's Champions League visit of Dynamo Kiev.

"His behaviour hurts me because I think that it shows a lack of respect for his team-mates. But I don't think it's a fault that deserves 100 years in prison," Del Bosque added.

"Nicolas has always been treated with love by the club in general and by me in particular. This is a bad example for the young players at the club."

Anelka has had a difficult introduction to life in Spain, scoring his first and so far only league goal for the club in last month's 3-0 win against Barcelona.

Only seven months into a seven-year deal, Anelka gave the first inkling that all was not well back in September when he claimed he was so unhappy that he was considering quitting the game. In November he complained about being played out of position and later that month he missed training with an injury, although the Real medics declared him to be fit.

Stoke City's manager Gudjon Thordarson has signed his son, a versatile Iceland midfielder Bjarni Gudjonsson, from Genk for £250,000. The 21-year-old spent 18 months at Newcastle United in the Kenny Dalglish era before moving to Belgium in 1998.

West Bromwich have parted company with the coach Allan Evans following the appointment of Gary Megson as manager. Evans was appointed earlier this season by Brian Little, who was sacked on Monday.

 Belize and Guatemala will face each other on a neutral ground in their 2002 World Cup qualifying matches because of their border tensions. The first match will be played on March 19 in Panama and it is likely that the return will also be played there on May 21. Guatemala has claimed parts, and at times all, of Belize during the past 150 years, though it officially recognised Belize's borders in 1992.

webTitle: Jags back on the road to cup glory

fields.headline: Jags back on the road to cup glory
fields.trailText: Partick Thistle have been in free fall since dropping to the Scottish Second Division but a victdory today against Ayr United will put them into the semi-finals of the Scottish Cup.
fields.body:
Partick Thistle are the native sons of Starbuck country but the coffee houses, the wine bars and the fusion restaurants of Glasgow's west end have a habit of ignoring their local football team. Not today, though.

Everybody's favourite other club are fashionable again and coaches have been booked to take 2,500 of their fans to Somerset Park, the home of Ayr United, for today's Scottish Cup tie, with a place in the semi-finals at stake.

These are heady times for the Jags, famously remembered for their Scottish League Cup triumph in 1971 in which they beat Celtic 4-1 (4-0 at half-time, which prompted the then Grandstand presenter Frank Bough to say: "That may be wrong, we'll check it").

The club has been in free fall since dropping to the Second Division and losing the support of the minority of Glaswegians who enjoy their football without the background noise of crude sectarian chants. But they are staging a mini-revival.

They will start underdogs because no Second Division team have reached a semi- final since league reorganisation in 1975. But they do possess a remarkable man in their team, the 38-year-old Ray Montgomerie, who has already experienced the elation of climbing the Hampden Park stairs to claim the cup.

He was Kilmarnock's captain when they beat Falkirk in the final three years ago. Ayr counter with another 38-year-old, Albert Craig, who played for Hamilton when they beat Graeme Souness's Rangers at Ibrox in 1987, arguably the biggest upset in recent finals.

"I get a lot of inspiration from guys such as Richard Gough and Lothar Matthäus and I have no plans to pack the game in for a long time," Montgomerie says. He is one of those odd footballers, a man who should have been capped for Scotland but never was.

Another non-Premier League side, Falkirk, take on Hibernian. Falkirk were Kilmarnock's victims in that 1997 final and under Alex Totten they have reserved their best for these one-off contests. Hibs, however, have looked like finalists for much of the season.

Rangers play Hearts on television tomorrow evening and their captain Lorenzo Amoruso said mischievously, after the league was virtually wrapped up at Celtic: "We can now concentrate on the cup."

It is not a view shared by the fans who resented being asked to pay £17 for a game they could go down to the pub and watch on TV. The club eventually knocked £7 off the price but there is unlikely to be a full house at Ibrox.

webTitle: Heskey arrival puts Fowler's future in doubt

fields.headline: Heskey arrival puts Fowler's future in doubt
fields.trailText: Liverpool yesterday completed the signing of Emile Heskey from Leicester in an £11m deal that will increase speculation over the future of the club's other celebrated strikers.
fields.body:
With the possible exception of Robbie Fowler, the red half of Liverpool yesterday celebrated the arrival of Emile Heskey, the most expensive player in the Anfield club's history.

Just 12 days after helping Leicester City to success in the Worthington Cup final, the timid youngster with the physique of a heavyweight boxer made his inevitable departure from Filbert Street in an £11m deal.

Today he is likely to line up for his new club for the first time at home to Sunderland, but as the 22-year-old England international completed the formalities of his transfer the talk on Merseyside was not of Heskey's potential, nor what he might add to an already proficient team, but of the ramifications of his arrival at a club with a roster of high-class strikers.

With Heskey citing the prospect of playing alongside his long-time friend Michael Owen as one of the reasons behind his decision to join Liverpool, question marks were being placed alongside the enigmatic Fowler, the undeniable truth being that three into two won't go.

"Owen and Fowler is probably the best strike partnership in Europe but I suppose by coming here I have to try and break it up," said Heskey.

Because of a recurring ankle injury which has twice necessitated surgery, Fowler has had a peripheral role this season as his manager Gérard Houllier's French revolution has moved Liverpool back into contention for the big prizes.

Houllier insists that Fowler, Owen and his other two front-line forwards, Titi Camara and Erik Meijer, will definitely be staying put, the inference being he will, in future, seek to pursue the sort of squad rotation system so beloved of Manchester United and Chelsea.

However, having been a regular fixture in the Liverpool senior side for many years it does remain to be seen how Fowler would take to the prospect of becoming a £15m-rated understudy.

"When people ask why we now have five strikers they should also inquire why it is Manchester United, Leeds United and Arsenal also have five strikers; we have five because I honestly believe we need five," said Houllier, who has now spent in excess of £40m since assuming sole responsibility for Liverpool's fortunes just over 12 months ago.

"I have been tracking Emile for the past four years, ever since I saw him play alongside Michael Owen in a youth team tournament. I was managing the French Under-18 side at the time but it was Emile who really impressed me."

Heskey said: "This is the club I have always supported and the one I always wanted to join. I appreciate that it might prove difficult to establish myself at a club which has so many class strikers but I am ready for the challenge."

As Heskey settled in at Anfield, gloom settled over Filbert Street despite the news that their manager Martin O'Neill will be handed perhaps £5m of the Heskey fee to purchase a replacement, possibly West Ham's Paulo Wanchope.

fields.headline: Best ready for biggest challenge
fields.standfirst: Roy Collins says his friend of 25 years will have been bemused by the premature obituary notices
fields.trailText: George Best Roy Collins says his friend of 25 years will have been bemused by the premature obituary notices.
fields.body:
The comfy bench seat in the corner of the Phene Arms in Chelsea was empty again yesterday, as it has been for three days since its famous regular occupant was admitted to hospital. It is the seat where a tracksuited George Best can be found most days, sometimes from opening time, sipping white wine on the rocks, glasses perched on the end of his nose as he begins his daily tussle with a newspaper crossword.

Out of deference to his celebrity status and his crocked, former footballer's knee, Bestie receives table service from the bar staff. This also allows him to stay in his seat with his back pressed firmly against the wall, a position he has always occupied since the day a few years ago when a passing nutter smashed a pint pot into the back of his head.

Best will retell the details of the blood seeping down his face as matter of factly as if he were describing a mundane daily chore such as walking to the local newsagents. But then events that would take on nightmarish proportions for us seem commonplace in the life of Best, a 53-year-old still getting into a 20-year-old's scrapes. And as the Phene is as much a second home to him as the Coach and Horses was to Jeffrey Bernard, it is perhaps not surprising that it has been the backdrop to some of the biggest dramas in his life.

Eighteen months ago he was sitting in the Phene with his teetotal son Calum when a van screeched to a halt outside and several men rushed out and began beating him black and blue. According to him they had not taken kindly to him hammering them on the pool table at another of his locals.

Best, who was admitted to the Cromwell Hospital on Wednesday with stomach pains, spent yesterday sitting up in bed doing the familiar crossword while surreally reading his obituary notices.

He will have been irritated and bemused that most of this premature prose, penned after false reports that he was fighting for his life on Thursday night, were echoes of the famous line "Where did it all go wrong, George?" attributed to a hotel waiter delivering champagne to the room he was sharing with one of his Miss Worlds.

It is, he complains, how people always see him: poor, tragic George, who threw away not only a football career but his life, and who is forced to trade on his notoriety as a famous drunk to make a living. He feels fulfilled with his renewed life as a full-time celebrity. And his reaction to boozy footballers and pop stars who say they are "frightened of ending up like George Best" is "You should be so lucky".

Some people are astonished to hear the details of Best's comfortable lifestyle, apparently believing that he has been living in a cardboard box under Waterloo Bridge. He has had his share of Waterloos: the premature ending of his football career; the descent into alcohol abuse that cost him his first marriage and led to him being imprisoned in 1984 for assaulting a policeman; most recently the loss of his flat to his former agent Murdo McLeod.

But life goes on its erratic, eventful way for Best and, no matter how chaotic it looks to outsiders, he and his second wife Alex, 27, who call each other Bestie, see themselves as sailing on a sea of tranquillity. Booze may have put him back in hospital with suspected liver damage but he has cleaned up his act considerably in recent years, helped by Alex and his agent and close friend Phil Hughes. And two or three times a year he books himself into Henlow Grange health farm.

Where he once had a reputation for 100% unreliability, he is now able to stay sober long enough to perform lucrative engagements on the after-dinner circuit and in advertising campaigns as well as holding down a regular spot as a football pundit on Sky TV on Saturday afternoons. He also has a share in his local Italian restaurant, where they serve wine under his own label.

He has had the odd well-publicised lapse, such as when he stood up, clearly the worse for wear, at a northern football writers' function at the end of last year and was ushered off stage. Because of his reputation, Sky, which picks him up from the Phene on Saturday mornings, has Alan Mullery on stand-by in case Bestie comes over a bit Jeffrey Bernard.

He has been so successful on the after-dinner circuit, sometimes selling out 400-seat venues two nights in a row, that he has been able to replace the lost flat with another, more splendid one in Cheyne Walk, one of London's most prestigious addresses. Recently he spent a week in Japan at the expense of a sports shop owner who decided that his presence would be a boost to sales at the store coincidentally called Bestie's.

Last year he was recruited by Littlewoods pools for an advertising campaign to woo punters back from the national lottery and it proved such a success that he was then approached by the lottery franchise-holder Camelot. It amused him that at one point he was featured in both campaigns.

Best, fearing the worst when the stomach pains began, went on the wagon 12 days ago and his agent said yesterday that he had vowed to stop drinking. However, it would be a serious threat to his career and lifestyle if he were to give it up permanently. Boozy men's-only nights where he performs most of his after-dinner engagements would test a man of iron will, let alone a man who once had a surgical implant which caused violent vomiting whenever he drank alcohol - and who still carried on raising his glass.

In any case, no one really believes he will give up now. Regulars in the Phene do not expect it will be long after his release from hospital that Bestie will be back in his familiar corner seat.

It is, he complains, how people always see him: poor, tragic George, who threw away not only a football career but his life, and who is forced to trade on his notoriety as a famous drunk to make a living. He feels fulfilled with his renewed life as a full-time celebrity. And his reaction to boozy footballers and pop stars who say they are "frightened of ending up like George Best" is "You should be so lucky". Some people are astonished to hear the details of Best's comfortable lifestyle, apparently believing that he has been living in a cardboard box under Waterloo Bridge. He has had his share of Waterloos: the premature ending of his football career; the descent into alcohol abuse that cost him his first marriage and led to him being imprisoned in 1984 for assaulting a policeman; most recently the loss of his flat to his former agent Murdo McLeod. But life goes on its erratic, eventful way for Best and, no matter how chaotic it looks to outsiders, he and his second wife Alex, 27, who call each other Bestie, see themselves as sailing on a sea of tranquillity. Booze may have put him back in hospital with suspected liver damage but he has cleaned up his act considerably in recent years, helped by Alex and his agent and close friend Phil Hughes. And two or three times a year he books himself into Henlow Grange health farm. Where he once had a reputation for 100% unreliability, he is now able to stay sober long enough to perform lucrative engagements on the after-dinner circuit and in advertising campaigns as well as holding down a regular spot as a football pundit on Sky TV on Saturday afternoons. He also has a share in his local Italian restaurant, where they serve wine under his own label. He has had the odd well-publicised lapse, such as when he stood up, clearly the worse for wear, at a northern football writers' function at the end of last year and was ushered off stage. Because of his reputation, Sky, which picks him up from the Phene on Saturday mornings, has Alan Mullery on stand-by in case Bestie comes over a bit Jeffrey Bernard. He has been so successful on the after-dinner circuit, sometimes selling out 400-seat venues two nights in a row, that he has been able to replace the lost flat with another, more splendid one in Cheyne Walk, one of London's most prestigious addresses. fields.headline: Barely 24 hours from Tulsa
fields.standfirst: Joe-Max Moore steps out for Everton at Chelsea today, his latest venture on the road from Oklahoma
fields.trailText: Joe-Max Moore Everton's contented Oklahoma-born striker is reaping the rewards of his big break last year.
fields.body:
Joe-Max Moore's success at Everton may not yet amount to a hill of beans, as his compatriots might say, but this Oklahoma-born striker is just about the most contented footballer you could hope to find. Forget all his recent Premiership trappings, the man's smile would light a shuttered room even if he were to be informed that in future he would be scoring goals for fun rather than a currency he still regards as alien.

Moore owes his upturn in fortunes to the shrewd judgment of Everton's veteran defender Richard Gough. Had the former Scotland international not whispered in his manager Walter Smith's ear, the 29-year-old would still be plying his trade rather less than 24 hours from his native Tulsa with the Major League Soccer club New England Revolution, instead of lining up at Chelsea today.

History has probably already been embroidered but, so the urban myth goes, it was a chance conversation between the two Scots last year which landed Moore his most important career break to date. Smith had decided he needed to bolster his wafer-thin squad by signing another forward to understudy his regular pairing of Kevin Campbell and Francis Jeffers, and he discussed his plight with Gough who, at the age of 37, has become Smith's confidant, first lieutenant and now captain. Gough, having recently returned from playing Stateside, knew just the man.

"He was free, which was one of the essential factors," Smith observes with the wry smile of a manager who is constantly being told his glass is neither half-full nor half-empty but completely drained.

An exchange of phone calls, a positive interjection by one of Britain's most reputable agents, Paul Stretford, and Moore was on his way to Goodison Park and, rather improbably, the delicious prospect of a reunion with Duncan McKenzie, Everton's Mini-car-leaping maverick of the 70s.

McKenzie memories
McKenzie, it seems, played a significant if unwitting role in convincing Moore his future lay not on the gridiron nor with the hoops but in football. Twenty or so years ago, when the youth of America were enthralled by the razzmatazz of the old North American Soccer League, Moore's oil-baron father part-owned the Tulsa Roughnecks, where the show-stopping star of an otherwise pedestrian side was, yes, the nomadic McKenzie.

"We had Duncan and he was my big hero," Moore says. "They were good days because the likes of Pele, George Best and Franz Beckenbauer were playing against us."

But being the offspring of a big fish in America's oil pond, who loved his football so much he bought the club, had its problems. Moore has long suffered from a whispering campaign. It is a subject he touches upon with understandable reluctance.

"I think everyone back home believes I'm the spoiled brat who made it in soccer because my dad was big in oil and owned the Roughnecks," he says. "But that's just not the case. I was a ballboy at the club and grew up watching the top stars who played for us or who came to town.

"The NASL was big at the time, but then it folded and the Roughnecks went under. At the same time the bottom dropped out of the oil market. My dad had a lot of money in that business and the smaller companies like ours just couldn't cope; there were bankruptcies all over the place."

Moore's family promptly headed west, where he landed a scholarship at the University of California, Los Angeles, the springboard to a professional career which has brought him 79 international caps for the United States, spells with the German second division clubs Saarbrücken and Nuremberg, a loan spell with Emelec in the Ecuadorian first division, and now utter contentment on the banks of the Mersey.

"This is what I have always wanted," he says. "I wanted to come to this country and play at the highest level. I'm here, it's happening and yet it still does not seem real.

"My wife Martha and I have settled in so quickly; everyone has been so welcoming, we couldn't have asked for a warmer reception. If I'm honest, I didn't know a lot about Everton before I came over here on trial. I knew of them but not much about them. But now I understand they are a huge, huge club with great tradition and magnificent support."

Moore's progress in the famous royal-blue jersey has been highly impressive. His burst of six goals in eight games - in all he has appeared 13 times for Everton - has been timely indeed for, with both Campbell and Jeffers sidelined through injury, he is now more mainstay than stand-in.

"At this level you simply must take your chance when it comes along," he says. "I always knew getting into the first team would be the easy part of the equation; it's staying in the team which is so difficult.

"It has all gone so well for me, but the demands of the Premiership are great and if I am to make a real success of this I'll have to show the sort of consistency which players from the other side of the Atlantic aren't exactly famed for."

Though Moore, who has been in the United States' last two World Cup squads, is the latest in a sprinkling of Americans to have made the grade in England, he admits that a Gold Rush-style stampede of his country's finest is unlikely.

"There have been a few before me - John Harkes, Kasey Keller, Cobi Jones, Brad Friedel and so on - but the problems with obtaining a work permit have often proved insurmountable," he says.

"There are players back home I believe would make the grade over here; not dozens of them but certainly a few. Football continues to grow in popularity in the States and I honestly believe that in a decade or so we will be strong enough to make a real impact on the international stage . . . maybe even to win the World Cup."

webTitle: Barber's nightmare hoping for a good hair day

fields.headline: Barber's nightmare hoping for a good hair day
fields.standfirst: Former bad boy desperate for Bradford to play their 'get out of jail free' card
fields.trailText: Jamie Lawrence Bradford's former bad boy has gone from Parkhurst to Premiership and is now one of the clubs most consistent performers in their pursuit for survival.
fields.body:
Those who have followed the wacky ways of Jamie Lawrence will know better than to adjust their television sets tomorrow, even if something does not seem quite right with the colour.

Leeds United are in town and Bradford City's answer to Dennis Rodman will mark the first top-flight derby at Valley Parade with a bottle-green barnet that would make Johnny Rotten cringe.

As someone who changes his hairstyle more often than Manchester United change their kit, Lawrence stood accused yesterday of being a Spice Boy-in-waiting by his manager, Paul Jewell. His background, however, is decidedly more gangsta rap, a tale of hard knocks on the meanest streets of south London, with several of his 30 years spent behind bars for robbery convictions.

From Parkhurst to the Premiership, it has been anything but a conventional route for a player who has emerged as one of Bradford's most consistent performers in their pursuit of survival.

"There are times when I wonder what I would be doing if it wasn't for football. Before I went to prison I'd never played for a team in my life. It was only when I was banged up that I started taking it seriously," he says.

"Because I didn't smoke, the only thing I could do was go to the gym and play football or do some weights. I started playing for the prison team at Camphill and I remember one Boxing Day, 11 months into a four-year sentence, when we played against Cowes. I scored twice and they asked the governor if I could play for them.

"It was a crossroads in my life and, thank God, I took the right route. Before then I had been involved in all kinds of stuff. The first robbery was a snooker hall and I got three years; the second was some geezer and a fight that turned into a robbery. I got four years for that, and I remember that was the worst moment of my life."

Lawrence still keeps in touch with his old prison officers and sent them Wembley tickets when he played for Leicester in the 1997 League Cup final against Middlesbrough. Rather than glorying in his past, he attempts to influence those who might be tempted to follow the same route. "I've gone from the bottom to the top and there are kids back in Balham who look up to me. I talk to them all the time and I try to point them in the right direction," he says.

"My mum and dad went back to Jamaica when I was in my teens and I was left in London, the big wide world, with no money and no job. You have to eat and in that position it is easier to go the other way than to do right by yourself.

"Being banged up isn't nice. The little things that you take for granted are suddenly gone, simple things like being able to go into your own fridge to get some bread and milk. You have to be strong but in a way it has made me a better person."

His aim is to make the Jamaica squad for the 2002 World Cup but of more immediacy is Bradford's fight against relegation and the contest for local bragging rights. "This place reminds me a lot of Leicester. I remember people gave us no chance of staying up there but we proved everyone wrong, and it is the same attitude here," he says.

"I've got three goals in the last three matches and I am benefiting from playing a lot more centrally; Dean Saunders has been drilling it into my head. I'm running into different channels and, if I keep scoring, Jamaica will have to notice me."

With his hair, how could they fail to notice him? He was football's first "pineapple head" long before Jason Lee came under the microscope of Fantasy Football. Then there was the peroxide crop that had Liverpool's Kop greeting him with a chorus of "There's only one pint of Guinness". That was followed by the recent red-top and now a grotbags green.

"There are a few more colours to experiment with yet, although I am not sure about the next one, but you can guarantee there is more to come. Look at it this way: at least it means my team-mates have no excuse for not picking me out."

Jamie Lawrence: flying winger, reformed criminal, barber's nightmare.

 Lee Mills will go straight into the Manchester City side for today's game against Barnsley, having completed a loan move from Bradford to Maine Road. City's manager Joe Royle, who is also tracking the Aston Villa veteran Colin Calderwood, said: "Lee's a proven goalscorer. He's on loan until the end of the season and if he does as well as I know he can his move could be a permanent one."

webTitle: Time for United to spend like kings

fields.headline: Time for United to spend like kings
fields.standfirst: Are Manchester United too big for the Premiership?
fields.trailText: For a long time now Manchester United's fame has been their fortune. But this week their fortune has brought them a new kind of fame. Are they now too big for the Premiership?
fields.body:
For a long time now Manchester United's fame has been their fortune. But this week their fortune has brought them a new kind of fame.

Ole Gunnar Solskjaer's winner in Bordeaux on Tuesday night turned out to be not so much a golden goal as the start of a unique gold rush. For no sooner had the stock market begun trading on Wednesday than United's share value rose by 26p to make them the first football club in the world worth £1bn.

Had Solskjaer realised the full implications as he gathered a long clearance from Raimond van der Gouw and held off two challenges before slipping the ball into the net, even this calmest of finishers might have frozen at the crucial moment. As route one goals go, this was no mere trunk road towards the quarter-finals of the Champions League, it was an expressway to Eldorado.

Consider the comparisons. Arsenal, though not exactly on the poverty line, are reckoned to be worth a mere £300m, and Chelsea, who exude rude financial health, have been valued at about £140m. Indeed it would be surprising if the rest of the Premiership put together equalled United's rating on the stock exchange.

Good for Manchester United, the plc, MUTV and the megastore. A combination of continued excellence on the field and business acumen off it continues to bring Old Trafford ever-increasing financial returns and the shareholders rising dividends.

Yet inevitably such a stark contrast between the wealth of one club and the relatively modest means of others must call into question the direction in which this state of affairs is leading the English game in general and the Premier League in particular.

The motives for setting up the Premier League were financial and political: more money and more voting power for the old First Division without the need to support the lower leagues. Now a situation has been reached in which Manchester United can more or less call whatever tune they choose because, despite having only one vote, they carry an awesome financial clout.

Even before their share value passed the £1bn mark on Wednesday, United clearly belonged to a superleague of their own in a Premier League which now looks rather less super than the original blueprint implied.

Indeed the Premier League appears to have spent the best part of eight seasons conspiring to give United a status which they had never previously enjoyed, not even in the 60s when Bobby Charlton, Denis Law and George Best were in their pomp. Presumably this was not part of the plan.

Surely the English league does not want to go the way of the Scottish championship, which for 10 of the past 12 seasons has been won by Rangers and, after a brief interruption by Celtic last time, looks like returning to Ibrox sooner rather than later. Yet if United win the Premiership for the sixth time in eight seasons, football in England will become even more subservient to an old firm of one club.

In the space of six years Sir Alex Ferguson's teams have won two league and FA Cup doubles, plus last season's addition of the European Cup in an historic treble. For Old Trafford, winning the championship has become a matter of routine.

For their own good, and the good of the game, United need a stronger challenge in domestic matters than they have been getting this season. David O'Leary's exciting young Leeds side are still grabbing for United's coat-tails at the top of the Premiership but Chelsea, Arsenal and Liverpool are now playing for Champions League places.

Next season United will be back in the FA Cup but will almost certainly field squad teams, as they do in the Worthington Cup. The next Fifa World Club Championship will demand their presence, whether or not they are European champions, but in January none of their Premiership rivals managed to exploit their fitful foray in Rio.

It is not as if United have started to spend like billionaires. Roy Keane apart, Ferguson's players have yet to command the sort of wages paid to leading talents in Italy or Spain. Dwight Yorke remains United's biggest signing at £12.6m, whereas last summer Internazionale paid Lazio £31m for Christian Vieri.

This may soon change, whatever the constraints of Manchester United plc. Just suppose David Beckham were sold to Inter this summer for £25-£30m. It is unlikely that either the supporters or the shareholders would be overwhelmed at the prospect of getting Newcastle's Nolberto Solano as a replacement. They would expect Rivaldo and nothing less.

Manchester United may just have been confirmed as the wealthiest club in the world but they have yet to act like it. If and when they do, the likes of Arsenal, Leeds and Chelsea will find it even harder to keep up, and Liverpool's signing of Emile Heskey for £11m will seem a snip.

However, it never does to look too far ahead. Ferguson will probably retire in three years' time and there is, for the moment, no obvious successor. By then, for better or worse, the present team will have been at least partly turned around.

And nothing lasts for ever, least of all on the stock market.

However, it never does to look too far ahead. Ferguson will probably retire in three years' time and there is, for the moment, no obvious successor. By then, for better or worse, the present team will have been at least partly turned around. And nothing lasts for ever, least of all on the stock market.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.standfirst: Red card rev-head drives ref crazy
fields.trailText: Driving on the pitch, literary formations, whingeing Frenchmen, buttocks, and atomic balls.
fields.body:
Carl Wood, a striker with Bulls Head in the Ironbridge Sunday League, found a novel way of protesting against his sending-off in a recent game. When the referee showed him the red card, he responded in kind by showing the ref the red car.

The 28-year-old plasterer was dismissed 10 minutes from the end of a match against local rivals Farmhouse for using foul and abusive language. But no sooner had the referee told Wood to get on his bike than the disgruntled player jumped in his car and roared across the pitch with the game still underway before stopping near the six-yard box, turning full circle and speeding off.

Players and spectators were left stunned. "I've never seen anything like it in 11 years of refereeing," said the match official Dave Simpson. "There was just total shock and horror all round."

Wood and his Peugeot 205 were later banned sine die by a disciplinary hearing, although it is understood he is appealing. Even so it brings a whole new meaning to the phrase: "The striker unleashed a 30-yard drive."

 Sir Alex Ferguson always did prefer an archetypal English formation. So perhaps we should not be too surprised by the fact that his autobiography ends on page 442.

 What is it with these French players, always whingeing? One minute it's Emmanuel Petit, then it's Frank Leboeuf. The poor soul doesn't like Chelsea's training facilities near Heathrow.

"I have never known such dreadful training conditions in my entire career," he moans. "We have to train amid gusts of wind and smells of coffee coming from the factory next door." And though it is hard to believe, there's worse. "Every morning at 10.45 the manager has to stop speaking to us because Concorde flies overhead and no one can hear themselves think."

Noisy, dirty, good in the air and Anglo-French. Sounds familiar, Frank.

 Actually, what we want are more French footballer quotes like this: "My husband has the best-looking pair of buttocks in the world. They are firm and nicely chubby." Adriana Karembeu on her hubby Christian of Real Madrid. Yes, we are trying to get to the bottom of rumours that Karembeu is on his way to Arsenal.

 Mike Emerich, a government agent who will help guard the US presidential candidates Al Gore and George Bush in the forthcoming election, is obviously good at defence. In nine years of coaching the Thomas Stone boys soccer team in Washington DC, their record stands at 127 wins, 16 draws and just four defeats.

 The recent game between Inter Tadley and Castle in the Basingstoke Sunday League had to be abandoned after 70 minutes. Reason? They ran out of balls.

Inter's pitch is next to the Atomic Weapons Establishment and during the match the players managed to kick no fewer than eight balls over the barbed-wire security fence.

"The place is strictly out of bounds and we could have caused a major incident if someone had clambered over to retrieve them," said the Castle secretary Greg Clarke. "Anyway, he might have come back day-glo green."

 Following Newcastle's lead, Sheffield Wednesday fans are to fight their club's plans to move them to different seats. Supporters are adamant that they're happy where they are and don't want to be moved from behind the pillars.

fields.headline: Drift to the right
fields.standfirst: Tom Bussmann struggles with his political conscience before heading for the Austrian slopes - a favourite haunt of Jorg Haider
fields.trailText: Tom Bussmann struggles with his political conscience before heading for the Austrian slopes - a favourite haunt of Jorg Haider
fields.body:
There was a time not so long ago when it was impossible to eat a politically-correct orange. Spanish oranges were handpicked by Franco, American fruit by brutalised Mexicans or Tom Joad in person, and nothing was more out than Outspan.

Now that Austria has taken over the role of World Leper from South Africa, skiing has gone the way of the orange. The reason for all this soul searching is that we had a skiing holiday booked in Austria, and well before Jörg Haider made the headlines.

Confused, we looked to our betters to give us a moral lead. On the one hand, the Belgian foreign minister (name's on the tip of my tongue) said no one should ski in Austria, probably not even the Austrians. On the other hand, Barbara Amiel took a whole page of the Daily Telegraph to explain why the then leader of the right-wing Freedom Party was so misunderstood, poor chap.

Comforted by Ms Amiel's cogent argument, we went ahead with our planned trip. Our chosen resort was Schladming and though we'd booked our Go flights months ago (of which more later) we found accommodation hard to come by.

Thanks to an Austrian friend who speaks fluent internet, we finished up staying at the Landauer hotel, and very nice it was. This pleasant family-run hotel is in Untertal, just outside Schladming, and with a great view of the valley.

We were lucky enough to get a large, comfortable family room in the Landauer's newly-built extension, which blended seamlessly in style with the older building. The extension boasts a lavishly-equipped fitness-centre with solarium and sauna, but as I had forgotten to bring my flip-flops (de rigueur for both sauna and evening wear) I cannot say whether my fellow guests looked any more attractive with their clothes off.

The skiing, I am told by those who ski, is excellent. We took a trip to the top of the Planai, (1,894m) which meant getting crushed by a packed and hellish throng of stone-faced skiers clattering their way into the gondolas.

The resort also attracts a raucous crowd. To see them in full song, head for Onkel Willi's Hütte, a goldmine disguised as a ski emporium. Inside, you can't breathe; outside, you can't hear. Loudspeakers thump out unremitting Austro-Bavarian popular music at a volume that carries more avalanche-potential than an army of off-piste snowboarders. Big this year is a song about zehn nackte friseusen, or 10 naked hairdressers, with lyrics laden with double entendres.

Non-skiers are in luck. Schladming has a stunning toboggan run, from the top of the Hochwurzen (1,850m) down a spectacular 7km run into the valley. When you are taking the lift, splash out on a Swatch Access.

This does away with the need for those naff bits of fiddly card on a bit of elastic you struggle to poke into a slot. Instead, your snazzy Swatch is computer-loaded with however many days of lift pass you want. Then you simply wave it airily at the gates and they open. The Swatch costs around £30, and you can use it all over the world.

As I mentioned, we flew Go from Stansted to Munich, which cost us £85 a head as we travelled out on a Thursday and returned on a Monday. At weekends they hike the price; at half-term they hike the price. But it's still much cheaper than conventional flights.

But you may need the money you save to buy a new set of luggage. When my cases arrived in Munich the costly metal Zero Halliburton was bandaged together with ServiceAir tape, and had a wheel missing. My Samsonite was no better.

I duly faxed Go the details, and they replied offering £144.50, based on something called Special Drawing Rights, and a message that "we calculate the applicable weight of the missing items to be 10 kg" - interesting, as I don't remember them picking them up. On an easyJet flight to Nice I had a case smashed on the way back. easyJet didn't quote me any Special Drawing Rights. They sent me a new case. Go or easyJet? My case rests.

The practicals

Rent a car with Budget (0845 6060608) when you fly Go and you'll receive a special rate. Show your Go itinerary when buying train and caoch tickets between London and Stansted and you'll be rewarded with a discount. Holiday details from the Austrian Touist Office on 020 7629 0461. Gasthof-Restaurant Landauer, tel 0043 3687 61166. The Bussmanns paid £67 a day for the apartment, plus £3 for their six year old. Their three year old was free. Half board (terrific value) was £11 per dault per day.

fields.headline: Stolen moments
fields.standfirst: Michael White learns the hard way that even in the most beautiful of surroundings, it pays to keep one hand on your wallet
fields.trailText: Michael White learns the hard way that even in the most beautiful of surroundings, it pays to keep one hand on your wallet
fields.body:
Like so many things in life, it was obvious with hindsight. But I had not lost a wallet to a pickpocket since 1986, when I was trying to get into Ferdinand Marcos's newly-liberated palace in Manila. Alas, I never did get in to inspect his wife's collection of 600 pairs of shoes, which became legendary the moment its discovery was relayed to the media.

In the press of the vast crowd, which had gathered the morning after Ferdy and Imelda's flight, I felt the wallet go. But this time, I felt nothing. It was a hot August morning in Barcelona, and Pat and I were walking down the hill from the Parc Güell, one of the spectacular memorials that form part of Antoni Gaudi's legacy to his native city.

That was mistake number one. Pat was feeling unwell, but I was greatly impressed by the modern and efficient metro system. We should have taken a cab to our next stop. Instead, we were walking slowly towards the train, slowly enough to look more than usually decrepit. So we must have looked an easy mark to the young man in American casual clothes - shorts, trainers, T-shirt and baseball cap, who (so Pat decided later) had been following us.

We should have known it was not to be our lucky day - walking down the busy high street towards the station, we were suddenly splattered with bird shit. It certainly felt like bird shit: there was rather a lot of it and the texture was slightly too pink. What else could it be? Step forward a helpful young man, who said in good-enough English: "How terrible. Can I help you clean up? Look at the mess, it must have been elephants."

I know, I know. Corny or what? But in that situation one is mainly concerned to get clean - that was mistake number two. There was a fountain across the street, our Good Samaritan explained. My initial reaction (it always is) was to reject help. But it was hot and he was decisive - mistake number three.

Actually, it wasn't a fountain. We stepped into the courtyard of a block of flats. "I live here," he said. "I have water and some paper tissues." All this happened in barely a minute. There seemed to be a lot of bird shit on my back (it must have been a low-flying bird). Anyway, my friend said: "Take your shirt off." Odd that, but I did.

He brushed me down, then said "Good luck, I'm late, I must go," and disappeared with a wave.

It was another two minutes before I realised I was travelling light. Keys in my right pocket (on the same bottle opener I bought at the age of 16), wallet in the left, I can barely move 10ft without being able to feel them there. Everything fell into place at that point. Just as I had realised too late in the Manila crowd that the man who accused someone behind me of taking the wallet was actually the pickpocket's accomplice, so I now realised I was the victim of a polished routine.

Pat had been wearing her handbag across her chest. That was why he'd settled for me, a few credit cards he wouldn't be able to use and the £100 in sterling, francs and pesetas which were (I think) inside the wallet. We phoned Marks and Spencer, whose Card Safe system we subscribed to in a moment of efficiency: they duly cancelled the cards.

For form's sake rather than insurance (what insurance?), we then reported to the local police station. Surprise, surprise, they knew this dodge rather well. Everyone we told laughed at us. "Hey, this is Barcelona," they said. Or " Beaucoup de vol a Barcelone ", as they put it across the frontier. After all, our hitch-hiking son had lost his rucksack, barely a foot away at the time, while on the phone at Barcelona.

Other friends had had bags razor-bladed and lost everything: car keys, car park ticket (nothing M&S can do about that), cards, everything except the mobile that allowed them to cancel the lot. Someone else's boyfriend, a lorry driver, had woken up in his cab to realise he'd been gassed and robbed. That was winter; in summer they concentrate on caravaners, she explained.

Oh yes, and there was the couple flagging down cars on the motorway, quite possibly one of whom was my mate in the baseball cap and T-shirt, because their caravan was "on fire". While kind-hearted friends of ours checked for the source of the smoke (a burning rag works quite well), chummy rifled the front seats of their opened car doors and made off. He probably said: "Good luck, I'm late, I must go."

Still, on my first visit since I hitch-hiked to Barcelona circa 1968, I liked the re-branded city and will go back. Probably with my wallet on a steel hawser.

fields.headline: Getting into character
fields.standfirst: Spike Jonze's Being John Malkovich is one of the most quirky and original films Hollywood has ever produced, says Joe Queenan. The question is, how will they cash in on its success?
fields.trailText: Spike Jonze's Being John Malkovich is one of the most quirky and original films Hollywood has ever produced, says Joe Queenan. The question is, how will they cash in on its success?
fields.body:
Every once in a while, Hollywood makes a film so thrillingly intelligent that you can't help wondering why they don't make more of them. Just such a film is Spike Jonze's Being John Malkovich, the most beguilingly quirky motion picture since David Mamet's The Spanish Prisoner.

In this coy little affair, the reliable John Cusack plays a hirsute, downwardly mobile urban puppeteer who is forced by the vicissitudes of the American marionette industry to take a job as a lowly filing clerk. Since even in the best of times there has never been much demand in the United States for adult puppetry (Cusack's tour de force is a lurid re-enactment of seminal events in the lives of Heloise and Abelard), Jonze quickly establishes the psychological terrain of his motion picture - NeverNeverLand - preparing the audience for the moment when Cusack stumbles upon a hidden passage leading inside the actor John Malkovich's head. That is, the movie starts out at a rarefied level of weirdness, and then gets weirder. But weird in a fun way. Not like Quentin Tarantino or Abel Ferrara. Those guys are nasty.

Once Cusack has unearthed the secret tunnel leading into Malkovich's brain, he does what any red-blooded American male - even a puppeteer - would do: he tries to figure out a way to make a lot of money out it. In due course, he and a confederate, played by the fetching Catherine Keener, set up a sort of cerebral theme park in which the opportunity to spend 15 minutes inside John Malkovich's brain is the single attraction. Obviously, a fun park with a ride like this doesn't need run-of-the-mill diversions like Ferris wheels.

Were Being John Malkovich merely a film about a bunch of people who spend their hard-earned cash on traipsing around inside the skull of a moderately famous bald actor with a very annoying voice for 15 minutes, before being dumped onto the side of the New Jersey turnpike, the audience's interest would probably flag pretty quickly. It is not. It is first and foremost a withering attack on the puppeteering industry, which has had this kind of woodshedding coming for decades. But it is also a compelling love story.

The epicentre of the love story is Cameron Diaz, who plays Cusack's long-suffering wife. One evening, she happens to be visiting Malkovich's brain while the actor is making love to Keener, whom Cusack openly worships. Because Diaz/Malkovich is a more passionate, adventurous partner than Malkovich himself, Keener now finds herself smitten by this riveting hybrid. This creates complications because she has little interest in the real John Malkovich, and absolutely no interest in Cusack, both of whom find her positively enthralling. Eventually, Cusack realises that if he is ever to win Keener's affection, he must dump Diaz and turn Malkovich into his own puppet. Meanwhile, Diaz realises that if she is ever to wind up in the sack with Keener, she must figure out a way to evict her old boyfriend from Malkovich's brain. Keener, for her part, has a hard time keeping track of who she is sleeping with at any particular time, so she tries to sleep with everybody. And Malkovich, reduced to a bystander's role as a tall, bald succubus with a very annoying voice, can do nothing but wait for all these lunatics to vacate his medulla oblongata and give him back his personality so that he can get back to making movies like Con Air.

As the preceding makes clear, Being John Malkovich is a complex and in some ways confusing motion picture that raises a host of philosophical questions about celebrity, gender politics, the meaning of life, and the thin line separating sex from insanity. However, none of these questions need concern us here. What concerns us is how Hollywood will respond to the success of Being John Malkovich, and what this portends for those of us who are aficionados of films of this ilk.

Traditionally, there have been two avenues the motion picture industry has taken in situations such as this. The first and most obvious is a series of sequels. The second is a series of rip-offs, or films 'inspired' by the success of the original. Personally, I am not all that sanguine about the prospects for Being John Malkovich II or Being John Malkovich II: First Blood. As much as I enjoyed Jonze's mind-bending film, I'd had quite enough of Malkovich's vacant delivery by the end of the proceedings, and frankly didn't feel that I needed to know anything more about the inner workings of his brain.

A far more profitable approach would be to create a whole series of films that take the Being John Malkovich theme in different directions. One thought is Being Jean-Claude Van Damne, in which a smart person like Cusack or Keener or just about anyone temporarily takes control of the Belgian kickboxer's brain and teaches him how to act. A not dissimilar approach could be taken in films like Being Adam Sandler, Being Pauly Shore and perhaps even Being Both Emilio Estevez And Charlie Sheen.

Another possibility is a film in which a trio of hapless college students are trapped inside a highly intimidating actor's brain: The Blair Witch Being Christopher Walken Project is one title that might be considered. Films I would be less enthusiastic about include Being Emma Thompson or Kenneth Branagh, Being Rosie O'Donnell, Being Kevin Costner, and, of course, Being Roberto Benigni. On the other hand, I would welcome a movie in which John Cusack discovers a secret aperture that leads directly into the brain of a bald movie star with a very annoying voice. I am not sure exactly where Jonze could go with Being Telly Savalas, but based on his most recent film, he certainly doesn't seem short on ideas.

In due course, he and a confederate, played by the fetching Catherine Keener, set up a sort of cerebral theme park in which the opportunity to spend 15 minutes inside John Malkovich's brain is the single attraction. Obviously, a fun park with a ride like this doesn't need run-of-the-mill diversions like Ferris wheels. Were Being John Malkovich merely a film about a bunch of people who spend their hard-earned cash on traipsing around inside the skull of a moderately famous bald actor with a very annoying voice for 15 minutes, before being dumped onto the side of the New Jersey turnpike, the audience's interest would probably flag pretty quickly. It is not. It is first and foremost a withering attack on the puppeteering industry, which has had this kind of woodshedding coming for decades. But it is also a compelling love story. The epicentre of the love story is Cameron Diaz, who plays Cusack's long-suffering wife. One evening, she happens to be visiting Malkovich's brain while the actor is making love to Keener, whom Cusack openly worships. Because Diaz/Malkovich is a more passionate, adventurous partner than Malkovich himself, Keener now finds herself smitten by this riveting hybrid. This creates complications because she has little interest in the real John Malkovich, and absolutely no interest in Cusack, both of whom find her positively enthralling. Eventually, Cusack realises that if he is ever to win Keener's affection, he must dump Diaz and turn Malkovich into his own puppet. Meanwhile, Diaz realises that if she is ever to wind up in the sack with Keener, she must figure out a way to evict her old boyfriend from Malkovich's brain. Keener, for her part, has a hard time keeping track of who she is sleeping with at any particular time, so she tries to sleep with everybody. And Malkovich, reduced to a bystander's role as a tall, bald succubus with a very annoying voice, can do nothing but wait for all these lunatics to vacate his medulla oblongata and give him back his personality so that he can get back to making movies like Con Air. As the preceding makes clear, Being John Malkovich is a complex and in some ways confusing motion picture that raises a host of philosophical questions about celebrity, gender politics, the meaning of life, and the thin line separating sex from insanity. However, none of these questions need concern us here. What concerns us is how Hollywood will respond to the success of Being John Malkovich, and what this portends for those of us who are aficionados of films of this ilk. Traditionally, there have been two avenues the motion picture industry has taken in situations such as this. The first and most obvious is a series of sequels. The second is a series of rip-offs, or films 'inspired' by the success of the original. Personally, I am not all that sanguine about the prospects for Being John Malkovich II or Being John Malkovich II: First Blood. As much as I enjoyed Jonze's mind-bending film, I'd had quite enough of Malkovich's vacant delivery by the end of the proceedings, and frankly didn't feel that I needed to know anything more about the inner workings of his brain. A far more profitable approach would be to create a whole series of films that take the Being John Malkovich theme in different directions. One thought is Being Jean-Claude Van Damne, in which a smart person like Cusack or Keener or just about anyone temporarily takes control of the Belgian kickboxer's brain and teaches him how to act. A not dissimilar approach could be taken in films like Being Adam Sandler, Being Pauly Shore and perhaps even Being Both Emilio Estevez And Charlie Sheen. Another possibility is a film in which a trio of hapless college students are trapped inside a highly intimidating actor's brain: The Blair Witch Being Christopher Walken Project is one title that might be considered. Films I would be less enthusiastic about include Being Emma Thompson or Kenneth Branagh, Being Rosie O'Donnell, Being Kevin Costner, and, of course, Being Roberto Benigni. On the other hand, I would welcome a movie in which John Cusack discovers a secret aperture that leads directly into the brain of a bald movie star with a very annoying voice. I am not sure exactly where Jonze could go with Being Telly Savalas, but based on his most recent film, he certainly doesn't seem short on ideas.

webTitle: I lost my heart in... Port Isaac, Cornwall

fields.headline: I lost my heart in... Port Isaac, Cornwall
fields.standfirst: Laurence Llewelyn-Bowen
fields.trailText: Laurence Llewelyn-Bowen.
fields.body:
The whole family adore going there for the same reason - familiarity. Life is so stressful and busy so holidays for me are about going somewhere you know, particularly with two small children.

My wife's family had been going to north Cornwall since she was tiny. We went when we first met and I loved it. Being Welsh, it reminded me of Pembrokeshire, where we went when I was a child.

Port Isaac is a typical ancient fishing village. It could be anywhere. It's a collection of organically-built houses which all relate to one another in some kind of way. In the summer, it is bunting and buckets and spades; in the winter it is a wind-ravaged, wild Celtic place, which is quite scary. The waves break over the roof of the pub, everyone gathers together and the lifeboat crew sing sea shanties.

It's basically about the beach, seeing friends - long lunches with lots of cider - and relaxing. It is totally informal and stress-free. We have no telephone and mobiles don't work there because of the granite cliffs, so we are totally separated from real life.

 Home Front: Inside Out with Laurence Llewelyn-Bowen is on BBC2 , Wednesdays at 8pm

fields.headline: Hit the right spot
fields.standfirst: Logging on to the web can make a world of difference.  Mark Espiner  checks out the sites
fields.trailText: Logging on to the web can make a world of difference. Mark Espiner checks out the sites
fields.body:
Calgary Bay. Fine white sand and clear aquamarine water. A biting wind coming in off the Atlantic. A remote and beautiful spot on Scotland's western isle of Mull. Isolated. I sat in the car parked up on the beach, looked out to America and read the decaying and rusting sign planted boldly above the high-tide mark that had been there for what looked like a hundred years.

From this spot, it declared, one of the first telegraph cables had been run from the British Isles to the United States. The beginning of telecommunications. It somehow seemed fitting that I had arrived at this spot via the internet.

A last-minute plan to drive around the western isles for new year in 1997 had pushed me to use the world wide web to organise my trip rather than the phone, which seemed to shunt me at every dial to voicemail or another 10 minutes on hold listening to Greensleeves. The info I needed - car hire, tourist information on the Holy Island of Iona, ferry timetables between the isles (with updates on potential industrial action) - was all readily available online. I logged on, printed off what I needed and set off.

From the early days of the internet, travel was one of the first pursuits to find its voice in the digital online commu nity, with the exchange of information on the internet bulletin boards on how to get from here to there with only so much cash, and what you could expect to encounter on the way.

Now, travel is the fastest growing area of the internet, with online booking of flights and holidays driving much of the developments in e-commerce and many more websites offering information on anything from fabulous outdoor pursuits at www.gorp.com to sushi bars across the planet at www.sushi.to

The bulletin boards still exist and continue to be useful, but the web has supplanted them in terms of access to information. Internet "portals" - are a good launch pad: these are web sites that have collected an index of web addresses and information for your needs. They can point you to the right source so that you don't have to randomly scan the vast internet landscape, racking up a huge phone bill in the process.

Nearly all the major search engine sites (Altavista, Yahoo, Excite, Hotbot) have travel sections that list sub-categories for travel interests. But there are other independent alternatives which have hand-picked and rated sites.

For example, the familiar brand of Encyclopaedia Britannica, which is a much more dynamic reference tool on the internet than it is in printed form, features different travel topics on a regular basis. Currently, it is looking at Freya Stark's life and adventures with associated websites for women travellers, such as Journeywoman. Find it at www.britannica.com.

There are many other portals relating to specific or speciality travel. For example, if South America is your goal, try Lanic which has a comprehensive list of sites to the region.

As it has grown, the internet has become a huge library to help you plan and prepare your trip. The Rough Guides website now has some of its books online, and following its collaboration with Hotwired, the online version of the avant-garde technological magazine Wired) has built up a huge database of travel information.

Fodors will also help you tailor your travel. Answer a few questions, by clicking in check boxes on the website, and it will construct a miniguide to your destination. Time Out's cityguides at www.timeout.com add to the free info pool of publishing brands, but there are countless other websites and ways of finding out about where you want to go.

For example, posting a note on the Lonely Planet's website bulletin board, called the Thorn Tree which you can access at the deja website, to ask about, say, climbing or hiking opportunities in Morocco, will yield first-hand experience and advice.

A slightly more sophisticated alternative to bulletin board suggestions and tips is Allexperts. As well as offering practical advice on subjects such as DIY and computer software, it also has travel aficionados proferring their info-wares. Choose the country or city, and the site throws up a list of "experts" plus their fields of interest. Choose one and email your query, and when you have received your advice by return of electronic post you are invited to rate your adviser.

My guide, David, was an Allexpert's expert on London, England and TS Eliot. Pretending that I was travelling to London, I asked for clues on literary walks in the city and sites in Britain that related to The Waste Land. Dave's advice? "I'll have a ponder on what you ask," he said but then suggested the publisher Faber & Faber; Lloyd's Bank, where he first worked, and the church of St Magnus Martyr. Fine, although the "then there's the Thames in general" for The Waste Land was a bit vague.

When researching the lay of the land, don't just throw "map of Brazil" into a search engine. Instead, visit mapquest. And if it is Brazil you are after, then a knowledge of Portuguese could be handy, and forget language tapes or nightschool - the internet has wrapped that too. Head for travlang which can give you an online language course. It doesn't offer only the standard languages either: if it's Bosnian, Basque or Zulu that you are after, you can learn it here, too.

Money talks all languages and internet currency translations are readily at hand. The universal currency convertor www.xe.net/currency performs quick and accurate exchange-rate calculations.

Groundwork planning and preparation done, you don't need to log off to buy your flight. Several company websites offer online flight booking and send you either a confirmation by email or post: easyJet, Go!, ebookers and deckchair and expedia.

Hotels, too, can be booked over the internet. But online booking here can be unreliable. Hotelguide puts details of hotels and availability on its site and purports to assist in the online booking of rooms. But when I rang one of the hotels listed the reception was completely unaware of any online booking facility.

However once you are out of the country and on the road, the powerful communication tool of the internet comes into its own. The advent of free web-based email with Hotmail now offered by many others, including Yahoo and Excite, means that travellers can pick up and send email from any internet café, which have opened in almost every outpost.

And with the advanced technology of eKno, which can be found at www.ekno, you can also capitalise on cheap international phonecalls, free voicemail (which can be accessed via the internet, too) and make use of its innovative "travel vault", which lets you enter all the important personal data (such as passport and insurance information) you really would not want to be without if your wallet or baggage is stolen or lost.

It is stored at a password-protected website accessible from anywhere in the world but only by you. The travel vault is Foreign Office approved. Incidentally, the Foreign Office website is well worth consulting before setting out for potential troublespots at www.fco.gov.uk

New technology for the traveller doesn't just mean internet access and email. There are now a host of gizmos designed to enhance the travel experience or holiday trip. A digital camera makes emailing pictures back home or putting them up on a website much easier. And they could be the illustrations for an online account of your travels from the road. There is a growing cult in these digital travelogues, and some of the web techniques required to maintain a website on the road are discussed at www.madnomad.com

Hand-held and affordable GPS systems to locate your exact position on the planet might prove useful for those straying further from the beaten track, while for the urban traveller, hyper-trendy personal organisers have optional software for navigation and travel aids.

The Palm Pilot has one very useful add-on - Citysync is a programme which is downloadable from www.citysync.com. Once installed, it gives city maps, places to eat, and telephone numbers for accommodation.

Such advances aim to help you survive without the printed word. But being absolutely wireless and still able to log on to the wired world is also achievable. The website Road Warrior tells you how to get online without having to rely on fixed phones and internet cafés as well as giving advice on other aspects of life on the road.

If all of this is bamboozling or even injects a certain kind of web-induced agoraphobia, you can always go for a virtual trip. Web cameras all over the world will show what places look like, such as Global passage.

You can even virtually visit the Mayan ruins at Palenque in Mexico at www.virtualpalenque.com. The photographs here are 360-degree interactive navigable views supported by some pacy archaeological notes.

The web is driven by information, and with its ease of communication it can really deliver independence and freedom. So if you really want to find a remote haven and enjoy the illusion of the lonely planet, then getting connected to the internet community is a first step that is well worth taking.
