webTitle: Estate agents put up home pages

fields.headline: Estate agents put up home pages
fields.standfirst:
Books and CDs are one thing but would you buy a house from the world wide web? Rupert Jones and Jessica McCallin investigate a new trend

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: In America, the internet has turned the way people buy and sell homes upside-down. Virtually every home for sale is advertised online and most house-hunters begin their search on the internet.
fields.body:
In America, the internet has turned the way people buy and sell homes upside-down. Virtually every home for sale is advertised online and most house-hunters begin their search on the internet.

Over here, new technology is certainly starting to transform the house-buying process, but for most people looking to move it is still all about ringing round the estate agents, scanning the ads in the local paper and pounding the streets.

However, a new initiative this week could change all that. In an attempt to maintain their dominance in a rapidly changing market, four of the UK's biggest estate agency chains have teamed up to launch a property website which, they say, will offer by far the largest choice of properties.

The site, called Rightmove, (www.rightmove.co.uk), is being developed by Countrywide Assured, Connells, the Halifax and Royal & SunAlliance, which between them have more than 1,700 estate agency branches.

Within two or three months Rightmove will feature details of almost 120,000 properties for sale - a fifth of all those on the market. With other estate agents, both large and small, expected to sign up for the service, it's planned that by the end of this year more than 50% of UK properties for sale will be displayed on the site. This would bring the UK property market much closer to that of America, where an estimated 98%-plus of all homes for sale can be found on the net, and more than nine out of 10 estate agents are on one website.

James Chapman, at Royal & SunAlliance Property Services, says that if a homebuyer can log on to one site and get access to most of the properties on the market, that has to be a good thing.

"The last thing people want to do is trawl around an electronic high street," he adds. "In an ideal world we would like to have 100% of UK agents on our site."

But critics say that far from offering a better-value way of buying and selling homes, Rightmove is simply another form of advertising space for estate agents - effectively a cyberspace version of the branch office window and the ads they take out in local papers.

House sellers cannot put their properties on to the site themselves: their details will be automatically added to the site when they register with a subscribing estate agent. They will pay no extra for this, but they will have to pay the estate agents' usual 1%-2% commission.

Rightmove is already up and running in a limited form. It enables browsers to access details of close to 50,000 properties on the books of Countrywide Assured estate agents such as Bairstow Eves, Mann & Co and John D Wood.

The information currently on the site is pretty basic: a small picture of the outside of the property, price, location and a short description of the basic features.

You can upload property details and photos directly from your computer, and amend the ad as often as you want.

HouseWeb says the number of people selling their properties privately via the net and other methods is increasing at a rate of knots. What many appear to be doing is using an estate agent and advertising their property on a website as well.

Here we identify some of the other leading property sites:

Easier
www.easier.co.uk

Lets sellers advertise their properties for free. The company makes money by passing on details to "carefully selected" partner companies, which will send you information about their products and services. There is no obligation to buy any of these products or services, but if you find marketing mail irritating you may want to think twice about registering.

UK Property Sales
www.ukpropertysales.com

Charges sellers £39 to advertise a property for three months. It lets buyers search for a home in a specified area and add their name to a mailing list which will notify them when a suitable property comes in. Fee includes a colour photo of the property and a 100-word description.

Loot
www.loot.com

Loot, the free ads paper, lists information on properties to buy and rent in London, Manchester and other areas on its site. Information on alternative properties, including hotel and guest houses, houseboats and retirement homes can be found. Advertising is free.

Fish4Homes
www.fish4homes.co.uk

Provides a database of properties for sale and rent which subscribing local newspapers and estate and letting agents supply and update. Has more than 100,000 properties listed. When you've found a property you are interested in you will then need to contact the agent. Its "Fish4 Me" service will email you with details of homes that come in that match your requirements.

Internet Property Finder
www.propertyfinder.co.uk

Holds details of 22,000 properties. Estate agents pay to display their properties. It is up to them how much information on a property is put on the site. To advertise your property on the site, you will have to register with an agent who uses the site first.

The Home Directory
www.homedirectory.com

Again, estate agents pay an advertising fee and individual homebuyers can use the site for free. Says it wants to become the definitive website for homebuyers, including information on local facilities, mortgages and moving.

HomeFreeHome
www.homefreehome.co.uk

Lets sellers advertise their properties for free. The site allows individuals to upload property details and photos. Buyers will be emailed when properties that fit their requirements are registered on the site.

fields.headline: Dot.com frenzy consumes market
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Free internet access: the issue explained
fields.trailText: The wave of internet and hi-tech companies launching on to the stock market shows no signs of letting up despite a warning this week by chancellor Gordon Brown to small investors hoping to make a dot com fortune.
fields.body:
The wave of internet and hi-tech companies launching on to the stock market shows no signs of letting up despite a warning this week by chancellor Gordon Brown to small investors hoping to make a dot com fortune.

Mr Brown urged caution in the wake of this week's FTSE 100 shake-up, which saw several young hi-tech firms push long-established brewers, housebuilders and supermarkets out of the index. His words coincided with unprecedented investor demand for lastminute.com shares ahead of its flotation next week which could value the 19-month-old company, run by 31-year old Brent Hoberman and 27-year-old Martha Lane-Fox, at as much as £1bn.

The deadline for applications for lastminute.com shares passed yesterday, but amateur punters are on the hunt for the next IPO (initial public offering) of a hi-tech company. The list of forthcoming hi-tech IPOs includes such names as Team Talk, currently valued at around £200m CountyWeb.com, an internet business directory believed to be worth £25m, and Bizzbuild, an e-commerce development company valued at £50m.

But the next blockbuster is likely to be egg.com, the Prudential financial services website, which could have a value running into the billions. A listing of future IPOs is available at www.iii.co.uk/newissues. But note if the stock is going for a placing (so available only to insitutions) or an offer, where small investors can participate. Check if the stock is floating on the main market, Aim or Ofex. Main market offerings are likely to have more substance. Remember how volatile these stocks can be. A week ago Freeserve saw its value plummet by £1.7bn in one day after alta vista and ntl blew a major hole in its "free" internet proposition.

webTitle: Relatives of Shipman victims promised full hearing at inquiry

fields.headline: Relatives of Shipman victims promised full hearing at inquiry
fields.trailText: Families of all Harold Shipman victims will get a full hearing from the independent inquiry into the issues raised by the GP's crimes, said its chairman yesterday.
fields.body:
Families of all Harold Shipman victims will get a full hearing from the independent inquiry into the issues raised by the GP's crimes, said its chairman yesterday.

Lord Laming of Tewin effectively put paid to ministers' hopes of a short, sharp inquiry lasting six months with his public reassurance to relatives that their concerns would be central. He tacitly accepted that the September deadline for his report was unlikely to be met.

"I have discussed this matter with the secretary of state [Alan Milburn] and he and I agreed that thoroughness will have to go hand in hand with speed," he said. "Once we have got into the inquiry and we have understood fully the complexities of the issues we will be tackling, we will be in a better position to advise him on our timetable."

The assurances failed to satisfy the families. Shipman, the Manchester GP jailed for 15 murders, is now thought to have killed more than 100 patients but is unlikely to be charged with any further crimes due to the impossibility of an impartial trial. Relatives, particularly of those who deaths were not considered at the trial, are unhappy that the inquiry is not to be held in public.

Ann Alexander, of the law firm Alexander Harris, said her clients had not been told about the arrangements before they were made public yesterday, and feared they were being asked only to relate their experiences - which was unacceptable.

"They are concerned that the evidence is open and that they should have an opportunity to take part in the cross-examination process," she said.

"They want to ensure that the right people give evidence, and that there isn't any suggestion that there's a cover-up.

"They want the inquiry to be conducted in a proper judicial manner," she said (ie, like those into BSE and the Bristol heart deaths). "Unless there's complete transparency, I don't see how the government is going to restore public confidence."

Lord Laming will have two other panel members: Hazel Genn, professor of socio-legal studies at University College and Aneez Esmail, head of Manchester university's school of primary care. He said anybody with relevant evidence would be invited to contribute, and that importance would be attached to addressing relatives' concerns.

The main purpose was to make recommendations to government about how best patients could be safeguarded from malign or inadequate doctors.

webTitle: Gunmen shoot dead lawyer of deposed Pakistani leader Sharif

fields.headline: Gunmen shoot dead lawyer of deposed Pakistani leader Sharif
fields.standfirst:
Killing follows ex-PM's attack on man who overthrew him

Pakistan coup: special report

Links to official sites and other Pakistan information

Pakistan Muslim League (unofficial site)/
fields.trailText: Three smartly dressed gunmen walked into an office in Karachi yesterday and shot dead one of the leading defence lawyers representing Pakistan's deposed prime minister Nawaz Sharif.
fields.body:
Three smartly dressed gunmen walked into an office in Karachi yesterday and shot dead one of the leading defence lawyers representing Pakistan's deposed prime minister Nawaz Sharif.

Iqbal Raad was hit several times in the chest and died in his chair at his second-floor office in the Paradise Chambers building in central Karachi. Two other men in the room, an office worker and a judge's son, were also killed in the attack.

The shooting comes two days after Mr Sharif gave evidence at his trial and accused Pakistan's military ruler, General Pervez Musharraf, of plotting to overthrow his government and inventing charges against him.

Witnesses said the gunmen, who were carrying a Kalashnikov rifle and pistols, ran from the building into a waiting car and disappeared in the crowded traffic.

Crowds gathered outside the lawyer's offices together with Mr Raad's wife and two sons as the bloodstained bodies were carried out. "This could be an act of sabotage to damage the smooth functioning of the trial. It could be personal enmity. We are not sure," said a senior police superintendent, Akhtar Hussain Gorchani.

Guns, including automatic weapons, are easily bought and sold across Pakistan although the government has tried to tackle the problem with a ban on the issuing of new arms licences.

Karachi, the capital of Sindh province in southern Pakistan, is one of the country's most violent cities. More than 4,000 people have died there in the past four years in a catalogue of political, ethnic and sectarian violence. In September 1996 Mir Murtaza Bhutto, the brother of then prime minister Benazir Bhutto, was killed in a police shooting.

Other defence lawyers in the Sharif case criticised the country's military rulers for not providing them with better protection.

"We need proper security. It will be very difficult for us to attend the proceedings unless we are given the right security," said Khwaja Sultan, the leading defence counsel in the trial. He said he would discuss the shooting with the judge at the next hearing on Monday.

Mr Sharif, his brother Shahbaz and five former senior government officials are on trial before a Karachi anti-terrorism court charged with attempted murder, hijacking, kidnapping and terrorism in a case based on the night of the October military coup. All deny the charges. If convicted they face the death penalty.

Another of Mr Raad's senior colleagues, Ijaz Batalvi, who withdrew from the defence team last month in protest at the judge, said the lawyers had been closely followed during the trial.

Two weeks ago Mr Raad had a fax machine and telephone stolen from his office.

"We have been watched, our telephones were tapped but we were ready for that," Mr Batalvi said. "This is different. This is real terror. I was never expecting something like this. I am shocked and I am sad."

Mr Raad was the former advocate general of Sindh province and also worked as a legal adviser to the former prime minister's Pakistan Muslim League party.

"It is extraordinary that this happened at a time when the case against Nawaz Sharif has entered a crucial stage," said Raja Zafar-ul Haq, one of the party's senior leaders.

He said Mr Raad had received threats.

The trial is drawing to a close and the prosecution had been due to start summing up on Monday.

Catalogue of political violence

October 16 1951 Liaquat Ali Khan, Pakistan's first prime minister, shot dead in Rawalpindi

April 4 1979 Ex-prime minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto found guilty of political murder and hanged

August 17 1988 Military dictator General Zia-ul Haq killed in plane crash

September 20 1996 Mir Murtaza, brother of then prime minister Benazir Bhutto, killed in police shoot-out in Karachi

October 17 1998 Hakim Mohammad Saeed, former governor of Sindh province, shot dead in Karachi

March 10 2000 Iqbal Raad, lawyer of former prime minister Nawaz Sharif, shot dead in Karachi

fields.headline: No way back
fields.standfirst:
Refugees stranded as Chechnya declares all-out war

Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: The Chechen leader, President Aslan Maskhadov, yesterday claimed that his forces were on the offensive in an "all-out partisan war" against the Russians.
fields.body:
The Chechen leader, President Aslan Maskhadov, yesterday claimed that his forces were on the offensive in an "all-out partisan war" against the Russians.

Mr Maskhadov made the claim as, after days of denials, military chiefs in Moscow admitted that 85 crack Russian paratroopers were killed by Chechen rebel forces in fierce mountain fighting last week.

In a telephone interview with the Guardian and two other western newspapers from an undisclosed location in southern Chechnya, President Maskhadov said battles were raging for control of up to eight villages in the Argun gorge, in the highlands of southern Chechnya, where several thousand guerrillas are hemmed in by a Russian air and artillery onslaught.

Russia's acting president, Vladimir Putin, said he would probably impose direct Russian presidential rule on Chechnya after the presidential election on March 26, which he is expected to win.

But while Mr Putin declared it his "historic mission" to tame Chechnya, Mr Maskhadov said: "All talk from Russian generals that they have won the war is complete rubbish."

The Chechen leader spoke of fierce fighting near the villages of Komsomolskoye, Ulus-Kert and Selmentausen, where his fighters inflicted a devastating blow on elite Russian units at the beginning of the month.

In a dawn ambush, the Chechens killed an entire company from a paratroopers' division. The Russians dismissed the reports, then admitted 31 deaths. Yesterday the defence ministry finally confirmed that 85 had been killed.

Russian newspapers reported that Igor Sergeyev, the defence minister, had ordered the losses to be covered up.

With Chechens still fleeing to refugee camps to escape the fighting, Mr Maskhadov revealed that he had just issued his third main order of the six-month war - "to start an all-out partisan war".

He added: "Now you see the results. We don't have a lack of weapons. If we were to run out of weapons, we could easily buy them from the Russians. As long as there are Russians in Chechnya we will not suffer a lack of anything."

In an interview published in Moscow as part of a forthcoming book, Mr Putin made it plain that Russia would be in Chechnya for years to come.

"After the presidential elections, direct presidential rule might be introduced for a couple of years," he said. "A local elite has to be created which understands that it is advantageous to Chechnya to remain in Russia. Today there cannot be and won't be any talks about any other status outside the framework of Russia."

Mr Putin described the last Chechen war, of 1994-96, as a "defeat" and a "crime" for Russia.

webTitle: Beijing talks tough to US as tension rises over Taiwan

fields.headline: Beijing talks tough to US as tension rises over Taiwan
fields.standfirst: Taiwan and China: special report
fields.trailText: China sent a tough message to the United States yesterday not to "interfere" with Taiwan, saying relations with Washington had reached a critical point.
fields.body:
China sent a tough message to the United States yesterday not to "interfere" with Taiwan, saying relations with Washington had reached a critical point.

The foreign minister, Tang Jiaxuan, accused the US of responsibility for "the tension in the Taiwan straits" in the run-up to presidential elections on the island in a week's time.

"What the US has done has inflated the arrogance of the separatist [pro-independence] forces in Taiwan," Mr Tang told a press conference in Beijing.

China's ambassador to the US has formally protested in Washington about a Pentagon decision to sell Taiwan upgraded missiles and radar equipment.

Most observers blame Beijing for raising the tension last month by threatening in a new white paper to use force if Taiwan continued to delay negotiations on reunification indefinitely.

Mr Tang said China was still waiting for the US to inform it of "the true outcome of the investigation" into last year's bombing of the Chinese embassy in Belgrade, and to "bring the perpetrators to justice".

Speaking to the international press at a conference called by the national people's congress - China's annual parliament - Mr Tang may have added a diplomatic gloss to Beijing's recent harsh statements.

But no one expects the foreign ministry to incur the suspicion of the Chinese armed forces and elements in the Communist party who may regard it as already too soft towards the outside world.

A Chinese TV programme has been portraying the might of the People's Liberation Army (PLA) every night this week to bolster the message, delivered to the congress by army delegates, that it is ready to take action on Taiwan.

On Thursday President Jiang Zemin donned a dark-green Maoist suit to meet the delegates, calling on them to "increase actual combat capability". Western diplomats in Beijing say senior PLA leaders have recently made a point of stressing to high-level foreign visitors that there is now a "timetable" for regainingTaiwan.

The generals do not mention a date but suggest that China cannot tolerate many more years of division while pro-independence opinion in Taiwan continues to grow.

"Retired army generals - who may still have influence - also believe strongly that the Taiwan issue must be settled before they themselves are dead and buried," says one diplomat.

The consensus among experts is still that China is highly unlikely to take action. Full-scale invasion is militarily unfeasible, given Taiwan's distance from the mainland and logistical difficulties - plus the risk of US counter-intervention.

Limited moves, such as occupying an offshore island or incursions into Taiwan's air or sea space, are tactically possible. But they would hardly assist in the strategic aim of persuading the reluctant Taiwanese of the need for reunification.

Yet analysts admit they are largely in the dark and are waiting anxiously to see whether whoever wins in Taiwan on March 18 can defuse the situation.

Mr Jiang has said whoever wins will be welcome to visit Beijing "as long as he supports the idea of one China".

Responding to Mr Tang, the US defence secretary, William Cohen, said yesterday in Hong Kong: "China is required in our opinion to seek a peaceful resolution on the situation in Taiwan, and not to try in any way to intimidate them."

Mr Cohen said the newly announced supplies to Taiwan are designed to keep its "20-year-old technology" working and do not increase the island's offensive capability.

Taiwan has also requested more advanced weaponry, including four guided-missile destroyers equipped with the sophisticated Aegis system.

Mr Cohen said the request was under review, hinting that further Chinese threats to Taiwan might tip the balance in favour of granting it.

However, Chinese anger with the US over Taiwan has historical roots. "It is an issue left over from the Chinese civil war which would have been resolved but for the intervention of the US seventh fleet," Mr Tang said yesterday.

He professed to be unaware of Bill Clinton's speech on Wednesday, in which the US president offered a more positive view of the Chinese white paper.

webTitle: Millwall offer Kosovo fans a refuge

fields.headline: Millwall offer Kosovo fans a refuge
fields.standfirst: Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: They have witnessed the horrors of war and endured an arduous journey to Britain - only to find themselves being used as scapegoats by some politicians.
fields.body:
They have witnessed the horrors of war and endured an arduous journey to Britain - only to find themselves being used as scapegoats by some politicians.

Come next week, however, a group of Kosovan refugees will at least have the warmth and support of Millwall football fans when they will travel to south-east London to watch the team in an ambitious attempt to make them feel more at home.

Police in south London are organising a coach for 25 Kosovans in the hope that exposure to the regulars of the New Den, Millwall's home ground, might help them integrate with the local community and improve their understanding of British culture.

Millwall fans are not exactly renowned for extending the hand of friendship to visitors, given that some of them are considered among the toughest in the country, but police and club officals remain optimistic that things might change.

The club has also offered coaching sessions and believes it can help the refugees integrate with their new surroundings. They are all living in a hostel near Millwall's ground and will attend the match against Blackpool on the club's offical anti-racist day.

Inspector Steve Burgess of Southwark police said: "A lot of the young men at the hostel are obsessed with football. We have already organised a number of matches with police to give them something to do.

"But taking them to the match is an opportunity to relieve some of the boredom and at the same time Millwall gain some potential fans."

Despite the notoriety of some of their supporters, Millwall are leading the way when it comes to anti-racist and community initiatives.

The club's spokesman Ken Chapman said: "Football is an international language. We want to celebrate in the terraces the cultural diversity that we also have in our teams.

"This is a chance to make the asylum seekers feel more accepted and at home in south London. And if they eventually settle here, hopefully they will become Millwall supporters."

Given the adverse publicity surrounding the presence of refugees in Britain at least those visiting the New Den next week will be able to empathise with the Millwall fans' anthem, which contains the line: "No one likes us, we don't care."

webTitle: Fetch the tissues - there's treacle on the telly

fields.headline: Fetch the tissues - there's treacle on the telly
fields.trailText: Channel surfing
fields.body:
It was Dan Keplinger's senior prom at high school in 1993 and he was determined to have as good a time as anybody else. Dan, who has cerebral palsy, had pushed aside his wheelchair and was on his knees dancing. What he lacked in coordination he made up for in fierce, determined movement. His partner stood several feet above Dan, dancing too. It wasn't exactly Fred and Ginger, but they seemed to be enjoying themselves.

Then the film slowed down, so that Dan's dancing became a languorous blur. A subtitle appeared on screen, words that Dan had typed by means of his strap-on head stick into his computer. As Dan danced, he wrote this: "What is love? I have loved a few women, always dreaming about them. But it never leads anywhere. I love Laura [a friend who volunteered to help him with his daily chores] and care about her and I think she feels the same for me - but not quite. I'm sure with other people it would lead to sex. My female friends say I will meet someone soon, but I see myself becoming a very old man, whacking off to pornos."

King Gimp (National Geographic) could have been an intolerably sentimental documentary. The incidental music - oboe, piano and unctuous synthesiser - signalled that this was going to be a treacly story about the triumph of the human spirit. It was annoying music that pigeonholed a life story uncomplicatedly for viewers who want to have easy tears over some poor cripple's misfortunes.

And sometimes Susan Hannah Hadary and William A Whiteford's film, which has been nominated for an Oscar in the best documentary short category, seemed in league with this music. It moved from adversity to triumph in the big leaps that have been denied to Dan. King Gimp was made up of scenes of Dan growing from age 13 when he was attending a special school and living with his mother to his graduation ceremony 13 years later, when this award- winning painter got his art degree.

It could have been sentimental but for its angry, insightful subject. He didn't want a Hawking-style computer voicebox, for instance, even though it would make his speech more readily comprehensible, because people would talk to the computer rather than him.

We saw him changing out of a sweatshirt into a T-shirt. It was a farcical wrangle between man and shirt which, most of the time, the T-shirt looked like winning. After he triumphed, Dan rolled up to the camera and said in his barely comprehensible voice: "Another day of crap." Thanks to this scene and Dan's angry attitude to the difficulties he had to put up with, we got an insight into the downside - his loneliness, his desperate need to express himself in paintings, his hunger for a sex life.

Television can be, but often isn't, good at this sort of programme. It should be good, because by watching, say, the struggles of someone with cerebral palsy - to get the education he deserves, to get the respect to which they are entitled, to get dressed single-handed - people like me, who have never known anyone who has cerebral palsy, let alone cared for them, might have their eyes opened.

But that, like Dan's sweatshirt, is a difficult thing to pull off, and too often this film unwarrantably accentuated the positive, leaving the viewer with too many misplaced feelings of warmth and a shortage of tissues.

Dan made this more than a Kleenex-fest, which is proper because he has struggled throughout his life to have his voice heard: to be regarded as something other than thick, to get out of special schools, to make teachers teach him. At one point Dan recalled a key moment from special school: "They knew I was special when I put together a puzzle with my knees."

Up popped the relevant footage: Dan was on his knees again, this time nudging one piece of jigsaw into place. It was going to take ages, time which this film didn't have to spare. Maybe, though, what we really needed was to watch Dan fill in a 3,000 piece jigsaw with his knees. The film would have lasted for at least 12 hours. It would have been boring, exasperating viewing, but then at least we would have understood Dan properly and felt some of his commitment and frustration. But such a film would not receive an Oscar nomination.

fields.headline: The Swindon swindle
fields.standfirst: Fancy that - an article on Swindon without a single mention of Melinda Messenger...
fields.trailText: • It was always certain that the contest to choose a single town to be upgraded, in this millennium year, to the status of city would end in tears, and although the process is not yet over, the tears are falling already. A leaked home office document suggests that the choice now lies between Wolverhampton and Brighton and Hove, but that Brighton and Hove may suffer because, although it's a single local government unit, it is really two towns rather than one. Luton, imaginatively described by a local MP as "far and away the most vibrant place to be at the moment", was the bookmakers' favourite but is not, it seems, the home office's, while poor Swindon was made the subject of many snooty objections. It had no history, some anonymous civil servant said, outside the 19th century when the railway came; it was not a rounded community; it was guilty of feuding with Reading (another contender); it was "particularly materialistic" and lacking in culture.
fields.body:
 It was always certain that the contest to choose a single town to be upgraded, in this millennium year, to the status of city would end in tears, and although the process is not yet over, the tears are falling already. A leaked home office document suggests that the choice now lies between Wolverhampton and Brighton and Hove, but that Brighton and Hove may suffer because, although it's a single local government unit, it is really two towns rather than one. Luton, imaginatively described by a local MP as "far and away the most vibrant place to be at the moment", was the bookmakers' favourite but is not, it seems, the home office's, while poor Swindon was made the subject of many snooty objections. It had no history, some anonymous civil servant said, outside the 19th century when the railway came; it was not a rounded community; it was guilty of feuding with Reading (another contender); it was "particularly materialistic" and lacking in culture.

All of this is full of injustice. Brighton came close to success in the last such contest, finishing runner-up to Sunderland. For it now to be excluded for having got married to Hove would be grotesque. This was a shotgun marriage, designed at the behest of the Banham Commission on local government reform, and solemnised by parliament under the Tories. Left to themselves, Brighton would still be Brighton, and Hove would still be Hove.

The case against Swindon is even more iniquitous. If cities which scarcely existed before the Victorian age are not to be seen as real cities, many across the world would have to be stripped of their status. Has the home office never heard of Australia? As for culture, the great town clerk Murray John, who more than any other man created the modern Swindon, foresaw this very difficulty, and nagged at succeeding governments to give the town a university. But neither university nor upgradeable polytechnic came its way. If its cafes and bars are not full of men with beards discussing Heidegger, that is not Swindon's fault*.

 Why was it always Laurel and Hardy rather than Hardy and Laurel? Why Abbott and Costello, Black and Decker, Sacco and Vanzetti rather than the other way round? I can see a case for Morecambe and Wise, where Morecambe was the ringleader - as perhaps was Sacco: I have never studied their case. But why Laurel and Hardy? Hardy, I suspect, was the better actor of the two; more rounded anyway. Yet Laurel is always given pre-eminence.

This issue arises particularly in the case of writers of musical comedy. In opera, the composer always comes first, with the librettist lagging behind. Richard Rodgers comes before Lorenz Hart and later before Oscar Hammerstein. And yet it is always Gilbert (words) and Sullivan (music): G and S, not S and G.

I began to ponder on this while sitting through three very enjoyable hours (though they might not be if one did not like G and S) of Topsy-Turvy, Mike Leigh's new film about them. Sullivan was much the more feted of the pair. He was the first to get knighted. When a special performance of The Gondoliers was put on for Queen Victoria, Gilbert's name was left off the programme. And yet, oddly enough, at one point in the film you see an advertisement for a coming Savoy opera which is said to be by "Sir Arthur Sullivan and WS Gilbert", rather than the other way round. When did that change, and why? This is the kind of mystery which it needs a Watson and Holmes to unravel.

 My thanks, to those who have pointed out where the otiose "r" now so often inserted into the word "withdrawal" has come from. It has migrated, they say, from what used to be February and now mostly seems to be Febuary.

 Smallweed read with horror the claim in the Guardian last weekend that if appointed at Celtic, the old West German world cup star Bertie Vogts would become the first German to manage a British club. Such claims are almost always unwise, since some smart obsessive will swiftly write in with a precedent. In this case I regard that as certain.

The young chap who wrote the piece is presumably unaware of the curious episode which occurred towards the end of the 40s at Theddlethorpe, Lincolnshire, when a man called Harold Flite, described as a German refugee, was appointed to run the local side, Theddlethorpe Trojans - then lying a handy fourth in the Louth and district league. This choice caused some consternation in the dressing room.

Though his face, overhung by a cowlick of dark hair, seemed strangely familiar, he had little knowledge of football, while some of his odd habits caused alarm. He used to greet his players not with a handshake but by throwing his arm out in front of him at an angle of 45 degrees. "Bit like a Nazi salute!" one told him jokingly, but Flite explained he had just invented a one-man form of high fives. When training the team, he would constantly consult a coaching manual which he would not allow them to see. One of them took his chance while Flite was busy negotiating the transfer of a fullback from Saltfleet St Peter United, to take a look at the cover. "It seems to be by some geezer called Meinkampf," he reported, but colleagues told him they thought there had been a winger called Meinkampf in the German team in the 30s.

As time went on the team talks became more bizarre. Priming his squad for a needle match against Utterby, he said of the Utterby penalty area: "Try to think of it as the Sudetenland." By then, the Trojans' skipper, a barber called Froop who did crosswords while waiting for customers, had begun to suspect Flite's true identity. "I believe him to be an anagram," he announced one night in the pub. Even then, it was not until a lad who was in the side to make up the numbers idly sketched a moustache on a photograph of the manager in that week's Theddlethorpe Trumpet that the penny finally dropped.

But by then, Flite had vanished. He was later said to be managing a team in Norway, under the name Leif Thorald. Theddlethorpe was left to find a new manager, which it speedily did. He, oddly enough, was another expatriate German - a fellow called Barton Mirmann.

 Readers are asked to note that this is probably the only piece written about Swindon in the British press in the last two years which excludes any mention at all of Melinda Messenger.

webTitle: Alan Bennett's etiquette of grief and rage

fields.headline: Alan Bennett's etiquette of grief and rage
fields.trailText: Wave riding
fields.body:
Demob-happy Zoë Ball, in her final week on the Radio 1 breakfast show, has been campaigning to prevent the Di Marcos leaving EastEnders. So have other Radio 1 DJs. What is it with Radio 1 and EastEnders? There's clearly a symbiotic relationship between the breakfast show, the tabloids and the soaps, with the first two parasitic on the third as well as on each other. It can't be long before they all meld into one intertextual heap.

Ball's laddishness has been trumpeted, but it's her androgyny that attracts teen and pre-teen listeners. There's a young-girliness about the way she moans and says she can't do things, and relates to Zoë A, a member of the baying, giggling background mob otherwise known as the zoo .

She kissed the show goodbye yesterday, so it seems the zoo format will disappear along with her. About time. In the future, the stale sound of the baying, giggling zoo team will be recalled with much the same air of astonishment as we now look back on Louis XIV's courtiers admiring le roi's public toilet-using. The Ball show has gone. Long Live the apparently zooless Sara Cox.

On Radio 4 Alan Bennett was back. His five-part story, Father! Father! Burning Bright, described the death of a father as experienced by his bitter son. Midgley is a middle-aged teacher, equally despised by his dad and wife, grudgingly granted leave by his headteacher to go and sit in vigil by the hospital bedside of his comatose father.

The terrain is clearly Bennett land, a place where people interject domestic non-sequiturs into key emotional moments. Where melancholy and regret escape apologetically, almost like wind.

At its start, Father! Father! seemed almost a Bennett self- parody. But he is the poet of diffidence, the bard of ambivalence. And here he mapped out how the consummately polite deal with grief and rage. He's an astute geographer of social exchanges and although the story wasn't exactly dramatic, it was certainly masterly, and the ending brilliant. In an endeavour to free himself from his constricted lifestyle, Midgeley is bedding a sympathetic nurse just as his father wakes up - sans son - before dying. Dad had triumphed again.

It takes a skilful soul to blend actuality and actors, and keep empathy from curdling into voyeurism, but BBC Scotland's Dave Batchelor, who last year gave us the brilliant Radio 3 production of Kark Kraus's The Last Days of Mankind, did just that in Postcards from Shannon (Radio 4), a drama-documentary about the Lockerbie crash. Shannon Davis was a 19-year-old Syracuse university student travelling round Europe, from where she sent postcards to her mother, Jane. Volunteer Phil Haigh was combing the area where the Pan Am crashed when he came upon Shannon's open suitcase with a letter from her mother ending: "We're all excited about you coming home for Christmas".

Writer George Rosie combined Shannon's postcards (convincingly read by Theresa Reid) and Phil's reminiscences (an equally sharp Mark McDonnell) with the real Jane's account and news bulletins to create a devastating piece of radio, impossible to hear without asking how people survive such sudden losses.

Shannon's postcards gave a strong sense of the perky American ("Florence is a neat city"), while Phil's battered incomprehension at the disaster conveyed how his life had been irrevocably altered too. There were moments of unbearable juxtaposition, as when Shannon's account of visiting Dachau segued into Phil's description of a fieldful of shoes. And when Jane and Phil met at a Lockerbie reception, the shared pain must have extended to every listener.

webTitle: Bullet trains or murder on the Virgin express?

fields.headline: Bullet trains or murder on the Virgin express?
fields.trailText: 'Sir' Richard Branson | Dennis | Declaring peace on John Prescott
fields.body:
Trains running at 205 miles an hour, cutting the London-Edinburgh journey time down to three hours and 15 minutes. Virgin-à-Grand Vitesse services leaving King's Cross every 10 minutes! Passengers given in-seat massages while the cast of The Lion King perform and Salman Rushdie's new girlfriend models the latest in the Agent Provocateur range of baby-doll sleepwear! I may have exaggerated this week's press reports, but whenever I see this science-fiction stuff about new trains, I know that "Sir" Richard Branson is in difficulties again.

He is desperate to win the National Lottery franchise, and - despite having one of the worst records of all privatised train operators - wants to get his hands on the so-far fairly reliable north-east line. And a highly critical biography by Tom Bower is about to be published which, if nothing else, will do harm to his considerable amour propre. So we get all this nonsense about bullet trains, most of which is printed uncritically by a press which remains far more in awe of Branson's achievements than the public. I've said before that I'll believe in miracle trains when I ride on one. But that's unfair. When I see a train maker standing in front of even one chassis, waving the appropriate cheque from Mr Branson, then I'll accept it. But I'm not holding my breath.

 A splendid moment at the party ITN gave this week for its retiring political editor, Michael Brunson. Margaret Thatcher was talking to Brunson's successor, John Sergeant (remember the famous time in 1990 when she handbagged him outside the Paris embassy?) and to Alan Duncan, the tiny ex-confidante of William Hague. "Where is Denis?" she suddenly remarked, "we have to go for dinner with Cap Weinberger."

"He's over there, talking to Michael Heseltine," Duncan told her, rather bravely I thought. She glowered, majestically. "Dinner is far more important," she said. "Go and tell him that if he doesn't come here within two minutes, I shall go over and scowl at them both." Naturally Denis was at her side within seconds. My informant assures me that she was, to some extent, consciously caricaturing herself.

 Jeffrey Archer begins his diary in this week's Spectator: "Last Friday evening I had dinner with Vanessa Redgrave at the Ivy." I wonder if Ms Redgrave is aware that this meal took place?

 If I were Frank Dobson (whom I like and respect a lot, though I'll be voting for Ken, like almost all Londoners) I'd spend more time pointing out that nearly all the people who know Ken and who have worked with him plan to vote against him. They convert old jokes to anti-Ken gags ("What if you had Saddam Hussein, Milosevic and Ken at gunpoint, but only two bullets?" "You'd shoot Ken twice, just to be sure.").

They shake their heads in mock amazement: "I can't understand why Ken didn't accept that terrific job Tony offered him - cultural ambassador to Grozny." I asked one well-known lefty MP why they hated him so much. Was it his rampant egomania?

"No," he said, "rampant egomania we can live with. We encourage rampant egomania. It's just that he's so damn' popular."

 I enjoyed hearing Kelvin MacKenzie whingeing on Thursday about the way the BBC had won the radio rights for home test cricket matches. Since his station, known as Talksport, had offered £2.5m more than the BBC over five years, he felt this proved that "though our money was good enough, possibly our accents were not good enough".

I doubt that. The BBC offers a width of audience and a range of ages which will do far more for cricket's popularity than the part Murdoch-owned station ever could. It was MacKenzie who, a few years ago, was moaning because the authorities wanted to end "bundling", the process by which cable viewers have to pay for a set of stations whether they want them or not.

Without bundling, Mr MacKenzie's Live TV would have folded much earlier than it did. But, of course, these mercantile buccaneers are always wildly in favour of the free market as long as it works their way. When it doesn't, they whine that the rules are unfair.

 I was outraged to see that my sketchwriting colleague Matthew Parris has unilaterally decided it's time to declare peace on John Prescott. It's all very well for him. What he didn't tell Times readers is that he is soon off to the remote and desolate French island of Kerguelen, 1,000 miles north of Antartica, until the middle of August, to make a film for Channel 4.

OK, we're all desperate to get away from Welsh question time, but what are the rest of us to write about? We need John Prescott, or at least we need the loveable caricature John Prescott we have invented between us.

In renouncing him, Matthew is like a mining company which finds a limitless seam of gold, then announces high-mindedly that it doesn't intend to dig there any more. The shareholders would be outraged. I regard it as my sacred duty to re-double my efforts on Ann Widdecombe, Michael Fabricant and, yes, John Prescott.

fields.headline: Crusading inertia
fields.standfirst: "The  old king wouldn't have said "Bugger Bognor" from his deathbed if they'd had a Butlin's there then. He'd have risen from it, rolled up his trousers and entered the knobbly knees contest."
fields.trailText: "The old king wouldn't have said "Bugger Bognor" from his deathbed if they'd had a Butlin's there then. He'd have risen from it, rolled up his trousers and entered the knobbly knees contest."
fields.body:
For some years now, I've been dreaming about Butlin's. Okay, so as first lines go it's nowhere near as lyrical as, "Last night I dreamed of Manderley", but it's the truth. Now, with my parents both dead, I find myself dreaming about Butlin's at least twice a week. I think it might be my Land Of Lost Content, but I wouldn't swear to it.

I'm a happy sort of bunny, and I always believe that where I am is the best place to be. But if I had to say when I was the happiest I've ever been, I'd say it was during the four summer holidays my parents and I spent at Butlin's, Bognor Regis, in the late 60s/early 70s. For an imaginative, solitary, hedonistic, working-class girl child at that time, it was very heaven - truly, my very own empire of the senses.

I'll tell you what: that old king wouldn't have said "Bugger Bognor" from his deathbed if they'd had a Butlin's there then. He'd have risen from it, rolled up his trousers and entered the knobbly knees contest. Arriving at the front office, you checked in the Old You at the desk and went to find your chalet, where the limber, lithe and most definitely not shy New You, already having slipped into its sarong and sandals, would rise smiling from the single bed, sand falling from its silky thighs, to take your hand and lead you out into the shimmering surrealism that was Butlin's at its best.

Bob Lind's Elusive Butterfly was often played during one of these holidays, and it is to the melancholy strains of this song that, in my dreams, I pad restlessly, vainly seeking my parents, through the deserted camp: through the echo-ey swimming pools with the parrots hanging from glass ceilings, past the abandoned crazy golf courses and through the Beachcomber Lounge, where the swimmers' legs move in eerie autonomy through the glass panels on the wall. But everything's in the wrong place now, and I can never find my way home again.

I went back there a few weeks ago. None of the fairground rides was open. Admittedly, it was February, but it also happened to be a scorching sunny, February day, as the majority of days in February were this year down here on the coast. And it was half term! Would it have killed them to open up a few dodgems and turn the waltzer on? The once-beautiful indoor swimming pool now had no room for swimming at all, only for queuing wearily in order finally to use the water slides: 15 minutes of boredom in return for 15 seconds of fun.

Most of Butlin's is now a covered mini-mall of fast-food outlets and tacky gift shops. It's very hard to imagine exactly who would derive pleasure from such a visit, unless they had been held prisoner in a concrete bunker for the past 50 years. In the fast-food outlets, people queued for 20 minutes for a plate of chips. What's it going to be like in summer? And why is such food called "fast" at all?

All in all, the decimation of my own little Shangri-La made me think of a phrase from a Joseph Heller novel, Good As Gold - "crusading inertia". Crusading inertia is best demonstrated, of course, by the "revolutionary" replacement of human telephone operators by recorded ones telling you to push buttons after the tone: far from speeding things up and helping companies to work at maximum efficiency, automation has actually slowed down this part of life, not to mention been responsible for dangerously raising the blood pressure of millions. Look at traffic: there's now so much of it that it actually takes longer to get across London than it did 20 years ago. Before long, things will be so bad that it would have taken a shorter time in the heyday of the hansom cab.

Crusading inertia - by which I mean a frenzied determination to replace existing mechanisms with new ones, which invariably prove less satisfactory, but then cannot be changed back due to a combination of stinginess and pride - is everywhere. It's those Virgin trains with 10 types of ticket and an absolute inability to get anywhere on time. It's when businesses screw up, blithely explaining that "the computers have crashed", as though the computers were Kings Of The Universe and thus naturally allowed to cause any length of inconvenience to we mere mortals without so much as an apology. Or those bar-codes that don't work properly, so the checkout girl spends a good three minutes obsessively passing the object over and over the scanner until it looks like she's conducting an imaginary orchestra.

The biggest example of all must be email, by which I remain distinctly underwhelmed. Both times when I attempted to speak to Guardian readers on its website, it took me the same time to receive and answer five e-mail questions as it would have done a dozen faxes. Nevertheless, a massive rush of my fans (80% of whom I'd reckon were calling from work - crusading inertia in the marketplace) caused the sites to collapse; that wouldn't happen to a fax. Most misguided of all must be email shopping. Whereas it would take most people less than an hour to pop out to Dixon's and pick up a simple computer accessory, it took a Mr Jon O'Neill 53 days - 53! - to attempt the same thing on-line, at which point he gave up and is still waiting for a refund for the item that never turned up.

If crusading inertia continues to pick up such sluggish speed, I can easily imagine us all in 20 years' time (surrounded by allegedly labour-saving technology but actually going to our graves far younger than our fathers), unable to make human contact, frustrated beyond recall by the sheer, bog-standard bovinity of machines, screaming ourselves into high blood pressure and heart attacks in our little padded cells - each life ending not with a bang, but with a piped version of The Four Seasons.

On an altogether cheerier note, the other day I was writing my next novel (Rough Hands, Orion Books, 2001, don't all rush at once) when a pun of such glittering, piquant perfection occurred to me that I had to get up and rush out into the garden simply because the force of my own cleverness forbade me to stay still. Sadly, I now believe that this pun is so gorgeous that it must have been thought of already. If this is so, could any reader supply me with details?

This is my pun: "They married in Hastings and repented in Leicester." Excuse me, I've just got to run outside again.

fields.headline: Underside
fields.trailText: To begin, we continue last week's look at institutional investors (huge salaries, justification for), with a gem from Wednesday's Newsnight, which focused on the internet bubble.
fields.body:
 To begin, we continue last week's look at institutional investors (huge salaries, justification for), with a gem from Wednesday's Newsnight, which focused on the internet bubble. Nicola Horlick, joint managing director of SG Asset Management, was asked how she felt about the FTSE 100 Index being choca with zero-profit ventures. She told a visibly pale Jeremy Paxman that: "[As] an investment manager I have to beat the index, so therefore I have to look at these things on their merits, and if I think that - I may think that -it's a bit strange that something's not going to make a profit for a considerable length of time, then you just have to find new valuation methods." Or, as the Bank of England told its first economist, don't tell us what to do, just why we did it. Definitions on a postcard please of "merits", "valuation" and "investment manager".

 Elsewhere in the wonderful world of bubble.com, the reductio ad absurdam of net fever emerged this week, with Jackpot Enterprises, one of Nevada's biggest slot machine operators, declaring on Wednesday that it is to transform itself into an internet investment company and set up a $100m web fund. The one-time bandits -one-armed or otherwise -are to pump money into assorted net ventures; as for the poor old low-tech fruit machines, J Net (that's the new handle, folks!) is "exploring options". Now, fruities, on the whole, pay out 70p for every £1 they take. Assuming Jackpot wishes to limit its losses, wouldn't its own machines prove a safer home for $100m than the bubble?

 And bubbles don't come much bubblier than the one surrounding Lastminute.com - which we featured last week along with its co-founder Martha Lane-Fox - whose float price is inflating faster than the lira in the 1970s. Nine years ago, we discover, Martha was a bit player in one of the more amusing hoaxes of recent times. Papa Robin, a big-hitting academic, told FT readers on May 18, 1991 that: "A thunderbolt may be about to strike early Christian history", with a new text emerging from ancient times, apparently containing quotes from Our Lord. The document had been unearthed by US Egyptologist, Batson D. Sealing. Alas, one week later RLF admitted he'd been had (Bats on the ceiling, geddit?). It seems he did consult Martha beforehand, but "[she] thought I must have noticed". Good to know the family's about-to-be multi-millionaire is hard to gull.

 Speaking of families, Tony Blair launched a "work-life balance" initiative this week, complete with a ying and yang-style logo. And where and when was the launch of this family-loving love in? Number 10 at, er, a big breakfast meet at 8.30am. Early-bird sponsors include BT, Sainsbury, Shell and a bank, NatWest, whose soon to be canned workers will doubtless have plenty of time to balance their commitments.

 Back in the pre-bubble world of the Royal Automobile Club, it emerged this week that the assorted horn-parping Mr Toads have been a little, ah, careful with their money; more than two-thirds of members did not feel able to contribute £100 of their hard, unearned £34,000 demutualisation windfall to a fund for long-suffering club staff. webTitle: Body Shop out on a limb

fields.headline: Body Shop out on a limb
fields.trailText: Roger Cowe's piece (Stakeholder rights slip off the agenda, March 10) makes for depressing reading. Enlightened business will find it hard to forgive the government for its cold feet about stakeholder rights.
fields.body:
Roger Cowe's piece (Stakeholder rights slip off the agenda, March 10) makes for depressing reading. Enlightened business will find it hard to forgive the government for its cold feet about stakeholder rights. If their company law review backs off fundamental reform it will miss the opportunity to put business on a 21st-century footing. Worse, they will confirm the damaging impression that business responsibility goes no further than making a profit - a lie which is doing enormous damage to people, the environment and communities around the world.

The Body Shop has put "stakeholder" reporting into practice for six years now. But there are far too few of us to have a significant impact on the problem. And unless the government does what it promised to do, it risks putting pioneering companies like ours - willing to live up to broader responsibilities - at a disadvantage to old-fashioned slash-and-burn capitalists.
Anita Roddick
The Body Shop International

 You overlook the community foundation movement. By pooling financial contributions through named funds in community foundations, companies can meet social needs in their area much more effectively.
Gaynor Humphries
Association of Community Trusts and Foundations

 Should businesses be major players in the voluntary world? Their involvement means private enterprise decides which voluntaries get the resources and what their agenda should be. Far better to tax companies and make the money available to residents of neighbourhoods.
Bob Holman
Glasgow

fields.headline: Cheated on benefits
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown ('Two strikes and you're out' threat, March 9) tells us at every turn that "work is the best route out of poverty", extols flexible labour markets and encourages employers to create more jobs paying below the national insurance threshold (around £80 a week or less).
fields.body:
Gordon Brown ('Two strikes and you're out' threat, March 9) tells us at every turn that "work is the best route out of poverty", extols flexible labour markets and encourages employers to create more jobs paying below the national insurance threshold (around £80 a week or less). Yet, with his colleagues at the DSS, he continues to preside over an antiquated and inflexible benefits system which penalises people for taking up precisely this kind of casual, temporary or part-time work. There isn't any point for someone on benefits to take a bar job at £20 a week, or the odd few days painting and decorating at £50 a day. If they declare it, their benefits are docked virtually pound for pound (and messed up for weeks hence). If they don't, they will now run the risk of having no benefits at all.

Why blame the individuals when it is the system which is morally corrupting? And how can such a system be squared with the government's goal of making work pay? So Gordon, instead of another clampdown on "benefit cheats", why don't you give us a benefits system which genuinely does make work pay - and most especially for those who are struggling to make ends meet at the very bottom of the flexible labour market?
Niall Cooper
Church Action on Poverty
churchaction@cwcom.net

 I've just done an archive search of your website. The latest anti-fraud "initiative" is something like the nineth announcement in just over a year. In other words, this isn't so much about policy as PR. While the government claims £500m in lost benefits, it receives £2bn in unspent social security payments. Fraud isn't going to stop until all claimants are implanted with tracking devices. I'm sure the treasury is working on it.
D Cameron
Stoke-on-Trent

fields.headline: Rip-off asylum vouchers
fields.trailText: I lived in Berlin when the asylum voucher system was introduced in Germany which is now to come into force in the UK (Keep the change, refugee voucher stores are told, March 10). Swap schemes were set up by churches, unions and student groups, in which those outraged at further infringement of refugee rights swapped asylum vouchers for cash.
fields.body:
I lived in Berlin when the asylum voucher system was introduced in Germany which is now to come into force in the UK (Keep the change, refugee voucher stores are told, March 10). Swap schemes were set up by churches, unions and student groups, in which those outraged at further infringement of refugee rights swapped asylum vouchers for cash. Asylum seekers were able to shop on more equal terms with the rest of the population; and the prejudice shown to those presenting an asylum voucher at the till was shared by people with a vote and some power to change the system.

It is appalling that asylum seekers, who live in exile, on lower levels of support than the rest of the population, should have their freedoms still further restricted. If the voucher scheme goes ahead, let's make it a point of pride for ordinary shoppers to present an asylum voucher for their weekly shop.
Catrin Davies
Welwyn Garden City, Herts
chdavies@lgu.ac.uk

 Surely the only response to this voucher scheme is to boycott any shop which displays a sticker saying they are part of it, as well as returning our reward cards stating why are doing this. Pressure from shoppers concerned about their own health led to many supermarkets withdrawing GM foods; we can show we are also concerned about other people's health and well being. And surely Millbank should approve, as it would be a good example of consumers standing up against an example of the "rip-off" culture.
Deborah Hart
London
daath@deborahhart. totalserve.co.uk

 Let's hear it from those stores who will agree to give change. Those who don't so declare will lose my custom and, I hope, the custom of lots of others.
Dave Watson
Oldham

 Last night in Sainsbury's I was standing behind a refugee family paying for the family shopping. A voucher was handed over and they were told that there would be no change. Now you say this is official policy. The poorest and most down-trodden section of society, the refugees and asylum seekers, who are already living a hand-to-mouth existence, are being exploited even more by the giants of the supermarket world. Is this the way that Sainsbury's can extricate itself from its precarious trading position? Why are these large firms being allowed to pocket extra profits from taxpayers' money at the same time that the living standards of refugees are driven down even further?
Darrall Cozens
Coventry
udarralc@sol.tilehill.ac.uk

 When Labour was elected in 1997 there were no real celebrations in the Fidler household. Oh yes, I was glad that the Tories had been booted out, but I had the feeling that there was something sinister about New Labour. The news that the company operating the refugee voucher scheme is highlighting the profiteering possibilities available is thoroughly repugnant, and for me the last straw. I will not be voting Labour any longer. Congratulations, Tony.
Andy Fidler
Harlech, Gwynedd
abfidler@hotmail.com

fields.headline: Four-letter wørds
fields.trailText: The Bank of England's decision to leave interest rates unchanged (Interest rates held after plea from industry, March 10), though widely expected, produced an instant reaction in the foreign exchange market: the pound dropped. Perhaps we should have more of the same.
fields.body:
The Bank of England's decision to leave interest rates unchanged (Interest rates held after plea from industry, March 10), though widely expected, produced an instant reaction in the foreign exchange market: the pound dropped. Perhaps we should have more of the same.
Walter Grey
London

 Francis Wheen (G2, March 8) says Pope asks "who breaks a butterfly upon a wheel?" Not so. In the Prologue To The Satires, Pope has his protagonist Dr Arbuthnot say those words, to try to hold Pope back. To which the poet replies: "Yet let me flap this bug with gilded wings ..." and proceeds to do so - rather in the manner of Wheen, don't you think?
Conrad Cork
Leicester
ConradCork@TadleyEwing.co.uk

 So we shall be using four letter words during the US election (Letters, March 10). Gush versus Bore?
Teddy Chapman
Bury St Edmunds, Suffolk.

 It was reassuring to see the concentration upon typographical accuracy in Just a regular guy (G2, March 6). Unfortunately, the Norwegian best-selling weekly magazine is Se og Hør (Look and Listen), not Se øg Hor which equates with "Look and Fornicate" - not quite the King Harald V family style.
David Parton
Eastbourne, E Sussex
nortrans@mistral.co.uk

 Ms Josephine Rowland says "my children will never be able to say these stones came from daddy's mines" (Fayed's £3.5m bill ends Rowland feud, March 10). I share her sentiment, for my kids are in exactly the same boat.
Jeff Williams
Hengoed, Mid Glam

 Re universal internet access (Letters, March 10): will anoraks be provided?
Glenn Hackney
Burnham on Crouch, Essex

fields.headline: Hull hailed
fields.trailText: Sadly your prejudice against municipal old Labour lets you down in your welcome piece on Hull (Welcome to Britain's capital of happiness, G2, March 9). The great Clive Sullivan was no "aldermanic" big-wig, but a flying Rugby League right-wing.
fields.body:
Sadly your prejudice against municipal old Labour lets you down in your welcome piece on Hull (Welcome to Britain's capital of happiness, G2, March 9). The great Clive Sullivan was no "aldermanic" big-wig, but a flying Rugby League right-wing. He "went north" from Cardiff at the age of 15 to escape the racism then pervasive in Welsh Rugby Union and, in a playing career spanning 21 years, won two Challenge Cup winners medals and captained Great Britain to victory in the 1972 World Cup. Indeed, he was the first black person to captain a British representative national team in any sport. The naming of Hull's main approach road after him following his death at the age of 42 in 1985 was the least the city could do to honour one of its finest adopted sons.
Terry Hopkinson
St John's College, Cambridge
th10007@hermes.cam.ac.uk

fields.headline: Mystery and romance
fields.standfirst:
The old formula keeps on selling

Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: The most striking literary characteristic of the "top 50" pick for World Book Day is its harmlessness. The list revolves around Catherine Cookson, Patricia Cornwell and Joanna Trollope, and finds space for Austen, Dickens and Hardy. It also features those well-known subversives and purveyors of smut Enid Blyton and Dick King-Smith - irony is not a favoured device of thriller and romantic writers - and suggests our fictional world is a pretty safe and predictable place. This is not, of course, a sample with any pretensions of objectivity. The agents of excluded authors, Jilly Cooper and my best-selling lord of Weston-super-Mare among them, need not lose too much sleep. None the less, as a random snapshot of literary preference it serves to challenge those who like to believe our culture is heading pell-mell towards some dumbed-down, illiterate future.
fields.body:
The most striking literary characteristic of the "top 50" pick for World Book Day is its harmlessness. The list revolves around Catherine Cookson, Patricia Cornwell and Joanna Trollope, and finds space for Austen, Dickens and Hardy. It also features those well-known subversives and purveyors of smut Enid Blyton and Dick King-Smith - irony is not a favoured device of thriller and romantic writers - and suggests our fictional world is a pretty safe and predictable place. This is not, of course, a sample with any pretensions of objectivity. The agents of excluded authors, Jilly Cooper and my best-selling lord of Weston-super-Mare among them, need not lose too much sleep. None the less, as a random snapshot of literary preference it serves to challenge those who like to believe our culture is heading pell-mell towards some dumbed-down, illiterate future.

If anything it is the stability of taste that is most striking. Ever since the mass of the population became literate, read ers have been inordinately fond of mystery and romance: the popularity of the likes of Dick Francis and Brian Jacques is nothing new. FR Leavis and his left-wing followers Raymond Williams and Richard Hoggart were perennially disappointed by popular taste - they wanted literature to be uplifting. Ordinary people just got on with their leisure reading, often acquiring not inconsiderable amounts of knowledge along the way. The historical consciousness of many comes from Brother Cadfael and Bernard Cornwell.

What is extraordinary about this sort of list is how much life there remains in the old dogs. Perhaps television adaptation helps keep certain "classic" authors in the public's mind; perhaps there is a generation by generation rediscovery of the greatness of Jane Austen and Charles Dickens and - this poll included young readers - Tolkien and even CS Lewis. Now there is a name for worriers about our moral condition to cherish.

fields.headline: Iraq's plight
fields.trailText: Peter Hain (Letters, March 9) says "Saddam plays politics with suffering". That is no doubt true, but it is also what the British and US governments are doing. If non-military sanctions were lifted entirely, Saddam would not be able to play politics with suffering.
fields.body:
Peter Hain (Letters, March 9) says "Saddam plays politics with suffering". That is no doubt true, but it is also what the British and US governments are doing. If non-military sanctions were lifted entirely, Saddam would not be able to play politics with suffering. And a massive programme of medical and other non-military aid to Iraq would at least show the people of Iraq that we have a higher moral standard than their own government's. It would also be likely to weaken the position of Saddam - something which a massive bombing campaign has clearly failed to do. Peter Hain would do better to listen to Denis Halliday and Hans von Sponeck - they have not resigned because they sympathise with Saddam, but because they have first-hand knowledge of what the sanctions are causing, and because they have consciences.
Tim Brown
Cambridge
timbrown@gn.apc.org

 There's a simple answer to Phil Woodford's question (Letters, March 10) about the difference in attitudes to sanctions on South Africa and Iraq. The South African people, through their organisations, called for them, while the Iraqi people, through the organisations we have done our best to undermine and destroy, are asking for them to be lifted.
Martin Cloake
London

fields.headline: Golden age for kid lit
fields.trailText: After the disgraceful and somewhat dated, "what is literature" debate that followed the Whitbread prize's Harry Potter versus Beowulf debacle, how refreshing it is to see that four out of the nation's top five favourite authors write for children (Dahl beats all competitors, March 10).
fields.body:
After the disgraceful and somewhat dated, "what is literature" debate that followed the Whitbread prize's Harry Potter versus Beowulf debacle, how refreshing it is to see that four out of the nation's top five favourite authors write for children (Dahl beats all competitors, March 10). Isn't it time we finally consigned the kid lit, poor cousin, low culture, slings and arrows, literary contempt back to the dark ages, from whence it came? A visit to any bookstore will confirm there has never been a better time for children's literature. We are living in the golden age. Let's at least take it seriously.
Dr Andrew Melrose
Brighton

webTitle: West alert to dangerous rites of spring in Kosovo

fields.headline: West alert to dangerous rites of spring in Kosovo
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Europe and the US injected a note of urgency yesterday into allied attempts to contain conflicts in Kosovo, saying ethnic tensions were flaring dangerously a year after Nato's bombing campaign.
fields.byline: Ian Black  in Brussels and  Richard Norton-Taylor
fields.body:
Europe and the US injected a note of urgency yesterday into allied attempts to contain conflicts in Kosovo, saying ethnic tensions were flaring dangerously a year after Nato's bombing campaign.

After talking to EU leaders in Brussels, the US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, said there was mounting concern about clashes between Serbs and ethnic Albanians in the Kosovan town of Mitrovice.

"The spring has not always been good for the Balkans," she said. "We have been consulting on ways to try to lower the temperature and press extremists not to pursue activities that complicate the situation."

General Wesley Clark, Nato's supreme commander, warned in London yesterday that Yugoslavia was "tightening the noose" on its reluctant federal partner, Montenegro.

Speaking at a conference organised by the Foreign Policy Centre, Gen Clark said it was getting harder and harder for K-For peacekeepers to police Kosovo. He said there was growing unrest in the south-eastern part of Serbia proper, where he feared that armed groups of men who claim to be protecting their families could provoke Serb over-reaction. He did not name them, but was referring to bands of ethnic Albanian paramilitaries.

Some observers see the current situation as an ominous rerun of events at this time last year - which led to war.

While in Brussels Mrs Albright was also seeing Javier Solana, the EU's foreign policy supremo, who wants reassure Washington that rapidly evolving EU defence plans will not undermine the western alliance.

She met Mr Solana in his Brussels headquarters, which this week took in the first European army officers ever involved in EU military planning. Earlier, Mr Solana had emphatically told the Guardian that the EU had no intention of creating a "European army".

"What we are doing is creating a new capability, but it is not going to be a European army," he insisted. "It's not going to fight wars, it's going to do crisis management.

"The Americans know what we are trying to do. It is not related to the construction of a European army, but we are trying to upgrade the armed forces of the European countries so they can act together.

"We are not talking about making war. We are talking about the establishment of peace and stability. We are not in the business of creating a European army, and we are not in the business of weakening Nato," he said.

Mr Solana, appointed last year to try to boost slow-moving efforts to give the EU greater clout on the world stage, maintained that military plans were moving "at the speed of light" compared with the introduction of Europe's single currency.

The EU decided at last December's Helsinki summit to establish a 50,000-to 60,000-strong rapid-reaction force capable of deploying within 60 days and sustaining itself for up to a year. This force, to be ready by 2003, would allow Europeans to take action outside Nato, where the US does not wish to be involved.

Mrs Albright also urged greater efforts from the EU to support Kosovo's UN administration and police force, which are facing mounting difficulties. But Romano Prodi, the European Commission president, rejected US charges that the EU was not opening its markets to Balkan countries, officials said. The issue is likely to be highlighted at a fundraising conference in Brussels later this month.

Mrs Albright refused to be drawn on questions about military planning for Kosovo, but Nato has already said it needs to boost troop strength in its K-For peacekeeping force - currently at 37,400 within the province and 44,000 overall to last summer's level of 49,000.

Washington is also pressing the EU for greater efforts to help the reformist Montenegrin president, Milo Djukanovic, who is under acute pressure from Belgrade to abandon any thought of leaving the Yugoslav federation.

webTitle: Tories question ministers on spies in Nato

fields.headline: Tories question ministers on spies in Nato
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: The controversy over a secret US report suggesting that Nato had a spy in its ranks in the early days of the Kosovo conflict entered the realm of British politics yesterday when the Conservatives demanded to know whether the government had a copy of the document.
fields.body:
The controversy over a secret US report suggesting that Nato had a spy in its ranks in the early days of the Kosovo conflict entered the realm of British politics yesterday when the Conservatives demanded to know whether the government had a copy of the document.

Francis Maude, shadow foreign secretary, is to table parliamentary questions next week asking ministers whether the US had told them about the report, which was drawn up last year by James McCarthy, a US air force general, now retired.

"The more information about these espionage allegations that comes to light, the more it strengthens our argument that we need a full inquiry about all aspects of the Kosovo conflict," Mr Maude, said yesterday.

"It would be utterly shameful if our government had been so blasé about Nato's operation in Kosovo that it allowed British military personnel to go into action with our enemies knowing their flight paths. We will be seeking reassurance that this was not the case".

General McCarthy carried out an internal Pentagon investigation into the vulnerability of Nato's "air tasking orders", giving details of allied bombing raids, including targets and reconnaissance flights.

He concluded that after the number of people who had access to the orders was reduced from 600 to 100 people, the effect on what the Serbs appeared to know was immediate.

Nato has insisted there is "no evidence" of a Nato spy passing on air tasking orders. However, a spokesman for the US air force said that while the report provided no conclusive evidence of a spy within Nato "there was a sense in Nato headquarters that the Serbs were pretty well informed about what we were doing".
