webTitle: The gene genie is out of the bottle

fields.headline: The gene genie is out of the bottle
fields.standfirst: There's a well-paid living to be made working  in 'life sciences'. Tim Radford looks at the implications of a revolution in biotechnology revolution
fields.trailText: Leap a little into the future. At the workshop down the road, tiny invisible employees are preparing to clean up a toxic landfill site. Right now, they live peacefully in petri dishes, or in freezer compartments, but some skilled supervisor is about to set the bacteria to work, by scattering them over poisoned soil, to convert toxic wastes into fresh air, water and harmless grit by fermenting them, as if making beer or compost.
fields.body:
Leap a little into the future. At the workshop down the road, tiny invisible employees are preparing to clean up a toxic landfill site. Right now, they live peacefully in petri dishes, or in freezer compartments, but some skilled supervisor is about to set the bacteria to work, by scattering them over poisoned soil, to convert toxic wastes into fresh air, water and harmless grit by fermenting them, as if making beer or compost.

At the clinic opposite, a patient with diabetes is checking in, to have new implants of genetically compatible islets of Langerhans (small groups of endocrine cells in the pancreas that secrete insulin). It will mean a night's discomfort: but no worries about an insulin crisis for six months or a year. A bit of tissue, grown in a bioreactor precisely for that sufferer, will take care of the problem.

Meanwhile, in the farmland at the end of the lane, there is a farmer harvesting plastic flowers. It's not quite as simple as that: actually, he is lifting tubers genetically reprogrammed to convert starches to polymers which can be shipped to factories to provide the feedstock for plastics which can be turned into bags, fibres and - yes, plastic tulips. No problem about unsold harvest: just compost the stuff and plough it back into the soil. Even the plastics are biodegradable, because scientists of the future will have seen to that.

This isn't fantasy: all these things are taking shape now. As Britain prepares for National Science Week - 10 days of 7,500 events which will celebrate science, engineering and technology from across the entire kingdom, kicking off on Friday - the managers of science have been looking ahead at the demand for jobs in the science sector.

The most dramatic strides are likely to be in biology, biochemistry and biotechnology: if it lives, it can be turned into product, and sold. If it lives, it could manufacture new jobs. Right now, the strange new world of biotechnology in Europe is a small, fragile one - but it is valued at more than £30bn.

In Britain alone, there are around 450 companies employing 45,000 people in shiny new industries based on clever things to be done with DNA. In a decade, there could be 100,000 new jobs, waiting for new recruits with a background in biology.

The horizons widen, say the experts. There are probably 800 small and medium enterprise biotech firms in Europe, probably 1,300 in the US, all of them armed with a little quiver of patented bright ideas that emerged from the laboratory and sped off in search of start-up capital. An industry that was almost unimaginable in the 70s is now growing at 20%, year on year, and threatens to falter for lack of skilled talent.

For the 17,000 or so young biologists now completing their first degree each year, things suddenly begin to look bright. But they don't look so bleak for the 75,000 or so other young people with decent science-based degrees, because the revolution in life sciences is going to need many of them: there is a powerful role for computing skills and mathematics in handling and decoding the 100,000 genes now being identified in the 3bn "letters" of DNA locked away in every human cell. The same revolutionary tides will break around medicine, dentistry, engineering, chemistry, veterinary sciences and agriculture.

"There are just so many fields that are going to be involved in biology. Everything from engineering individual people in theory, right the way through to the need for increased biological input to forensic science," says Dave Phoenix, reader in biochemistry at the university of central Lancashire, and editor of the Journal of Biological Education.

"Your average everyday person is going to be coming across biology-based issues more and more. So you are going to have more and more people being educated to understand them but also more people getting educated to become involved in the generation of future ideas."

Alan Malcolm, chief executive of the Institute of Biology, agrees. "It's the subject of the 21st century, without any doubt whatsoever. The discipline has the ability to solve many of the problems that technology has brought us in the 20th century.

"So we have alternatives to chemical fertiliser, alternatives to fossil fuel, the further development of medicines. All these things imply biology, whether it is genetics, pharmaceuticals, the environment, agriculture..."

Britain's biggest industry is food production, he points out. It is three times bigger than pharmaceuticals, three times the size of motorcar production. "The market biology's in is either guaranteed to stay the same, such as food, or guaranteed to increase as we look at pharmaceutical intervention in the diseases of the 21st century, such as cancer, heart disease and diseases of ageing."

Much of the pharmaceutical intervention is going to grow out of a new way of understanding both health and disease. The hereditary, single-gene disorder diseases such as Huntington's chorea, or Duchenne muscular dystrophy, are already being pursued by small research firms and big academic laboratories.

But in the near future, there will be a new understanding of why some people are likely to suffer heart disease, why others are more at risk of cancer, or late onset diabetes, and all of this will be based on a new understanding of the human genome, the string of genes in the 23 chromosomes that make each human unique, and the genomes of old human enemies such as the tuberculosis bacillus, the malaria parasite, or the heliobacter that causes stomach ulcers.

According to the UK Bioindustry Association, some are working in what would once have been science-fiction fields such as bioremediation, the use of genetically selected plants or micro-organisms to restore terrain blighted by industry. But many of the new teams of academically qualified entrepreneurs have focused on human health. There's a killing to be made in saving people from death.

The biotechnology revolution will change the future more profoundly even than the information technology revolution, according to John Sime, the Bioindustry Association's chief executive officer.

"To find a smarter way to buy a book is one thing, but to find a smarter way to cure Alzheimer's or Parkinson's is an achievement of an altogether different order," he says.

"We are on the brink of that. We are making, now, discoveries in biology which when they are turned into products, will meet a huge number of unmet needs. The stuff that is coming out of the human genome project, by itself, is over the next 20 years or so, going to change the way we all live our lives."

Sure, he says, the Americans are making the running. "But we have the strength in the science base here, we have the commercialisation potential, we have the clinical trials capability, we have everything we need here to turn the things being found into serious therapies which will earn serious money for the UK and provide a lot of very interesting jobs and im prove the health and welfare of mankind enormously.

"All of that should make for a very interesting career prospect for youngsters. My guess is that before very long we will see a biotech person as well known and probably nearly as rich as Bill Gates."

He knows the public is worried about GM crops. He doesn't think people are quite so worried about long term risks to human health, though there are questions to be answered about the long-term effect on the countryside and the environment. But the biotechnology revolution could bring benefits to the countryside as well. And GM crops could certainly have benefits for human health.

"The potential in those areas is going to be huge. We are on the brink of - perhaps within 10 years - being able to produce crops with considerably altered nutritional value. I am sure we are going to produce foods which make a contribution to positive health care, things like grains that deliver vitamins and nutrients that are missing from ordinary foods," he says.

"There will be all sorts of products on the marketplace to achieve and maintain good health. Some of those will be prescription only, some will be over the counter and some you will buy in your supermarket. All of them will come from biotechnology."

webTitle: Why I chose a genetically modified career in research

fields.headline: Why I chose a genetically modified career in research
fields.standfirst: Dr Claire Cockcroft reports on the ups and downs of her life as a molecular biologist
fields.trailText: It was a tough decision. Did I follow my musical aspirations or head for a career in science where there appeared to be more opportunities and job stability? I opted for the best of both worlds, with music playing second fiddle to a stimulating career in biotechnology - music definitely refreshes the mind after a frustrating day in the lab.
fields.body:
It was a tough decision. Did I follow my musical aspirations or head for a career in science where there appeared to be more opportunities and job stability? I opted for the best of both worlds, with music playing second fiddle to a stimulating career in biotechnology - music definitely refreshes the mind after a frustrating day in the lab.

However, while there are a wealth of opportunities and diverse career paths out there for scientists, job instability and a succession of temporary contracts are the reality of academic research.

My first taste of "real" research came during the fourth year of my biochemistry degree at Oxford. The project was based at the Max Planck Institute in Marburg, Germany, and was a far cry from the previous years' practical classes.

I looked at enzymes, the proteins catalysing the chemistry of life, isolated from life-forms popularly known as extremeophiles because they live in some of the most inhospitable parts of the planet such as hot, sulphurous springs.

These peculiar proteins function under an astonishing range of temperatures and in chemical conditions that would normally destroy most proteins and render them useless. It was an exciting start, but maybe not the most realistic insight into research as the results flowed fast and furious and in three months I didn't get the chance to become disheartened from the frustrations of repeated experimental failure.

I did realise that a high level of self-motivation, an inquisitive mind and good investigative skills would be central to success in science. Contributing good results to the group was exciting and rewarding; I was convinced that a PhD was for me.

It was the enthusiastic lecturing of Professors Chris Leaver and Hugh Dickinson that led me to consider an alternative avenue of research: the controversial field of plant genetic engineering.

I saw an enormous potential for the power of plant biotechnology and wanted to be part of it. Crops could be genetically modified to grow on soils that would normally be too salty or acidic, a problem for much of the developing world, and plants were being engineered to take up and break down harmful contaminants from the environment, a process called phytoremediation.

It was the great diversity of research interests, close collaborations with industry and first-rate facilities that attracted me to the Institute of Biotechnology in Cambridge. Current projects range from explosive-eating plants, which have the potential to be used in clean-up operations world-wide, to enzyme engineering.

In October 1994 I joined Dr Jim Murray's group as a PhD student. We are attempting to understand how plant growth rate is controlled at the molecular level by looking at genes regulating cell division.

We showed that plant growth rate can be increased by optimising the levels of naturally occurring plant regulatory proteins. The plants are more competitive and reach maturity more quickly but other characteristics are not disturbed. This could eventually lead to reduced agrochemical inputs due to improved competitiveness of crops over weeds.

Life as a researcher is pretty precarious and has its ups and downs. The results are often baffling and it is easy to get demoralised; positions are temporary and the grant application procedure rears its head every few years. But there are numerous opportunities to work abroad in some of the best research institutions: the world is your oyster.

There's also the stereotypical image of the boffin in a white lab coat to contend with. Scientists are perceived to be untrustworthy, anti-social and to lack the ability to communicate their research to the public. Working in such a topical area, it is important to be prepared to explain what you do and the wider implications of it in society.

To help resolve this image crisis, I am giving a lecture for science week in Cambridge about the merits of the plant kingdom - from the early uses of plants in medicines to a new agricultural age which could see plants becoming the factories of the future.

The road of research is not paved with gold, but it is exciting, interesting, challenging and highly rewarding.

 Dr Claire Cockcroft is at the Institute of Biotechnology in Cambridge.

It was an exciting start, but maybe not the most realistic insight into research as the results flowed fast and furious and in three months I didn't get the chance to become disheartened from the frustrations of repeated experimental failure. I did realise that a high level of self-motivation, an inquisitive mind and good investigative skills would be central to success in science. Contributing good results to the group was exciting and rewarding; I was convinced that a PhD was for me. It was the enthusiastic lecturing of Professors Chris Leaver and Hugh Dickinson that led me to consider an alternative avenue of research: the controversial field of plant genetic engineering. I saw an enormous potential for the power of plant biotechnology and wanted to be part of it. Crops could be genetically modified to grow on soils that would normally be too salty or acidic, a problem for much of the developing world, and plants were being engineered to take up and break down harmful contaminants from the environment, a process called phytoremediation. It was the great diversity of research interests, close collaborations with industry and first-rate facilities that attracted me to the Institute of Biotechnology in Cambridge. Current projects range from explosive-eating plants, which have the potential to be used in clean-up operations world-wide, to enzyme engineering. In October 1994 I joined Dr Jim Murray's group as a PhD student. We are attempting to understand how plant growth rate is controlled at the molecular level by looking at genes regulating cell division. We showed that plant growth rate can be increased by optimising the levels of naturally occurring plant regulatory proteins. The plants are more competitive and reach maturity more quickly but other characteristics are not disturbed. This could eventually lead to reduced agrochemical inputs due to improved competitiveness of crops over weeds. Life as a researcher is pretty precarious and has its ups and downs. The results are often baffling and it is easy to get demoralised; positions are temporary and the grant application procedure rears its head every few years. But there are numerous opportunities to work abroad in some of the best research institutions: the world is your oyster. There's also the stereotypical image of the boffin in a white lab coat to contend with. Scientists are perceived to be untrustworthy, anti-social and to lack the ability to communicate their research to the public. Working in such a topical area, it is important to be prepared to explain what you do and the wider implications of it in society. To help resolve this image crisis, I am giving a lecture for science week in Cambridge about the merits of the plant kingdom - from the early uses of plants in medicines to a new agricultural age which could see plants becoming the factories of the future. The road of research is not paved with gold, but it is exciting, interesting, challenging and highly rewarding.  Dr Claire Cockcroft is at the Institute of Biotechnology in Cambridge.

fields.headline: Capital bet for a venture
fields.standfirst: There's a tax effective way to break into the techno boom, reports Patrick Sherwen
fields.trailText: One area of investment that seems to have been overlooked by the techno-vultures so far is the venture capital trust (VCT). But, says Jason Hollands, an adviser at Best Investment, investors ignore VCTs to their cost.
fields.body:
One area of investment that seems to have been overlooked by the techno-vultures so far is the venture capital trust (VCT). But, says Jason Hollands, an adviser at Best Investment, investors ignore VCTs to their cost.

The VCT was launched in 1995 by Kenneth Clarke, then chancellor of the exchequer. The idea was to encourage funding of new companies by offering these tax incentives for long term investment:

 Investors receive 20% pure income tax relief on subscription to a trust;

 Any returns made are free of tax provided the shares are held for at least five years;

 Capital gains tax (CGT) can be deferred at the investor's marginal rate if gains made elsewhere are rolled over into a VCT.

Mr Hollands says this makes them a suitable vehicle for the growing band of direct investors who have built up CGT liability in excess of their £7,100 annual allowance from their investments over the last tax year and now want to defer it before the new financial year starts in April.

Deferral allows some of the pain to be absorbed by spreading the liability over the investor's allowance in future years.

There is a compelling investment argument for VCTs too. Their focus on start-up companies means that at the moment they tend to have a strong technology focus. This will make them attractive to many in itself. On top of that, VCTs invest primarily in unquoted companies or stocks on the Alternative Investment Market (Aim) so investors get in at the pre-flotation stage and avoid the risk attached to some of the more optimistic valuations that abound in the main market.

VCTS are perceived as a high risk investment, but Mr Hollands says: "The risk of VCTs is often overstated because the tax benefits mean you are only paying 40p for a quid's worth of shares so the performance only has to be all right to do well."

Against that is the structural inflexibility of VCTs. If the investor is not happy with the performance of the trust in the first five years pulling out means sacrificing the tax benefits. It is also hard to sell VCT shares because the secondary market is so illiquid. "The best way to get out of a VCT is at the wind-up," says Mr Hollands, and that usually means a seven year wait.

For those drawn to VCTs, there are some interesting funds on the market at the moment and a few more on the horizon. One likely to grab investors' attention is the e-Technology VCT to be launched sometime soon by Pinder Fry Benjamin. Few details are available but the presence of David Svenson, the former Microsoft chairman, on the board will appeal to techno-freaks.

Oxford Technology 2 has just opened for subscription and is looking for capital of £6m and Quester VCT 3, another fund with a tech focus has just extended its offer period to take in a further £18m on top of the £30m already in.

Here is a list of the other VCTs still taking in new money, their investment strategies and the degree to which they are subscribed:

 Aim VCT 'C' - 80% Aim and pre-Aim, 20% fixed interest - 20%.

 Baronsmead VCT 2 - 25% Aim, 55% unquoted, 20% fixed interest - 20%.

 BWD Aim VCT- 75% Aim and pre-Aim, 25% BWD equity unit trusts - 15%.

 Downing Classic VCT 2 - 25% start-ups, 25% developing, 50% mature (inc Aim) - 40%.

 Murray VCT 4 - 80% unquoted, 20% fixed interest - 17.1%

 Pennine Downing Ethical VCT - 40% Aim, 40% unquoted, 20% fixed interest - 74%

 ProVen VCT - 75% unquoted, 25% fixed interest - 3.8%.

 Singer & Friedlander Aim VCT 2 - 75% Aim, 25% fixed interest - 0%.

A free fact sheet on VCTs is available to Jobs & Money readers from Best Investment. Call 0870-5800222 for a copy.

fields.headline: Cash and carry ends
fields.standfirst: Act fast to make the  most of a tax break for pensions before it goes, writes Patrick Collinson
fields.trailText: Want a gift of thousands of pounds from the taxman? Then act now to use up pension tax reliefs before the axe comes down on them next year.
fields.body:
Want a gift of thousands of pounds from the taxman? Then act now to use up pension tax reliefs before the axe comes down on them next year.

Tax reliefs on pensions are about as generous as the Inland Revenue gets. The taxman hands back all the income tax you have paid if you put your money into a pension. So it costs a lower rate, 23%, taxpayer, only 77p to put £1 into a pension. If you are a higher rate, 40%, taxpayer, it costs just 60p to put £1 into a pension.

Where the tax reliefs become even more generous is that you can use up personal pension tax reliefs from previous tax years if you did not take advantage of them then. For example, say you are 38 years old and earn £40,000 a year. At this age, the Inland Revenue lets you put 20% of your salary into a personal pension with full tax relief, ie: £8,000. If you have been paying only £4,000 for the last six years, you have the potential to enjoy tax relief on £24,000 (six times £4,000).

But the government has decided that "carry forward" tax relief is over-generous and is scrapping it from April 5, 2001.

Scottish Life pensions guru Alastair Buchanan says: "The government said it would cancel it last autumn and despite protests, it confirmed that line recently to 'simplify matters'."

But with "carry back" - carry forward's close relation which will remain - Mr Buchanan calculates that pension buyers can go back as far as the 1992-93 tax year provided they act before April 5. He warns that you can count earnings only from employment but purchasers could use lump sums for the actual payment. "It is best suited for those with highly variable earnings."

The sort of professions he has in mind covers everything from actors to zoo owners. "Using carry forward can help gain higher rate tax relief in a good year, whereas you might only have had basic rate relief if you had bought the pension in the year you earned the money," he adds.

"You should consider maximising the use of 'carry forward' while you still can," says Frank Williamson, tax adviser at accountants Pannell Kerr Forster (PKF). "It will be a bitter pill to swallow if someone leaves it to the last possible minute, only then to find out that it is not possible to fully maximise the opportunity."

Carry forward is most useful to people who have had variable earnings and only applies to those who have personal pensions, not company pensions. PKF gives the example of one client, Sarah, 42, who owns her own mobile phone shop.

In the first year of her business, Sarah invested a modest amount into her personal pension. But with the boom in mobile phones, profits have risen and she can now "catch up" on the earlier years. She earned £48,000 in 1999 and used carry forward to catch up on £19,839 of contributions. The benefit to her was tax relief at the top rate worth £7,827.65.

Although there is another year before carry forward is abolished, there is an incentive to act before April 5 this year for lower rate tax payers. This is because the lower rate of tax falls to 22% from 23% on April 6, so the amount of tax you can claim back after that date will be smaller.

Legal & General says that if you pay in a £5,000 net contribution by April 5 it will be worth £6,495 with the 23% tax relief added in, but on April 6 it would be worth £6,410.

L&G's pension expert, Andy Agar, says that anyone wanting to use carry forward should speak to their financial adviser who will give you a single premium personal pension application form to make the payment. You also have to fill in Inland Revenue form PP42. Alternatively, you can contact L&G directly to obtain the forms.

One pensions adviser from Wolverhampton-based Torquil Clark warns that the Budget may contain a bombshell far bigger than the loss of carry forward relief. Every year there is speculation that the chancellor could remove the higher rate tax relief on pensions so that high income earners can obtain relief only at the lower rate band.

"There is a much stronger possibility that it might happen this year than there ever has been in the past," says Thomas McPhail of Torquil Clark. The advice is that if you haven't used up your full pension tax reliefs, do so quickly. The Budget is on March 21, so you'd better get your skates on.

webTitle: It could be wise to spread your bets

fields.headline: It could be wise to spread your bets
fields.standfirst: Funds tracking the FTSE 100 may be courting danger, say Patrick Collinson and Patrick Sherwen
fields.trailText: A warning bell rang for investors in highly-popular FTSE 100 tracker funds after hi-tech companies with sky-high market valuations elbowed some of the grandest names of British industry out of the index.
fields.body:
A warning bell rang for investors in highly-popular FTSE 100 tracker funds after hi-tech companies with sky-high market valuations elbowed some of the grandest names of British industry out of the index.

We all know Whitbread pubs. Lots of us drink Newcastle Brown Ale, brewed by Scottish & Newcastle, or Beefeater gin, Tia Maria or Courvoisier, all produced by Allied Domecq. But this week the mandarins who control the make-up of the FTSE 100 shares index called time on these companies and unceremoniously ejected them from the elite group of blue-chip companies that make up the index.

Replacing them are a host of companies few will have heard of, let alone bought their products. In comes Baltimore Technologies, which is now worth around £4.5bn even though it has no recorded profits and and issues no dividends. Also coming in are two biotechnology companies, Nycomed Amersham and Celltech.

The more techno-aware of us will probably have heard of two other new entrants, internet provider Freeserve and hand-held computer maker Psion. The outgoing companies had profits last year of around £2.1bn, the incoming stocks earned just £179m.

But for an investor in a FTSE 100 tracker fund, it now means that their investment is very heavily geared towards the technology bubble that has inflated the stock market in recent months. It's not just that the "old economy" stocks been pushed out. One of the existing FTSE 100 stocks, mobile phone company Vodafone, has grown so massively after its £107bn takeover of Germany's Mannesman that it alone now makes up 15% of the index. Direct Line, Barclays, Credit Suisse, Alliance & Leicester plus many others have persuaded thousands of investors to buy FTSE 100 tracker funds, but some financial advisers now warn that they may have unwittingly bought into high-risk, hi-tech funds.

Jason Hollands of Best Investments says: "The changes to the FTSE 100 see the exit of several profitable "old economy" stocks and their replacement by speculative high-technology businesses.

"While these new FTSE 100 companies are undoubtedly exciting businesses they also carry considerable risks and further exasperate the concentration of the FTSE 100 around TMT themes (technology, media, telecommunciations).

"Given the concentration of the FTSE 100 and the stretched valuations being placed on technology and telecom stocks we believe that index tracker funds - many of which receive the Government's Cat mark endorsement - can no longer be considered as low-risk investments."

Others are advising that in vestors consider switching to all-share trackers, which follow the fortunes of the 800 companies that make up the All-share index, and will therefore continue to include a broad spread of British companies across different sectors.

A spokesman for Virgin Direct, which runs one of the biggest all-share trackers, says: "We deliberately chose to offer an all-share fund rather than a 100-only fund because it gives investors broader diversification. In an all-share tracker, if the technology stocks blow out, then the out-of-favour stocks that are resting further down the market will then probably come through."

Giant investment manager Fidelity has also issued a warning this week about the new make-up of the FTSE 100. Investment strategist John Ross says the index is now likely to be more volatile and will pay out lower dividends.

"The companies that are joining the index tend not to make a profit and do not pay a dividend, unlike those leaving the index. Therefore the price earnings ratio for the FTSE 100 will rise and the dividend yield will fall," he says.

webTitle: It's true! Hector wants to hear your problems

fields.headline: It's true! Hector wants to hear your problems
fields.standfirst: The Revenue is launching an inquiry into its investigators to find if they are as dogged as people think, says David Brodie
fields.trailText: What is the difference between a tax investigator and a rottweiler? A rottweiler will eventually let go! This gag reflects our universal dread of tax investigations and stories that inspectors do not give up on their pound of flesh. But the taxman can't be all that bad, since he is now inviting our comments on how investigations are conducted.
fields.body:
What is the difference between a tax investigator and a rottweiler? A rottweiler will eventually let go! This gag reflects our universal dread of tax investigations and stories that inspectors do not give up on their pound of flesh. But the taxman can't be all that bad, since he is now inviting our comments on how investigations are conducted.

Two years after the first self-assessment deadline, the Revenue has launched a formal study of tax investigations - now known as "inquiries" - "to highlight areas which are working well and where improvements could be made". Anyone who has faced an inquiry into their tax return is encouraged to visit the Revenue's website, www.inlandrevenue.gov.uk/questionnaire/q4.htm and complete an on-line questionnaire.

Responses will be analysed jointly by the Revenue and Ann Hansford of Bristol Business School, commissioned by the Chartered Institute of Taxation, and their findings will be announced in the winter with a view to possible changes in next year's Budget.

Although almost half a million taxpayers have now faced self-assessment inquiries, Dr Hansford says that only a dozen individual taxpayers have responded to the questionnaire so far and she urges more to come forward before the March 24 closing date. Given the small numbers involved, your response may have considerable impact and you may remain anonymous.

There was widespread unease when the new-style inquiries were introduced with the advent of self assessment in 1996/97. In particular, there were fears about the introduction of "random inquiries", allowing the taxman to select any tax return for in-depth investigation, and that we would see a tough US-style audit regime.

The Revenue responded that inquiries would be conducted in a "neutral" fashion, with no presumption of guilt. Some statutory safeguards were introduced, including your right to ask independent appeal commissioners to order closure of an inquiry if the inspector is dragging it out. And the Revenue has a Code of Practice, given to every taxpayer facing an inquiry, which explains how the investigation should be conducted and the safeguards available, including the promise to be courteous and fair.

Despite all this, there have been many complaints. Taxpayers say that they feel "presumed guilty until proven innocent", that letters received from the Revenue are intimidating or difficult to understand, and that they are asked for information that is difficult to produce.

So the current review offers everyone a chance to air their grievances, or to comment positively if they felt that the enquiry went well. Much of the questionnaire is fairly simple - you are asked to respond "yes" or "no" to questions like: "Did you understand the opening letter?" and: "Did you understand how the final tax liability was calculated?"

Even more interesting are questions like: "Did you feel that you had to go to an interview?", since taxpayers often feel compelled to attend a meeting even though the Code of Practice says there is no such obligation. There are also large boxes where you can describe your personal experience and opinions in some detail.

Past experience suggests that the Revenue will be fairly candid in reporting on the responses to this questionnaire, and this should be ensured by the involvement of Bristol Business School. So it is certainly worth giving your view.

If you do not have access to the internet, ask for a paper questionnaire from Philippa Staples at Compliance Division (Technical), Apsley House, Wellington Road North, Stockport SK4 1EZ or telephone her on 0161-475-2702.

Reports this week that 20,000 penalty notices were wrongly sent to taxpayers who actually filed their tax returns on time are being examined by the Revenue. A spokeswoman says that the investigation is not complete, but current indications are that the figure was lower and that it was due to human error rather than a computer bug. If you think you have received an incorrect penalty notice, telephone your tax office which should cancel any charge erroneously made.

 David Brodie is director of TaxAid, the charity which provides free tax advice to people who cannot afford professional fees. Phone 0171-624-3768 between 10 am and 12 noon, Mondays to Thursdays.

fields.headline: Pick of the piggy banks
fields.standfirst: Jessica McCallin offers a guide to the most interesting savings accounts for young people
fields.trailText: One key personal finance lesson is to shop around for the best deals. And with interest rates of 6.95% gross paid twice yearly and a minimum deposit of £1, Nationwide's Smart 2 Save account offers children the best deal on an instant-access account.
fields.body:
One key personal finance lesson is to shop around for the best deals. And with interest rates of 6.95% gross paid twice yearly and a minimum deposit of £1, Nationwide's Smart 2 Save account offers children the best deal on an instant-access account.

Coventry Building Society's Interest Zone, with a rate of 6.7% gross, follows close behind, but children can only get access to their money once they are seven years old.

Among the lesser known building societies Saffron Walden tops the list. The society offers children a 6.85% rate of interest before tax and instant access to their funds on a £1 minimum deposit.

Lambeth Building Society's Cat's Whiskers childrens account offers a slightly better rate of 6.90%, but requires a minimum deposit of £100 - a sum most children are not likely to have at hand. However, other accounts pay higher rates based on higher minimum deposits. On a minimum of £500, Abbey National will pay 7%, but stop your child getting at the money for four years. To get 7.15% from Dumfermline Building Society they need a minimum deposit of £500 and must wait three years.

Lying somewhere between is the Ipswich Building Society's Young Savers Club account. It pays 7% with instant access, but requires a minimum deposit of £500.

In contrast to these rates, National Savings' rates appear pathetic. Its Children's Bond, for example, pays only 5.65% and has a five-year notice period. But the interest is tax-free and is useful for parents giving money.

There is nothing wrong with long notice periods, not to stash extra bits of pocket money away, but to build up a sizeable amount of money for big purchases in the future. And if the child is happy to wait for access to the money there are plenty of far more profitable options. ISAs are an obvious choice. Many of the cash ones pay over 7% tax-free, and if you open a stocks and shares one the returns can be much higher.

The benefit of an ISA is that money can be taken out of the account within the tax year. This can come in handy if the latest children's fads and fashions dictate that your child must have that exorbitantly priced pair of trainers. Just remember that you can't put the money back, so they will be losing out on interest.

Unit or investment trusts are another alternative. Some have cut minimum monthy payments - typically £50 to £100 and, therefore, prohibitive for children - to much more kid-friendly sums of £10 or £25 a month. M&G has cut its minimum to £10 a month. Invesco GT Rupert Children's Fund accepts a minimum payment of £20 a month. And Henderson's recently-launched Jump plan, aimed at young investors, has cut its minimum to £25, paid each month or every three months.

webTitle: Financial education gap of rich and poor

fields.headline: Financial education gap of rich and poor
fields.standfirst:
Youngsters from underprivileged families can have a lifelong handicap in dealing with their finances, finds Patrick Collinson

www.fsa.gov.uk
www.pfeg.org.uk
www.youngmoney.co.uk
fields.trailText: Children are to learn about personal finance at school as part of the national curriculum from September, in a bid to close the "huge gaps" in financial skills between youngsters from rich and poor families.
fields.body:
Children are to learn about personal finance at school as part of the national curriculum from September, in a bid to close the "huge gaps" in financial skills between youngsters from rich and poor families.

Research released by the Financial Services Authority this week revealed that while one in six children from poor families has a savings account, they are rarely used and hold tiny sums of money. In contrast, eight out of 10 children from affluent areas have savings accounts which they use regularly, and by the age of seven they have an understanding of cheques, credit cards and banks which far outstrips that of infants from poor areas.

Educators believe that this gap stays with children through to adulthood, leaving them with a permanent handicap in dealing with financial institutions, services and products.

To challenge the huge gaps in children's understanding of finance, the FSA is working with the department for education and employment on developing personal finance guidelines for school lessons beginning in September.

This week it unveiled Mega Money: giant three-dimensional coins designed to support teachers' numeracy work in primary classrooms. FSA chairman Howard Davies says: "We see basic numeracy skills as being the key to children managing their personal finances when they are older.

"Personal finance education will be included in the national curriculum from this September, so we must ensure that teachers are confident they will be given the full support and guidance they need."

In the spring, the FSA will make available to teachers a website with a special section devoted to assisting personal finance lessons. The research on children's understanding of money issues, carried out by Loughborough University's Centre for Research in Social Policy, was presented to 200 primary school teachers at the FSA's first conference on financial education earlier this week.

Researchers interviewed children from two primary schools in the Midlands; one in a deprived area, one in an affluent area. They identified significant gaps between the two, with children from low income households having little or no knowledge of financial institutions.

They see their parents operating a cash-based lifestyle and are aware of the careful budgeting employed by parents to pay the bills. On the other hand, children from high-income households have little experience of budgeting and very limited knowledge of household bills.

One seven-year-old from a poorer area said: "There's the gas card from the shop, you buy that and put it in this little slot... if you don't you can't watch television and can't have any food 'cause the cooker is off."

Dr Julia Loumidis of Loughborough University says: "The extent of differences between the experiences of children from low and high income households is very worrying.

"Children growing up in low income households are being denied the opportunity to acquire the financial skills that children in higher-income households take for granted."

The way that personal finance will be taught in schools has yet to be fully decided, but there are fears that children could be bombarded with sales literature from financial services companies.

Virgin Direct runs a website for children called youngmoney.co.uk, which aims to educate and inform in a fun way, using quizzes and online competitions to keep young net users interested.

It makes no attempt to sell Virgin Direct's financial products, but other companies may be less reticent. In particular, the selection of material and the definitions used could be slanted to suit a company's set of products.

For example, Virgin Direct gives a definition of mortgage endowments which highlights the drawbacks: "They are often unclear how much you are having to pay in charges and the plans are often very rigid."

Virgin doesn't sell endowments and can therefore tell children about the drawbacks; companies which sell them are unlikely to inform youngsters in the same way.

The Personal Finance Education Group, made up of a wide range of financial institutions in partnership with the DfEE, has produced guidelines about what will be expected in money lessons.

Children aged 5-7 will learn about what money is, how to recognise coins and notes, risks such as losing it or having it stolen, and how to keep money safe.

By the time they hit 14-16 the guidelines suggest they will have to understand a wide range of products such as bank accounts, mortgages, insurance, pensions and shares.

They will also have to understand complex issues such as the pros and cons of a company being mutual or owned by shareholders.

fields.headline: Hidden cost of legacy
fields.standfirst: The Wallbanks inherited a farm - and a £100,000 bill for repairs to a church, reports Richard Colbey
fields.trailText: When Andrew and Gail Wallbank inherited Glebe Farm and its large old farmhouse, in the Warwickshire village of Aston Cantlow, from Gail's father, they were prepared for substantial repair bills. However, they did expect those repairs to be restricted to their own land.
fields.body:
When Andrew and Gail Wallbank inherited Glebe Farm and its large old farmhouse, in the Warwickshire village of Aston Cantlow, from Gail's father, they were prepared for substantial repair bills. However, they did expect those repairs to be restricted to their own land.

It came as something of a shock then when the local parish church presented them with a bill for nearly £100,000 for work done on the part of the church where the altar and the choir is contained, known as the chancel.

By accepting their inheritance the Wallbanks had fallen into a trap set for purchasers of old vicarages, rectories and similar properties by the Chancel Repairs Act 1932, and had become lay rectors. This entitles them to the chief seat in the chancel but also requires them to bear the cost of repairing it. In many villages this liability has been annulled, by the church itself taking over the responsibility for repairs.

However, the right to claim from the lay rector is not lost until this has happened "since time immemorial". Theoretically this means 1189, the date by which it was fixed by the 1275 Statute of Westminster. On the rare occasions when the concept is considered by the courts a period of a hundred years usually suffices.

However, this rather arcane concession is of little help to the Wallbanks as the church produced accounts to show that a former owner of their property paid for repairs as recently as 1968.

The Wallbanks' best hope of avoiding liability appears to be the European Convention on Human Rights. They have argued that to force them to pay in these circumstances would be in breach of their right to not to be arbitrarily deprived of property or possessions. Mr Justice Ferris, who has heard the case in the High Court, reserved his decision to consider this aspect of the case.

It may, however, be that the Wallbanks will not persuade him that something that was done in accordance with law, however obscure, is arbitrary. The Wallbanks live in Wales and let the property out. The only way they could raise money for the repairs is by selling the property, but they are unlikely to find a buyer willing to take on the liability.

Few conveyancing solicitors, let alone property buyers, appreciate the significance of this legislation. However, the Act potentially extends to anyone who has a house within a parish. This can also lead to a duty to repair a church aisle which was built for the benefit of former owners of the house. It is only liability for the main structure of a church that cannot fall on property owning parishioners.

Anyone buying a country property, particularly a substantial one, would be well advised to ensure that enquiries are made of the vendor that there is no danger of being caught by this trap.

If the church succeeds against the Wallbanks it may well become much more rigorous in enforcing previously disregarded rights against "lay rectors".

 Richard Colbey is a barrister

webTitle: Mixed messages but future looks bright

fields.headline: Mixed messages but future looks bright
fields.standfirst: Government plans to build thousands of new houses will have only a negligible effect on demand. Elizabeth Langton reports
fields.trailText: Government plans to ease the housing crisis in the south-east with the construction of 215,000 new homes will do little to take the heat out of the market, according to Britain's biggest lender, the Halifax.
fields.body:
Government plans to ease the housing crisis in the south-east with the construction of 215,000 new homes will do little to take the heat out of the market, according to Britain's biggest lender, the Halifax.

Martin Ellis, Halifax group economist, says increasing the supply of property will, "relieve some of the upward pressure and prices won't rise quite so sharply". But because the building programme announced by the deputy prime minister is spread out over five years, it won't make a huge difference, he says.

With spring just around the corner, thousands of people will be questioning whether now is the right time to move house or whether they should hold tight and watch the market closely during the next few months.

Those taking the pulse of the property market are split over the state of its health. According to the Nationwide, consumer confidence is high and the housing market is buoyant - the building society's figures show house prices rose by 2.2% in February. The Halifax, on the other hand, says the market is slowing and house prices fell by 0.9% in February.

Whatever the ups and downs, housing market experts can think of few reasons why those who want to move should hold back. First-time buyers should grab the chance and, provided they can afford it, buy now, says Ray Boulger, of mortgage brokers John Charcol.

But as new mortgage lending rose by £3.64bn in December, the biggest rise in more than 10 years, debt counsellors sounded a note of caution. Last week the National Association of Citizens Advice Bureaux (Nacab) announced that demand for help with personal debt had risen dramatically. It has seen widespread evidence that consumers are being encouraged to borrow more than they can afford.

As some buyers rush to take out new loans, others are still struggling with the fall-out from the last recession, says Nacab. Many of those who were plunged into negative equity and lost their homes in the early 90s still owe lenders tens of thousands of pounds, a spokeswoman said.

Recent reports suggest that two lending practices, commonplace during the 80s boom, have returned to the market. The 100% mortgage is with us again, as are the extraordinary salary multiples that some lenders are prepared to use to calculate loans.

Mr Boulger says there are some very good 100% mortgages around, as well as some very bad products. First-time buyers should look carefully at what's on offer, "but if they can afford the mortgage they are better off buying now than risk missing out by waiting to see what the market does". He adds that those currently renting may be paying significantly more to their landlord than they would for a mortgage.

There is no doubt that last year was a good one for homeowners. House prices rose by 15% nationally and by 23% in greater London, according to official figures from the land registry. The booming market meant that the 1999 leap was the highest average year-on-year rise since 1996.

The price rises were not restricted to the south-east. In the south-west prices rose by 17.26%, taking the average price of a house from £79,747 to £93,508. In the east midlands, values increased by 13.5% from £62,593 to £70,826. In the north, rises were less dramatic. The average price rose by 5.24% from £58,617 to £61,689.

Even in London, there are still bargains to be had. In Brent, the constituency of would-be London mayor Ken Livingstone, first-time buyers can buy a one-bedroom flat within walking distance of Kensal Green tube station for £88,950 through Westways estate agent. In nearby Willesden, a two-bedroom flat can be had for £120,000 through Cameron Stiff &Co.

In trendy Camden, a stone's throw from Labour mayoral candidate Frank Dobson's patch, a two-double-bedroom maisonette on the first and second floors of a local authority owned block is on the market for £159,950 through local agent Hotblack Desiato.

Gone are the days when buying and selling was looked upon as a means to get rich quick. Today's buyers should buy the home they want to live in, says Mr Boulger. "There's little to be gained in trying to beat the market," he says. "First-time buyers should only think about putting off moving when prices are falling."

Jeremy Leaf, Royal Institu tion of Chartered Surveyors housing spokesman, points out that in London, where shortages of good quality properties have led to steep price rises, buyers are still competing for many homes. Mr Leaf says the market is not as frantic as it has been but advises buyers to research the market in their chosen area. House-hunters should be prepared for competition for properties, he says. "Sellers need to have six or seven people interested in a property to ensure they get one good sale. However, people drop out for all sorts of reasons so buyers shouldn't be discouraged."

Don't panic is also the message from Martin Ellis. He says last year's house price increases are "unsustainable". Like many lenders, Mr Ellis expects the impact of the recent interest rate rises - four since last September - and the end of Miras to help cool the market down. Together they added £750 to the annual mortgage payments for a borrower with a £60,000 interest-only loan, says the Halifax. Also, as those in jobs with average pay get priced out of the market, demand will fall and price rises will slow.

Mr Leaf has noticed that the number of homes coming on to the market is increasing. "Sellers appreciate that the current boom won't go on forever and are starting to think about moving now."

"I don't think it is a bad time to buy," says Mr Ellis. "There aren't any huge risks associated with buying now as there were in the late 80s." The relationship between incomes and borrowings is a healthy one, he says. Only in greater London has the house price to earnings ratio started to rise above the 15-year average.

Mr Ellis says: "We're not expecting the market to grow so rapidly but similarly we're not expecting it to fall either."

Howard Davies, chairman of the Financial Services Authority, has warned of the dangers of lenders offering generous income multiples to borrowers struggling to get a foothold in the market. But loans offered on such generous terms are still very much in the minority, says Mr Ellis.

Figures from the Nationwide also suggest current shortages could be easing as activity increases. The building society's monthly house price index reports that house sales rose by nearly 5% in January. "Although sales remain below their level in the 80s, they have now risen to their highest since 1989."

And the future looks bright, according to the report. "We expect house prices to rise by 11% this year and sales to increase by 8% to around 1.6 million," says the Nationwide.

"There aren't any huge risks associated with buying now as there were in the late 80s." The relationship between incomes and borrowings is a healthy one, he says. Only in greater London has the house price to earnings ratio started to rise above the 15-year average. Mr Ellis says: "We're not expecting the market to grow so rapidly but similarly we're not expecting it to fall either." Howard Davies, chairman of the Financial Services Authority, has warned of the dangers of lenders offering generous income multiples to borrowers struggling to get a foothold in the market. But loans offered on such generous terms are still very much in the minority, says Mr Ellis. Figures from the Nationwide also suggest current shortages could be easing as activity increases. The building society's monthly house price index reports that house sales rose by nearly 5% in January. "Although sales remain below their level in the 80s, they have now risen to their highest since 1989." And the future looks bright, according to the report. "We expect house prices to rise by 11% this year and sales to increase by 8% to around 1.6 million," says the Nationwide.

webTitle: Revving up to find formula for success

fields.headline: Revving up to find formula for success
fields.standfirst: As a new grand prix season lines up on the starting grid in Australia, Patrick Sherwen looks at the options in an industry crying out for skilled young people to take up the challenge
fields.trailText: Tomorrow morning roughly four million people will plonk themselves in front of the telly to watch Jenson Button in his brand new BMW Williams F1 car become the youngest ever British Formula 1 driver.
fields.body:
Tomorrow morning roughly four million people will plonk themselves in front of the telly to watch Jenson Button in his brand new BMW Williams F1 car become the youngest ever British Formula 1 driver.

The 20-year-old Button makes his debut amid a buzz of excitement about Britain's involvement this season. Apart from Mr Button and the first outing for the Williams F1 with its new partner BMW, there is also the debut of Jaguar's new team. Jaguar Racing will provide a ride for two more British drivers: Eddie Irvine and Johnny Herbert. On top of that Irishman Eddie Jordan is full of confidence and expects to better or equal last year's third place behind Ferrari and McLaren Mercedes in this season's constructors' championship. The sport has never been more attractive to young enthusiasts hoping to make it a career. But how do you go about it? It's not the sort of occupation many school careers officers are cut out to deal with.

Until recently there were virtually no training or educational programmes specific to the subject. But in the last year several new courses and scholarships - such as the Racecar Engineering/Pilbeam Scholarship which offers a one-year, salaried work placement at Pilbeam Racing Designs - have sprung up to meet the demand from an industry worth £1.5bn in the UK alone. The courses range from B-Tech Higher National Diplomas to an MSc starting this year at Cranfield university. The focus of the courses tends to be on engineering; drivers still have to take a less formal route based primarily on racing experience. But some also teach the student what is involved in managing a racing team, such as business and marketing skills.

John Paling, admissions tutor for Derby university's HND in motor sport technology, says Derby may launch a course covering the marketing and commercial side next year. In the meantime, he says, most job opportunities are on the technical side. McLaren gets 3,000 applications a year for design positions, he says, but cannot get enough technicians, responsible for fabrication of components, programming and operating computer-operated machine tools.

Derby set up its course after a request from the industry. "We were approached by a company that races classic cars which asked if we had any engineering students who could support their teams," says Mr Paling. Cranfield's course was also designed to meet an industry need, says Clive Temple at the university. The support for the course is illustrated by the £500,000 invested in it by the Engineering and Physical Research Council and the endorsement by the Motor Sports Association and the Motorsport Industries Association.

Mr Paling is confident that students of motor sport will not struggle to find work. "As long as they are up to standard on the practical side and the academic side they shouldn't have any problem getting a job," he says. Mr Paling says he looks for signs that the candidate is a "natural engineer" - which seems to translate as a person with a history of tinkering with mechanical devices - and passion. Nav Sidhu, the media manager for Williams F1, the company behind the BMW Williams F1 racing team, says extreme commitment is vital. "If you are working at an insurance company or a bank the bottom line is that you walk in at 8.30am and out at 6.30pm. In this business it is anything but," he says.

Williams F1 is estimated to be worth £300m and employs 400 people who often put in 18-hour days. Motor sport is big business and there are lots of jobs to be done. Williams F1 has departments devoted to engineering, design and testing but it also has a museum and and an IT support team. Mr Sidhu says you do not have to come from a motor sport background to work in these areas of the company. "There is a misconception that to get into Formula 1 you have to come from Formula 1 and that's not true. We all have to start somewhere. "

Motor sport courses are good news, since they help graduates get a foot in the door and supply the industry with the young talent it is in sore need of. "The future is youth and there is not a great deal of youth in Formula 1," he says. Malcolm Tierney, head of research and development at Jaguar Racing, says the courses are good for those who want go into generalist roles. "These courses give a good grounding in all the areas that make up a team. They'll allow you to decide which areas you want to go into and give a bit of back ground in the others too," he says. Perversely, those who want more specialist jobs should probably go for non-motor sport courses in the relevant subject, he advises.

If someone wants a design job in hydraulics - a key area of racing car construction - they need to be a specialist in hydraulics, not a specialist in motor sport or motor sport-related hydraulics, he says.

Courses in motorsport are run by Cranfield university (John Nixon, 01234-754152), the university of Derby (John Paling, 01332-591291), Oxford Brookes (Julia Unna, 01865-483500) and Swansea institute of higher education (Roger Dowden, 01792-481168). Information about the Pilbeam scholarship is available on 01778-424838.

webTitle: Have a go if you think you're rich enough

fields.headline: Have a go if you think you're rich enough
fields.standfirst: Next month at Old Trafford precious soccer memorabilia including 20,000 old Man U programmes go on sale. Stewart Dalby reports
fields.trailText: It used to be golf, but now football is easily the biggest growth area in sports memorabilia collecting. Christie's holds two large auctions each year, usually in Edinburgh. David Convery, specialist at the auction house, says: "We started our football auctions in 1989. Then we grossed £50,000. Last year our two sales realised more than £500,000."
fields.body:
It used to be golf, but now football is easily the biggest growth area in sports memorabilia collecting. Christie's holds two large auctions each year, usually in Edinburgh. David Convery, specialist at the auction house, says: "We started our football auctions in 1989. Then we grossed £50,000. Last year our two sales realised more than £500,000."

Even allowing for the greater volume of material coming on to the market - and inflation - this still means that prices have increased almost 10-fold in 10 years.

The growing popularity of football ephemera mirrors the makeover the game has had in the past decade or so. Television payments have brought, to the Premier League at least, new continental-style, all-seater stadiums with restaurants, megastores and shops, making football more of a family affair than a male preserve. The millions which top players can earn and the flotation of clubs on the Stock Exchange, with millions of new shareholders, have changed the face of football radically. It is all a far cry from the days when mostly men were packed like sardines on windswept terraces. Most recently, medals, caps and shirts have been collected and fetched surprisingly high prices. A collection of 30 England caps belonging to the late Billy Wright, one of England's most capped players, realised £110,000 at a Christie's auction, with individual caps fetching £8,000 to £9,000 each.

A World Cup medal belonging to George Cohen, the England full back, was offered at auction for £60,000. The point about this is that England has only won the World Cup once, in 1966, and there were only 11 medals. There were none for those in the squad who did not play or for the manager. The medal did not go at the auction and in the end was sold privately. The sum paid has not been revealed, but since George Cohen said he needed the money for his pension it must have been substantial.

Programmes, comics and books have always been collected, but prices have risen steeply in recent years. So, for a number of reasons, there will great interest among the hard core of collectors in the Leslie Millman collection of Manchester United Football Club programmes which Phillips auction house is selling over two days on April 10 and 11.

First, it is claimed to be the most important collection of football programmes ever to come to auction. It comprises more than 10,000 Manchester United football programmes and other memorabilia and follows the team from their early days as Second Division Newton Heath to recent seasons as, arguably, the most successful and certainly the wealthiest club in the world.

Second, the sale is to take place at Old Trafford, the club's home ground and, third, Manchester United are currently heading towards their sixth league title in eight seasons and doing well in Europe.

Colin Palmer, who is organising the sale, says: "Because it is Manchester United you expect to pay a premium." David Convery agrees. He says: "We have sold a George Best cap for £9,000 and a shirt worn by Bobby Charlton in the 1966 World Cup semi-final for £15,000. If it were anyone else prices would be much lower."

John Eastwood, manager of Extra Cover, the shop in St John's Wood, north London, which sells sporting memorabilia, says: "It is like property prices - if you are talking Manchester it is like London properties. They just soar away."

So while you can get programmes for a few pounds or tens of pounds, some of the rare items at the sale at Old Trafford have very fancy estimates. One of the rarest items is a programme from 1958 for a game against Wolverhampton Wanderers which never took place. A week previously saw the tragic Munich air disaster in which many of the Man U team and staff died. The game was cancelled and printed programmes were incinerated. Only a few exist today. This one is estimated to fetch £4,000 to £5,000.

The earliest programmes in the collection date back to the 1890s, long before the building of Old Trafford. One single-sheet programme for this year illustrates "Today's Team" with named figures drawn in their positions for the match. Played at The Chuckery against Walsall Town Swifts on November 8 1890, it cost 1d and is now estimated to fetch between £7,000 and £9,000.

Other memorabilia includes a Ryan Giggs shirt, a Sir Alex Ferguson Toby jug and a Jensen car belonging to the late Sir Matt Busby. But the programmes will probably dominate the sale and it will be interesting to see whether the estimates will be exceeded, given that Manchester United is currently riding the crest of a wave.

For further information telephone Phillips, 01244-313-936; Christie's, 0171-581-7611, or Extra Cover, 101 Boundary Road, St John's Wood, London NW8 ORG, 0171-625-1191.

fields.headline: The nuts and bolts
fields.trailText: To undertake an Msc in motorsport engineering and management at Cranfield university full-time course-candidates are expected to obtain or possess a minimum of a second class honours degree in a relevant engineering or science-based discipline;
fields.body:
To undertake an Msc in motorsport engineering and management at Cranfield university full-time course-candidates are expected to obtain or possess a minimum of a second class honours degree in a relevant engineering or science-based discipline;

Part-time course-candidates are expected to have a degree or its equivalent, and be employed in a graduate level position within the motorsport or automotive sector

The course covers:

 Advanced materials for motorsport metals and non-metalllic materials:

 Motorsport power-train design:

 Computational fluid dynamics (CFD) for motorsport

 Structural design for motorsport and aerodynamics:

 Management for motorsport-basic concepts and case studies.

 Fees for a full-time student from the EU are £5,500. The part-time course costs a basic £250 plus £1,000 per module. To study any single module be prepared to pay £1,500 a time.

Motorsport studentships worth £2,750 will be offered to suitably qualified candidates Also prospective students can compete for EPSRC funding to help with tuition fees and living costs. Other sources include NatWest Bank Postgraduate Loans tailored for Cranfield students at competitive interest rates (01234-754171), DfEE Career Development Loans (0800-585505) or the Royal Academy of Engineering. The deadline for applications is August 31.

Winning is the only thing that matters for Malcolm

Motorsport vehicle dynamics and systems: At only 43, Malcolm Tierney, head of research and development at Jaguar Racing, can look back on a long career in motor sport and remember that it took him five years before he went from aeronautical engineering into Formula 1

He started out with a Bsc from Bath university in aeronautical engineering, working on military aircraft at British Aerospace (BAe). The experience of working at BAe proved to be a good start but opportunities to jump to another career path, as he wanted to do, were rare.

"The teams were much smaller and Formula 1 wasn't the international sport it is today," he says. But two offers came along and he went as a designer to Toleman Group Motorsport, which became Benneton in 1986. He had a season as a race engineer with Michael Andretti on Indycars in the US and18 months running Ricardo Patrese's team at Renault Williams.

He no longer travels with the race teams as he once did. But his purpose is clear. "One of the reasons I wanted to get into this business is that the measure of your success or failure isn't just a balance sheet. Winning is all that matters," he says.

Jordan's Ben waits for the starting flag to drop

Ben Ferrey is 23 and appears to be somewhere near the front of the grid as he waits for the flag to drop.

He is waiting to hear whether he will get a place on Cranfield university's new Msc in motorsport engineering and management. With an award from the Royal Academy of Engineering, months as a student engineer with the Jordan Formula 1 team and the possibility of a first-class degree in mechanical engineering from Imperial College on the way, he stands a good chance.

Mr Ferrey's enthusiasm for the work is clear, and never more so than when he talks of winning his place with Jordan. "I was extremely pleased. It was something I'd wanted to do and I was very lucky. Even being at Imperial College it is very hard to get noticed because so many people want to do what I want to do," he says.

What Mr Ferrey wants to do is a "technically challenging job" and says Champ Cars in the US - formerly known as Indycars - offer more opportunities than F1 as regulations are less restrictive. "I don't have my mind set just on F1. There are a lot of areas in motorsport that are all interesting - it just happens that F1 is the highest profile," he says.

fields.headline: William Harris
fields.standfirst: Managing director of Britt Allcroft, the company behind Thomas the Tank Engine
fields.trailText: When did you first become a manager?
fields.body:
When did you first become a manager?

In 1979, as a very green second-year student at Price Waterhouse.

What has been your best moment in management?

When we acquired the underlying rights to Thomas the Tank Engine in May 1998.

What was your greatest mistake?

Not doing the deal much earlier.

Which deal would you most like to have done?

Negotiating the rights in DOS for Microsoft.

What do you find most annoying in your staff?

Failure to delegate.

Does your organisation have a glass ceiling?

No. The sky's the limit.

What management wisdom is most overrated?

Needing to have 20 or 30 years' experience of an industry. I'd choose a good manager over an experienced manager any day.

What is the one lesson you have learned that you would pass on to young managers?

Lessons are best learned by making mistakes. Just try not to make them career threatening.

Which management guru do you believe in?

I don't. I prefer advice from a number of different people.

Who is your management hero?

Dilbert!

Who is your favourite politician?

Tony Benn, but I agree with him on very little.

How much were you paid last year?

Enough to keep the bank manager happy.

If you could change one aspect of British business, what would it be?

Teach us three foreign languages.

What phrase or saying do you most overuse?

"Wow."

Apart from quality time with your family, what else makes you happiest in life?

Good company with good food.

What annoys you most?

People who stand and chat, surrounded by trolleys, blocking supermarket aisles.

How do you relax?

Skiing. I have to concentrate so hard I forget everything else.

What was your last cultural experience?

New York on foot.

What is your favourite city?

Berlin, before the wall came down.

Favourite journey?

Going home on a May evening with the bluebells in bloom.

What is your greatest regret?

Losing touch with old friends - they might win the Lottery one day!

What is your biggest fear?

Missing last orders at the Tally Ho (my local).

What will be the big business issue of the next decade?

Managing change.

What would you really like to have been?

A pathologist.

fields.headline: Get a part-time life
fields.standfirst: Women faced with the tough choice between work and home now have a champion in Lindsay Swan, who specialises in jobs to suit modern mums. Martyn Seal talked to her
fields.trailText: If you listen to the government on the issue of employment you might think a full-time job is everyone's aspiration. But the truth is that for parents and carers, the disabled or those not of the 60-hour-week shoulder-to-the-grindstone mentality, part-time work is a godsend, especially to those with lives to lead outside the 9-to-6 (or longer) working day.
fields.body:
If you listen to the government on the issue of employment you might think a full-time job is everyone's aspiration. But the truth is that for parents and carers, the disabled or those not of the 60-hour-week shoulder-to-the-grindstone mentality, part-time work is a godsend, especially to those with lives to lead outside the 9-to-6 (or longer) working day.

Full-time employment can hit first-time mothers particularly hard when they've been used to the stimulus of work, but find the demands of parenthood incompatible with the culture of their former employment.

This was what Lindsay Swan came across when she took up the school run after scaling down her full-time career. "I had a PR company for 20 years and then it amalgamated. I just kept one large client account which I did from home, so I was able to be around for my children. I started to do school runs and met these women who'd had superb careers but were then faced with the choice of working or bringing up their children."

It puzzled her, what seemed a ridiculous waste of talent, but it might have remained just a talking point if it hadn't been for her friend Elaine Howe.

"My big break was meeting Elaine," Ms Swan says. "My idea was very loose, simply realising that there were a huge number of women who weren't able to work because they had children. When I mentioned it to Elaine she said: 'Right, let's do something about it'."

And that's exactly what they did. They set up a recruitment consultancy specialising in part-time employment called Working Options. With Ms Swan's background in PR and Ms Howe's former work as a management accountant they found their skills and experience a big plus.

"I was a manager with a multi-media company for many years," Ms Howe explains. "Consequently I was used to dealing with recruitment agencies and with staff, so I brought managerial skills to the business. On the other side Lindsay is much better at marketing in terms of her PR ability, so between us we have complementary skills. In a start-up situation that keeps your costs down."

By happy coincidence the two women lived next door to each other. "Lindsay and I would occasionally chat over the garden wall and since I was finding it difficult trying to return to work part-time, the subject came up. The recruitment consultancies I'd come across all dealt with full-time working. Part-time positions weren't really available," says Ms Howe.

From the start the aim was to make their view of part-time employment thoroughly business-like. "In everything we've done we always believed you have to make a strong business case. We've now been going a year and we've seen a huge number of changes as companies realise that to have the pick of excellent employees and to retain them you have to offer more than just loads of money," says Ms Swan.

They now have more than 1,000 people on their books. "The beauty of this idea is that it's absolutely right for now," says Ms Swan. "People are questioning whether they want to work all the time or whether they want to balance work with their lives."

But the struggle to persuade businesses to accept part-time working arrangements hasn't been straightforward. "There are still a lot of companies that are not switched on to flexible working," says Ms Howe. "Their immediate reaction is if we do it for one, we're setting a precedent. There are still many companies which do not embrace a flexible working pattern. But it's coming."

In their view, the long hours culture isn't necessarily productive. It isn't about how many hours you put in, but results gained. They also find it difficult to understand the government's attitude towards the issue of childcare. "Children are treated like an embarrassment. Abroad, governments subsidise and take the lead in maternity policies which companies have no option but to enforce, whereas here you're still not allowed to claim your childcare costs as a taxable expense."

The best thing about their current working arrangements is that, although they're now working full-time, they are able to adapt their hours to suit their family needs. It's a position they'd like to give to more employees who want it.
