fields.headline: Dear weekend
fields.standfirst:
Guardian Weekend, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Email: weekend@guardian.co.uk.
Fax: 020-7239 9935. Letters should reach us by Tuesday afternoon for inclusion on Saturday, and may be edited.
fields.trailText: Dear weekend
fields.body:
John Pilger presents a devastating account of the economic sanctions crushing the ordinary people of Iraq, and the role the British government plays in maintaining these sanctions (Squeezed To Death, March 4). Over the past two years, we have openly broken the sanctions by taking toys and medical supplies to Iraqi children's hospitals without applying for export licences. Some of us have been arrested and threatened with prosecution.

We do not accept the government's right to a moral veto over our attempts to help individuals in Iraq. Last month, the UN humanitarian co-ordinator for Iraq resigned over the impact of sanctions on the civilian population, saying he could not be silent in the face of 'a true human tragedy'. Neither can we.
Milan Rai, Andrea Needham, Martin Thomas, Simon Emdin, Dave Rolstone, Joanne Baker
Voices In The Wilderness UK voices@viwuk.freeserve.co.uk

I suggest that we all write letters, beginning 'Dear murderer', to Tony Blair and Robin Cook and repeat them every week until either sanctions are hugely revised, or the thought police arrive.
Ken Norman
Bowness-on-Solway, Cumbria

In response to a news broadcast in March 1998 about a high cancer incidence in Basra, I sought to provide a cheap and humane cancer treatment. Arrangements were made with the Basra doctor; drugs were bought and ready to send. At the last minute, the Iraqi chargé d'affaires in London told me that his government had suddenly prohibited the sending of gifts of medicine, and the project collapsed. Those upset by miseries caused by shortage of medicines should not allow themselves to be duped by Iraqi propaganda.
Dr Robert Jones
London SE24

John Pilger quotes Robin Cook: 'We must uphold the sanctity of international law and the UN.' Who can recall Cook invoking this when it came to bombing Serbia? If the security council proposes lifting sanctions on Iraq, the US and UK will simply turn up and veto the proposal with protestations about upholding 'the sanctity of...' etc.
Adrian Kozlowski
Moseley, Birmingham

With his concern for public libraries as 'our street-corner universities' (Shelf Life, March 4), perhaps Chris Smith should have words with his colleagues on Leicester City Council, who have just voted to close six public libraries as part of their budget proposals. This decision, taken despite fierce local opposition, is surely one of Labour's most inexplicable contributions to the 150th anniversary of the Public Libraries Act.
Roger Blackmore
Deputy Leader, Liberal Democrat Group
Leicester City Council

Roger Fisken's assertion that complementary medicine should not only appear to work but be underpinned by philosophical assumptions (Dear Weekend, March 4) reminds me of a remark attributed to Sir Keith Joseph: 'I can see that it works in practice, but does it work in theory?'
RA Sheed
Manea, March, Cambs

How it is that the very same people who, quite rightly, insist on rigorous testing of GM foods are so eager to accept untested homeopathic and herbal treatments?
David Colquhoun
Professor of pharmacology, University College, London WC1

webTitle: There is no such thing as a simple murder

fields.headline: There is no such thing as a simple murder
fields.standfirst: "Masters is the guru of extreme motivation, who tells us what was going through the killer's head, but never why we need to know that"
fields.trailText: "Masters is the guru of extreme motivation, who tells us what was going through the killer's head, but never why we need to know that"
fields.body:
Everywhere I turn, I see Brian Masters, author of books and articles on Jeffrey Dahmer, Denis Nilsen, Rosemary West and every other murderer in between. I am genuinely worried that I have become as obsessed by Masters as he is by weirdo killers. I watch his every twitch, every bead of sweat on the speckled skin of his bald head, trying to work out what possessed him to go on Newsnight to discuss Dr Harold Shipman's motivations, or on Modern Times to muse on Myra Hindley's culpability.

Masters is the guru of extreme motivation: the man who tells us exactly what was going through the killer's head. The one thing that is never explained, however, is why we need to know what was going through the killer's head. It might as well be the Oasis songbook for all the sense it is going to make. Writing on Denis Nilsen, Masters argued that he killed for company. I can just about swallow that this is a kind of explanation for Nilsen's crimes, but it is not an explanation that makes any sense. What can you do with this kind of information - except, perhaps, petition the police to stake-out anyone who has ever placed a lonely hearts ad in case they turn homicidal?

There was a time when anyone who asked about motivation was a joke. Literally. The joke was about an actor who spent five hours worrying about his motivation before picking up a glass of water. I cannot remember the punchline, but the point was that actors are stupid. Everyday acts such as eating and drinking require little motivation. The few actions that do are the big questions, the ones that make the drama tick. Why does Iago go after Othello with such demonic fury? There are hundreds of surface reasons, ranging from spite through sexual jealousy to racism, but, at bottom, Iago's motivation is a cold, dark mystery, and a performance that respects this is always more powerful.

I often work with actors now, and soon found out that they are far from stupid, at least during office hours. A writer can learn a lot from an actor because they are such careful readers. Maybe this is why so many successful novelists were one-time actors. (And, conversely, why so few editors, critics or academics ever make it as novelists: I've been all three, and talking about books always seems preferable to reading them.) I have never yet heard an actor ask about motivation, but script editors ask it all the time. And because they have to relay the answer upwards, to the money men, there is no room for ambiguity. Motivation is like Apollo 9: it has to be big, it must have a point and everyone has to know where it is going.

I was reminded of all the script conferences on motivation I've ever had while watching Anthony Minghella's film version of The Talented Mr Ripley. Clearly, Minghella has become as obsessed by Masters as I have. The key Masters moment comes on a rowing boat, after Ripley has beaten his friend Dickie Greenleaf to death. Ripley drapes one of Dickie's arms over himself, and lies in his embrace until dark. It is only through Dickie's death that Ripley achieves the intimacy he wanted so much when he was alive: in my view, the best use of the "killing for company" hypothesis in an adapted screenplay.

Minghella easily wins the Masters award (a Master of the Universe action figurine I keep in a drawer), but I would be less happy seeing him receive an Oscar for Ripley. In Patricia Highsmith's original book, Ripley is not homosexual. Instead, he has a fascination for Dickie and his world that is so powerful, it tilts over into erotic desire. When this happens, the basically hetero Ripley is both aware of it and amazed. True, in 1956, when the novel was published, homosexual themes tended to be relegated to the sub-text. But Highsmith continued to write Ripley novels until the late 70s, by which time she had created many gay characters and was widely known to be a lesbian herself. If Ripley was gay, Highsmith would have written him gay. Instead, she gave us a mystery: why is someone with so much intelligence, sensitivity and charisma as Ripley a complete psychopath?

Minghella's re-writing of Ripley destroys the mystery by making his motivation transparent. He kills because he cannot come to terms with his homosexuality. He is repressed. Just as the killer in American Beauty is homosexual and repressed. If I were feeling feisty, I would argue that both films are simply dim-witted homophobia wrapped up in psychobabble. But I am not sure they are. In the high-concept world of contemporary cinema, as in the high-concept world of television documentaries and Newsnight features, everything requires a simple motivation. Which is great news for Masters, but not so good for writers, directors or actors. Nor, I suspect, for anyone else. Even in a post-religious world, evil remains a mystery. And mysteries are complex - they require long thought, not short answers.

 Alexander Chancellor is away.

fields.headline: Bodies beautiful
fields.standfirst: Interiors, exteriors, objects, even sculpture - nothing, it seems, is beyond the designer Nigel Coates. Which makes it all the more intriguing to see how he fills his home. By Charlotte Abrahams
fields.trailText: Interiors, exteriors, objects, even sculpture - nothing, it seems, is beyond the designer Nigel Coates. Which makes it all the more intriguing to see how he fills his home. By Charlotte Abrahams
fields.body:
Nigel Coates is not often at home. I have been told by his people that this is a rare opportunity to step into his world, and I should be suitably grateful. And I am. I mean, Nigel Coates is very famous - maybe not stop-him-in-the-street-for-an-autograph type famous but, in design terms, he's a superstar. He and his architectural practice, Branson Coates, are behind many well- known - and controversial - buildings. There's the National Centre for Popular Music, in Sheffield, housed in four giant stainless-steel drums; and the visionary Oyster House, designed as a House of the Future for the 1998 Ideal Home exhibition (a project that represents the exhibition's only flirtation with serious modern design).

There are also the innovative shop interiors for, among others, the clothing chain Jigsaw and fashion designer Katharine Hamnett. And, in case you didn't already know, Branson Coates is also responsible for that giant sculpture of a man and a woman that houses the Body Zone exhibition in the Millennium Dome.

So, here I am early on a sunny March morning, standing outside his flat. I ring the bell and am admitted to the kind of post-strewn, shared hall found in every apartment block in London. But ahead, through the open door of his flat, I can see that Nigel Coates's place is anything but ordinary. For a start, his hallway has been decorated with a wall-to-wall, floor-to-ceiling mural of cavorting nudes, and the sitting room, reached through a silver door, is crammed full of Coates's own work.

In the centre is the Leg Over chair, a flexible piece of phallic upholstery with three different positions (it's in its relaxed state this morning). Set in a friendly arc around the fire is his Oxo sofa system, originally designed for the Oyster House and now available commercially, produced by Hitch Mylius. Examples of his glasswork (design by Coates, production by Simon Moore) are everywhere, grouped in pairs of contrasting sizes, which, I discover, is one of Coates' big things. The subtle and vaguely organic rugs on the floor are also his (manufactured by Kappa Lamda), and were, like the sofa, designed originally for the Oyster House. And over on the glass shelf sits a basalt maquette of the Body.

It is one thing to design the centrepiece for a major exhibition, entirely another to open a shop and fill it with Body-related memorabilia. But Coates has done just that. As if the Dome gift emporium were not enough, his new shop contains jewellery - necklaces, rings, bracelets and cufflinks that refer visually, in some way or another, to the Body: lumps of crystal with a miniature Body inside; a clothing line with T-shirts printed with abstract Body shapes; Body maquettes (in bronze as well as basalt); and a range of Body-related china that is due to be launched soon in association with Wedgwood.

All of which begs the question: has Nigel Coates, once the enfant terrible of British architecture and creator of X-rated furniture (he once did a stool with an erect penis), sold out to the Millennium machine? Is his chic Clerkenwell studio-shop no more than a smart site for souvenirs?

"The pieces we've done are not just mugs with a picture of the Dome figures stuck on the front," Coates retorts. "It's a far cry from the Festival of Britain-type stuff. But if you're doing pieces that are for sale in the Dome shop, then you have to encompass that end."

Coates is bullish, even though the Dome has the status of Britain's favourite failure. The negative perceptions of the Greenwich experience, he thinks, do not affect him. Moreover, he is pleased with his Body and doesn't see why it cannot be used in other work. "We've done that one piece which we are proud of," he says. "It was an immense amount of effort, and as a piece of construction it's got a lot of innovation in it." The Body itself, he adds, "hasn't been criticised. I stand by it. It is one of the things to mark the millennium. The products might drift away, but at the same time there is something worth remembering about it. I've even had a ring made with an intaglio of the two figures - that means something to me, to have it as a signet ring."

Maybe he is right. The millennium was a historic moment and, perhaps, once Dome-bashing ceases to be our favourite sport, we will realise that there was something about it worth preserving.

Besides, it's not as if this Body Zone-related stuff has come from nowhere. For Coates, the human form has always been a key source of inspiration. This is seen in its most overt form in pieces such as the Leg Over chair, the award-winning Tongue chair, and the Genie stool (the one with the wooden penis). But it is also there in a more subtle form in the rest of his work - his interest lies, as he puts it, "in the phenomenology of ourselves", rather than in the way the body looks in a picture in a magazine. "The body is the first laboratory of being able to appreciate space," he explains, "and of course architecture is the correspondence to the body - doors are vaguely body-shaped, windows have to be the right height to look through, etc - all of these have a paradigmatic relationship with the body."

It would be easy to misread Coates. The rude furniture could be seen as no more than a gimmick to amuse some and shock others - but he is too clever for that. Yes, he likes to create things that have a spirit, work that gives a "bit of a poke", and says that his ideas are closer to the subversive spirit of a fashion designer than the rigorous functionality of an architect; but they also have subtlety.

It was Nigel Coates, for example, who won the commission to build a sympathetic-yet-modern extension to the Georgian almshouses of the Geffrye Museum in east London; and Branson Coates that designed the chic and simple range of Lloyd Loom chairs that furnished the Oyster House and gave the oh-so-traditional furniture company a contemporary relaunch. Similarly, the new shop, with its Body goods, turns out not to be simply a way of making money on the back of a famous image (although he does admit to seizing an opportunity), but a game exploring what a brand can be.

And, whether you believe it or not, it is perfectly in tune with the Coates philosophy. It is typical that his new T-shirt bears the slogan "Emergency Branding". He is, he insists, not interested in creating a consistent image. If there is a big idea, it is to make things that do not dictate their particular use, but instead allow individuals to interpret them as they wish. "It's not a total 'look'; it's a sort of ricochet - the pleasure of putting one thing next to another, that has a sort of aesthetic about it, which I think, is connected to the way we use space.

"None of our projects is a total style statement. They are all about moving through them, about enjoying the juxtapositions." And this is what makes his flat so interesting. Enjoyable juxtapositions abound, from the repeated setting of a large vase beside a small one to the clash of the flat's original features with the highly contemporary furniture he has put inside it.

Not for him the all-white minimalism of the archetypal architect's space. For Coates, rigorous minimalism is the last vestige of the 60s idea that an architect should design everything. "I like things clean and simple," he says, "but I don't like things which flatten out the meaning or experience of a place. I think that is what is wanted when people can't cope with the complexity of modern life. What I love is complexity, ricochet and quixotic nature, that there's always something unexpected around the corner."

Before I leave, I check out the bathroom: there's industrial-style slate, an old stainless-steel sink and, because of the architecture of the building, a sense of faded luxury. A ricochet if ever I saw one.

 The Nigel Coates shop, 1 Honduras Street, London EC1, 020-7336 1425

There are also the innovative shop interiors for, among others, the clothing chain Jigsaw and fashion designer Katharine Hamnett. And, in case you didn't already know, Branson Coates is also responsible for that giant sculpture of a man and a woman that houses the Body Zone exhibition in the Millennium Dome. So, here I am early on a sunny March morning, standing outside his flat. I ring the bell and am admitted to the kind of post-strewn, shared hall found in every apartment block in London. But ahead, through the open door of his flat, I can see that Nigel Coates's place is anything but ordinary. For a start, his hallway has been decorated with a wall-to-wall, floor-to-ceiling mural of cavorting nudes, and the sitting room, reached through a silver door, is crammed full of Coates's own work. In the centre is the Leg Over chair, a flexible piece of phallic upholstery with three different positions (it's in its relaxed state this morning). Set in a friendly arc around the fire is his Oxo sofa system, originally designed for the Oyster House and now available commercially, produced by Hitch Mylius. Examples of his glasswork (design by Coates, production by Simon Moore) are everywhere, grouped in pairs of contrasting sizes, which, I discover, is one of Coates' big things. The subtle and vaguely organic rugs on the floor are also his (manufactured by Kappa Lamda), and were, like the sofa, designed originally for the Oyster House. And over on the glass shelf sits a basalt maquette of the Body. It is one thing to design the centrepiece for a major exhibition, entirely another to open a shop and fill it with Body-related memorabilia. But Coates has done just that. As if the Dome gift emporium were not enough, his new shop contains jewellery - necklaces, rings, bracelets and cufflinks that refer visually, in some way or another, to the Body: lumps of crystal with a miniature Body inside; a clothing line with T-shirts printed with abstract Body shapes; Body maquettes (in bronze as well as basalt); and a range of Body-related china that is due to be launched soon in association with Wedgwood. All of which begs the question: has Nigel Coates, once the enfant terrible of British architecture and creator of X-rated furniture (he once did a stool with an erect penis), sold out to the Millennium machine? Is his chic Clerkenwell studio-shop no more than a smart site for souvenirs? "The pieces we've done are not just mugs with a picture of the Dome figures stuck on the front," Coates retorts. "It's a far cry from the Festival of Britain-type stuff. But if you're doing pieces that are for sale in the Dome shop, then you have to encompass that end." Coates is bullish, even though the Dome has the status of Britain's favourite failure. The negative perceptions of the Greenwich experience, he thinks, do not affect him. Moreover, he is pleased with his Body and doesn't see why it cannot be used in other work. "We've done that one piece which we are proud of," he says. "It was an immense amount of effort, and as a piece of construction it's got a lot of innovation in it." The Body itself, he adds, "hasn't been criticised. I stand by it. It is one of the things to mark the millennium. The products might drift away, but at the same time there is something worth remembering about it. I've even had a ring made with an intaglio of the two figures - that means something to me, to have it as a signet ring." Maybe he is right. The millennium was a historic moment and, perhaps, once Dome-bashing ceases to be our favourite sport, we will realise that there was something about it worth preserving. Besides, it's not as if this Body Zone-related stuff has come from nowhere. For Coates, the human form has always been a key source of inspiration. This is seen in its most overt form in pieces such as the Leg Over chair, the award-winning Tongue chair, and the Genie stool (the one with the wooden penis). But it is also there in a more subtle form in the rest of his work - his interest lies, as he puts it, "in the phenomenology of ourselves", rather than in the way the body looks in a picture in a magazine. "The body is the first laboratory of being able to appreciate space," he explains, "and of course architecture is the correspondence to the body - doors are vaguely body-shaped, windows have to be the right height to look through, etc - all of these have a paradigmatic relationship with the body." It would be easy to misread Coates. The rude furniture could be seen as no more than a gimmick to amuse some and shock others - but he is too clever for that. Yes, he likes to create things that have a spirit, work that gives a "bit of a poke", and says that his ideas are closer to the subversive spirit of a fashion designer than the rigorous functionality of an architect; but they also have subtlety. It was Nigel Coates, for example, who won the commission to build a sympathetic-yet-modern extension to the Georgian almshouses of the Geffrye Museum in east London; and Branson Coates that designed the chic and simple range of Lloyd Loom chairs that furnished the Oyster House and gave the oh-so-traditional furniture company a contemporary relaunch. Similarly, the new shop, with its Body goods, turns out not to be simply a way of making money on the back of a famous image (although he does admit to seizing an opportunity), but a game exploring what a brand can be. And, whether you believe it or not, it is perfectly in tune with the Coates philosophy. It is typical that his new T-shirt bears the slogan "Emergency Branding". He is, he insists, not interested in creating a consistent image. If there is a big idea, it is to make things that do not dictate their particular use, but instead allow individuals to interpret them as they wish. "It's not a total 'look'; it's a sort of ricochet - the pleasure of putting one thing next to another, that has a sort of aesthetic about it, which I think, is connected to the way we use space. "None of our projects is a total style statement. They are all about moving through them, about enjoying the juxtapositions." And this is what makes his flat so interesting. Enjoyable juxtapositions abound, from the repeated setting of a large vase beside a small one to the clash of the flat's original features with the highly contemporary furniture he has put inside it. Not for him the all-white minimalism of the archetypal architect's space. For Coates, rigorous minimalism is the last vestige of the 60s idea that an architect should design everything. "I like things clean and simple," he says, "but I don't like things which flatten out the meaning or experience of a place. I think that is what is wanted when people can't cope with the complexity of modern life. What I love is complexity, ricochet and quixotic nature, that there's always something unexpected around the corner." Before I leave, I check out the bathroom: there's industrial-style slate, an old stainless-steel sink and, because of the architecture of the building, a sense of faded luxury. A ricochet if ever I saw one.  The Nigel Coates shop, 1 Honduras Street, London EC1, 020-7336 1425 www.nigelcoates.com

fields.headline: Smitten in futureville
fields.standfirst: It was the first new Jewish city to be built since biblical times, a corner of the Mediterranean that is forever Bauhaus. It encapsulated the aspirations and flaws of the state of  Israel to come. Tel Aviv, Linda Grant finds, is her kind of town
fields.trailText: It was the first new Jewish city to be built since biblical times, a corner of the Mediterranean that is forever Bauhaus. It encapsulated the aspirations and flaws of the state of  Israel to come. Tel Aviv, Linda Grant finds, is her kind of town
fields.body:
Two years ago exactly, I fell in love with a city no one falls in love with. I had gone to Israel to write about the 50th anniversary of the country. I spent the first 24 hours in Tel Aviv holed up in a concrete shoebox of a hotel on the seashore. I stood on my balcony and looked out and what I saw was a dump, a monstrosity, a 60s council estate writ large. But on the second day, drinking my breakfast coffee in the March sunshine, I noticed the curved lines of the dingy apartment buildings along Ha Yarkon Street and something stirred in my memory. I saw that another city was sticking out like the bones of the dead from the ground. Before my eyes an entire Bauhaus town was assembling itself: flat-roofed boxes that had once been white, dazzling white, under the Mediterranean sun; buildings like machines constructed of glass and concrete; clean, uncluttered facades to cleanse the eye; two buildings facing each other on a corner like a pair of ships' prows.

The houses now were stained and derelict, overgrown with oleander and hibiscus bushes; palm trees had taken root in the spaces between the lots. All the trash of city living - peeling stucco, air-conditioning vents, skips, electrical cables, natural gas tanks and street signs - obscured the memory that, 60 years ago, Tel Aviv had been conceived as an experiment in modern living by the socialists and other political ideologues who found themselves washed up on the very edge of the Middle East. Tel Aviv still contains the largest collection of Bauhaus architecture in the world: 6,500 buildings. It is a monument to the age of Modernism. Who designed and constructed these places? Who lived in them? I was avid to know and determined to find out.

I went to the Tel Aviv Municipal Museum. Closed two years ago. I went to the Art Museum, where tours of the Bauhaus architecture of the city were advertised in my guide book. Discontinued. An exhibition on the Bauhaus architecture of Tel Aviv had taken place in the 80s and a catalogue had been published. It was out of print. If you type the word Jerusalem into the online bookseller Amazon's search engine, you'll get 495 hits. Type in Tel Aviv and you get 10, only four of which are in print - of those, one is a map and another the proceedings of an astronomy conference. I asked in Steimatsky, the Israeli bookstore chain, if they could recommend novels set in Tel Aviv. A young assistant said that he could think of none. David Grossman and Amos Oz were rooted in Jerusalem. The people of Tel Aviv were suffering collective amnesia about their city's history.

By this time I was sure that I would write a novel set in this mysterious city that appeared to have no memory of its own past. Months later, I came to see that Tel Aviv was a metaphor. It stood for the flawed aspirations of its founders, who in 1909 assembled on a sand-dune north of the Arab town of Jaffa and dreamed of creating the first Jewish metropolis since biblical times. They were turning their backs against the past towards the future. They were trying to reinvent themselves for the 20th century in a longing much bigger than political nationalism. In building the new city, they wanted to rebuild the new Jew from the ground up, but in so doing they had built into their vision an abandonment of their history. The state of the Bauhaus city today speaks both of the dreams and of the in-built failures of Modernism.

It took months of tramping the streets and examining the archives of the Palestine Post (the forerunner to the Jerusalem Post) to discover what the inhabitants of the city themselves could not tell me. Tel Aviv has its origins in a decision in 1887 to build a Jewish suburb just outside Jaffa, in a neighbourhood called Neve Tsedek. Small, mainly one-storey houses were constructed in a Mediterranean style. By 1909, they had overflowed the new area and on April 11 a group of 66 families, calling themselves the Achusath Bayit housing association, gathered on the sand-dunes of what was then known as Sheikh Jibalis Vineyard, after the owner from whom the land had been purchased.

They were in buoyant mood because they had just heard news from Odessa that Chaim Nachman Bialik, the most celebrated Hebrew poet of his day, was asking to join them. The group's leader, Meier Dizengoff, later to become the fledgling town's first mayor, organised a lot-drawing ceremony, using 60 pebbles bearing the names of each family and 60 more pebbles marked with the number of the building plot. (What happened to the other six families is unrecorded.)

After a long discussion about the name of the new town, they settled on Tel Aviv, the Hebrew translation of Altneuland, a utopian novel by the Zionist leader and journalist Theodor Herzl, whose coverage of the Dreyfus trial in France had led to the founding of the Zionist Congress. Altneuland meant old and new land. Tel means an excavated mound, signifying the remains of old settlements; aviv is the first sprouting of new wheat. The construction work was carried out by Arab labourers and supplies were transported by camel, but the founders were already conceiving Tel Aviv as the opposite of Jaffa. Where Jaffa had history and ancient stones, Tel Aviv would be brash, new, a work-in-progress. To one observer, Jaffa seemed a dozen centuries and 10,000 miles away.

During the first world war, the population of the still embryonic city was evacuated and the return began only after General Allenby (after whom the principal street would be named) re-took it at the head of a victorious British Army. The earliest architects came from Russia, and their style was influenced not only by what they had left behind, but also by the fashion for Orientalism that swept the West in the aftermath of the opening of the tomb of Tutankhamun.

Until 1925, there was no development plan. Tel Aviv was mushrooming with what one observer described as "a shocking mixture of forms and plans and a fray of shoving, queue-jumping wills which personify the immense revolution that has taken place on the sand-dunes". A German visitor in 1924 wrote that "all aesthetically-minded people are beside themselves with horror at the ugliness and tastelessness and banality... but I am impressed by the pace of things here, by the colossal vitality which this town has about it."

In the 30s, suddenly, in place of random development, of buildings commissioned by individuals to suit their own overblown and untutored fantasies, there was real urgency about housing. The population of Zionist pioneers - part of the turn-of-the century pogrom emigration that would take millions of Jews from eastern Europe to America - were joined by another and very different band of immigrants.

In Tel Aviv in those days, there was a common saying you could hear in the cafes along the Allenby Road: "I didn't come here from conviction, I came here from Germany." The speakers were the Yekkes, the German Jews who, forced out of their country by fascism, saw cities such as London as the desired place of their exodus but could only get visas to Palestine, regarded by many as a primitive Oriental dump populated, apart from Arabs, by Oestjuden - Jews from the east, Poland and Russia. The Oestjuden, for their part, gave the German Jews their nickname, the Yekkes, because it was both the Hebrew word for jacket that the formal German Jews never took off, even in the stifling heat of the summer, and because it was an acronym for the words Yehudi Kashe Havanah - Jews who don't understand.

What was it that they could not comprehend? Many of the Yekkes were far from being Zionists. They were in Palestine on sufferance and determined that, come what may, they would do their best to re-create on the edge of the desert a new Berlin. They were not the scum of the east European shtetls, rabbis at best, beetroot farmers at worst, but saw themselves as the Weimar Republic in exile. Many were businessmen, doctors and lawyers who struggled to make a living in a town bloated with unemployed professionals. Some could only find work as window-cleaners and labourers, and these were the first to volunteer to fight in whatever army would take them when the second world war finally began. Others started shops on the Allenby Road, and attempted to introduce the chic styles of Berlin and Vienna to a country of pioneers who prided themselves on having drained malaria-ridden swamps.

Advertisements in the Palestine Post indicate the desperation of German ladies offering translation services and dancing lessons. Others still would import to their adopted homeland every progressive thought that had thrived in Germany before fascism: socialism, feminism, psychoanalysis, the new art and the new architecture. Above all, they were Modernists, and not only in the sense that they were living in one of the newest cities on earth, but also because they subscribed to an intellectual and artistic movement. It was for these unwilling immigrants that the White City, as it came to be called, was created.

On the one hand, there was a desperate need for housing, on the other a glut of unemployed architects trained at the Bauhaus in the International Style. Gradually, an entire Bauhaus city took shape along the shoreline, but subtly different from one that might have been built in Germany. Walls existed not so much for privacy but as barriers against the blinding Mediterranean light. Windows were narrow and recessed, each with a balcony shaded by the balcony above it so that, in those days before air- conditioning, the residents could sit out and catch the breeze from the shore. Later, they built on pilotis, slim columns that allowed the dust and dirt from the road to blow under the house instead of rushing at the doors and windows.

Excitement at this new architecture was at fever pitch. Families came with picnics at the weekend to sit on the street and watch the buildings under construction; the noisy work of drills and cement mixers, the hammering and the shouting in the hot air seemed all the more miraculous when they considered that 20 years before there was nothing there at all. For the many who were not ideological Zionists, it was not the dream of the Jewish homeland that excited them, but the notion of a brand new Jewish city, complete with library, art gallery and symphony orchestra. Such was the influx of musicians prohibited from playing for German orchestras at home that another saying became common in the 30s: "Anyone arriving from the boat without a violin case must be a pianist."

In contrast to the radio, which brought only bad news from home, Tel Aviv was the Jews' affirmation that there was a future, and one visibly growing before their eyes. Someone remarked that Allenby Street seemed to be getting longer even as he walked along it. In the 30s, a journalist wrote in a newspaper for German-speaking immigrants: "Not everyone can spend the whole of his natural life in a tragedy of sacrifice. For this majority of people there needs to be a Tel Aviv." If Jaffa was the world's oldest working port, the biblical city from where Jonah set sail for Tarsus on the ill-fated journey that would see him swallowed by the whale, Tel Aviv was the shock of the new, of the present tense and the future merging, moment by moment.

Modernism was a unified and universal concept, one that could be applied to art, architecture, music, literature, dress and even political thought. Modernism's mandate was to reject the past and reject the notion that one regime was as good as the next. Everything outmoded and outdated was to be abandoned: representational painting, buildings with decoration, symphonies with tunes, and literature steaming with purple prose. Understanding this, it is not surprising that the refugees from Germany were almost entirely uninterested in Arab culture. This was left to the British, and Miss Violet Barber, who established a folk museum in Jerusalem that collected specimens of local interest.

At their most enlightened, the Yekkes hoped that they could bring progressive ideas to the benighted peoples of the Middle East. They wanted to rid them of undemocratic practices, the subordination of women and feudal land rights, and open their eyes to 20th-century life. That this mission might be inherently colonial never occurred to them. They were unabashed elitists who believed wholeheartedly in the innate superiority of their ideas. Theirs was not a time when the plurality of cultures was respected.

Looking for Tel Aviv's past, I had spent a day with a woman I won't name, for she wasn't giving me an interview for publication. She was born in 1914, already a socialist and a feminist when, at the age of 19 in Berlin, she saw, in April 1933, the first window of a Jewish shop being smashed by Nazis and left Germany forever the following month. Today, she volunteers at a Jerusalem human-rights organisation, monitoring details of atrocities committed by the Israeli state. She votes in the general elections for Hadash, the Arab/Jewish communist party, and in the local elections for the Arab lists. "I am not a Zionist," she told me. When, in May 1948, Ben Gurion declared the state of Israel, she stood on the street and wept, knowing that she was now a citizen of a country she thought had no right to exist.

But when I asked her about what she read, she replied, only English literature, "the greatest in the world". Which authors? William Trevor and Jennifer Johnston. I pointed out that they were Irish. It was, she told me, the same thing. I asked her if she read Israel's great novelists, Amos Oz and David Grossman. "Oestjuden," she replied. I told her that I, the daughter of Polish and Russian shtetl immigrants, was also an Oestjude. She was surprised. I seemed to her quite cultivated. She was a snob and an elitist, and she embodied, on the one hand, a faultless list of left-wing anti-Zionist credentials, and on the other the mistake inherent in any deep-seated belief in the shining utopian future: that it must be imposed on others for their own good.

To the rest of the Jewish population of Palestine, the Yekkes were the object of suspicion: "Instead of a heart, they have a clock," was another saying. The absence of ardent Zionism was another strike against them. Had it not been for fascism, the Yekkes would have stayed comfortably in Berlin and Vienna, assimilated, loyal, quintessentially European in their outlook. Elsewhere, the political factions intent on ridding Palestine of the British were arming themselves for guerrilla war and had little time for art and orchestras. To them, Tel Aviv had an entirely different function.

Jerusalem was the headquarters of the British Mandate, it was a British-controlled town, in which the British had their own cultural stake, for it was the capital of another parallel country, the Holy Land. Jerusalem was stuffed full of sites of Christian pilgrimage and worship; Tel Aviv had nothing. One Mandate official described it as "gruesomely go-ahead".

A German guidebook still in use today speaks about the non-Jewish revulsion for the city: "In Tel Aviv... there is nothing capable of distracting you from the encounter with Jewishness, there are no sites of antiquity to visit, and no heroic land scapes, let alone any spectacular sites of pilgrimage which might put up some sort of cultural protective screen between you and the Jew."

Reading AH Sherman's Mandate Days, a collection of letters and diaries of British officials, one is struck by how their sympathies naturally seemed to lie with the Arab population, whose traditional virtues of courtesy, hospitality, good manners, a ritualised code of behaviour where much was left unsaid, and a conspicuous absence of women, chimed not only with public-school life but also with a prevailing admiration for the writings of TE Lawrence.

By contrast, the Jews were perceived as noisy, ill-mannered, over-talkative and bolshie in both senses of the word. The common complaint about present-day Israeli rudeness in contrast to the more likeable attributes of the Palestinians has some roots in the perseverance of this predilection. Tel Aviv was the stronghold of the new Jew, who saw no reason to practise subservience to Christians when they didn't have to. The new Jew prided himself or herself on speaking bluntly and to the point. Either they were experimenting with ideas that were never to catch on in England - dispensing with history, for example - or they were waging a covert war against the British. Neither was an attractive proposition to the Mandate civil servants and policemen, for whom a posting to Palestine had been viewed from home as an opportunity to walk in the footsteps of the Messiah.

Tel Aviv was the headquarters of the terrorists who were trying to drive the British out. When the second world war started, the city became the recreation centre for a variety of armies stationed in the Middle East. Officers' clubs mushroomed along the waterfront. When the war ended, and the campaign against British rule resumed, whole sections of Tel Aviv were deemed no-go areas for British troops. Bombs went off all over the place at unexpected hours. Kidnappings and curfews were commonplace.

I talked to Yasaf Nachmayas, a veteran of the Irgun, the Zionist terrorist organisation, who spoke reverently of Menachim Begin - the Irgun's leader and later one of Israel's most intransigent of right-wing prime ministers - as "my captain". Nachmayas came from a family that had been in Palestine for six generations, arriving there from Sarajevo at the end of the 18th century, he thought. He regarded the Arab population as the enemy, pure and simple. The two were fighting over the same bit of land, what could you do? He had no ill-feelings towards the Arabs, no agenda to "improve" them. I asked him what he made of the country he had fought for. His faced turned sad, very suddenly. "I didn't think there would be the intolerance," he replied.

In the aftermath of the bombing of the King David Hotel, in Jerusalem in 1946, the perpetrators fled to Tel Aviv. The history of the war against the British for the state is contained in the city's small museums, which document the exploits of each faction: Haganah, Irgun, Lehi. Even before the British pulled out, there was a tacit acceptance that they had lost the war in Tel Aviv. The police force was overwhelmingly Jewish and the terrorists had infiltrated it with a network of informers. Nachmayas' value to the Irgun was that he spoke fluent, accentless English and was used to impersonate British soldiers when the Irgun needed to get access to the enemies' arms storehouses. The Irgun radio transmitter was in his parents' apartment, somewhere in the White City.

In May 1948, when he was ready to declare the new state of Israel, after receiving the go-ahead from the United Nations, Ben Gurion looked for a building in which to make the announcement. He chose the art museum on Rothschild Boulevard, the first house to have been built in Tel Aviv, then owned by the city's first mayor, Meier Dizengoff, who in the 20s would ride out every morning on a white horse to inspect his domain. It is said that the museum's director was ordered to take down the paintings of nude women from the walls so as not to offend the rabbis and other puritanical members of the Zionist executive. The building is now a museum of the beginning of the Israeli state. If you ask the grumpy curator, he will let you watch an English-language film about the history of the city. You see footage of the news of the birth of Israel being received by a crowd in Times Square. Watching it, I thought of my parents in Liverpool, seated by their wireless in their honeymoon flat, hearing the same news. I thought of a Polish couple I had met in a café in Haifa, holding hands in the sunshine. They heard it in a Displaced Persons camp in Italy to which they had been moved from the work camp in Russia where they had met.

I had wanted to try to get inside the minds of those who lacked the benefit of hindsight; who thought that the recent past was a nightmare they could turn their backs on. I came to see that they never, in a million years, thought of themselves as thieves, as people who had stolen another people's country. In his book 1949: The First Israelis, the Israeli journalist Tom Segev writes of the extraordinary reunions that would take place in those early days - mothers bumping into sons they had not seen for 14 years, sisters reunited by newspaper advertisements. The heartrending radio programme, Who Recognises, Who Knows, sent out plaintive messages into the ether in case they might find a relative, not gassed or shot, but miraculously residing in a boxy white building on Frishman Street.

These were the days before the Holocaust industry. The past was a total nightmare, the present a grim struggle as the new state tried to feed and house and find work for the swollen population. The future was the only tense in which they could place their faith. But Tel Aviv never became a new Berlin.

Even in the 30s, another group of immigrants was arriving from Yemen: Jews who had never left the biblical lands. After 1948, and the beginning of the long wars with the Arab world, an influx of immigrants from North Africa, Iran, Iraq and Turkey introduced the Yekkes to Jews who were even further removed than the Oestjuden from their conception of what was European. These Sephardim saw themselves treated with disdain by the Ashkenazi, the European Jews who dominated left-of-centre political parties. Tel Aviv's Sephardi neighbourhoods are today strongholds of the Likud and Shas, the ultra-Orthodox religious party.

But none of this could account for the physical decline of the White City. One day, on my third visit in seven months, the manager of the bookshop in the Tel Aviv Museum of Art called me back when I had found out that the catalogue of the Bauhaus exhibition was no longer in print. "Wait," she called out. "You have no initiative." Why, she asked me, didn't I call the author of the book, Dr Michael Levin, a professor at the Bezalel art school in Jerusalem. When I rang him, he invited me to his house. He had been born in Jerusalem in 1943. We spoke for hours about Tel Aviv, and gradually its history was revealed to me.

He told me that, when he was a child, he asked his father why it was that in Tel Aviv they sat out in cafes in the evening (Tel Aviv today remains a city where a cafe is to be found on every street corner). The answer was in the nature of the architecture. A decree by the mayor of Jerusalem in the 20s had forced every new building to be constructed of Jerusalem stone, ideal for the climate, for it absorbed heat slowly. In Tel Aviv, they built with concrete. The sun oozed through the walls and by the evening the brand new apartments, those supposed machines for modern living, were like hothouses, driving people out of doors. And where to go, asked the Yekkes, if not to cafes that they nostalgically remembered from Berlin?

This was one way in which the faulty architecture had influenced the lifestyle of the new city, but idealism was also to be the source of its destruction. When the Yekkes arrived in Tel Aviv, some had managed to evade the Nazi stripping of their financial assets. Facing unemployment, they had a sum of money, which they invested by commissioning the construction of an apartment building. They would reside in one flat and live on the rents from the others. But at the end of the war, the municipal council passed rent-control acts and suddenly the owners found that they could barely live off their receipts, let alone maintain the buildings that were already corroding in the salt air from the sea. Almost nothing was understood about long-term maintenance, Dr Levin told me. So the long decline began, barely a decade after the White City rose from the sand.

Tel Aviv today is a divided city. Ha Yarkon Street, where once Arthur Koestler was kept awake by noisy gramophones from the officers' clubs along the shore, is no longer open to the sea. A row of five-star hotels, constructed in the 60s and 70s, acts as a barrier, blocking the breeze. Pink condominiums overshadow what remains of the White City. The focus is on the marina and the esplanade, where you can watch the early-morning joggers take their exercise. Many of them work in the skyscrapers of the stock exchange, built over the Arab neighbourhood of Manshieh that was destroyed in the 1948 war. By the bus station, there is a shanty-town of shacks, a little city of illegal immigrants from the Third World to whom Tel Aviv is also a dream: not of the first Jewish city for 2,000 years, but of an opportunity, like any other, for a new life in a prosperous country.

Just as I was finishing my novel, something new appeared on the Amazon search engine when once again I typed in the words Tel Aviv. It was a book called Tel Aviv: From Dream To Reality, by a man called Joachim Schlor, and published by Reaktion Books. Schlor is a German non-Jew and he, too, had fallen in love with Tel Aviv. "No feature of special interest arrests the eye," the book begins. "Yet the streets themselves are beautiful, and it is only by wandering through them again and again, curious, observant and aiming for nowhere in particular, that one can truly get to know Tel Aviv." And on the next page I read: "I wish that more of the many people in Western Europe who engage in debate about Israel and the Middle Eastern conflict would make contact with this contemporary city, would question it and listen to it."

Schlor's book, not mine, is the history Tel Aviv has been waiting for. Yet we begin from the same starting point, that in that city which still has inhabitants who are older than itself, lie the paradoxes of many things: of Modernism, of Jewish identity, of political idealism, as well as of the Israeli state. To be a new Jew was to be a paradox: the people who instead of a land had had a story, a narrative of their existence, had decided that it was only the future that counted. They were fatally wrong. One of the tragedies of Israel is not just what was done to the Palestinians, but what the Jews did to themselves: they wanted to rid themselves of the memories of the diaspora. "They crave," wrote one observer quoted by Schlor, "to get away from their past and to put out of their mind all the marks of indignity, all the stigmata of shame, all the yellow patches that Jew-hatred has ever devised. They even crave to put out of their mind part of their own mind."

Still Tel Aviv enchants me. The present urban mess that is the city speaks for the country. Absorbed in euphoria, they failed to see the reality as it was... but the road they took was the road they believed to be right, and they followed it with wholehearted confidence and belief in their cause. For that, they are to be envied."
