fields.bodyText: Two years ago exactly, I fell in love with a city no one falls in love with. I had gone to Israel to write about the 50th anniversary of the country. I spent the first 24 hours in Tel Aviv holed up in a concrete shoebox of a hotel on the seashore. I stood on my balcony and looked out and what I saw was a dump, a monstrosity, a 60s council estate writ large. But on the second day, drinking my breakfast coffee in the March sunshine, I noticed the curved lines of the dingy apartment buildings along Ha Yarkon Street and something stirred in my memory. I saw that another city was sticking out like the bones of the dead from the ground. Before my eyes an entire Bauhaus town was assembling itself: flat-roofed boxes that had once been white, dazzling white, under the Mediterranean sun; buildings like machines constructed of glass and concrete; clean, uncluttered facades to cleanse the eye; two buildings facing each other on a corner like a pair of ships' prows. The houses now were stained and derelict, overgrown with oleander and hibiscus bushes; palm trees had taken root in the spaces between the lots. All the trash of city living - peeling stucco, air-conditioning vents, skips, electrical cables, natural gas tanks and street signs - obscured the memory that, 60 years ago, Tel Aviv had been conceived as an experiment in modern living by the socialists and other political ideologues who found themselves washed up on the very edge of the Middle East. Tel Aviv still contains the largest collection of Bauhaus architecture in the world: 6,500 buildings. It is a monument to the age of Modernism. Who designed and constructed these places? Who lived in them? I was avid to know and determined to find out. I went to the Tel Aviv Municipal Museum. Closed two years ago. I went to the Art Museum, where tours of the Bauhaus architecture of the city were advertised in my guide book. Discontinued. An exhibition on the Bauhaus architecture of Tel Aviv had taken place in the 80s and a catalogue had been published. It was out of print. If you type the word Jerusalem into the online bookseller Amazon's search engine, you'll get 495 hits. Type in Tel Aviv and you get 10, only four of which are in print - of those, one is a map and another the proceedings of an astronomy conference. I asked in Steimatsky, the Israeli bookstore chain, if they could recommend novels set in Tel Aviv. A young assistant said that he could think of none. David Grossman and Amos Oz were rooted in Jerusalem. The people of Tel Aviv were suffering collective amnesia about their city's history. By this time I was sure that I would write a novel set in this mysterious city that appeared to have no memory of its own past. Months later, I came to see that Tel Aviv was a metaphor. It stood for the flawed aspirations of its founders, who in 1909 assembled on a sand-dune north of the Arab town of Jaffa and dreamed of creating the first Jewish metropolis since biblical times. They were turning their backs against the past towards the future. They were trying to reinvent themselves for the 20th century in a longing much bigger than political nationalism. In building the new city, they wanted to rebuild the new Jew from the ground up, but in so doing they had built into their vision an abandonment of their history. The state of the Bauhaus city today speaks both of the dreams and of the in-built failures of Modernism. It took months of tramping the streets and examining the archives of the Palestine Post (the forerunner to the Jerusalem Post) to discover what the inhabitants of the city themselves could not tell me. Tel Aviv has its origins in a decision in 1887 to build a Jewish suburb just outside Jaffa, in a neighbourhood called Neve Tsedek. Small, mainly one-storey houses were constructed in a Mediterranean style. By 1909, they had overflowed the new area and on April 11 a group of 66 families, calling themselves the Achusath Bayit housing association, gathered on the sand-dunes of what was then known as Sheikh Jibalis Vineyard, after the owner from whom the land had been purchased. They were in buoyant mood because they had just heard news from Odessa that Chaim Nachman Bialik, the most celebrated Hebrew poet of his day, was asking to join them. The group's leader, Meier Dizengoff, later to become the fledgling town's first mayor, organised a lot-drawing ceremony, using 60 pebbles bearing the names of each family and 60 more pebbles marked with the number of the building plot. (What happened to the other six families is unrecorded.) After a long discussion about the name of the new town, they settled on Tel Aviv, the Hebrew translation of Altneuland, a utopian novel by the Zionist leader and journalist Theodor Herzl, whose coverage of the Dreyfus trial in France had led to the founding of the Zionist Congress. Altneuland meant old and new land. Tel means an excavated mound, signifying the remains of old settlements; aviv is the first sprouting of new wheat. The construction work was carried out by Arab labourers and supplies were transported by camel, but the founders were already conceiving Tel Aviv as the opposite of Jaffa. Where Jaffa had history and ancient stones, Tel Aviv would be brash, new, a work-in-progress. To one observer, Jaffa seemed a dozen centuries and 10,000 miles away. During the first world war, the population of the still embryonic city was evacuated and the return began only after General Allenby (after whom the principal street would be named) re-took it at the head of a victorious British Army. The earliest architects came from Russia, and their style was influenced not only by what they had left behind, but also by the fashion for Orientalism that swept the West in the aftermath of the opening of the tomb of Tutankhamun. Until 1925, there was no development plan. Tel Aviv was mushrooming with what one observer described as "a shocking mixture of forms and plans and a fray of shoving, queue-jumping wills which personify the immense revolution that has taken place on the sand-dunes". A German visitor in 1924 wrote that "all aesthetically-minded people are beside themselves with horror at the ugliness and tastelessness and banality... but I am impressed by the pace of things here, by the colossal vitality which this town has about it." In the 30s, suddenly, in place of random development, of buildings commissioned by individuals to suit their own overblown and untutored fantasies, there was real urgency about housing. The population of Zionist pioneers - part of the turn-of-the century pogrom emigration that would take millions of Jews from eastern Europe to America - were joined by another and very different band of immigrants. In Tel Aviv in those days, there was a common saying you could hear in the cafes along the Allenby Road: "I didn't come here from conviction, I came here from Germany." The speakers were the Yekkes, the German Jews who, forced out of their country by fascism, saw cities such as London as the desired place of their exodus but could only get visas to Palestine, regarded by many as a primitive Oriental dump populated, apart from Arabs, by Oestjuden - Jews from the east, Poland and Russia. The Oestjuden, for their part, gave the German Jews their nickname, the Yekkes, because it was both the Hebrew word for jacket that the formal German Jews never took off, even in the stifling heat of the summer, and because it was an acronym for the words Yehudi Kashe Havanah - Jews who don't understand. What was it that they could not comprehend? Many of the Yekkes were far from being Zionists. They were in Palestine on sufferance and determined that, come what may, they would do their best to re-create on the edge of the desert a new Berlin. They were not the scum of the east European shtetls, rabbis at best, beetroot farmers at worst, but saw themselves as the Weimar Republic in exile. Many were businessmen, doctors and lawyers who struggled to make a living in a town bloated with unemployed professionals. Some could only find work as window-cleaners and labourers, and these were the first to volunteer to fight in whatever army would take them when the second world war finally began. Others started shops on the Allenby Road, and attempted to introduce the chic styles of Berlin and Vienna to a country of pioneers who prided themselves on having drained malaria-ridden swamps. Advertisements in the Palestine Post indicate the desperation of German ladies offering translation services and dancing lessons. Others still would import to their adopted homeland every progressive thought that had thrived in Germany before fascism: socialism, feminism, psychoanalysis, the new art and the new architecture. Above all, they were Modernists, and not only in the sense that they were living in one of the newest cities on earth, but also because they subscribed to an intellectual and artistic movement. It was for these unwilling immigrants that the White City, as it came to be called, was created. On the one hand, there was a desperate need for housing, on the other a glut of unemployed architects trained at the Bauhaus in the International Style. Gradually, an entire Bauhaus city took shape along the shoreline, but subtly different from one that might have been built in Germany. Walls existed not so much for privacy but as barriers against the blinding Mediterranean light. Windows were narrow and recessed, each with a balcony shaded by the balcony above it so that, in those days before air- conditioning, the residents could sit out and catch the breeze from the shore. Later, they built on pilotis, slim columns that allowed the dust and dirt from the road to blow under the house instead of rushing at the doors and windows. Excitement at this new architecture was at fever pitch. Families came with picnics at the weekend to sit on the street and watch the buildings under construction; the noisy work of drills and cement mixers, the hammering and the shouting in the hot air seemed all the more miraculous when they considered that 20 years before there was nothing there at all. For the many who were not ideological Zionists, it was not the dream of the Jewish homeland that excited them, but the notion of a brand new Jewish city, complete with library, art gallery and symphony orchestra. Such was the influx of musicians prohibited from playing for German orchestras at home that another saying became common in the 30s: "Anyone arriving from the boat without a violin case must be a pianist." In contrast to the radio, which brought only bad news from home, Tel Aviv was the Jews' affirmation that there was a future, and one visibly growing before their eyes. Someone remarked that Allenby Street seemed to be getting longer even as he walked along it. In the 30s, a journalist wrote in a newspaper for German-speaking immigrants: "Not everyone can spend the whole of his natural life in a tragedy of sacrifice. For this majority of people there needs to be a Tel Aviv." If Jaffa was the world's oldest working port, the biblical city from where Jonah set sail for Tarsus on the ill-fated journey that would see him swallowed by the whale, Tel Aviv was the shock of the new, of the present tense and the future merging, moment by moment. Modernism was a unified and universal concept, one that could be applied to art, architecture, music, literature, dress and even political thought. Modernism's mandate was to reject the past and reject the notion that one regime was as good as the next. Everything outmoded and outdated was to be abandoned: representational painting, buildings with decoration, symphonies with tunes, and literature steaming with purple prose. Understanding this, it is not surprising that the refugees from Germany were almost entirely uninterested in Arab culture. This was left to the British, and Miss Violet Barber, who established a folk museum in Jerusalem that collected specimens of local interest. At their most enlightened, the Yekkes hoped that they could bring progressive ideas to the benighted peoples of the Middle East. They wanted to rid them of undemocratic practices, the subordination of women and feudal land rights, and open their eyes to 20th-century life. That this mission might be inherently colonial never occurred to them. They were unabashed elitists who believed wholeheartedly in the innate superiority of their ideas. Theirs was not a time when the plurality of cultures was respected. Looking for Tel Aviv's past, I had spent a day with a woman I won't name, for she wasn't giving me an interview for publication. She was born in 1914, already a socialist and a feminist when, at the age of 19 in Berlin, she saw, in April 1933, the first window of a Jewish shop being smashed by Nazis and left Germany forever the following month. Today, she volunteers at a Jerusalem human-rights organisation, monitoring details of atrocities committed by the Israeli state. She votes in the general elections for Hadash, the Arab/Jewish communist party, and in the local elections for the Arab lists. "I am not a Zionist," she told me. When, in May 1948, Ben Gurion declared the state of Israel, she stood on the street and wept, knowing that she was now a citizen of a country she thought had no right to exist. But when I asked her about what she read, she replied, only English literature, "the greatest in the world". Which authors? William Trevor and Jennifer Johnston. I pointed out that they were Irish. It was, she told me, the same thing. I asked her if she read Israel's great novelists, Amos Oz and David Grossman. "Oestjuden," she replied. I told her that I, the daughter of Polish and Russian shtetl immigrants, was also an Oestjude. She was surprised. I seemed to her quite cultivated. She was a snob and an elitist, and she embodied, on the one hand, a faultless list of left-wing anti-Zionist credentials, and on the other the mistake inherent in any deep-seated belief in the shining utopian future: that it must be imposed on others for their own good. To the rest of the Jewish population of Palestine, the Yekkes were the object of suspicion: "Instead of a heart, they have a clock," was another saying. The absence of ardent Zionism was another strike against them. Had it not been for fascism, the Yekkes would have stayed comfortably in Berlin and Vienna, assimilated, loyal, quintessentially European in their outlook. Elsewhere, the political factions intent on ridding Palestine of the British were arming themselves for guerrilla war and had little time for art and orchestras. To them, Tel Aviv had an entirely different function. Jerusalem was the headquarters of the British Mandate, it was a British-controlled town, in which the British had their own cultural stake, for it was the capital of another parallel country, the Holy Land. Jerusalem was stuffed full of sites of Christian pilgrimage and worship; Tel Aviv had nothing. One Mandate official described it as "gruesomely go-ahead". A German guidebook still in use today speaks about the non-Jewish revulsion for the city: "In Tel Aviv... there is nothing capable of distracting you from the encounter with Jewishness, there are no sites of antiquity to visit, and no heroic land scapes, let alone any spectacular sites of pilgrimage which might put up some sort of cultural protective screen between you and the Jew." Reading AH Sherman's Mandate Days, a collection of letters and diaries of British officials, one is struck by how their sympathies naturally seemed to lie with the Arab population, whose traditional virtues of courtesy, hospitality, good manners, a ritualised code of behaviour where much was left unsaid, and a conspicuous absence of women, chimed not only with public-school life but also with a prevailing admiration for the writings of TE Lawrence. By contrast, the Jews were perceived as noisy, ill-mannered, over-talkative and bolshie in both senses of the word. The common complaint about present-day Israeli rudeness in contrast to the more likeable attributes of the Palestinians has some roots in the perseverance of this predilection. Tel Aviv was the stronghold of the new Jew, who saw no reason to practise subservience to Christians when they didn't have to. The new Jew prided himself or herself on speaking bluntly and to the point. Either they were experimenting with ideas that were never to catch on in England - dispensing with history, for example - or they were waging a covert war against the British. Neither was an attractive proposition to the Mandate civil servants and policemen, for whom a posting to Palestine had been viewed from home as an opportunity to walk in the footsteps of the Messiah. Tel Aviv was the headquarters of the terrorists who were trying to drive the British out. When the second world war started, the city became the recreation centre for a variety of armies stationed in the Middle East. Officers' clubs mushroomed along the waterfront. When the war ended, and the campaign against British rule resumed, whole sections of Tel Aviv were deemed no-go areas for British troops. Bombs went off all over the place at unexpected hours. Kidnappings and curfews were commonplace. I talked to Yasaf Nachmayas, a veteran of the Irgun, the Zionist terrorist organisation, who spoke reverently of Menachim Begin - the Irgun's leader and later one of Israel's most intransigent of right-wing prime ministers - as "my captain". Nachmayas came from a family that had been in Palestine for six generations, arriving there from Sarajevo at the end of the 18th century, he thought. He regarded the Arab population as the enemy, pure and simple. The two were fighting over the same bit of land, what could you do? He had no ill-feelings towards the Arabs, no agenda to "improve" them. I asked him what he made of the country he had fought for. His faced turned sad, very suddenly. "I didn't think there would be the intolerance," he replied. In the aftermath of the bombing of the King David Hotel, in Jerusalem in 1946, the perpetrators fled to Tel Aviv. The history of the war against the British for the state is contained in the city's small museums, which document the exploits of each faction: Haganah, Irgun, Lehi. Even before the British pulled out, there was a tacit acceptance that they had lost the war in Tel Aviv. The police force was overwhelmingly Jewish and the terrorists had infiltrated it with a network of informers. Nachmayas' value to the Irgun was that he spoke fluent, accentless English and was used to impersonate British soldiers when the Irgun needed to get access to the enemies' arms storehouses. The Irgun radio transmitter was in his parents' apartment, somewhere in the White City. In May 1948, when he was ready to declare the new state of Israel, after receiving the go-ahead from the United Nations, Ben Gurion looked for a building in which to make the announcement. He chose the art museum on Rothschild Boulevard, the first house to have been built in Tel Aviv, then owned by the city's first mayor, Meier Dizengoff, who in the 20s would ride out every morning on a white horse to inspect his domain. It is said that the museum's director was ordered to take down the paintings of nude women from the walls so as not to offend the rabbis and other puritanical members of the Zionist executive. The building is now a museum of the beginning of the Israeli state. If you ask the grumpy curator, he will let you watch an English-language film about the history of the city. You see footage of the news of the birth of Israel being received by a crowd in Times Square. Watching it, I thought of my parents in Liverpool, seated by their wireless in their honeymoon flat, hearing the same news. I thought of a Polish couple I had met in a café in Haifa, holding hands in the sunshine. They heard it in a Displaced Persons camp in Italy to which they had been moved from the work camp in Russia where they had met. I had wanted to try to get inside the minds of those who lacked the benefit of hindsight; who thought that the recent past was a nightmare they could turn their backs on. I came to see that they never, in a million years, thought of themselves as thieves, as people who had stolen another people's country. In his book 1949: The First Israelis, the Israeli journalist Tom Segev writes of the extraordinary reunions that would take place in those early days - mothers bumping into sons they had not seen for 14 years, sisters reunited by newspaper advertisements. The heartrending radio programme, Who Recognises, Who Knows, sent out plaintive messages into the ether in case they might find a relative, not gassed or shot, but miraculously residing in a boxy white building on Frishman Street. These were the days before the Holocaust industry. The past was a total nightmare, the present a grim struggle as the new state tried to feed and house and find work for the swollen population. The future was the only tense in which they could place their faith. But Tel Aviv never became a new Berlin. Even in the 30s, another group of immigrants was arriving from Yemen: Jews who had never left the biblical lands. After 1948, and the beginning of the long wars with the Arab world, an influx of immigrants from North Africa, Iran, Iraq and Turkey introduced the Yekkes to Jews who were even further removed than the Oestjuden from their conception of what was European. These Sephardim saw themselves treated with disdain by the Ashkenazi, the European Jews who dominated left-of-centre political parties. Tel Aviv's Sephardi neighbourhoods are today strongholds of the Likud and Shas, the ultra-Orthodox religious party. But none of this could account for the physical decline of the White City. One day, on my third visit in seven months, the manager of the bookshop in the Tel Aviv Museum of Art called me back when I had found out that the catalogue of the Bauhaus exhibition was no longer in print. "Wait," she called out. "You have no initiative." Why, she asked me, didn't I call the author of the book, Dr Michael Levin, a professor at the Bezalel art school in Jerusalem. When I rang him, he invited me to his house. He had been born in Jerusalem in 1943. We spoke for hours about Tel Aviv, and gradually its history was revealed to me. He told me that, when he was a child, he asked his father why it was that in Tel Aviv they sat out in cafes in the evening (Tel Aviv today remains a city where a cafe is to be found on every street corner). The answer was in the nature of the architecture. A decree by the mayor of Jerusalem in the 20s had forced every new building to be constructed of Jerusalem stone, ideal for the climate, for it absorbed heat slowly. In Tel Aviv, they built with concrete. The sun oozed through the walls and by the evening the brand new apartments, those supposed machines for modern living, were like hothouses, driving people out of doors. And where to go, asked the Yekkes, if not to cafes that they nostalgically remembered from Berlin? This was one way in which the faulty architecture had influenced the lifestyle of the new city, but idealism was also to be the source of its destruction. When the Yekkes arrived in Tel Aviv, some had managed to evade the Nazi stripping of their financial assets. Facing unemployment, they had a sum of money, which they invested by commissioning the construction of an apartment building. They would reside in one flat and live on the rents from the others. But at the end of the war, the municipal council passed rent-control acts and suddenly the owners found that they could barely live off their receipts, let alone maintain the buildings that were already corroding in the salt air from the sea. Almost nothing was understood about long-term maintenance, Dr Levin told me. So the long decline began, barely a decade after the White City rose from the sand. Tel Aviv today is a divided city. Ha Yarkon Street, where once Arthur Koestler was kept awake by noisy gramophones from the officers' clubs along the shore, is no longer open to the sea. A row of five-star hotels, constructed in the 60s and 70s, acts as a barrier, blocking the breeze. Pink condominiums overshadow what remains of the White City. The focus is on the marina and the esplanade, where you can watch the early-morning joggers take their exercise. Many of them work in the skyscrapers of the stock exchange, built over the Arab neighbourhood of Manshieh that was destroyed in the 1948 war. By the bus station, there is a shanty-town of shacks, a little city of illegal immigrants from the Third World to whom Tel Aviv is also a dream: not of the first Jewish city for 2,000 years, but of an opportunity, like any other, for a new life in a prosperous country. Just as I was finishing my novel, something new appeared on the Amazon search engine when once again I typed in the words Tel Aviv. It was a book called Tel Aviv: From Dream To Reality, by a man called Joachim Schlor, and published by Reaktion Books. Schlor is a German non-Jew and he, too, had fallen in love with Tel Aviv. "No feature of special interest arrests the eye," the book begins. "Yet the streets themselves are beautiful, and it is only by wandering through them again and again, curious, observant and aiming for nowhere in particular, that one can truly get to know Tel Aviv." And on the next page I read: "I wish that more of the many people in Western Europe who engage in debate about Israel and the Middle Eastern conflict would make contact with this contemporary city, would question it and listen to it." Schlor's book, not mine, is the history Tel Aviv has been waiting for. Yet we begin from the same starting point, that in that city which still has inhabitants who are older than itself, lie the paradoxes of many things: of Modernism, of Jewish identity, of political idealism, as well as of the Israeli state. To be a new Jew was to be a paradox: the people who instead of a land had had a story, a narrative of their existence, had decided that it was only the future that counted. They were fatally wrong. One of the tragedies of Israel is not just what was done to the Palestinians, but what the Jews did to themselves: they wanted to rid themselves of the memories of the diaspora. "They crave," wrote one observer quoted by Schlor, "to get away from their past and to put out of their mind all the marks of indignity, all the stigmata of shame, all the yellow patches that Jew-hatred has ever devised. They even crave to put out of their mind part of their own mind." Still Tel Aviv enchants me. The present urban mess that is the city speaks for the country. Like Israel, it turned out, in Tom Segev's words, "less enlightened, less idealistic, less altruistic and less Ashkenazi than the [founders] had hoped... the future would promise neither justice for all, nor equality for all, nor peace. Perhaps the first Israelis never recognised this. Absorbed in euphoria, they failed to see the reality as it was... but the road they took was the road they believed to be right, and they followed it with wholehearted confidence and belief in their cause. For that, they are to be envied." All dreams are chaotic, seldom peaceful and have a tendency sometimes to turn into nightmares. But if you walk Tel Aviv's streets and listen to its people, you catch a glimpse of what the ghosts thought they were building

fields.headline: The net addict
fields.trailText: My health
fields.body:
I hate my GP. According to him, nothing is ever wrong with me. It's only thanks to the net that I can check my symptoms properly. At www.drkoop.com, there's even an alphabetic disease finder: Aids, Allergies, Alzheimer's, Arthritis...

You learn about everything. My doctor hates that I know those difficult words he throws at me for £60 a visit (I adore the NHS, but I simply don't have time to use it). During one of my surfing evenings, I came across www. cromwell-hospital.co.uk. It's fabulous: they offer transoesophaegal echochardiograms, mastalgia treatment and the Helicobacter Pylori Breath Test Clinic, all starred NEW! I thought of having the breath test (I floss to death, but I'm always terrified of offending somebody), but then I came across its new 'Softlight' hair-removal service, done by nurses using lasers. Marika was in a hurry when she did my last bikini wax, so she really mangled me. I thought of teaching her a lesson by permanent removal of her source of work, but I couldn't bear the notion of a laser so close to my most sensitive area (young Sean Connery in Goldfinger flashed through my mind). Besides, Marika always tells me what her other clients are up to; even the net doesn't do that.

'You are a hypochondriac,' says my mother. 'Get yourself a man and you'll be fine.' It's amazing that someone who devoured the whole Virago list when I was a child has ended up finding peace in serial marriage, the Daily Mail and God (the latter through a new church that has opened in a failed PC shop near her). I decided to check angelfire.com, a site on hypochondria that I found through the Mamma search engine. This reassured me that I am perfectly normal. And there's a messageboard: I've started exchanging emails with Alan, who also suffers from migraine. Who knows...

fields.headline: Spadework
fields.trailText: Hot clips | Best foot forward
fields.body:
Hot clips
It's painful seeing a plant getting bent out of shape because it's tied too tight to a stake - but it's also easy never quite to not get around to doing anything about it. Plantklips (left) were first used in the vineyards of Australia, and are designed to fix plants to any thickness or shape of wire or stake. They can be moved easily as the plants grow, are suitable for roses, tomatoes, climbers and saplings, and cost £4.50 for 10 (green or clear), from Garden Images, 01564 794035.

Best foot forward
You don't need a huge garden to grow veg: 4ft-square will produce a surprising amount if you follow the method devised by Mel Bartholomew in the US. Vegetables are grown in 16, 1ft-square blocks. For more tips, Colin Shaw is running a workshop at the Henry Doubleday Research Assocation's Ryton Organic Gardens, near Coventry, on March 23, from 10am-12.30pm, and again on April 8. Admission, £15 (HDRA members, £12); 02476 308211 for details.

Plant of the week
Flowers appear from mid-summer to mid-autumn on Clematis texensis 'Gravetye Beauty' - small, delicate, and a vibrant vermilion colour. The plant is a scrambler, doing well climbing over other shrubs or a plant support. It needs to be planted soon and kept well-watered through spring and summer. Readers can buy one of these plants for the special price of £17.99 (inc UK p&p). Plants are supplied in two-litre pots and come with full instructions. Due to very limited availability of this variety, we are unfortunately only able to supply the first 200 orders received. To order, send a cheque or postal order, payable to Thompson & Morgan (Young Plants) Ltd, to: This Week's Offer, Dept GUC29, PO Box 89, St Leonards-on-Sea, East Sussex TN38 9ZX, or call 0870 8701361 with credit-card details. Last orders March 21. Usual delivery is 28 days.

Time to...
Mend fences and trelliswork before plants start shinning up them. It's worth buying galvanised nails and screws (they don't rust); and remember, if you're thinking of painting fences with creosote, how much plants hate the stuff. Less toxic is this range of chalky-coloured, water-based paints for outdoor use, from Casa, 01296 770139.

fields.headline: Weekend garden
fields.standfirst: Which annuals to sow for the coming summer? Christopher Lloyd has some truly brilliant ideas
fields.trailText: Which annuals to sow for the coming summer? Christopher Lloyd has some truly brilliant ideas
fields.body:
There is always so much to be said about what seeds one might plan to sow this year that it is difficult to know where to start. I went back to calendula, the pot marigold, last year and did not regret it. Although it is a hardy annual, we sowed seeds in March under glass and brought the plants on quickly in individual pots so that they were ready to follow spring bedding by mid-May.

I like bright-orange, fully double marigolds, myself, and the Extra Selected strain of 'Radio' served us well. That combines and contrasts nicely with love-in-a-mist. Instead of using the familiar blue 'Miss Jekyll' strain of Nigella damascena , we went for the purplish N. hispanica , which has striking flowers over quite a long June period. We raised this the same way as the calendula.

This kind of bedding gives you a few weeks but then needs a follow-on. One suggestion I would make is the bedding collarette dahlia 'Dandy', which is single but with an inner circle of half petals, often in a different colour. This is an intriguing arrangement. If you sowed the dahlia under cold glass in the first week of May and grew the seedlings on in one-litre pots, by the first week in July they'd have made nice bushy plants that are almost ready to flower. A late sowing of a cold-sensitive subject such as this gets over the danger of it being set back by cold nights in its early stages of development. Naturally, you'll want them to be well hardened off by planting-out time.

An annual that responds well to a late-ish sowing is the spider flower, Cleome pungens . When bruised, the plant has a strong, mustard-oil smell and, be warned, is attractive to the caterpillars of the cabbage white butterfly. But, if well-grown, single plants have almost the habit of a sturdy shrub, with a central leader to 1.5m. The palmate leaves are handsome and the dense flower heads continue to perform without need of dead-heading for three months. They do tend to wilt somewhat in strong sunshine, so a half-shaded position is ideal. There are separate colour strains available in white, pink or rosy purple, or a mixture of the three, which are all compatible colours. But I often want to combine the white one with orange tithonias. A mixture that included pink would not be suitable.

The one thing this annual insists on is to be grown well and without a check. A late-April sowing will be early enough. Get the seedlings into individual pots and, if they need to be kept waiting, pot them on so that they never starve. Each plant should have the support of a single, strong cane with a single tie to its main stem.

An annual planting that I have made twice now, and mean to repeat again this year, is a pretty even mixture, 0.3m tall, of Helenium amarum and Gaillardia 'Red Plume'. You rarely see the helenium, which has very bright green, linear foliage (each plant is the better for a little brushwood support) and a long succession of small, yellow, typical helenium daisies. The gaillardia, basically another daisy, is fully double and a rich shade of deep, brownish red. August to October is their season.

The everlasting Helichrysum 'Dargan Hill Monarch' is a small shrub (0.5m) that can be grown from seed or cuttings. There is a long succession of its papery yellow daisies held above rather greyish-green foliage. It has a season lasting till the first frosts.

There are three annual climbers that make wonderful fillers to clamber over other plants. The black-eyed Susan, Thunbergia alata , comes in three separate colours or a mixture of the three. Always, unless you have a prejudice against the colour, go for the orange strain, which is its natural colour and the most effective. The flower is rounded, spreading out from a tube, and has a black centre. Mina lobata has short chains of tubular flowers whose colouring changes as the flowers age, from white, through yellow to orange. It is an unusual-looking climber. I have seen it making a column up peasticks, but I like it over Cotoneaster horizontalis , or over a rose or the dying stems of alstroemerias or delphiniums. It has many uses.

And Rhodochiton atrosanguineus makes long trails of dangling purple blossom with a seemingly unending season. The persistent calyx is like a lampshade. You get the longest flowering season from this if you sow it in September, pot the seedlings individually and over-winter them under just-frost-free glass, planting out in May. You will still get decent results by sowing now.

Another annual, or short-lived perennial, whose seeds it might be best to keep by for an August sowing so as to get strong, bushy plants to bed out spring 2001, is the sweet scabious, Scabiosa atropurpurea (1m). I like this in its deep maroon 'Ace Of Spades' strain, in which the pin-cushion of white stamens shows up in delightful contrast - a good cut flower for late summer

fields.headline: Count your chickens...
fields.trailText: The knowledge
fields.body:
The subject
Gallus domesticus . Native to Asia. Primary role: cheap protein (we buy around 500,000 tonnes a year). Secondary role: emblem of the ills of modern food production.

The basics
When chickens were reared in spacious farmyards, they were an expensive treat. Modern 'broilers' are raised in crowded barns and slaughtered at 42 days, long before they have a chance to develop any flavour. Which wouldn't happen, anyway, because they don't exercise. And they're bred to grow fast. Flavour? Texture? Who cares?

The details
Aka the good news: it's getting easier to buy a decent chicken. Widely available options include organic, corn-fed and several options sheltering under the free-range umbrella. Look for relatively scrawny legs, indicating an active life, and a breast that's peaked rather than plump. (Plump usually means soft, fatty flesh.) The best news: in a tasting of 10 'premium' birds from leading supermarkets, the Knowledge found nary a bad one. And at prices ranging from £2.95/kg to £5.49/kg - though Gallus gloriosus usually comes from Plenty o' Pounds.

Joint winners, both Gallic Galli: Janzé 'Label Rouge' (£4.15/kg, Waitrose) and corn-fed Loué 'Label Rouge' (£4.29/kg, Sainsbury's). Best of British: M&S Free-Range Organic (£5.25/kg). The French birds had the upper claw. Kelly Turkeys, champ of that other bird, is now selling chickens that have earned some rave reviews. Warning: corn-fed chickens may be as insipid as the industrial version, despite their Simpson-like yellow glow. Warning: organic doesn't always mean tiptop taste.

Where to buy
No, the question is how much to pay. Answer: a lot. Look around, ask searching questions, and if at first you don't succeed, try, try again. Kelly Chickens: 01245 223581 email: info@kelly-turkeys.com. Be prepared for prices that'll make you squawk, and quality that'll make you purr.

The easy way out
Unlikely. The best birds are sold whole. Learn to use a boning knife, for chrissake!

fields.headline: Regional pride
fields.standfirst: The Provencal tian may seem just a simple vegetable bake. But, says Elisabeth Luard, it's a whole lot more important than that
fields.trailText: The Provencal tian may seem just a simple vegetable bake. But, says Elisabeth Luard, it's a whole lot more important than that
fields.body:
The tian of Provence - a dish of vegetables cooked in a shallow earthenware terrine - belongs to that venerable band of one-pot meals that takes its name from the vessel in which it cooks. Three things distinguish the tian from all other cooking pots: first, it must be rounded and of a diameter that reflects the requirements of the household; next, it should be glazed within, and unglazed without; finally, the edge of the dish must be no higher than will accommodate the ingredients in a single layer.

As befits a peasant dish, the ingredients for a tian are as variable as you please, being dependent on what could be grown or gathered close to home. The traditional favourite is chard - "blettes" in French, "blea" in the Provençal - which thrives where lesser spinaches must wilt; it is a vegetable so popular in the canton of Nice that the inhabitants were known in less delicate times as "caga-blea" (shit-chard). In their proper season, aubergines, onions, peppers, tomatoes, courgettes, artichokes - the classic combinations of the Mediterranean kitchen - are also ideal for a tian. Olive oil provides the necessary richness, garlic and herbs the essential flavouring. For substance, a handful of rice, or a ladleful of chickpeas saved from a soup, might be added.

For pleasure and feast days, the tian wears a topping of breadcrumbs and cheese, crisped under the grill (in the old days, it would be sent to the baker to cook in the residual heat of his ovens). For strength, eggs are stirred in to set with the juices; or a bit of meat or poultry from the Sunday pot-au-feu; or a layer of Cantal or Gruyère cheese, to melt in the middle. By the sea, tians are served with a side dish of fresh sardines or anchovies; in the hills, with "mountain-fish" - salt cod. The whole is served without fuss or flourish in its own dish, as a first course or the main event, depending on its composition.

Such dishes, simple and adaptable, are not so much recipes as reactions, obeying the rules of necessity rather than conscious choice. Ideally, all ingredients should undergo all cooking processes in the same dish - and no cheating. Well, maybe a little; in fact, as much as you please. The preliminary frying can easily be completed in an iron pan rather than by placing the earthenware directly on the heat. But if authenticity is your goal, temper the tian before you set it on the flame. I've tempered many a tian in my time, and cracked as many more. There are ways of tempering that involve oil and salt and garlic, but the simplest is to fill the dish with cold water right to the brim and heat it until the water evaporates completely. And don't blame me if it doesn't work; blame the potter. The most reliable tians are made of the good red clay of Vallauris, the little village chosen by Picasso for his ceramic workshop.

If you're still in any doubt as to a tian's proper shape and colour, you'll find its likeness in the National Gallery of Scotland, in a detail of Velazquez's haunting portrait, Old Woman Cooking Eggs. The venerable lady's frying implement, though undoubtedly made by a Spanish potter, is the perfect model of the Provençal tian. The people of Catalunya and their neighbours in Provence share far more than culinary habit. Both speak a version of the langue-d'oc dialect - as opposed to the langue-d'ail (or d'oui), the basis for modern French - a language considered subversive on both sides of the border. In Spain, during the Franco years, the Catalan language was officially banned from all public utterance; in Provence, for reasons of religion as well as of politics, both language and literature were ruthlessly suppressed for five centuries.

It was not until well into the 19th century that Frederic Mistral, poet of Provence at a time when romanticism cast its rosy glow, set himself the task of reclaiming his people's past. That he considered the tian - both container and contents - worthy of a full description is an indication of the place it held in the people's hearts. Mistral, the inspiration for many a modern separatist movement, had a fine nose for the things that matter. And to a people forbidden to express themselves in any way except domestic habit, the tian mattered. All the great dishes are political statements: they speak to the people of who they are.

The tian may be a newcomer to modern menus, but that's only because it took so long to come out of the closet. Now that it's out, feel free to play. Rules are made to be broken, and this is a dish, after all, with the whiff of subversion about its little earthenware ears. Oh, I nearly forgot: serve your tian neither cold nor hot, but barely warm - the temperature of a summer's day in Provence, in the shade of an olive grove, beside a field of lavender, in the shadow of a vine-covered terrace. Ah well. It's the thought that counts.

All recipes serve six.

Tian of spinach and raisins

800g spinach, picked and washed
2 medium onions, peeled and finely chopped
50g unsalted butter
30g raisins
1/5 whole nutmeg, finely grated

1/4 tsp ground allspice
Salt and pepper
1 sprig thyme
1 handful picked flat-leaf parsley
1 tsp picked chervil (if available)
200ml double cream
2 very fresh egg yolks
2 tbsp olive oil
30g pinenuts, roasted golden brown

Preheat the oven to 160C/325F/ gas mark 3. Put a pan of water on to boil. Plunge the spinach into the boiling water and cook for just a minute or so. Drain the spinach, cool it under ice or running water, then squeeze the leaves as dry as you can. Fry the onions in the butter until soft and golden, add the raisins, nut meg, allspice, salt and pepper. Finely chop the spinach and herbs, and mix into the onion mix, then pour in the cream, egg yolks and pinenuts. Stir well.

Warm an oven-proof dish, put in a tablespoon or two of olive oil, and pour in the spinach mix. Cook the tian in the oven for 20 minutes or so until the mixture has only barely set. This eats best when only just warm.

Tian of courgettes and tomatoes
A handsome dish is best for this tian, as after the initial preparation and the final assembling, the whole caboodle is cooked in the oven and then taken to table. It would be criminal to cook such a beauty and then break it up on to separate plates.

2 medium onions
2 red peppers
90ml olive oil
Salt and pepper
1 clove garlic, finely chopped
1kg very ripe tomatoes
1kg slender courgettes
1 small sprig thyme
25g finest Parmesan, grated

Preheat the oven to 190C/375F/ gas mark 5. First off, peel, halve and thinly slice the onions, and do likewise with the peppers. Heat a large frying pan, pour in the olive oil, and toss in the onion and pepper along with some salt and pepper. Fry gently until the vegetables have softened and are just lightly coloured, then add the garlic, stir everything together, and spread the mixture out over the base of an earthenware dish.

Remove the eye from the tomatoes and thinly slice the flesh. Top and tail the courgettes, and cut into thin diagonal slices. Lay alternate rows of tomato and courgette on top of the onion-and-pepper base. Season with milled pepper and sea salt, drop in the thyme, and spoon over a little more oil. Place the tian in the oven, and bake for 30-40 minutes, until it has darkened at the edges and the courgettes are quite soft.

Strew the Parmesan over the top of the dish, and bake for five minutes longer. This tian is at its best served just warm an hour or so after cooking, either just as it is or with little pieces of griddled lamb, chicken or fish.

Tian of leeks, potatoes and ceps
Good to eat on its own, and as an accompaniment for simply roasted or poached fish and meat.

1kg leeks
10g very good dried ceps
1.5kg waxy potatoes, peeled and thinly sliced
2 medium onions, peeled and finely chopped
100g unsalted fine butter
1 small sprig thyme
1 clove garlic, finely chopped
Salt and pepper
Asiago or Emmenthal cheese, grated (optional)

Preheat the oven to 190C/375F/ gas mark 5. Trim the excess dark green from the leeks and remove the root. Cut the leeks into 1.5cm lengths and submerge them in cold water. Wash the leeks a few times to remove all the grit, then drain. Place the dried ceps in a bowl and cover with luke-warm water for around 20 minutes. Rinse the potato slices in a colander under the cold tap until the water runs clear. Drain the ceps through a fine sieve, retaining their soaking liquid, and squeeze them dry.

Liberally grease a gratin dish with half the butter, then scatter in the onion and ceps, and scatter over the garlic and thyme. Place a layer of potatoes on top, then follow with the leeks. Season liberally, then top with the remaining potatoes (I prefer the dish to look random in design, and not horridly patterned, such as the fish-scale effect.) Dot the gratin with the rest of the butter, then pour in the cep liquor and enough water to come just below the top layer, and bake for 45 minutes. Turn down the heat to 135C/275F/gas mark 1, and cook for 15 minutes more. Spread the grated cheese on top, bake for a further five minutes, then turn off the oven and leave the tian to sit awhile. (I have as deep a suspicion of piping-hot food as I do of food served straight from the fridge.)

Tian of onions
Long, slow cooking helps the onions collapse into the enormous quantity of liquid they render. When the liquid has all but evaporated, the onions will be soft and slightly sweetened.

2.5kg medium-sized onions
2 bayleaves
25g caster sugar
Sea salt and fresh black pepper
1 small sprig thyme, tied
150ml white wine
60g unsalted butter

Preheat the oven to 150C/300F/gas mark 2 (or even the next grade up, depending on the reliability of your oven). Peel the onions, leaving the root intact, cut each through the root into six pieces and lay, in a random fashion, in the tian. Pop in the bayleaves, and sprinkle the sugar, salt and pepper over the top. Add the thyme, pour in the wine and add 75ml water. Cut the butter into thin slices, and lay on top.

Bake the tian for 45 minutes or so, then turn the onions, taking care not to break them up too much, and cook for a further half an hour. Turn carefully again. As the liquid content varies so much in onions, cook for a further hour, or even an hour and a half, until the onions are coloured and collapsed, and there is very little liquid residue

 Elisabeth Luard is a food writer. Her next book, Saffron And Sunshine, will be published by Bantam Press in the autumn. She also holds week-long residential cooking-workshops in Haute Provence throughout June. Email: info@artinprovence.com.

And to a people forbidden to express themselves in any way except domestic habit, the tian mattered. All the great dishes are political statements: they speak to the people of who they are. The tian may be a newcomer to modern menus, but that's only because it took so long to come out of the closet. Now that it's out, feel free to play. Rules are made to be broken, and this is a dish, after all, with the whiff of subversion about its little earthenware ears. Oh, I nearly forgot: serve your tian neither cold nor hot, but barely warm - the temperature of a summer's day in Provence, in the shade of an olive grove, beside a field of lavender, in the shadow of a vine-covered terrace. Ah well. It's the thought that counts. All recipes serve six. Tian of spinach and raisins 800g spinach, picked and washed 2 medium onions, peeled and finely chopped 50g unsalted butter 30g raisins 1/5 whole nutmeg, finely grated 1/4 tsp ground allspice Salt and pepper 1 sprig thyme 1 handful picked flat-leaf parsley 1 tsp picked chervil (if available) 200ml double cream 2 very fresh egg yolks 2 tbsp olive oil 30g pinenuts, roasted golden brown Preheat the oven to 160C/325F/ gas mark 3. Put a pan of water on to boil. Plunge the spinach into the boiling water and cook for just a minute or so. Drain the spinach, cool it under ice or running water, then squeeze the leaves as dry as you can. Fry the onions in the butter until soft and golden, add the raisins, nut meg, allspice, salt and pepper. Finely chop the spinach and herbs, and mix into the onion mix, then pour in the cream, egg yolks and pinenuts. Stir well. Warm an oven-proof dish, put in a tablespoon or two of olive oil, and pour in the spinach mix. Cook the tian in the oven for 20 minutes or so until the mixture has only barely set. This eats best when only just warm. Tian of courgettes and tomatoes A handsome dish is best for this tian, as after the initial preparation and the final assembling, the whole caboodle is cooked in the oven and then taken to table. It would be criminal to cook such a beauty and then break it up on to separate plates. 2 medium onions 2 red peppers 90ml olive oil Salt and pepper 1 clove garlic, finely chopped 1kg very ripe tomatoes 1kg slender courgettes 1 small sprig thyme 25g finest Parmesan, grated Preheat the oven to 190C/375F/ gas mark 5. First off, peel, halve and thinly slice the onions, and do likewise with the peppers. Heat a large frying pan, pour in the olive oil, and toss in the onion and pepper along with some salt and pepper. Fry gently until the vegetables have softened and are just lightly coloured, then add the garlic, stir everything together, and spread the mixture out over the base of an earthenware dish. Remove the eye from the tomatoes and thinly slice the flesh. Top and tail the courgettes, and cut into thin diagonal slices. Lay alternate rows of tomato and courgette on top of the onion-and-pepper base. Season with milled pepper and sea salt, drop in the thyme, and spoon over a little more oil. Place the tian in the oven, and bake for 30-40 minutes, until it has darkened at the edges and the courgettes are quite soft. Strew the Parmesan over the top of the dish, and bake for five minutes longer. This tian is at its best served just warm an hour or so after cooking, either just as it is or with little pieces of griddled lamb, chicken or fish. Tian of leeks, potatoes and ceps Good to eat on its own, and as an accompaniment for simply roasted or poached fish and meat. 1kg leeks 10g very good dried ceps 1.5kg waxy potatoes, peeled and thinly sliced 2 medium onions, peeled and finely chopped 100g unsalted fine butter 1 small sprig thyme 1 clove garlic, finely chopped Salt and pepper Asiago or Emmenthal cheese, grated (optional) Preheat the oven to 190C/375F/ gas mark 5. Trim the excess dark green from the leeks and remove the root. Cut the leeks into 1.5cm lengths and submerge them in cold water. Wash the leeks a few times to remove all the grit, then drain. Place the dried ceps in a bowl and cover with luke-warm water for around 20 minutes. Rinse the potato slices in a colander under the cold tap until the water runs clear. Drain the ceps through a fine sieve, retaining their soaking liquid, and squeeze them dry. Liberally grease a gratin dish with half the butter, then scatter in the onion and ceps, and scatter over the garlic and thyme. Place a layer of potatoes on top, then follow with the leeks. Season liberally, then top with the remaining potatoes (I prefer the dish to look random in design, and not horridly patterned, such as the fish-scale effect.) Dot the gratin with the rest of the butter, then pour in the cep liquor and enough water to come just below the top layer, and bake for 45 minutes. Turn down the heat to 135C/275F/gas mark 1, and cook for 15 minutes more. Spread the grated cheese on top, bake for a further five minutes, then turn off the oven and leave the tian to sit awhile. (I have as deep a suspicion of piping-hot food as I do of food served straight from the fridge.) Tian of onions Long, slow cooking helps the onions collapse into the enormous quantity of liquid they render. When the liquid has all but evaporated, the onions will be soft and slightly sweetened. 2.5kg medium-sized onions 2 bayleaves 25g caster sugar Sea salt and fresh black pepper 1 small sprig thyme, tied 150ml white wine 60g unsalted butter Preheat the oven to 150C/300F/gas mark 2 (or even the next grade up, depending on the reliability of your oven). Peel the onions, leaving the root intact, cut each through the root into six pieces and lay, in a random fashion, in the tian. Pop in the bayleaves, and sprinkle the sugar, salt and pepper over the top. Add the thyme, pour in the wine and add 75ml water. Cut the butter into thin slices, and lay on top. Bake the tian for 45 minutes or so, then turn the onions, taking care not to break them up too much, and cook for a further half an hour. Turn carefully again. As the liquid content varies so much in onions, cook for a further hour, or even an hour and a half, until the onions are coloured and collapsed, and there is very little liquid residue  Elisabeth Luard is a food writer. Her next book, Saffron And Sunshine, will be published by Bantam Press in the autumn. She also holds week-long residential cooking-workshops in Haute Provence throughout June. Email: info@artinprovence.com.

fields.headline: Eating out
fields.standfirst: Asia di Cuba has had a real critical pasting, but Matthew Fort quite likes it, actually
fields.trailText: Asia di Cuba has had a real critical pasting, but Matthew Fort quite likes it, actually
fields.body:
I passed on the Mambo King, Mojito and Cheeky Tiki. It was a day, I decided, for a caipirinha, the classic cocktail of Brazil, made of cachaca (aka Brazilian white lightning), lime, ice and sugar. It may have been a bit purist for the glitz of Asia di Cuba, but it suited my mood: funky, hunky and kinda chunky. Very chunky.

Did Asia di Cuba or St Martin's Lane, the hotel in which it is housed, register on your social seismograph when they opened last year? There was, if you remember, a bit of fuss in the more outré columns of our more outré newspapers and magazines. Most of the comment focused on the high- fashion alliance of Ian Shrager, the US's most avant-garde hotelier, and Philippe Starck, France's most acceptable avant-garde design export, and some of the wackier consequences thereof, particularly in the dining line.

In truth, the St Martin's Lane hotel is a bit Alice in Wonderlandish. Messrs Shrager and Starck have taken a very dull, neo-brutalist, one-time office block and turned it into a playground of the senses, with the emphasis on the playground. Simple-minded cove that I am, I was confused as to whether the objects in the reception area, for example, were contemporary works of art or tables and chairs, until I saw Aubretia, an unquestionable work of art herself, perched on one.

There is a brasserie, of which I had heard mixed views, and there is a dining room, where we were to lunch, which is really rather splendid: a heady mix of high-kitsch, low-kitsch and the preposterously kitsch - and that goes for the staff as well as the decor. There are fat pillars, some covered in books on shelves, interspersed with 40s and 50s radios and TVs. There is one pillar covered with dusky pink velveteen, dimpled with buttons, and another bedecked with vases full of what looked, at a distance, very much like plastic azaleas. Over each table hangs a naked lightbulb at the end of a long loop of flex - and not any old bulb or any old flex, come to that.

It's a kind of anti-design design, all very good-humoured and kinda fun. And it works, because it's all stitched together with a strong basic structure. In fact, you can see how, when we all grow tired of this version of the Starck vision (by about the end of next week), it will be a morning's work to strip away the frou-frou and replace it with something else.

The staff had the good humour and the kitsch well buttoned-up, but they lacked the strong underlying structure. Some of them lacked a command of basic English, too. They were willing enough, but willingness alone does not divert irritation from the failure to deliver a glass of wine when it was needed, ignorance about the contents of a particular dish, languid ease between courses and the failure to deliver our dishes at more or less the same time. As the dining room was not exactly full to overflowing, and there were only two of us, this did seem inexplicable and inexcusable.

But the food itself, when it arrived and for all its fired-up fusionism, was a great deal better than I had feared it would be. The idea that there is a real symbiosis between the foods of Asia and Cuba owes more to restaurateurs who are randy for novelty than to any natural relationship, but individual dishes were as beguiling as the decor, and for much the same reasons. The ceviche of mussels and clams "Mixto" - or, as the menu subscript put it, "poached Chilean mussels, cockles, Manila clams, rock shrimp, tomato and citrus juices" - was like seafood in a particularly piquant Bloody Mary, though without the vodka. The tomato and citrus juice elements were charmingly fresh and spiced without being punitive and, more importantly, drowning the flavours of the shellfish.

The calamari salad "Asia di Cuba", with hearts of palm, banana, coconut, cashew nuts, rocket and endive frisée with sesame orange dressing, was one of the best salads I have tasted in a decade (tasted only - it was Aubretia's to eat), even if the squid had a decorative rather than a starring role. It was crushingly fresh, clean-flavoured and well-balanced.

When Aubretia followed this up with marinated brochette of salmon and saltcod, she decided that she was on to another winner. The cod was of the lightly-salted-in-this-kitchen variety, rather than the rank, leathery stuff so beloved of the Italians and the Provençal French. Chunks of it were strung together with the salmon along a piece of lemongrass, and the whole was ample and beautifully cooked. Sadly, a mountainous haystack of noodles and a sea of overpowering, lacquer-like sauce stuff rather spoiled the initial impressions.

I couldn't make up my mind about my palomillo of lamb, which was a bit like a kebab that had been beaten to the thickness of a hardback book cover and the size of a sheet of A4. It was spread with mojito, which I take to be a garlic-and-herb mix, and there were also, in no particular order, fried peppers, aubergine, onions, watercress and a "herbed rice cracker", about which I can remember nothing whatsoever. One of our many waiters suggested rather cheekily that the dish was sufficiently large to share with Aubretia, but I put him right on that point. It was interesting rather than overwhelming.

The bill, on the other hand, was overwhelming as well as interesting. In fact, it was fascinating. It's a long time since food so comprehensively outscored drink on one of my bills. The grand total was £76.50, £14 of which went on my cocktail, a bottle of water and two espressos. The rest was eatables, with the salmon and saltcod dish setting the pace at £19.50 and a rather solid Vietnamese banana bread pudding adding its £9.50-worth to the total, it's not hard to see why.

I think the bill and the service rather take the fun edge off Asia di Cuba. As a place, it lifts the spirits. As an experience, it rather dashes them, in spite of the benign influence of the caipirinha.

fields.headline: Lorraine Kelly
fields.standfirst: Lorraine Kelly, 40, was born in Glasgow. She began her career on a local newspaper before joining TVAM as a reporter. She now presents Lorraine for GMTV every weekday. Her latest fitness video, Figure Happy, has just been released. She is married with a daughter, and lives in Berkshire
fields.trailText: Lorraine Kelly, 40, was born in Glasgow. She began her career on a local newspaper before joining TVAM as a reporter. She now presents Lorraine for GMTV every weekday. Her latest fitness video, Figure Happy, has just been released. She is married with a daughter, and lives in Berkshire
fields.body:
What is your idea of perfect happiness?
Being on the island of Barra in the Outer Hebrides, a blazing hot day, champers and seafood on the beach with all my friends and family.

What is your greatest fear?
Alzheimer's.

What is the trait you most deplore in yourself?
Impatience.

What is the trait you most deplore in others?
Meanness.

What makes you depressed?
Bigots.

What do you most dislike about your appearance?
My fat upper arms.

What is your most unappealing habit?
Interrupting people.

What is your favourite smell?
Freesias.

What is your favourite word?
Brilliant.

What is your favourite journey?
To Glasgow.

How did you vote in the last election?
Labour.

How will you vote in the next election?
The same.

For what cause would you die?
To save my daughter's life.

Do you believe in monogamy?
Yes.

What or who is the greatest love of your life?
My husband. My daughter.

Which living person do you most despise?
Bill Clinton.

Have you ever said 'I love you' and not meant it?
Yes.

How do you relax?
Aromatherapy bath.

How often do you have sex?
Not often enough!

What single thing would improve the quality of your life?
My show to be moved until later in the day.

What would your motto be?
Seize the day.

Do you believe in life after death?
No.

How would you like to be remembered?
As a good, honest woman who liked a drink and a laugh.

What is the most important lesson life has taught you?
Do as you would be done by.

webTitle: The loneliness of the cross country runner

fields.headline: The loneliness of the cross country runner
fields.standfirst: Adrian Mole, aged 32 and three quarters. By Sue Townsend
fields.trailText: Adrian Mole, aged 32 and three quarters. By Sue Townsend
fields.body:
Monday, February 28, 2000, Arthur Askey Way

Glenn returned home from school today with a letter from his physical education teacher, Mr Lunt. It said: "Dear Mr Mole, Glenn gave me the following note at the beginning of games today. Although it is not written in Glenn's handwriting, I feel sure that it is not written in yours either."

I read the enclosed ill-written note. It said: "Dear Mr Lunt, something tragic 'as happened to Glenn my son he has got a terminal decease and he wont live long it is only a matter of time he dous not no so dont tell him it wood be better if he did not do cross country running as it mite set him off yours sinserly Mr Mole."

Glenn broke down and admitted that he had persuaded his mother, Sharon Bott, to write the note. He said,"I 'ate cross-country runnin', Dad. We 'ave to wear shorts an' run through villages an' the villagers laugh an' call me chicken legs."

I confronted Sharon in her chaotic kitchen, where she was defrosting chicken korma for the kids' tea. Not for the first time, I was appalled that I had once enjoyed sexual relations with this woman. She now makes Moby Dick look dainty.

As she prised the lids off the foil containers, she whined, "I've gotta soft heart, Aidy, I don't like to think of our Glenn 'aving the piss took out of him."

I asked her not to interfere in Glenn's education in future. She said, "I am his mother. 'E's got 'alf my genes."

I said, "Yes, the grammar, punctuation and spelling genes, unfortunately." As I was leaving, she said, "I still love you to bits, Aidy." I pretended not to hear her

I wrote Mr Lunt the following reply: "Dear Mr Lunt, My own adolescence was made a torment by taunts about my acned complexion. Glenn has a similar complex about his abnormally thin legs. Will you please allow Glenn to wear tracksuit trousers on his next cross-country run, or change the route and stick to unpopulated fields and lanes in future, thus avoiding the taunts of ignorant fox-killing, songbird-culling, hedge-removing, river-polluting country dwellers. I remain Sir, AA Mole."

Tuesday, February 29

Leap Day. A letter from the Rt Hon Neil Kinnock! Whom I met once when I was the offal chef in Hoi Polloi, the Soho restaurant before it was reopened as the Oxygen Bar, H2O.

The letter said: "Dear Mr Mole, I have great pleasure in enclosing your invitation to the Labour Party Centenary Dinner on Monday, April 10, 2000. I will be hosting the evening, and I am delighted that once again the Prime Minister will be our guest of honour.

"As you may expect there will be very strict security. I regret therefore that I am unable to give you the exact location at this stage except to say that it will be at a central London hotel..."

I obviously made a lasting impression on Mr Kinnock. He must have truly enjoyed his sheep's testicle in blackcurrant coulis.

8.30pm Sharon Bott has just left this house in tears. She arrived uninvited at 7.30 in a taxi. She produced a bottle of Safeway's Cava, then got down on one huge knee and asked me to marry her. I turned her down. Glenn was disappointed. He said, "I would 'ave bin the only one in our class to 'ave a mam and dad livin' together."

Wednesday, March 1

A terse reply from Lunt: "Dear Mr Mole, The wearing of tracksuit trousers is prohibited during cross-country runs. Best wishes, Mr Lunt. PS As a country dweller, I find your remarks about country folk extremely offensive."

Friday, March 3

My mother has just pointed to the small print at the bottom of my Centenary Dinner invitation. The tickets cost £600. I have made an optician's appointment.

fields.headline: Dulcie Domum
fields.standfirst: 'Suddenly aware of horrible stink in the room apart from me. Dead rodent'
fields.trailText: 'Suddenly aware of horrible stink in the room apart from me. Dead rodent'
fields.body:
Bad breath has arrived - with bad timing. I put an ad in the paper offering pre-exam last-minute coaching, and several anxious mothers have rung up. Mrs Aston and her daughter Gabrielle are coming this afternoon for a preliminary chat.

"There's someone on the phone for you - Sharon Beale," says ex-Spouse through the bathroom door, where I am shaving my legs for Mrs Aston. "Is it about coaching?" I enquire. "No, and she rang yesterday," warns ex-Spouse petulantly. Assure him I will ring her back. Her name rings a bell. Sharon Beale. Or is it EastEnders? Glad I do not have to coach Janine. Attila the Hun in a gymslip.

Downstairs, aged aunt accosts me. "I'm not feeling very well, dearrr ," she whispers. "I think that tuna at lunch was a bit underrrcooked." I took her out for a little treat to The Bull & Duck, and they've poisoned the poor old thing. Express concern, settle aunt comfortably in bed, and remind her that I have a meeting this afternoon. Hope any further indisposition will be silent. What else could go wrong? At least we put down mouse poison three days ago, and the scamperings of recent weeks have ceased.

Mrs Aston and Gabrielle arrive. The dining room is so tiny that my terrible breath will probably fill it in five minutes and we will all pass out. Heroically launch the attempt to hold a conversation without exhaling. Hope rodents will refrain from scampering and aunt from vomiting - the sound of which, I find, rarely assists scholarly endeavour.

Mrs Aston is delightful, and Gabrielle quiet and pale. "Gabrielle's having a lot of trouble with Dickens," she confides. "Ah, yes, I do understand!" fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.trailText: Australia
fields.body:
Australia has a long way to go to catch up with France, but not in the way you might think. In terms of customer confidence, in the less-than-a-tenner range, the Wallabies have the Frogs groggy (as do the Kiwis). I say this based on years of readers' letters and conversations with same. What emerges loud and clear is that if you buy a 10-quid French wine, you take a much greater gamble on being thrilled than you do with a same-priced Aussie red or white.

However, when I remarked to one bosom wine-drinking pal recently that I planned to visit the Barossa next year, she protested, 'But you've only just come back from Coonawarra!' She would not, in a million years, have reacted similarly if I had reported that, having investigated the Rhne this year, I intended to potter around the Loire next. French vineyard diversity, I conclude, is taken for granted. Australia's is yet to be fully appreciated.

Part of the reason for this is that the term 'Australian' carries such weight by itself, which the adjective 'French' does not. Safeway's Australian Shiraz 1998 (15 points, out of 20, £4.49) offers the confidence of its provenance loud and clear, and indeed justifies it with warm fruit that is juicy yet attitudinal and fully-charged. It's a terrific quaffing wine. I do not think a bottle labelled Safeway's French Syrah would seem half, nay a quarter, so exciting. On the other hand (and, at £6.99, on a different level of expectation), Mamre Brook Chardonnay 1998 (Safeway, 16 points) says it's from the Barossa Valley, so we might assume this to imply more complexity and indi viduality. So it proves: the wine flows softly and ripely, offering a lithe richness, civilised fruitiness and an elegant finish. Safeway's Riddoch Cabernet Shiraz 1997 (16 points, £7.99) is from the Coonawarra, and this 'bio-clime', dubbed the Aussie equivalent of the French terroir, is in subtle evidence in the fruit, which carries delightful hints of spice, mint, blueberries and blackcurrants. (You will not, however, find these last two wines at all branches of Safeway: call 01622 712926 for details.)

Somerfield's own-label Australian Cabernet Sauvignon 1998 (15.5 points, £4.99), without demonstrating any specific vineyard bio-clime, still reeks of and resounds with the Aussie sun, flair, inventiveness and sullen richness of demeanour. It's a hugely soft yet dry-sided wine of consummate quaffability. Over at Tesco, there is Penfold's Koonunga Hill Shiraz/Cabernet Sauvignon 1997 (16 points, £6.99), and most elegant it is, too, with a lively varnish to the soft fruit that is not normally as high-gloss as this. The wine purrs across the tastebuds on padded feet. Tesco's McLaren Vale Shiraz 1997 (16 points, £6.99) is proud to point to its particular bio-climatic origins, and its fruit is an exemplary example, for the money, of the substance, staying power and potency of shirazes from that region.

At Thresher and Victoria Wine, there is Tatachilla Grenache Shiraz 1998 (16 points, £5.99), from a McLaren Vale estate that has progressed hugely since its latest change of ownership in 1995. A decade ago, I saw grapes destined for Tatachilla swollen with irrigated water, but this can hardly have been true of the beauties that went into this bargain blend. The wine has style, bravura and loads of fruit, but is never silly or too juicy, the tannins being temperate and tasty. Samuels Bay Grenache 1997 (16 points, £6.49) is one of the most concentrated examples of this grape I've tasted. Plummy, cigar-edged, perfumed, rich, very free-flowing yet delicate, it has considerable charm. It is made by Adam Wynn in South Australia, and is, one presumes, a blend of several vineyards' fruit.

And last, at Unwins and Fuller's (and possibly Majestic), there is Ironstone Shiraz/Grenache 1997. This combines several themes, uniting an impressive Rhne-style dryness with an Italian sense of food-friendliness, underneath which is a uniquely Western Australian posture to the fruit that is never blowsy or pretentious. The grapes, gathered from unirrigated vineyards several hundred kilometres apart, are grown in iron-oxide gravel, hence the name and the taste of the wine. It rates 16.5 points and costs £6.99.

 Superplonk 2000 and Streetplonk 2000 are published by Hodder at £5.99 each. To order copies at the special price of £4.99 per book, plus 99p UK p&p, freephone CultureShop on 0800 3166102.

fields.headline: How to... swim
fields.trailText: Guy Browning
fields.body:
You can pretend to swim by splashing around while all the time keeping one foot on the bottom. You might be able to get away with this in the local municipal swimming baths, but not with the surfing crowd at Malibu.

The first stroke most people master is the doggy paddle, although you'd have thought we would start with the fish paddle, because fish are generally better role-models when it comes to swimming. But then, we're odd like that - we also try to swim like a butterfly, which is actually better known for flying.

Once you're in the water, you have a choice of strokes. Backstroke is where you lie on your back and then, just at the point of sinking, you throw your arms back and make like a paddle-steamer. You carry on like this until you do a full-power reverse karate chop on the concrete side of the pool and decide that swimming on your front might be more sensible. Again, you won't find many fishes swimming past on their back.

With breaststroke, you can choose to do it with your head out of the water or with it dipping under. If you're doing the dipping one and you don't come up after the third dip, the technical name for what you're doing is drowning. Sidestroke is for people who, given a horse, would ride side-saddle. It's a very efficient stroke, but it does give the impression that you're having a prolonged ogle at anyone swimming in the lane alongside you.

There are two types of front crawl: there's the controlled application of power, as practised by Australians, and there's the crawl done by British men, which involves doing one length at maximum effort, beating the hell out of the water, creating more wake than a passing car-ferry and knocking unconscious any other swimmer who happens to be in the way.

You can combine the various strokes into the individual medley, which is where you start with something impressive such as the butterfly, swallow half the pool in the process, and then do a few strokes of something else while you fight for air and try to stop choking.

The one area where the British excel in the pool is headgear, especially those rubber helmets with flowers stuck on them that seem designed for covert operations in lily ponds. These helmets are worn by a certain kind of lady who drifts aimlessly around the pool like a dormant Portuguese man-of-war. Look at these women closely, and you'll notice they've generally got one foot on the bottom.

webTitle: Judges veto rape victims' right to know

fields.headline: Judges veto rape victims' right to know
fields.trailText: The crown prosecution service does not have to consult rape victims prior to dropping cases, the high court ruled yesterday.
fields.body:
The crown prosecution service does not have to consult rape victims prior to dropping cases, the high court ruled yesterday.

The ruling follows legal action by a teenager who challenged a decision by prosecutors not to tell her that they were dropping charges against a gang she alleged had raped and sexually assaulted her.

The CPS and police were strongly criticised for failing to tell the girl, from north London, who was 14 at the time of the alleged attack, that a decision not to proceed had been made in June 1998.

But two senior judges ruled that the director of public prosecutions was under no legal duty to consult "C", who cannot be named for legal reasons, before abandoning proceedings against two youths and three other girls accused of taking part in, or assisting, the alleged sexual assaults.

If the girl, now 16, had won her case, it would have opened the way for other victims of alleged sexual assaults and serious crimes to question CPS decisions to drop cases. C only found out that her alleged attackers no longer faced trial when she saw one of them near her home in north London. His bail conditions required him to stay away from the area.

The girl asked the police why the charges had been dropped in June 1998 without her knowledge, then persuaded her parents to seek legal aid to bring a high court challenge.

Lord Justice Rose, sitting with Mr Justice Alliott, said: "It is extremely regrettable that the applicant was not informed by the CPS or police of the decision not to proceed with her case and that she learned of that decision by other means."

Common courtesy, CPS guidelines at the time and the victim's charter all pointed to the desirability of informing her, particularly when the complainant was so young, said the judge. But that did not mean C was entitled to be specifically consulted about the decision.
