webTitle: Campaigning life of a democrat abroad

fields.headline: Campaigning life of a democrat abroad
fields.standfirst:
The trained architect in the thick of a US election

The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Some people may not have noticed that a crucially important election is being fought in London this year: it's the one to choose the next president of the USA, and about 250,000 American citizens living over here are eligible to vote in it.
fields.body:
Some people may not have noticed that a crucially important election is being fought in London this year: it's the one to choose the next president of the USA, and about 250,000 American citizens living over here are eligible to vote in it.

Andy Goldberg is the international campaign chair for Democrats Abroad, a constituent part of the democratic party. They vote in the primaries and they send delegates to the convention; and even if the whole thing is now reduced to a ritualised dance since there is only one candidate to choose from, there will still be a caucus meeting in London on Monday night to decide which nine members will be sent to the convention in Los Angeles to vote for Al Gore.

All the organisation is done by amateurs. Andy Goldberg works as a press officer for the College of Occupational Therapists. But he came to this country when his wife was posted here by her American employer.

He trained as an architect, which seems a deeply unpolitical profession, but the connection is obvious to him: "I graduated right in the thick of the bigest recession to hit us in 30 years. I did find some work eventually for a landscape architect." One November afternoon it struck him that "One November afternoon in New York State I was digging out trees and planting bulbs in the frozen ground. It's very hard work to dig bulbs into frozen ground; and I had this kind of - well, not an epiphany exactly - but I thought: 'Actually, working in politics; that's a lot more fun than planting bulbs in the frozen ground."

Within a couple of months he was working for the Democratic party in New York and then moved to Washington as a lobbyist and staffer for three different member of congress. It was, he says, a very different training from the sort of politics he is involved with in England.

"I think people are about 10 or 20 years further ahead in the US than here. People in the US have the idea that 'we own the government' and that 'we have the right to go and change things if they're working the wrong way'. When we got to this time of year in Washington - the start of the legislative year - my congressman would be meeting every single day with 10 different groups of constituents."

Yet the matter of politics here is sometimes more congenial, even if its manner can be frustrating. In the US he worked for years of frustration on gun control, on the staff of a woman who had been elected to congress after her husband was killed and her son gravely wounded. "When her congressman still voted against gun control, she ran against him and beat him by 16 points." But once she reached congress, their efforts ran into a wall. "It's not the best environment. We were working to ensure that children couldn't have access to guns: regulating gun dealers and gun shops, or putting childproof locks on guns. But even those sort of things the gun advocates fought tooth and nail."

In England, he says, the whole political system works entirely differently. But it's obvious, as he talks, that effectiveness is not really what draws volunteers to politics. It is the chance to take part in the theatre of it all. How else to explain the fact that the system under which Democrats Abroad elect their delegates is nicely balanced to maximise the number of people who get to go to Los Angeles, so that the 22 delegates who end up there will carry nine votes between them, each flying half way round the world to cast a little less than half a vote for Al Gore who will win the election anyway. That's real participatory democracy.

webTitle: Pupil barristers lose right to minimum wage

fields.headline: Pupil barristers lose right to minimum wage
fields.trailText: Pupil barristers lost the right to be paid the national minimum wage yesterday when three appeal court judges overturned a high court ruling last year which deemed them to be workers.
fields.body:
Pupil barristers lost the right to be paid the national minimum wage yesterday when three appeal court judges overturned a high court ruling last year which deemed them to be workers.

Last year's ruling, which applied only to pupils aged at least 26, was seen as a breakthrough for cash-strapped pupils, 43% of whom are either unfunded or paid less than £6,000 a year.

But yesterday the lord chief justice, Lord Bingham, said pupils were not "working under contracts of apprenticeship" under the national minimum wage act and were therefore not entitled to be paid the statutory £3.70 an hour.

Pupils, many of whom have run up large debts at bar school, have to serve two pupillages of six months each before they can practise independently as barristers. During the second six months they may take on their own cases, but earnings are usually small.

Some chambers provide funded pupillages, guaranteeing a certain level of income to top up the pupil's own earnings. The most prestigious commercial chambers pay as much as £25,000 a year. But many pay as little as £5,000 to £6,000 a year, and many pupillages are unfunded, leaving the pupil to rely on parental support or bank loans.

fields.headline: Monkey farm closes after demos
fields.trailText: A monkey farm which has been the focus of regular animal rights protests for the past 15 months is to close, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
A monkey farm which has been the focus of regular animal rights protests for the past 15 months is to close, it emerged yesterday.

Managers at Shamrock Monkey Farm at Small Dole, near Henfield, West Sussex, said they will shut the farm in the next few weeks.

Jobs will be lost, according to a statement from the firm which pledged the humane relocation of the animals. It said: "The effective date of the closure will be dictated by the professional relocation of the animals residing in the facility".

The move is being claimed as a victory by animal rights activists who have held dozens of protests at the farm.

They have campaigned over the monkeys being imported by Shamrock from Mauritius, China and other parts of Asia, before being sold on to medical laboratories in the UK and elsewhere in Europe.

The police were called to many of the demonstrations, often resulting in arrests. There have also been attacks on members of farm staff.

Mark Roberts, spokesman for the Save the Shamrock Monkeys group, said: "This is totally a victory for all the people who have come to the farm and written letters during the past 15 months."

fields.headline: Church caretaker 'fired for pay claim'
fields.standfirst: Low pay legislation inspires humble worker and would-be high flyers in the legal profession to join the battle for a living wage
fields.trailText: A Baptist church caretaker claims she was sacked and threatened with eviction when she asked to be paid the minimum wage.
fields.body:
A Baptist church caretaker claims she was sacked and threatened with eviction when she asked to be paid the minimum wage.

Diane Pool, 58, is going to an employment tribunal next month claiming unfair dismissal, which the church denies. However, regardless of the outcome, it has told Mrs Pool she will have to leave the terraced cottage next door to Immanuel church in Southsea, Hampshire, where she has lived for 20 years.

She also claims that the local church, which is a member of the Baptist Union, failed to pay her national insurance contributions, and she is consequently not entitled to benefits or state pension.

Mrs Pool, who is on medication for depression, said yesterday: "This whole thing has left me feeling awful. I've given up many things for this church, and this happens. I never wanted it to go this far, but they wouldn't back down. I used to have a lot of friends in the church but not anymore. Some have said they're praying for me, but I doubt that's going to put a roof over my head.

Me and my husband have raised five children in this home; at our time of life we didn't expect to have to move."

She and her husband, Dominic, 51, moved in in 1979. A practising Catholic, she had been a volunteer at the church; her fulltime job included unlocking the church for services, weddings and funerals, setting out the hall for meetings, and dealing with volunteer groups and societies that used the church.

She started on £18 a week, subject to an annual increase of £2. In 1991 the church froze her pay at £40, saying the house had become too expensive; it pays the council tax, water rates and phone rental on the property, which an estate agent valued at £70,000.

Mrs Pool said she had occasionally mentioned her salary to the church, but the introduction of the minimum wage last year galvanised her resolve - it is £3.10 an hour where accommodation is provided.

"When I realised I was getting so much less I was shocked," she said, estimating she worked up to 40 hours a week. Portsmouth citizens advice bureau, which is handling her case, estimates she was paid an average £2 an hour.

Last April she approached the minister, the Rev Roger Grant, who came to the church in 1996; she was told he had no direct say, and was referred to the treasurer. "The treasurer said he'd look into it, but nothing happened," Mrs Pool said.

"My daughters told me to contact the citizens advice. They went to the church but it still disputed my claim. Then one Monday last October a letter dropped through my door. It said I was fired. They didn't even knock on the door first, or tell me to my face."

The Pools face an uncertain future. He brings home £600 a month as a warehouseman; renting a similar property locally would cost around £400 a month. The council has offered to rehouse them in a tower block, but Mrs Pool is reluctant: "I've got nine grandchildren, and I often have a few over to stay for the weekend. I shan't be able to do that in a small flat in a tower block. We've been told we'll just have to change our lifestyle."

A neighbour, Barbara Jones, said: "For church people to do this is awful. You wonder why. After all the work she has put in, I think it's a disgrace."

The church declined to comment until the case had been heard, but is expected to dispute Mrs Pool's hours, and to claim she was dismissed because it does not need a full-time caretaker and not because of her wage demand.

webTitle: Red tape cut in assessing teachers

fields.headline: Red tape cut in assessing teachers
fields.trailText: Headteachers yesterday won a package of concessions to help cut the red tape involved in assessing their staff for performance-related pay.
fields.body:
Headteachers yesterday won a package of concessions to help cut the red tape involved in assessing their staff for performance-related pay.

The government announced an extra £20m to provide supply teachers so that heads and other senior staff will have more time to introduce the new system, which starts with assessments to determine whether teachers qualify for a higher pay scale.

Heads of larger schools who will have to handle 40 or more applications will be given more time - until autumn half term - for the assessment.

The education and employment minister, Lady Blackstone, told delegates at the Secondary Heads Association annual conference that the government was determined to ensure that the assessment process for the pay increases was manageable and successful.

Heads of larger schools had been worried about having to complete all assessments by the end of July, a deadline that will still apply to smaller schools. Performance-related pay will be introduced in September.

Lady Blackstone said the application process would "help to focus teachers' development and improve their performance. But to make the process work properly, heads and their management teams will have to invest time in it - time which is always in short supply."

John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association, said: "This is exactly what we asked for and we are delighted that the government has listened to us and acted."

Rebecca Smithers

fields.headline: Fitness personality dies at 93
fields.trailText: TV and radio fitness personality Eileen Fowler has died at the age of 93 in an Essex care home.
fields.body:
TV and radio fitness personality Eileen Fowler has died at the age of 93 in an Essex care home.

Famous for her catchphrase "down with a bounce - with a bounce come up", she rose to fame on BBC radio after the war, when her school marm manner and clipped tones gave listeners an early foretaste of the onset of fitness regimes such as aerobics.

The home in Colchester said yesterday that she had been there a while and had continued to practice daily fitness routines, though the manager declined to say whether her death on Tuesday had been sudden.

"She was a real character," said Kit Walton. "She will be sadly missed by the other residents and the staff."

Fowler made the transition to television in middle age, and went on to publish a bestseller, Stay Young Forever, and several fitness records.

webTitle: Hip joint identifies blaze death MP

fields.headline: Hip joint identifies blaze death MP
fields.standfirst: More about Michael Colvin MP
fields.trailText: The serial number on an artificial hip joint and some distinctive jewellery were all that could be used to identify the remains of the Conservative MP Michael Colvin and his wife after a fire destroyed their country mansion, an inquest heard yesterday.
fields.body:
The serial number on an artificial hip joint and some distinctive jewellery were all that could be used to identify the remains of the Conservative MP Michael Colvin and his wife after a fire destroyed their country mansion, an inquest heard yesterday.

The blaze was so fierce at the house in Tangley, Hampshire, that temperatures reached 1,000C, destroying everything but parts of the couple's skeletons. Just a fragment of the serial number on a hip joint fitted to the Tory backbencher in 1996 was found.

Mr Colvin, 67, and his wife Nichola, 62, died when fire swept through Tangley House early on February 24. Search teams, who found two sets of human remains, believe the fire started accidentally.

The inquest into their death was opened and adjourned yesterday in Winchester, Hampshire.

Coroner's officer Roger Matcham told the court: "Due to the ferocity of the fire very little of the bodies has been recovered. Parts of skeletons were found in the vicinity of the bedrooms at Tangley House."

Three floors of the couple's mansion, including their bedroom, collapsed during the blaze. The couple were sleeping in their first floor bedroom when the fire broke out.

The mid Hampshire assistant deputy coroner, Richard Mark Charter, said he was satisfied there was good identification of the Colvins. Mr Matcham told the hearing that the home office pathologist Roger Ainsworth examined two sections of an artificial hip joint which had the remains of a serial number on it.

"A call was made to the Fitzroy Nuffield hospital in London, where Mr Colvin had received a hip replacement operation on July 24 1996."

He said the hospital confirmed the serial number of the hip.

Mr Colvin was Conservative MP for Romsey. He first entered the Commons in 1979.

The couple's funeral will take place next Thursday at St Thomas's church, in Tangley. A memorial service for the Colvins is due to be held at Romsey Abbey on March 31.

webTitle: Student who found future in the past

fields.headline: Student who found future in the past
fields.standfirst: Andrew Jennings Director of Wessex archaeological charity
fields.trailText: Every time a little more of the countryside is concreted over, whether for cars or for houses, there is one group of conservationists to whom the news is not entirely unwelcome.
fields.body:
Every time a little more of the countryside is concreted over, whether for cars or for houses, there is one group of conservationists to whom the news is not entirely unwelcome.

Archaeologists in Britain today are almost dependent on development. Andrew Jennings is the director of Wessex Archaeology, a registered charity which is one of the bodies competing to investigate almost any patch of land before the bulldozers go in.

"I grew up in Wallingford [in Oxfordshire], a Saxon town, and I suppose that throughout my youth I was interested generally in the history around me.

"I was fortunate enough whilst at school to do some archaeological work, but I came then to the conclusion that there was no future in archaeology."

"No jobs," he adds, when I laugh at this phrase. "Anyway - I thought I would do physics or aeronautics, or something like that at university but then I had the opportunity to work on an excavation in what would now be termed a gap year and that convinced me that irrespective of whether there was a future in it, I must do it."

What gave archaeology a future in his lifetime was a set of government regulations known as PPG 16, which require developers to pay for the archaeological investigations of their sites: the prudent ones ask for a survey before they even apply for planning permission. This has turned the profession into a cluster of competing companies and charities, but ensured that there is plenty of work for them.

It's been 15 years, he says, since he was down on his knees in the dirt. He is now managing a company with 120 employees, which spent millions of pounds digging ahead of the route of a road expansion scheme and undertakes about 300 projects a year.

But he can still remember the attractions that pulled him into something that seemed to have no future in 1973, when he graduated. It is a subject unique in its combination of very large vision and concentration on tiny detail.

"It borrows from every form of science, whether biology, geology, history, or whatever, and the key to succesful archaeology is to be able to use the information from all those sources and to meld them together - but at the same time it is forensic in its detail. You don't have to be a pedant to be an archaeologist."

He gives a little noise to express shock that anyone could entertain so mistaken an idea. "But it starts off from a very high degree of questioning. We are actually looking at the soil grains to ask what sort of processes led to something being buried.

"We look at the grains of rock in the pottery to see the information there."

Sitting in Salisbury, where his offices are, he can look around at the bleak and wind-blown chalk downs. But where they look to an untrained eye to be some of the last tracts of unexploited nature in the south, Andrew Jennings sees them with an archaeologist's eye as a monument to the first great wave of human development in this country when the first farmers started to clear the forests on the hillsides. They are unexploited by us only because they were exploited out 8,000 years ago.

When he moved to Salisbury this kind of perspective was the province a small and apparently diminishing band of antiquarians. The company employed 11 people. Now it employs 10 times as many.

His most unusual customer is a football club: Southampton FC is building a stadium on a site which was part of the original Saxon port, and so Wessex Archaeology is recording the remains of that occupation before the new barbarians move in.

He is delighted with this. "We have had to change from being government paid organisations begging for a slice of the limited budget that the government made available, to people who operate in the ways in which our clients expected us to work- under contract, to fixed timetables, with fixed budgets and quality standards. We are as efficient as they are - so don't say anything about demotion."

 Profiles by Andrew Brown

webTitle: Oxford English Dictionary to go online

fields.headline: Oxford English Dictionary to go online
fields.standfirst:
Tome's 60m words will make it the largest reference book on the internet
Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: You hear some unlikely stories if you walk into the neo-classical headquarters of the Oxford English Dictionary these days. The first is that the book's scholarly, white-bearded Victorian founder, Sir James Murray, is to be played in a Hollywood film by Mel Gibson.
fields.body:
You hear some unlikely stories if you walk into the neo-classical headquarters of the Oxford English Dictionary these days. The first is that the book's scholarly, white-bearded Victorian founder, Sir James Murray, is to be played in a Hollywood film by Mel Gibson.

That is true; and it is part of a world full of change for the OED, regarded as the supreme authority on the English language. On Tuesday the dictionary - on which work started 143 years ago - goes online, all 60m words of it.

It will instantly become the internet's biggest, most prestige-laden reference book, dwarfing the 44m-word Encyclopaedia Britannica which launched its own website last year. Yesterday Britannica said that its free site, financed by advertising, had 17m users last month.

To emphasise continuity, the button launching the OED site will be pressed by Sir James Murray's great-great-great grandson Thomas, aged five. But the boy's action means that one of the glories of the world's publishing history may die as a printed book.

Online, it will evolve into a creature different from Murray's - less venerable, monstrously larger, far quicker at reflecting shifts in the lan guage. If its editors' vision comes true, it will be on tap electronically at every school and college as part of Tony Blair's national grid for learning rather than mouldering away on bookshelves at £1,800 for a 20-volume set.

But the web edition will depend chiefly on institutional or public authority subscriptions of £400-£1,000 a year. Its prime overseas markets are the US and Japan. And that has led to another unlikely story: the new US editor of these mostly chaste Victorian tomes is more famous as the author of a best-selling scholarly paperback entitled The F-Word.

This is true too. Moreover the editor, Jesse Sheidlower, a former Random House executive, is taking a hard look at the OED's definitions of the f-word and other obscenities on which he is an authority.

Embarrassingly for his new colleagues, some of these entries - like most of the 300,000 other main words -have lain in the dictionary unrevised since it first came out in 1928, or long before that.

They will have to go, he said. The word "bloody", in an entry thought to have been written by Murray in the 1880s, is defined as "now constantly in the minds of the lowest classes but by respectable people considered a horrid word". It appeals only to the imagination of "the rough classes".

You cannot say this kind of thing any more, especially not in the classless US, in Mr Sheidlower's view.

A combined entry for the f-word and the c-word, written after the Lady Chatterley trial made it legal to print them in the 1960s, said both were "for centuries, and still by the great majority, regarded as a taboo-word; until recent times not often recorded in print but frequent in coarse speech".

fields.headline: BT worker's £129,000 racial abuse payout
fields.standfirst: Colleagues told victim he was the 'next Stephen Lawrence'
fields.trailText: A British Telecom worker who was subjected to three years of racial abuse and bullying by colleagues has been awarded £129,000 in compensation.
fields.body:
A British Telecom worker who was subjected to three years of racial abuse and bullying by colleagues has been awarded £129,000 in compensation.

Nathan Lee, 53, who is of Chinese origin, told an industrial tribunal that he had twice considered committing suicide after he was threatened with being run over by a fork-lift truck, told he would be beaten up and had staples hidden in his food.

At one point colleagues threatened that he would be "the next Stephen Lawrence".

Yesterday Mr Lee, who worked at the BT depot in Crayford, Kent, said he was disappointed by the size of the payout after his legal representatives had pushed for a sum of at least £280,000.

"It is much lower than I had anticipated. I am now considering a possible appeal against the size of the award with my solicitors and my barrister.

"I feel this does not reflect the ordeal I suffered. I was expecting compensation well over £200,000. I'm not being greedy - I want justice."

Mr Lee's ordeal began in May 1995 and went on until May 1998, when the contract for his £22,000-a-year job was terminated. He told the hearing, which sat in November, that although he had complained to management about the treatment he had suffered, no action was taken against the perpetrators.

Mr Lee, who now walks with a stick, told the tribunal that the Stephen Lawrence threat was "the final straw". His ordeal had been compounded by BT's failure to apologise and by having to relive his nightmare at the hearing.

"I was in constant fear of my life as a result of threats I was receiving at work," he said.

He told the tribunal the abuse had wrecked his health, shattered his confidence and made him wish that he was not Chinese.

He described how he had thought about killing himself.

"I knew there was some rat poison in the cellar and I sat down and put the poison in my hand and went to put it in my mouth. Then I remembered the words of a teacher who told me as a child it was wrong to commit suicide."

Mr Lee, who made 20 unsuccessful attempts to find work after his dismissal in May 1998, told the tribunal: "I feel that life has no purpose for me. I often wish an accident would happen to me so I would die.

"I feel unable to carry on. I still feel frightened when I leave my house in case someone attacks me."

Describing his workplace, where most of his colleagues were white, Mr Lee said: "There was an atmosphere of mob rule. I was publicly humiliated and denigrated.

"These acts did not take place on a one-to-one basis. I became isolated and ostracised by my fellow workers. I was treated like a second-class citizen."

Mr Lee, who began to keep a diary of the abuse he suffered, told the tribunal how his colleagues targeted his food. One worker publicly accused him of eating "camel shit" in the depot's canteen and on another occasion he said he found staples hidden in his noodles. One of his tormentors brought a flick-knife to work and hurled it at a bench next to where Mr Lee was standing, calling him a "bastard Chinaman".

Mr Lee found out about the award yesterday when the employment tribunal wrote to his solicitors.

Ajmail Hussein, Mr Lee's legal representative from the employment specialists Gadwah Solicitors, said: "We shall be studying all the documents which outline the reasons for the tribunal deciding to award this amount of money before deciding our next move, but this is lower than we had anticipated."

fields.headline: Punishment shooting hits Ulster hopes
fields.standfirst:
IRA attack comes as Mandelson speaks of 'window of opportunity' for restoring suspended Northern Ireland assembly before Easter
Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The IRA yesterday carried out its first punishment shooting in almost five months, leaving a 30-year-old man in hospital in Belfast with wounds to both legs.
fields.body:
The IRA yesterday carried out its first punishment shooting in almost five months, leaving a 30-year-old man in hospital in Belfast with wounds to both legs.

The assault was another blow to the fragile peace process. It came as the British and Irish governments were beginning to address ways of reframing the arms decommissioning issue.

They had viewed as significant the IRA's move away from such attacks after Sinn Fein criticised them at the conclusion of ex-US senator George Mitchell's review of the Good Friday agreement in November. They see an end to punishment attacks as an important confidence-building gesture.

The IRA has halted punishment shootings and assaults at Sinn Fein's behest at key points before. There were no attacks in the six weeks leading up to President Clinton's first visit to Northern Ireland in 1995 or in the same period before the Good Friday agreement was sealed in 1998.

The latest victim was shot in both knees in the republican Ardoyne area of north Belfast. He underwent surgery at the Royal Victoria hospital.

Republican sources said crime and anti-social behaviour, including joy-riding and drug-dealing, was on the increase in many areas since the IRA stopped punishment shootings. There have been five beatings since the Sinn Fein statement. The last IRA punishment shooting was in October in Strabane, Co Tyrone. RUC figures demonstrate that loyalist attacks have continued, with 17 shootings in the same period.

The attack follows the abduction close to midnight on Wednesday of Mark Kelly, 22, from Armagh. Five masked men abducted him in a Ford Transit van which police believe crossed the border into Monaghan. Detectives believe the IRA could be responsible, and are increasingly concerned for Mr Kelly's safety.

Mick Conlon, Sinn Fein councillor for north Belfast, refused to condemn yesterday's IRA shooting. He said such incidents were regrettable, but said residents in deprived communities often demanded them because of what he called the ongoing policing vacuum in republican areas.

But SDLP councillor Alban Maginness said: "The IRA is indifferent to the Mitchell principles of democracy and non-violence _ people in the Ardoyne do not support such punishment shootings. They do not want to see human rights undermined by the IRA."

Father Patrick McCafferty, who led the funeral service last year for Eamon Molloy, one of the IRA's so-called disappeared victims, said: "I would hope such attacks end immediately. They serve no purpose. They are fruitless and barbarous."

In trying to find a solution to the decommissioning deadlock, which saw the suspension of the Stormont institutions last month, the Irish government has called for immediate moves on demilitarisation. It also indicated last weekend it was prepared to accept an extension to the May 22 deadline in the agreement for arms to be put beyond use.

Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, did not desist from either proposal in a key speech in Dublin on Thursday, and even appeared to back an altered timeframe for decommissioning during a radio interview yesterday. Unionists suspect Dublin is engaged in a kite-flying exercise with his approval.

Mr Mandelson yesterday spoke of a window of opportunity for restoring the institutions before Easter, but offered no reason for his optimism.

Meanwhile, detectives investigating the murder of solicitor Rosemary Nelson last March were still questioning a couple after officers discovered ammunition at their home near Armagh.

They are the first people to be arrested as part of the year-long inquiry, and can be detained for up to seven days under the prevention of terrorism act.

Norfolk deputy chief constable Colin Port was called in to lead the allegation because of claims of police collusion in Ms Nelson's murder in a car bomb attack at her home in Lurgan, Co Armagh. His team of 65 officers, including 20 from the RUC, has so far interviewed 5,000 people.

webTitle: Head of fresh start school quits

fields.headline: Head of fresh start school quits
fields.trailText: The first "superhead", brought in to turn round a failing school in Islington, north London, resigned unexpectedly yesterday from his £70,000 a year job.
fields.body:
The first "superhead", brought in to turn round a failing school in Islington, north London, resigned unexpectedly yesterday from his £70,000 a year job.

Torsten Friedag was appointed in January last year to head the failing George Orwell school, which was reopened as the Islington Arts and Media school last autumn.

The school, refurnished at a cost of £8m was relaunched under the government's fresh start scheme, whereby schools with a poor record are given a change of name and staff.

The education and employment secretary, David Blunkett, endorsed Mr Friedag's appointment and attended the reopening amid a fanfare of publicity.

Mr Friedag was hailed as a visionary head capable of turning around a school which had become notorious for poor academic performance, truancy, violence and disruption.

But yesterday Islington education authority said in a statement that he had decided that the interests of the pupils would be best served if someone with "different skills" took the school on to its next stage.

It is understood that the poor attendance and violent behaviour among pupils that had characterised the George Orwell school were still prevalent.

Islington's acting director of education, Simon Jenkins, called Mr Friedag's resignation a "brave and mature decision".

Mr Friedag said: "The establishment of the school has been a great enterprise. I am sad to be leaving, and I gave this a great deal of thought. I am proud of what we have achieved.

"I do believe it is the right time for somebody else to take on the challenge."

The resignation is a blow to the fresh start policy. Doug McAvoy, general secretary of the National Union of Teachers, said that if the scheme were "done properly and without the glare of publicity that generally accompanies it, it could work."

webTitle: Thirty injured at Waterloo train crash

fields.headline: Thirty injured at Waterloo train crash
fields.standfirst: More about transport
fields.trailText: A passenger was seriously injured and 29 others were hurt when their train hit empty carriages waiting at a platform at Waterloo station, London, yesterday. It was the third serious rail incident since the Paddington train crash in October.
fields.body:
A passenger was seriously injured and 29 others were hurt when their train hit empty carriages waiting at a platform at Waterloo station, London, yesterday. It was the third serious rail incident since the Paddington train crash in October.

The accident happened when a South West Trains service carrying 120 people struck a set of empty carriages at platform five, shunting them into buffers.

A man with facial injuries was taken to hospital for treatment with his neck in a cushioned brace. Three passengers needed stretchers. Paramedics treated others for whiplash injuries, leg injuries and cuts and bruises.

Fourteen, including one seriously hurt passenger, were taken to the nearby St Thomas' hospital. Others were treated at University College hospital and Waterloo medical centre.

South West Trains at once dismissed signalling or track faults as a cause of the crash. Its chief executive, Graham Eccles, said, "It is either a fault of the train or driver error. The driver is shocked."

Calling the crash "regrettable", Mr Eccles said the track was not damaged. But the force of the accident had been enough to displace sinks on the moving train.

The train, the 13.09 from Hampton Court, was arriving at Waterloo to be linked with the empty carriages to form a 13.52 service to Chessington.

British transport police said the train driver was found to be negative in a routine breathalyser test.

In January part of a South West Trains commuter service from Salisbury to Waterloo left the track near Hook, Hampshire, and careered for more than 400 yards before "jumping" back on to the line.

On December 16 a Connex train from Gillingham, Kent, to Charing Cross derailed inside a tunnel near Strood station. Passengers were stranded for 45 minutes.

fields.headline: Hospital waiting lists up 10,000
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Hospital waiting lists grew by more than 10,000 during the flu crisis in January, leaving the government seriously adrift of its target to cut treatment queues before the next general election.
fields.body:
Hospital waiting lists grew by more than 10,000 during the flu crisis in January, leaving the government seriously adrift of its target to cut treatment queues before the next general election.

Although the January increase, announced yesterday, was not as bad as had been feared, Labour has to achieve a further cut of more than 60,000 in numbers waiting in England if it is to hit its target.

John Denham, the health minister, forecast figures for February and March would show a resumed fall and said the government remained "well on target" to go into the election showing its promised net reduction of 100,000.

If last year's trend is repeated, however, there will be a substantial rise in April when hospitals scale down surgery sessions at Easter. And with next winter likely to produce further increases, as wards are cleared in anticipation of seasonal pressures, ministers will know they must get significantly ahead of their target by the end of November in readiness for an election in spring 2001.

The latest figures show that 1,118,700 people were awaiting treatment at the end of January, up 10,700 on the previous month. The number waiting more than a year rose sharply, by 4.7%, to 53,700. Of these, 97 had been in the queue for 18 months or more in breach of the guarantee in the NHS patient's charter - the fourth successive month more than 60 people were in this position.

The department of health used to come down heavily on any hospital reporting an 18-month wait, but the failing now appears to be overlooked.

Mr Denham said the "relatively small" overall rise in the number waiting was a tribute to the planning for winter pressures and the hard work and dedication of health workers. An alternative interpretation would be that the much publicised problems of the NHS in the post-Christmas flu outbreak were less widespread than was suggested at the time.

One health region, Northern and Yorkshire, managed to achieve a marginal reduction in its waiting list in January. Three regions - London, the South West and the South East - together accounted for 60% of the net increase.

Liam Fox, shadow health secretary, said the figures showed the NHS was getting worse under Labour. "To rub salt into the NHS's wounds, the government is diverting funds from patient care into making the health service Euro-compliant, feeding the prime minister's obsession with scrapping the pound.

"The public will quite rightly wonder what sort of warped priorities the government actually has. It is quite clear that New Labour puts politics before patients."

Mr Denham said the "relatively small" overall rise in the number waiting was a tribute to the planning for winter pressures and the hard work and dedication of health workers. An alternative interpretation would be that the much publicised problems of the NHS in the post-Christmas flu outbreak were less widespread than was suggested at the time. One health region, Northern and Yorkshire, managed to achieve a marginal reduction in its waiting list in January. Three regions - London, the South West and the South East - together accounted for 60% of the net increase. Liam Fox, shadow health secretary, said the figures showed the NHS was getting worse under Labour. "To rub salt into the NHS's wounds, the government is diverting funds from patient care into making the health service Euro-compliant, feeding the prime minister's obsession with scrapping the pound. "The public will quite rightly wonder what sort of warped priorities the government actually has. It is quite clear that New Labour puts politics before patients."

fields.headline: Inquiry damns solicitors' leader
fields.trailText: Complaints of bullying against Kamlesh Bahl, vice president of the Law Society, have been upheld in a damning report following an inquiry by a retired law lord.
fields.body:
Complaints of bullying against Kamlesh Bahl, vice president of the Law Society, have been upheld in a damning report following an inquiry by a retired law lord.

The result of Lord Griffiths's report, delivered to the society yesterday, has thrown into doubt Ms Bahl's succession to the presidency, which had been set for July. She had been on course to lead the 80,000 solicitors in England and Wales as their first woman and first ethnic minority president, when five of the society's staff made allegations of bullying and harassment against her.

The complaints escalated into a public row, with Ms Bahl accusing the president, Robert Sayer, of threatening to have her physically removed from the premises, an allegation he denies, backed up by the society's secretary general, Jane Betts. Mr Sayer asked Ms Bahl to stay away from the society's headquarters in Chancery Lane, central London, while the complaints were investigated, but she refused to go.

Lord Griffiths's inquiry team, which included two members of the employment appeal tribunal, said they regretted that they were driven to conclude that at times Ms Bahl resorted to bullying tactics. She had "treated staff without due consideration, demanding immediate responses to her own wishes without due regard for their other duties." At times she was "demeaning and humiliating" and at other times "offensively aggressive".

The panel concluded: "In many ways she usurped the secretary general's role as head of staff and introduced an atmosphere of fear and confusion in the line of command."

The report made no recommendations and left the society to decide how to handle the "delicate matter".

Ms Bahl, a former chairwoman of the equal opportunities commission, has signalled she will not go quietly. She announced this week that she had assembled a legal team to consider a high court challenge to the society's disciplinary procedures.

She told the Law Society Gazette: "I have some severe concerns about the process. It is very important the society examines the manner in which the complaints have been handled. I don't believe they were handled in the best possible way or that I have been treated fairly." She added: "Instead of matters being handled confidentially, there has been a public witchhunt on the front pages of daily newspapers."

The Manufacturing Science and Finance union, which represents society staff, said yesterday that bullying at work should be dealt with severely.

Its regional official, Peter Skyte, said the union demanded firm and appropriate action against Ms Bahl. "In an employee this would be viewed as gross misconduct, resulting in dismissal and we expect no less a penalty or different standards for a Law Society office holder.

The society said in a statement that the report would be considered at its council meeting on Thursday; until then it would be inappropriate to comment. Ms Bahl could not be reached for comment last night.

fields.headline: Brady 'just playing the system'
fields.standfirst:
Force-feeding 'paranoid' moors murderer lawful and fair, says judge
Inside court 6-1
Angela Neustatter: my father met Ian Brady
fields.trailText: The decision to force-feed Ian Brady was "in all respects lawful, rational and fair," ruled Mr Justice Kay yesterday as he rejected the moors murderer's challenge to Ashworth hospital's refusal to let him starve.
fields.body:
The decision to force-feed Ian Brady was "in all respects lawful, rational and fair," ruled Mr Justice Kay yesterday as he rejected the moors murderer's challenge to Ashworth hospital's refusal to let him starve.

He said he was satisfied Brady had started the hunger strike in protest at being moved from one ward to another at the Merseyside hospital. The judge held that Brady had never told medical officer James Collins that it was his intention to starve himself to death.

In reaching his decision, he had been swayed by Dr Collins, who described Brady as psychopathic, prone to narcissism, egocentricity, histrionics, obsessionality, need for control, paranoia, litigiousness, lack of remorse and lack of empathy.

While Brady did not consent to artificial feeding via a tube inserted through his nose to his stomach, he did not offer any resistance either. According to Dr Collins, Brady had talked of receiving a massive psychological boost from previous hunger strikes which he saw as a battle of wills with the authorities.

Dr Collins told the hearing, held in private at the high court in Liverpool last week at the request of Brady's solicitors, that after the transfer from Jade ward last September, he had "felt the need to do something and get his own back and exercise the control and address the needs of his self confidence and narcissism".

The doctor had concluded that Brady's decision to refuse food was caused by the personality disorder. It was "a very, very unusual decision by a very, very unusual person" in circumstances which were not very unusual, though they were legitimate grounds for complaint.

Brady's hunger strike began after a six-strong control and restraint team entered his room in full riot gear without warning on September 30, last year. The judge said: "Without offering any explanation they manhandled him, strip-searched him and took him under restraint to a waiting van. Half an hour after their arrival in his room, the team delivered the applicant to Lawrence ward, where he remained under restraint until the team withdrew. The total period of restraint lasted for about 50 minutes.

"The response of the applicant to these events was an immediate refusal to take food or nutritionally sweetened drinks. From that day to this he has been on hunger strike. It is clear from the medical records and not disputed by the applicant that, in the early stages, his motive was to protest rather than to starve himself to death. He had deployed hunger strikes as a tactic with the prison authorities many years before."

Under the mental health act 1983, patients suffering from a mental disorder may be given treatment against their will, including force-feeding, if the treatment is for the disorder they suffer from. The courts have held that this is lawful even if the patient is mentally competent to refuse the treatment.

So a central issue in the Brady case was whether the force-feeding could be said to be treatment for his personality disorder.

Under the broad wording of the particular section in the act, said the judge, a range of acts ancillary to the main treatment were covered.

He was "entirely satisfied" that the decision to start and continue force-feeding was justified by the act and was "in all respects lawful, rational and fair".

Where a case is not covered by the act, force-feeding can be done only if the patient lacks the mental capacity to take his own decisions. In that case the doctor can impose feeding in the patient's best interests.

The judge said that had Brady's case not come under the act, feeding was still lawful because he lacked the capacity to take decisions as a result of his disorder, and doctors had lawfully taken the steps they did "in what they have lawfully and reasonably perceived to be his best interests."

Brady had been engaged in a battle of wills so that, as a result of his severe personality disorder, he had eschewed weighing up information and balancing risks and needs, which mean his decisions were taken without capacity.

The judge said he was unable to arrive at a certain conclusion as to what Brady's present intention was. "That is one of the consequences of trying to assess the workings of such a disordered personality and mind," he said.

"Looking at the history of the present hunger strike and what the applicant has and has not said about it, I can see very little material prior to the commencement of proceedings which would point to a clear, settled or unequivocal intention on the part of the applicant to starve himself to death.

"Dr Collins takes the view that these proceedings are a staging post on the road to renegotiations.

"In my judgment, that is probably correct and the likelihood (but not the certainty) is that the applicant is playing the system."

webTitle: Injunction on Downing St nanny's story is upheld

fields.headline: Injunction on Downing St nanny's story is upheld
fields.trailText: A Sunday newspaper yesterday failed in its high court attempt to overturn a legal ban on publishing details about nanny Ros Mark's life with the prime minister's family.
fields.body:
A Sunday newspaper yesterday failed in its high court attempt to overturn a legal ban on publishing details about nanny Ros Mark's life with the prime minister's family.

A judge continued an injunction obtained in the early hours of last Sunday against the Mail on Sunday by Tony Blair's wife, Cherie.

Before the hearing, it was announced that Mrs Blair had dropped her claim for damages against Ms Mark over the publication of details of the Blairs' life in Downing Street.

In a joint statement issued by Mrs Blair and Ms Mark, Mrs Blair accepted that Ms Mark had not sent a 450-page account of her life with the Blairs to the Mail on Sunday.

In return for Mrs Blair dropping legal proceedings, Ms Mark agreed to return any copies of the manuscript still in her possession and to keep confidential any information she had about the prime minister's family.

The statement said: "The Blairs stand by the supportive words of the prime minister about Ros Mark on Sunday and they do not believe that Ros Mark would knowingly do or say anything that would damage or embarrass their family. Ros Mark has reiterated that she has at no stage authorised publication of any material relating to the Blairs, nor would she have authorised any such publication without the Blairs' consent."

webTitle: Trials of GM crops given go-ahead

fields.headline: Trials of GM crops given go-ahead
fields.standfirst: GM food: special report
fields.trailText: Full-scale trials of three GM crops across England and Wales were given the go-ahead last night by an independent committee of scientists, to the anger of environment groups.
fields.body:
Full-scale trials of three GM crops across England and Wales were given the go-ahead last night by an independent committee of scientists, to the anger of environment groups.

The government feared the trials would have to be abandoned because not enough farmers could be found willing to plant the crops, but ministers were said to have "put a rocket" under the biotech industry and a number of new farmer "volunteers" were found in the last two weeks.

After an eight-hour meeting yesterday scientists agreed that 15 fields of genetically modified oilseed rape, 16 fields of GM maize and 25 fields of mixed GM sugar and fodder beet could be planted this spring. The fields will be monitored regularly to check the effect on animals and birds, field weeds, and the spread of pollen to see if it contaminates other crops or wild plants.

Greenpeace described the plan last night as "a potential tragedy and genetic tyranny".

The agreement on where the plantings were to be placed should have been reached a month ago but there were fewer than half the farmers needed for meaningful trials. Planting should have started on March 1, and will now be delayed for at least another three weeks to give time for the sites to be advertised in local newspapers to warn people where the trials are taking place. One scientist on the committee said: "It's a very tight timetable now but just about credible."

Michael Meacher, the environment minister, who insisted that the trials should take place to check that GMs did not have an adverse effect on the British environment, will be mightily relieved. He will announce that the trials will go ahead and produce maps of the sites at a press conference next week.

Last night Peter Melchett, executive director of Greenpeace, who is due to go on trial with 27 others for criminal damage on April 3 after attacking a GM crop last summer, was dismayed that the trials were going ahead.

He said: "This is a potential tragedy for the environment. Britain will be bombarded with GM pollen without any regard for wildlife, the public or GM free farmers. The whole process has been nothing short of genetic tyranny with an almost complete absence of public consultation.

"The government seem hellbent on spending taxpayers money to promote a polluting technology that nobody wants which poses real threats to organic growers and beekeepers."

Greenpeace is to continue its campaign against the crops and will declare GM-free zones, inviting local people to join in keeping the crops out. Areas where the crop trials are to take place will be leafletted "to inform people of the hazards they pose" but the organisation will stop short of inciting people to destroy them.

The cabinet office, which controls government comments on GM matters, said in a statement that the committee had found enough fields. Details would be announced next Thursday.

"The UK has led the world by setting up these scientific trials. They will provide the important answers to key environmental questions. Ministers have made it perfectly clear that there will not be commercial growing in this country until they are satisfied there will be no unnacceptable affects on the environment." The statement said there would be no commercial production until the trials were completed.

The scientific steering committee includes members from English Nature, the RSPB, the Game Conservancy and the Institute of Environmental and Grassland Research.

They were urged not to speak to the press. However, one said that at the last minute the industry had found volunteers from enough places to make the trials worthwhile.

That meant that in a variety of locations and different farming methods it was possible to test the effects of growing the crops.

"In some parts of the country there is practically no wildlife left because of intensive farming so the effect of GM crops would be hard to measure. In other less intensive areas there might be a direct effect. It is these things we have to measure."

The trials are to last three years. The biotech industry has to find more volunteers for autumn planting of crops.

fields.headline: Livingstone campaign setback
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone's campaign to become independent mayor of London suffered a setback yesterday when it emerged that activists in his Brent East constituency voted by 2-1 to back Frank Dobson's rival candidacy.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone's campaign to become independent mayor of London suffered a setback yesterday when it emerged that activists in his Brent East constituency voted by 2-1 to back Frank Dobson's rival candidacy.

Since the local party had earlier urged their MP to "stay and fight" after Mr Dobson's victory in Labour's electoral college, Thursday night's vote was no surprise.

But the 31-14 vote underlined the hope of party HQ at Millbank that far fewer activists than feared would follow Mr Livingstone out of the party, especially as it will not discipline dissidents unless they are clearly seen to be campaigning for the former GLC leader or putting his posters up in their windows.

webTitle: Brady fails to win right to die in jail

fields.headline: Brady fails to win right to die in jail
fields.standfirst:
Inside court 6-1
Angela Neustatter: my father met Ian Brady
fields.trailText: The Moors murderer Ian Brady failed yesterday in his legal move to be allowed to starve himself to death.
fields.body:
The Moors murderer Ian Brady failed yesterday in his legal move to be allowed to starve himself to death.

Mr Justice Maurice Kay, at the high court in Liverpool, said the decision by doctors at Ashworth hospital, Merseyside, to start force-feeding Brady last October was "in all respects lawful, rational and fair".

The judge held that artificial feeding through a tube inserted in Brady's stomach through his nose was lawful under the 1983 mental health act, which allows treatment for a mental disorder to be administered against the patient's will. He said treatment included acts ancillary to the main treatment.

Had the case not come under the act, the judge said the force-feeding would still be lawful because Brady lacked the mental capacity to take decisions for himself, and therefore doctors could treat him against his will in his best interests. Brady's severe personality disorder prevented him from weighing up information and balancing risks and needs, thereby depriving him of the capacity to decide for himself.

The judge refused permission to appeal against the decision.

Brady, 62, who was in court for last week's hearing, held in private, was not there yesterday to hear the result. He said in a statement: "I have prepared myself for today's decision which means that I am still not allowed to starve myself to death, nothwithstanding the fact that the eminent professor of forensic psychiatry, Tony Maden, was satisfied that my decision was unimpaired by my mental illness."

fields.headline: Soccer legend Best renounces alcohol
fields.standfirst:
Football Unlimited
Manchester United Biography of George Best
Cromwell Liver Centre
Liver disease: FAQs from the Texas Liver Organisation
fields.trailText: George Best, who became a legend on the football pitch and then in the country's pubs and clubs, yesterday vowed to finish one of the most colourful aspects of his career when he said he would give up drinking.
fields.body:
George Best, who became a legend on the football pitch and then in the country's pubs and clubs, yesterday vowed to finish one of the most colourful aspects of his career when he said he would give up drinking.

Best, 53, who is being treated at the Cromwell hosptial, west London, for a suspected alcohol-related illness told his personal assistant Phil Hughes that his days of drinking binges were over and he would never touch a drink again.

Mr Hughes said: "After this he will have to stop drinking. He has said as much. His wife Alex will be pleased. He is not fighting for his life. He's quite happy, he's doing the crossword with his wife. He is up and about now but will be here for another week."

Best, who lives in Chelsea, west London, was initially seen by doctors last weak after complaining of feeling unwell and suffering from severe stomach pains.

A number of tests were conducted and he was told to return to hospital on Wednesday, where he was kept in by doctors and is expected to remain for another seven days.

Roger Williams, Best's consultant, said that he was showing signs of improvement with his liver condition and was eating well and was in good spirits. Prof Williams added there was "every expectation" that Best would make a substantial recovery.

During his heyday with Manchester United and Northern Ireland in the 1960s and 1970s, Best illuminated matches with his sumptuous skills.

In recent weeks friends had noticed that Best had been feeling particularly unwell and looking pale. According to some reports, he was taken to hospital after his skin turned yellow, a symptom of jaundice which is one of the first signs of cirrhosis of the liver.

John Farrar, Best's agent, yesterday denied that he was at death's door or that his liver had failed but confirmed that the former footballer's illness was long-standing.

Mr Farrar said: "We do not yet know what is the matter but George has certainly not been well for some time. The tests have been done so we can get to the bottom of what is wrong with him.

"The talk of him being at death's door has been blown out of proportion. It is likely to be a few days before we know the full outcome and in the meantime we have to leave it to the medical experts."

Best has received flowers from Noel and Meg Gallagher as well as "get well" messages from comic Jimmy Tarbuck, and chat show host Michael Parkinson, who has known him for more than 30 years.

He said: "He's in there because of what he does to himself. He knows he's got a problem - now he knows he's got to deal with it. He's had a severe warning."

He's quite happy, he's doing the crossword with his wife. He is up and about now but will be here for another week." Best, who lives in Chelsea, west London, was initially seen by doctors last weak after complaining of feeling unwell and suffering from severe stomach pains. A number of tests were conducted and he was told to return to hospital on Wednesday, where he was kept in by doctors and is expected to remain for another seven days. Roger Williams, Best's consultant, said that he was showing signs of improvement with his liver condition and was eating well and was in good spirits. Prof Williams added there was "every expectation" that Best would make a substantial recovery. During his heyday with Manchester United and Northern Ireland in the 1960s and 1970s, Best illuminated matches with his sumptuous skills. In recent weeks friends had noticed that Best had been feeling particularly unwell and looking pale. According to some reports, he was taken to hospital after his skin turned yellow, a symptom of jaundice which is one of the first signs of cirrhosis of the liver. John Farrar, Best's agent, yesterday denied that he was at death's door or that his liver had failed but confirmed that the former footballer's illness was long-standing. Mr Farrar said: "We do not yet know what is the matter but George has certainly not been well for some time. The tests have been done so we can get to the bottom of what is wrong with him. "The talk of him being at death's door has been blown out of proportion. It is likely to be a few days before we know the full outcome and in the meantime we have to leave it to the medical experts." Best has received flowers from Noel and Meg Gallagher as well as "get well" messages from comic Jimmy Tarbuck, and chat show host Michael Parkinson, who has known him for more than 30 years. He said: "He's in there because of what he does to himself. He knows he's got a problem - now he knows he's got to deal with it. He's had a severe warning."

webTitle: Blair rounds on Scottish backers of section 28

fields.headline: Blair rounds on Scottish backers of section 28
fields.standfirst: More about section 28
fields.trailText: Tony Blair went head to head with the pro-section 28 movement in Scotland yesterday, lambasting as utter nonsense a high-profile advertising campaign to keep the clause.
fields.body:
Tony Blair went head to head with the pro-section 28 movement in Scotland yesterday, lambasting as utter nonsense a high-profile advertising campaign to keep the clause.

In a strongly worded speech to the Scottish Labour party conference in Edinburgh he said he had been astonished at the tactics adopted by anti-repeal campaigners. His comments were attacked by the Stagecoach tycoon, Brian Souter, who has funded the campaign with £500,000 of his own money.

During his two-day visit to Scotland, Mr Blair has been constantly confronted by hoardings and media adverts against repeal of section 28, which bans the promotion of the acceptability of homosexuality in schools.

On Thursday evening, his entourage had to run a gauntlet of chanting protesters outside a school in Kilsyth, north of Glasgow.

"Drugs are the real threat to our children, not the phony threat plastered all over these clause 28 posters around Scotland," Mr Blair told the delegates yesterday. "I've never seen anything more extraordinary. No wonder parents are concerned.

"They're told we're going to make kids have homosexual role playing. Kids are going to be force-fed gay sex education. And it's Donald [Dewar, Scotland's first minister] who's doing it. What utter nonsense."

Mr Blair said no child was going to be given gay sex lessons in school; sex education in schools would only be given in consultation with parents; and parents could withdraw children from sex education.

"In England, clause 28 hasn't even applied to schools for the past six years and not a single one of these invented situations has ever taken place. That poster campaign has no place in proper political debate," he said.

Mr Souter said Mr Blair was out of touch with the views of the Scottish people. "Tony Blair's attacks on the keep the clause campaign are completely unjustified and he is out of touch with the people on these issues. Seventy-one per cent of his own constituents oppose repeal. These posters are entirely accurate.

"Scottish parents don't need a lecture from Tony Blair who can now return to England safe in the knowledge that his children are bussed halfway across London each day to grant-maintained schools where he is assured that only traditional values are promulgated. Unlike Scottish children who will be left unprotected and vulnerable after the repeal of section 28."

Repeal of the clause has been badly mishandled by the Scottish executive and some Labour delegates said yesterday that the strong stance taken by Mr Blair only pointed up the hesitancy and lack of conviction on the issue shown by the first minister and his cabinet.

After weeks of controversy, the executive finally agreed a vaguely worded replacement clause which stresses the importance of stable family life.

Mr Blair's speech in Edinburgh was designed to rally the increasingly fractured Scottish wing of the party.

As well as the handling of section 28, the Scottish executive has come under attack for the cost and viability of the new parliament building, the compromise deal struck on tuition fees and growing questions over Donald Dewar's authority.

webTitle: John Major bows out, diffident to the end

fields.headline: John Major bows out, diffident to the end
fields.standfirst: Hague pays tribute to former premier, but Thatcher remains silent
fields.trailText: John Major, the most diffident British prime minister of the 20th century, last night bowed out of elective politics in characteristic style. "I would rather go while I am being urged to stay rather than stay beyond the time when I would go," he explained - awkwardly, but with evident sincerity.
fields.body:
John Major, the most diffident British prime minister of the 20th century, last night bowed out of elective politics in characteristic style. "I would rather go while I am being urged to stay rather than stay beyond the time when I would go," he explained - awkwardly, but with evident sincerity.

William Hague led tributes to his contributions to public life during a meteoric 20-year career at Westminster. His remarks included praise for the "golden economic legacy" Mr Major handily bequeathed to Tony Blair in 1997 after the worst election defeat in 100 years, though Mr Hague did not put it that way.

Lady Thatcher, who promoted his candidacy after her dramatic fall in 1990 then harried his premiership to its ruin, did not issue an immediate tribute. Diehard Major loyalists in the moderate Tory ranks were not holding their breath last night.

What exactly Mr Major will do with his extra time was not immediately clear. He is entitled to a peerage and already has some useful outside earnings, including £25,000 a time appearances on the global lecture circuit.

He and his quietly determined wife, Dame Norma (who never wanted to live in Downing St and didn't), are soon to become grandparents. The underdog winner of the 1992 general election is also enough of a masochist to want to watch more English cricket.

His decision to stand down from the Commons and his ultra-safe seat at Huntingdon, at the expected election in mid-2001, at the young age of 58, follows a trend towards early retirement and post-political careers among ex-cabinet heavyweights.

Only Sir Edward Heath, Tory prime minister from 1970-74, has bucked the trend, by refusing to go to the Lords and staying on as an MP and father of the house until the age of 83. Even he admitted this week "there may be a limit" - a hint that he too may go.

Both ex-prime ministers are under pressure to make their positions known as the decks are cleared for the election. Huntingdon - where the Majors intend to go on living - is a Tory stronghold which survived 1997 with an 18,140 majority.

As a result the sound of Tory hopefuls heading down the M11 could be heard loud and clear last night while party leaders recalled what Charles Kennedy unkindly called his continuing "battle against extremism," including Mr Hague's.

Mr Hague concentrated on his predecessor's opt-out from the EU single currency, his work for peace in Northern Ireland and his negotiating skills. Mr Major repaid the courtesy by predicting that Mr Hague would make it to No 10 - one day.

First elected an MP in 1979 Mr Major did not shine in the galaxy of young Conservative talent - the Pattens and Waldegraves - who eventually served under him.

He rose by stealth, but fell rather more noisily as Britain's ejection from the European exchange rate (ERM) in 1992 crippled his authority and unleashed the Euro-sceptic flood.

Last night he said: "This decision, foreshadowed on the day after the last election, has been very hard for me to make. Nevertheless, my views on the morrow of defeat have not changed: after a great deal of soul-searching and sadness, I have decided that I should not contest the next general election."

Apart from his pension, his lectures and his unexpectedly successful memoirs, Mr Major sits on prestigious US-led boards, including the $3bn Carlyle Group, which raises private equity for the burgeoning IT industries.

Since his defeat in 1997 he has spoken in support of the Good Friday agreement and the war in Kosovo.

Mr Major has also notably relaxed, in comparison to his hyper-defensive seven years at the top. Recently he joked that in 1997 he would have come second - "even if I was the only candidate".

fields.headline: White' s week
fields.standfirst: Jim White explores the wider, weirder world of sport :  Flexing their muscles in search of the formula for success
fields.trailText: The formula for success, Dons on a slippery slope, and Stan on his own again.
fields.body:
There was a moment at Twickenham last Saturday when it became clear that a new world sporting order was in place. It was, by no coincidence at all, precisely the same moment that the shouty Welshman a couple of seats along from me finally sank his head in mute resignation. Garin Jenkins, the traditionally shaped Welsh hooker, a man whose chest begins just below his chin and continues south to his knees, had just lost the ball and looked up to see an awful white spectre swish past. It was Phil Greening, his opposite number, gambolling towards the line like a teenage full-back. Jenkins wheezed off in futile pursuit but the look on his face said it all: I am history.

In every sport, fitness and conditioning are on the march. Footballers who eat bananas are no longer considered deviants, runners bore on about their body-fat ratios, even hookers have ceased to be beer monsters. Microseconds win trophies and microseconds are now earned in the gym.

And nowhere is the change more noticeable than in formula one. Stirling Moss and Graham Hill might have warmed up for a grand prix season with a pipe and a handy Chateau Margaux, Nigel Mansell might have thought he was keeping in shape with the odd round of golf, but most of the drivers lining up at the start of tomorrow's Australian grand prix will have spent the past three months undertaking the kind of intensive training regimes more normally associated with Olympic oarsmen; most, though not Eddie Irvine, a driver whose idea of a cardiovascular work-out involves uncorking a bottle of Veuve Clicquot while cruising with a yacht-full of models round St Tropez harbour.

"I hear guys like Eddie saying they can go down the pub every night and still climb in a car the next morning," says Bernie Shrosbree, of the Benetton formula one team. "But Eddie, you're not world champion, mate. When you are, tell me about it."

Shrosbree was talking as he showed me round Benetton's new human-performance centre, a £4m facility at the team's headquarters a short spin from Silverstone. Formula one factories are mostly places that concentrate on mechanical performance, where mil lions are invested perfecting carbon-fibre wishbones and titanium push-rod rocker systems, the kind of engineering that can shave vital moments from lap times. But Shrosbree reckons that concentration on the fitness of the driver will produce equal dividends.

"A formula one race presents the physiological demands of a half-marathon. Plus, G-forces batter the driver, breaking down his strength continuously. Fatigue sets in, which is where mistakes are made. Quite simply, the fitter you are the better all your senses work," says Shrosbree, a former marine, triathlete and champion cross-country skier who, at the age of 41, is a terrifying advertisement for his cause.

"Everyone's talked about the need to get drivers fit but not many have done much about it, to be honest with you."

But now Benetton have. Shrosbree presides over a state-of-the-art clinic chock-full with alarming-looking pieces of gym equipment more readily associated with Torquemada than Murray Walker. Since the beginning of January he has been putting the two Benetton drivers Giancarlo Fisichella and Alexander Wurz through a pounding physical routine here, generally lasting more than five hours a day. Three months of that and they must be astonishing specimens.

"People often ask me how fit they are," says Shrosbree, a man who, one suspects, is not easily satisfied. "Compared to your average office worker, they're supermen. Compared to Daley Thompson, well... No disrespect, though, these guys have special skills. Just being superfit doesn't mean you'll win a formula one race. On the other hand, drivers need to be aware that they can't get away with that old cocky attitude of 'I can piss it' any more."

Now that the season is about to start, Shrosbree's work with the Benetton pair is complete. He will remain in Britain helping sportsmen from other disciplines who have heard about his facility; the rallying champion Colin McRae is a regular. So, away from his iron gaze, will his drivers maintain their schedule? Or will they succumb to the circuit with its myriad distractions which Irvine finds so seductive?

"They will be accompanied by a physio at all times," says Shrosbree. "But we have given them a routine that fits their needs. Ultimately it's up to them, but they're good lads, I think they are aware now it is in their best interests to keep it up. We may not have the fastest car but we've got the best-prepared drivers and I'm convinced it will give us an edge."

The proof of the Shrosbree way will come in Melbourne. But even if the Benetton car explodes in a plume of smoke on the first bend, the consolation is that at least his drivers will be in good enough shape to help push it back to the pits.

Dons on a slippery slope from heaven

When Sam Hammam heard this week that the transfer of John Hartson to Tottenham had fallen through he announced that God must be a Wimbledon season-ticket holder. A cynic might say there is something in it: if He were going to support anyone, the stands at Wimbledon would be the best place to display His divine uniqueness.

Dons fans, however, are thinking that if the man upstairs really is one of them, how come the future looks decidedly less than heavenly? Indeed, all the elements are in place for a horrible decline. The Norwegian owners appear to be wondering if, at £30m, they paid way over the odds for a club without tangible assets, what is known in football as doing a Goldberg. Good players, it has been announced, will have to go, as journeymen arrive from the owners' other club, Molde.

Meanwhile, with Hammam's departure the spirit that epitomised the team for so long is seeping away. To cap it all the new managing director decided to spend his first weekend in charge skiing rather than watching the team, which, as a piece of PR, makes Martin Edwards look like Max Clifford. Did anyone mention the words Crystal and Palace?

Stan gets it right at last

Only the stone-hearted would not have found a touch of sympathy for Stan Collymore this week. After playing at Forest, where if he scored a wonder goal his team-mates would spurn his celebrations and trot back to their own half, he moved to Liverpool where the reaction was much the same. At Aston Villa it got worse: his colleagues ignored him and his manager publicly maligned him. But then he moved to Leicester and finally found a forward partner who not only passed to him but set up a hat-trick and enthusiastically celebrated it with him into the bargain. And what happens? Before they can play together again, Emile Heskey moves to Liverpool. You're right, Stan: you are not being paranoid, the world really is out to get you.

fields.headline: Forever young and miserable
fields.standfirst: Jean-Michel Basquiat died at the tender age of 28, but his work was already full of death and decay.  Jonathan Jones reports
fields.trailText: Jean-Michel Basquiat died at the tender age of 28, but his work was already full of death and decay. Jonathan Jones reports
fields.body:
Jean-Michel Basquiat is a survivor - which is a strange thing to say about an artist who died of a heroin overdose at the age of 28. He's the New York art star of the 80s who still seems contemporary, while Keith Haring and Jeff Koons are as historical as Madonna. Basquiat just gets newer, more urgent, and the energy, wit and passion of his art are unmistakable in this retrospective of drawings and collages.

Basquiat was the author of his own myth, a romantic about art. His personal icon - a crown - is as much a trademark in this show as Joseph Beuys's felt hat. Like Beuys, Basquiat had an amazing ability to assimilate the stuff around him. The graffitist's urge to make a mark on the world translates in his drawings into an infectious aesthetic appetite. The jagged line of his crayon ranges across the history of art.

He takes the grand New York tradition of abstract expressionism, rubs its face in the dirt, and then makes it serve him. Sometimes he draws like the senile Willem de Kooning. Other times, he draws death in life: the skull beneath the skin. His skull portraits are not melancholy, but angry and vital. He is fascinated by anatomy and dedicates lithographs of disconnected spines, teeth, pelvic bones and skulls to Leonardo da Vinci. Basquiat anatomises a body, a self, flared and disassembled, in an art that is a carnival and a dance of death.

But the paradox of his art is that while it is full of self-assertion, it is really about the disintegration of self. His crowns and self-portraits cannot disguise a sense that everything in his bony drawings is crumbling to dust. Another of his icons is a dinosaur, T Rex, the unconquerable dead monster, wearing a crown.

Basquiat may assert a royal authorial presence, but the more you look at his art, the more you see decay. Like the refined, scholarly graffiti painter Cy Twombly, his drawings evoke a ruined city - New York. Twombly's graffiti is punitively scrawled on Roman ruins; Basquiat's is similarly full of archaeological obsessions, dinosaur bones, baseball cards, pictures from old newspapers, traces of pop culture gone by.

Rub out the word, said William Burroughs. Basquiat rubs out any illusion that American history coheres. His anarchic juxtapositions chronicle an America descending into chaos, from baseball players with their faces whited out to Lenny Bruce's US navy identification card to the inquiry into an assassination which announces: "We Have Decided The Bullet Must Have Been Going Very Fast."

 Jean-Michel Basquiat is at Stephen Lacey, London EC1 (0171-837 5507), till March 18.
