But the paradox of his art is that while it is full of self-assertion, it is really about the disintegration of self. His crowns and self-portraits cannot disguise a sense that everything in his bony drawings is crumbling to dust. Another of his icons is a dinosaur, T Rex, the unconquerable dead monster, wearing a crown. Basquiat may assert a royal authorial presence, but the more you look at his art, the more you see decay. Like the refined, scholarly graffiti painter Cy Twombly, his drawings evoke a ruined city - New York. Twombly's graffiti is punitively scrawled on Roman ruins; Basquiat's is similarly full of archaeological obsessions, dinosaur bones, baseball cards, pictures from old newspapers, traces of pop culture gone by. Rub out the word, said William Burroughs. Basquiat rubs out any illusion that American history coheres. His anarchic juxtapositions chronicle an America descending into chaos, from baseball players with their faces whited out to Lenny Bruce's US navy identification card to the inquiry into an assassination which announces: "We Have Decided The Bullet Must Have Been Going Very Fast."  Jean-Michel Basquiat is at Stephen Lacey, London EC1 (0171-837 5507), till March 18.

webTitle: Hick-hop wisdom with a funky strut

fields.headline: Hick-hop wisdom with a funky strut
fields.trailText: Lost in music
fields.body:
The "visitation" came earlier this week, when I was trying to find a reason to overcome my fear of a 35,000ft certain-death plunge and commit to a plane trip to New York to interview Richard Hell. What I needed was an omniscient outside voice with the erudition to appease the two squabbling voices inside my head, Live a Little and his adversary, But Think How High It Is. "Imagine how many planes are up in the air at this very moment," said Leo. Nope: heard that one before and it doesn't help. "Why not try one of those getting-you-through-it courses," offered Sam, before helpfully reminding me that a cockpit exploded on one of them recently. "If you're gonna go, you're gonna go," philosophised Jamie. But I needed more.

Then, spookily, with perfect timing, it arrived. A disembodied voice this time, tasting of hard- living, nicotine and wisdom, half-rapping to me over a funky strut and an epic, crashing backdrop redolent of Neil Young's The Loner: "Those who dwell on disaster, let sorrow be their master..."

There it is. I've admitted it. A song "spoke to me" and changed the course of my life. Pop became its old self - catalyst, as opposed to just screen saver. That's not supposed to happen these days, is it? But it did. It was real. Where the advice of friends failed, the wisdom of a transcendental melody and a world-weary voice succeeded.

Jim White, the composer of the song in question, Ten Miles to Go on a Nine Mile Road, would probably say this was all out of my control anyway, that decisions are just an illusion and the course of life is predetermined at God's weekly think-tank. He's that sort of guy: a former male model, fashion photographer, surfer, lifeguard, movie director, waiter, vagrant, preacher and construction worker, who didn't write his first song until he'd taken life, elucidated a flicker of sense from it, then turned it inside out to double check.

Most musicians talk about the problem of having a life's worth of experience to put into their first album and only a year or two's to put into the follow-up. White has a bigger challenge: he had around 60 lives' worth of experience to put into his 1997 debut LP, Wrong-Eyed Jesus, and now has to equal it. It wouldn't have been surprising, in fact, if he'd abandoned music in the same way that he'd abandoned his other careers, slipped off into the darkness only to turn up in Snitchbend, Colorado, as a travelling limerick salesman. But after a few minor hitches ("Jim who?" say Virgin, his ever-alert new British record label), I'm through to his New York number. Yes - he's still recording his second album, due for release towards the end of the year. This time he's got Morcheeba and Sade's old backing band, Sweetback, to help.

White recorded his first album for virtually nothing in a flash of post-nervous breakdown inspiration, after he'd financed his first feature film by driving a taxi for 100 hours a week in New York. Normally, you'd worry about the excruciating gestation period of its sequel, but White is such an all-seeing, all-knowing presence, you can't imagine him compromising for anyone.

Ten Miles to Go on a Nine Mile Road, a divine, almost skin-shedding leap from the DIY rural death songs on Wrong-Eyed Jesus, would be an appropriate epitaph for White, who, despite being more aware of the futility of existence than any other songwriter in the universe, is still out there, in there, searching. "One day it hit me," he said in 1998. "I realised that if I live enough antithetical lifestyles, I'll find my way back to myself." Wise, weather-beaten country ghost funk (or "hick-hop", as he calls it) is just another pitstop on his never-ending journey to a form of sanctity that doesn't come with a price sticker. Get on board while you've got the chance.

webTitle: That's what I call a school play

fields.headline: That's what I call a school play
fields.standfirst: A group of untrained Sussex teenagers took over grand old Glyndebourne last week - and brought the house down with their opera, Zoë.  Erica Jeal finds out how they did it
fields.trailText: A group of untrained Sussex teenagers took over grand old Glyndebourne last week - and brought the house down with their opera, Zoë. Erica Jeal finds out how they did it
fields.body:
Last week something unusual happened in the music world: the critics united in joyful approval of a new opera called Zoë. They praised its "darkling-chromatic, noir-ish" sound (the Financial Times) and its cast of "stars" (the Independent). "If I see another new opera as enthralling as Zoë this year," summed up Richard Morrison in the Times, "I shall count myself very lucky." There was talk of a transfer to London and a TV broadcast. What made the raves remarkable is that they were about an opera performed by a bunch of teenagers, with a libretto by a scriptwriter from The Bill. Zoë was the latest offering from Glyndebourne's education department.

The largely privately funded Glyndebourne had already proved it knew how to get things right. Misper, an opera for performers in their early teens, was staged in the main auditorium in February 1997 and was so successful, both educationally and artistically, that it was revived the following March.

The re-opening of the Royal Opera House and the creation of smaller performance spaces within it has given the ROH education department a chance to catch up with Glyndebourne's exemplary record. One of the first shows staged in its Linbury studio theatre in December was an education project. Separation: The Story of Bullman and the Moonsisters was the result of a six-month collaboration between the ROH education department and St Clement Danes, a state primary school in the neighbourhood. Workshop-style classes drew out the children's ideas and led to the creation of a storyline, a libretto, music, designs and ultimately a complete and structured opera company entirely staffed by schoolchildren aged seven to 11.

Every element of the production, from performing and fundraising to scenery building, was undertaken by the 101 children in the company. Professionals from the opera house were on hand to help, but the children were encouraged to work as independently as possible. A walk around the school in one of the periods set aside for opera would have convinced anyone that they were taking the work seriously: the two 10-year-old press officers, Jesus and Ryan, were so professional it seemed they had been doing the job for years.

Only a handful of the pupils who helped write the score and played in the orchestra were taking individual music lessons and hardly any could read music, but that didn't matter. Working with glockenspiels, xylophones and every other percussion instrument imaginable, composer John Browne taught basic ideas of pulse, rhythm and imagery and guided the children as they developed these into melodies and accompaniments. The end result was described as "inspiring, wildly entertaining and profoundly moving" by Opera magazine.

In contrast, Zoë was written for a cast of teenagers. Composer John Lunn and librettist Stephen Plaice used ideas from workshops they ran last summer in schools and sixth-form colleges around Brighton. Plaice found he didn't have to tone down the gritty style he had gleaned from The Bill - the happy ending he originally gave the work proved unpopular and was discarded for something that better reflected the dark side of adolescence.

The story of Zoë touches on a whole range of subjects, from eco-warriors and student-teacher affairs through to a first kiss. The music takes in pop, dance, contemporary classical and trip-hop. It is scored for a full orchestra (at Glyndebourne last week it was played by the Brighton Youth Orchestra) and an electronic clip track of drum beats, samples and scratches.

For seven weeks at the beginning of the year, rehearsals involving a cast of four adult professionals, eight teenage principals and a chorus of nearly 40 were held at a frosty and seemingly deserted Glyndebourne. Pupils from state schools within the east Brighton education action zone had been cast alongside those from private schools in the better-heeled areas of the town. Last week's audiences were also largely schoolchildren - with hotdogs and sweets replacing the usual interval picnics.

Katie Tearle, who has run Glyndebourne's education department since 1986, is the first to emphasise the range of benefits that projects such as Zoë can bring. "People can get their hands dirty," she says. "They can join in the creative process, meet composers, experience the whole professional way in which Glyndebourne puts on an opera. These are all valuable educational experiences."

Many of the performers will soon be sitting their A levels and one might expect them to be spending time on revision instead of opera. But director Stephen Langridge didn't find the timing of the project a problem. "All of the performers had to go through two or three auditions to get in. They're completely committed or they wouldn't be here."

Back at St Clement Danes, Separation was put together during the school timetable. In the weeks before the performances, the opera took up roughly half of the curriculum time. The children obviously had a great deal of fun. But was it educational? Rachel Hatter, a year four teacher, thinks so. "We saw the children becoming more independent, and the shyer ones coming out of their shells," she says. And, adds Darryl Jaffray, the ROH's director of education, "it was part of their curriculum. Everything they did was feeding some other aspect of their education."

This is the crux - these projects are designed to add to an education rather than to foster an immediate appreciation of Mozart and Puccini. Even after weeks of working to promote Separation, the St Clement Danes press officers weren't bowled over by the prospect of visits to the new Covent Garden. "I wouldn't mind going, but opera's not my favourite thing," said Jesus. Ryan agreed: he'd rather see a pantomime.

The Glyndebourne teenagers may perhaps be more likely to become interested in classical opera. Orlando Whippy, in his final year at Varndean sixth form college, started going to grand opera after being involved in Misper, but "it was normally my granddad dragging me along". And, for his classmate Poppy Roe, it was working with a professional company that has been the most rewarding aspect of Zoë, rather than an increased awareness of the joys of opera.

Fortunately, the managements of both Glyndebourne and Covent Garden seem to realise that the benefits of their education work are felt in many areas, not just the box office. Jesus and Ryan probably didn't suspect that they were giving something back to the Royal Opera. "We, too, learn from the people we work with," comments Darryl Jaffray. "The more people we involve, the richer our own product on stage will be." And Katie Tearle doesn't find it hard to picture any of the Zoë teenagers on the other side of the curtain in a few months. "They all now know that they can really be a part of opera, in all its guises. It's the best audience development we can do."

 Information about education projects can be found at www.glyndebourne.com and www.roh.org.uk/education/

fields.headline: The last word on...   Education
fields.standfirst: Only the educated are free - Epictetus
fields.trailText: Another senior Labour politician has sent his child to private school. Anyone needing to know why has only to consult these pages earlier this week for a graphic account of the difference between the opposite ends of Britain's educational spectrum. The facts are plain enough: private education succeeds, public education sometimes struggles and too often fails by comparison.
fields.body:
Another senior Labour politician has sent his child to private school. Anyone needing to know why has only to consult these pages earlier this week for a graphic account of the difference between the opposite ends of Britain's educational spectrum. The facts are plain enough: private education succeeds, public education sometimes struggles and too often fails by comparison.

Education has become a burning issue because - so all the measurements tell us - the majority of our children are not achieving nearly as much as they should. Blame is attributed to, among other things, a generation's worth of misplaced educational theory and practice.

In our contemporary view education is seen as essential to participation in an advanced economy. The economy itself requires an educated and motivated workforce, say the pundits, and individuals can only profit from opportunities afforded by such an economy if they are equipped to respond to its demands. Both these points are doubtless true; even if one regrets them to some degree, the facts of life make them unavoidable.

But a large part of the problem with education is that this connection has become too direct. Aristotle said that we educate ourselves so that we can make noble use of our leisure; this is a view directly opposed to the contemporary belief that we educate ourselves in order to get a job. To that extent the contemporary view distorts the purpose of schooling, by aiming not at the development of individuals as ends in themselves, but as instruments in the economic process.

The key is to distinguish education from training, to recognise that children require both, and to be unabashed about what is involved in the latter. Young children need to be trained in multiplication tables, reading, spelling and writing, exactly as an athlete trains his body: it takes coaching, repetition, and practice. When children have acquired skills they can use by reflex, it gives them the confidence and the materials to profit from the next step, which is education proper: the process of learn ing to think, to reflect, to reason, and to know how to find information when needed.

Above all, education involves refining capacities for judgment and evaluation; Heraclitus remarked that learning is only a means to an end, which is understanding - and understanding is the ultimate value in education.

"Education" etymologically means "leading out" or "bringing out", an idea that owes itself to Plato, who believed that we have pre-existing immortal souls which know all things in their disembodied state, but which we forget at birth. Thus, learning is remembering; schooling is the activity of bringing out our hidden memories.

That improbable notion was modified by later thinkers, for whom education became the evocation of talents and capabilities implicit in the individual. In one good sense, this is closer to the mark: we still think that human gifts can be helped to flourish if given the right opportunities.

But a school can only educate as well as train if the circumstances for doing so are right. A school is like a lens focusing the rays of the sun; it groups a substantial number of children together, thereby concentrating and magnifying the character of their community background. This explains much of the difference between schools whose pupils come from privileged, educated, wealthy, and aspirational backgrounds, as opposed to those that are deprived, impoverished, dysfunctional and limited.

In the case of so-called "sink" schools in problem areas, part of the solution is surely, therefore, to do the opposite of congregating children together during school hours; it is to have many smaller units with high staff-to-pupil ratios, where children can be treated and taught as individuals, and given an opportunity to experience the kind of intellectual space needed for assimilating what is learned, and connecting it with the wider educational experience.

Only then will they have a chance of the richer life indicated by Euripides when he said "He who misses the opportunity to learn loses the past and is dead to the future."

fields.headline: Roads to God
fields.standfirst:
Face to Faith

Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: In around 1678AD, an Algerian galley intercepted a British fishing vessel off the Spanish coast and took its crew captive. Among the prisoners was Joseph Pitts, a 15-year-old cabin boy, whom the abductors correctly surmised would fetch a handsome price in the slave market.
fields.body:
In around 1678AD, an Algerian galley intercepted a British fishing vessel off the Spanish coast and took its crew captive. Among the prisoners was Joseph Pitts, a 15-year-old cabin boy, whom the abductors correctly surmised would fetch a handsome price in the slave market.

Pitts was forced to renounce Christianity for Islam. But he was then bought by a elderly gentleman under whom he became the first known Englishman to perform the Hajj - or greater pilgrimage.

Pitts recognised that spiritual renewal was the essence of the Hajj, most visibly symbolised by the two white sheets worn for its duration by the pilgrims. Identical to the burial shrouds in which Muslims will be committed back to their creator (indeed many retain their pilgrimage garb for just this purpose), they signify a readiness to sacrifice everything for the love of God.

This is the sense in which the Hajj demands to be understood - not as an excursion to a foreign land but a departure from this very world. Having obeyed the innate spiritual calling to return to the source of his being, the hajji makes efforts to dispose of his affairs before he sets out. Wills are drawn up, creditors are repaid and forgiveness is asked.

Pilgrims make for Arafat, some 12 miles south-west of Mecca, the path before them resounding to the drone of the talbiyah, the ritual recitation in which they declare their appearance before their Lord. On this vast, exposed plain they assemble, earnestly beseeching God for forgiveness, in a dress rehearsal of the day of judgment when, Muslim eschatology holds, they will be asked to account for all they did.

The ritual content of the Hajj is essentially a re-enactment of Abraham's tortuous journey to sacrifice his first-born son. Muslim authorities hold this to be Ishmael, with the location not Jerusalem's Mount Moriah but the environs of Mecca, where the patriarch settled and rebuilt the foundations of the Ka'ba, the cubical structure believed to be the world's first place of worship. Each rite imbues the hajji with a progressively increasing sense of what it must have been like for Abraham to have been miraculously blessed with a son in his dotage, only to be asked to give him up again by his own hand.

The Danish thinker Soren Kierkegaard excoriated those who conceived of Abraham's act as a normal prophetic trial. For him, it represented a supreme spiritual movement for Abraham to give up all that he loved knowing on "the strength of the absurd" that it would be restored. He seems to come close to saying faith begins where reason ends. Perhaps the inexplicability of Abraham's actions is why Muslims are asked to feel, more than comprehend, what it must be like to give up everything in the knowledge that to renounce the world is to receive true spiritual content ment.

webTitle: MP urges Straw to stop the rot in Met

fields.headline: MP urges Straw to stop the rot in Met
fields.standfirst: Guardian disclosures bring call for inquiry into anti-corruption squad
fields.trailText: The home secretary, Jack Straw, has been asked by a Labour MP to set up an independent judicial inquiry following a Guardian investigation exposing the discredited methods used by the Metropolitan police's secretive anti-corruption squad.
fields.byline: Michael Sean Gillard  and Laurie Flynn
fields.body:
The home secretary, Jack Straw, has been asked by a Labour MP to set up an independent judicial inquiry following a Guardian investigation exposing the discredited methods used by the Metropolitan police's secretive anti-corruption squad.

The Guardian also revealed last week that the complaints investigation branch (CIB) is itself under investigation in three separate inquiries following the collapse of four high profile trials against serving and former officers.

Andrew Mackinlay, the MP for Thurrock in Essex, wrote to Mr Straw early in the week urging an independent inquiry, led by a high court judge, into the CIB, supported by a police investigation team with "no links" to the Met. Only this, he wrote, would "reassure the public that all is being done to root out corruption" in the Met.

Mr Mackinlay is particularly concerned about the murky events surrounding two police operations and the role of the intelligence services.

One of the operations, codenamed Cornwall, was a seriously flawed CIB investigation into one of Mr Mackinlay's constituents, Met Detective Inspector John Redgrave.

Mr Redgrave and his partner, Detective Constable Michael Charman, have been under investigation by the CIB for six years.

The CIB inquiry related to claims made in 1994 by an informant, Geoffrey Brennan. His information led Mr Redgrave and Mr Charman to set up a sting operation, codenamed Nightshade, a year earlier.

One of Operation Nightshade's most promising lines of inquiry concerned an illegal arms deal via Sierra Leone. It was on-going when Brennan claimed to have given Mr Redgrave and Mr Charman £50,000 to turn a blind eye to a theft. He later withdrew the allegation.

CIB kept the two detectives under secret investigation in Operation Cornwall for the next three years. In 1997 they were suspended for a further three years even though CIB knew then that Mr Brennan had withdrawn his claim.

Last December Mr Redgrave and Mr Charman were told by CIB that they would not face criminal proceedings, but they remain suspended on full pay with one disciplinary charge outstanding.

Both detectives now hope a judicial inquiry will uncover whether they were the victims of a plot by the intelligence services to undermine Operation Nightshade and protect its targets, in particular a US-based gang of arms dealers who were never arrested.

Mr Brennan had been approached in 1993 by a Texan-based gang with an offer to sell arms. The arms dealers were led by a shadowy American called Roger Crooks and boasted of high political connections.

The weapons list on offer included M16 assault rifles, grenade and rocket launchers, plastic explosives, mines and ammunition.

Two undercover Met officers under Mr Redgrave's control were introduced by Mr Brennan to the Texan gang, posing as buyers for Northern Ireland loyalist terrorists.

The plan was to ship the arms from the US to Ireland via Sierra Leone where Mr Crooks was based.

A series of negotiations in London and Houston were then secretly taped by the Met's undercover officers.

Confidential Met and US customs documents seen by the Guardian confirm this and contradict claims by CIB and sections of the Met that the arms deal was not genuine but designed to disguise the two officers' corruption.

The Guardian's investigation suggests there are sensitive diplomatic reasons which could explain why Operation Nightshade is still being officially denied.

These are the issues which an judicial inquiry should address:

Police documents show some of the arms on offer had been stolen from a national guard armoury in Florida. The Met undercover officer who negotiated the arms deal with Mr Crooks told the Guardian that US customs officers confirmed this to him. But a national guard spokesman is now denying there was such a robbery.

The arms were to be routed by Mr Crooks through the Sierra Leone capital, Freetown, a centre of illegal gun and diamond dealing, to finance the civil war and associated regional conflicts. Mr Crooks had a diplomatic passport from the Sierra Leone government, and was the manager of several legitimate busineses. There is no suggestion that his employers knew about his arms dealing activities.

On two occasions during Operation Nightshade, Mr Crooks was questioned, once by US customs in Houston and then by the Met's anti-terrorist squad (SO13) in London. On both occasions he apparently revealed his role in the arms deal but was allowed to go free. The Met undercover officer and Mr Redgrave confirmed this to the Guardian and said the security service MI5 was involved. Mr Crooks later claimed that throughout the arms deal he was acting as an informant. But the question is for whom? Dave Tucker, the then boss of SO13, which works closely with MI5, denied any knowledge of Mr Crooks or these events when contacted by the Guardian.

Three years later, in May 1997, Mr Crooks was at the heart of a US navy plan to rescue American citizens stranded in Sierra Leone during another military coup. The British and US governments and international mining companies were heavily involved in Sierra Leone at the time. One year later foreign office officials and MI6 were exposed for breaking the government's own arms embargo by allowing a UK mercenary firm, Sandline, to supply arms to the deposed government.

Mr Crooks was linked to Sandline's operation through the lease of a helicopter he owned.

He was later deported from Sierra Leone in June 1998 by the restored government for allegedly supplying arms to the rebels.

Mr Mackinlay, a member of the foreign affairs select committee which examined the Sandline affair in 1998, said: "There are a number of questions that need to be answered and some issues that ought to be re-visited by parliament.

"These issues underscore the deficiency of scrutiny of the security services for which there is no parliamentary oversight."

His call for an independent judicial inquiry is supported by former prime minister Sir Edward Heath and John Horam, Tory MP for Orpington.

Additional research by Laura Milne.

fields.headline: Robert Parry
fields.standfirst: Labour MP nicknamed 'Gulliver' for his travels
fields.trailText: Robert "Bob" Parry, who has died of diabetes at 67 after representing three Liverpool seats for Labour from 1970-97, was a walking contradiction. When he strode out of parliament on his frequent absences, he might have been heading home to manoeuvre for the Militant Tendency, or going off to Heathrow to use his MP status to comfort foreign dictators.
fields.body:
Robert "Bob" Parry, who has died of diabetes at 67 after representing three Liverpool seats for Labour from 1970-97, was a walking contradiction. When he strode out of parliament on his frequent absences, he might have been heading home to manoeuvre for the Militant Tendency, or going off to Heathrow to use his MP status to comfort foreign dictators.

A devout, abortion-bashing Catholic of Irish origins, and a hard left co-founder of the campaign group, he could enthuse both about the Pope and Derek Hatton. His client states included Libya, Iraq and North Korea.

Parry's only demonstration against a foreign dictatorship - that of China - led to his arrest in Tienanmen Square in April 1992, and had a curious background. In 1976, he spent six weeks in Hong Kong, sponsored by Liverpool Chinese restaurateurs anxious to protect their families' interests there. In 1980, he asked a record number of questions, mostly about Hong Kong, and defied the Labour whips by voting in favour of allowing 50,000 Hong Kong Chinese families the right of abode in Britain. When there was a tight vote on the NHS in January 1997, Labour whips found that Bob was in Taiwan.

But sometimes his stamina ran out; on his third visit to Libya, in 1988, he conceded: "I'm against all terrorism and if it [is proved] that Libya is supplying the IRA then that's that - I will cut all my ties with the country!"

Parry's frequent foreign travels earned him the nickname of "Gulliver" back in Liverpool, where he was born the oldest of 10 children of an Irish vehicle-builder. He attended Bishop Goss Roman Catholic School, and at 17 was given a trial for Everton. After three years in the building trade, he went to work as an organiser for Nupe, the National Union of Public Employees, at 27.

Three years later, he was elected to the city council, and two years after that was selected to replace the formidable Liverpool Exchange MP, Bessie Braddock. He entered the Commons in 1970, but lacked fluency and political intelligence. After Neil Kinnock attacked Militant at the 1985 Labour conference, he denounced the party leader as "the biggest traitor since Ramsay MacDonald."

Parry's foreign adventures were the reverse side of his failure to find a real role in parliament. He welcomed a PLO invitation to visit Jordan and the west bank twice in 1981, repaying his hosts by taking anti-Israel stances. The next year he was invited to Afghanistan by its Soviet puppet regime. In 1988, he urged British recognition of North Korea and, the next year, the withdrawal of US troops from South Korea.

He opposed US-UK intervention to oust Saddam Hussein from Kuwait in 1990. Then, with Ronnie Campbell and Dennis Canavan, he flew to Baghdad, nominally to intercede for hostages held by Saddam.

However, he still found time for spasmodic activities in support of Liverpool dock strikers and slum clearance, and against factory closures. There were even heroic efforts to make up to the Labour whips for his frequent rebellions and absences. Thus, he turned up on July 22 1993 for a crucial vote on the European social contract only a day after discharging himself from hospital following a quadruple heart bypass operation.

Poor health forced him to step down before the 1997 election. His wife Marie died in 1987.

 Robert Parry, politician, born January 8 1922; died March 9 2000

fields.headline: Peter Sanger
fields.trailText: The photographer and educationist Peter Sanger, who has died aged 63, was among the principal pioneers of photography degrees, and later of the recruitment of full fee-paying overseas students to British higher education.
fields.body:
The photographer and educationist Peter Sanger, who has died aged 63, was among the principal pioneers of photography degrees, and later of the recruitment of full fee-paying overseas students to British higher education.

Born in Pinner, Middlesex, he turned down an exhibition to read mathematics at Cambridge, because he wanted to be a photographer. He worked in a London studio, for Kodak, and in 1962 began teaching at two of the main colleges offering photography in London - Harrow and Ealing. In 1974, he set up the department of audio-visual studies at West Surrey College of Art and Design, which provided one of the country's leading degree courses in the new subject. He was appointed principal of Maidstone College of Art in 1987, and a director after its absorption into Kent Institute of Art and Design.

In the late 1980s, when government underfunding was troubling all higher education establishments, Sanger led one of the first British Council higher education recruitment missions to the far east. He played a decisive part in raising export income from British higher education to £1.7 bn, while British art and design higher education is now known overseas as the best in the world.

He is survived by his wife, Jacqueline, and his two sons.

 Peter John Sanger, photographer and educationist, born October 18 1936; died January 14 2000

fields.headline: Eileen Fowler
fields.standfirst: Britain's first keep-fit guru who helped a nation fight the flab
fields.trailText: In the days before aerobics and working-out, Eileen Fowler, who has died aged 93, was Britain's first health guru. When exercise seemed to be more about hard labour or Germanic naturism, she   brought in the idea that it could be fun. Her instructions - "Down with a bounce; with a bounce, come up" - were catchwords, broadcast every morning at 6.45 in the BBC's first keep-fit programme.
fields.body:
In the days before aerobics and working-out, Eileen Fowler, who has died aged 93, was Britain's first health guru. When exercise seemed to be more about hard labour or Germanic naturism, she brought in the idea that it could be fun. Her instructions - "Down with a bounce; with a bounce, come up" - were catchwords, broadcast every morning at 6.45 in the BBC's first keep-fit programme.

There was no nonsense about Eileen's ideas of health (and efficiency). Women, she believed, should start getting fit by standing properly at the sink, while men could "take the bulge from their bodies by getting up from an armchair without putting their hands on the sides." She spent most of her life trying to make the flabby fit, through radio, television and personal appearances at rallies that took on the flavour of revivalist fervour.

Born in Hertfordshire, Fowler was stage-struck as a child, much to the pain of her parents. But they eventually relented and allowed her to train in music and dance. At 18, she appeared in Wild Violets on the London stage.

Her inspiration, she said, came from her French grand mother, who told her, somewhat enigmatically, that she should keep slim because "you are only as good as your feet, Eileen." After a decade as an actress, she turned to fitness, a craze then sweeping 1930s Europe.

From 1934-45, Fowler set up classes, encouraging everyone to exercise. Her first class was in a village at sixpence a go, but she soon graduated to putting a spring in the step of middle-class wives and factory workers. Having been rejected by the WAAF, she went around the country organising outdoor pageants, improvising with costumes made from blackout material. She also met her husband, a Rank Organisation executive. Her radio career began on April 1 1954; at its peak, it had half a million listeners.

In 1956, Fowler launched the Keep-Fit Association, before moving to television, where she appeared with a line-up of glowing "gels" with EF emblazoned on their chests. Her first show drew 10,000 requests for her exercises, which had comforting titles such as "stretchaway", "skipalong" and "swingtime". Sacked from television a decade later, she returned in the 70s with a "dance disco" fitness programme. She also had an early-morning slot on the Today programme, which was once saved from the axe by public demand.

There was never a chance that Eileen would stop jumping for joy. She was, after all, a pretty good advertisment for her philosophy; in her 60s she was, she said, "just 2lb and 1in on the waistline more than when I was 20." Small and lithe, she kept going in good health almost to the end, encouraging fellow residents of her Colchester old people's home to keep on moving. "My aim in life is to keep families fit," she said.

Her husband died in 1987.

 Eileen Fowler, keep-fit instructor, born 1906; died March 7 2000

fields.headline: An English repentance
fields.standfirst:
We robbed, colonised and persecuted the Irish. Now we must try to heal their past

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: As an Englishman, I am deeply troubled by the bitter legacy which my country has bequeathed to the peoples of Ireland. We invaded Ireland and fought our own battles there. We robbed the Irish people of their language and literature, and attempted to rob them of their church. We colonised Ireland with foreigners and persecuted the Irish people when they would not conform to our religion. We drove the Roman Catholics into exile, killed thousands of men, women and children and invoked God as our justification.
fields.body:
As an Englishman, I am deeply troubled by the bitter legacy which my country has bequeathed to the peoples of Ireland. We invaded Ireland and fought our own battles there. We robbed the Irish people of their language and literature, and attempted to rob them of their church. We colonised Ireland with foreigners and persecuted the Irish people when they would not conform to our religion. We drove the Roman Catholics into exile, killed thousands of men, women and children and invoked God as our justification.

We failed to feed a starving people whose country was politically part of our own, leaving millions to die or emigrate without hope. We degraded the Irish people by caricaturing them in the British press and media. When they protested we met violence with violence. These atrocities were not confined to the native Irish. When it suited our purpose, we "planted" the land with Protestants, took advantage of their loyalty, and then told them we no longer needed them.

Lest we be tempted to brush it off as a little local difficulty, we should recall the words of Tony Blair on the Good Friday agreement last June, in the House of Commons: "If this agreement goes down . . . there will be no decommissioning . . . and there is no doubt at all that there will be renewed violence."

The Sinn Fein leader Gerry Adams commented: "If the agreement goes, then whatever chance there is of getting decommissioning has gone . . . Events on the ground could spiral out of control." We have to ask ourselves, can history be healed? To pose such a question is to lay oneself open to the charge of naivety, mischief-making, support for terrorism or lack of patriotism. Such a reaction is dangerous and misguided.

I used to think the answer was straightforward. The way to deal with the pain of history was to forgive and forget. The trouble is, forgive and forget does not work because it is untrue to human psychology and it is bad theology as well. The only way to deal with pain and resentment is not to forgive and forget, but to remember and repent or, more realistically, remember and change. Maya Angelou's words have a universal reference:

"History, despite its wrenching pain,

Cannot be unlived, but if faced

With courage need not be lived

again."

Archbishop Runcie put it a little differently: "Those who do not wish to look at the past, or understand the past . . . become easy victims of fatal lies and suspicions about other people in the present." In Northern Ireland the events of the past three years have demonstrated that only where there is political leadership and sufficient will for progress towards reconciliation can it become possible to sit down and discuss the unthinkable with those one has always regarded as unspeakable.

In a tantalisingly short period of time this had begun to happen in the assembly and the executive. Mindsets were changing and barriers were coming down, yet decommissioning has become the linchpin on which the whole edifice of devolved government has tottered.

The Good Friday agreement was equivocal on decommissioning of paramilitary weapons. There would have been no agreement had it been too specific. In June 1999 Mr Blair said: "Decommissioning is not a prior condition, but it is plainly part of the process."

Despite General de Chastelain having indicated that decommissioning did not need to begin until late March to be completed by the deadline, and the fact that the IRA ceasefire is still holding, the Ulster unionists produced a deadline of their own, presenting Peter Mandelson with his agonising dilemma.

Exempted from the ban on handguns following the Dunblane massacre, the whole of Northern Ireland is awash with firearms. Thousands of legally licensed weapons are in the homes and gun clubs of the province. In 1998, the RUC confirmed there were 139,588 legally held guns, the majority in unionist hands. If there is to be any movement on decommissioning, should the 12,090 legally held handguns not be the first to go?

The Ulster unionists and David Trimble have had a good press here, but we could be forgiven for thinking that theirs is the whole story. How do people of republican sympathies actually feel at this moment? David Granville has written in the Irish Democrat: "It should be remembered that the whole decommissioning issue looks very different from places like South Armagh with its fortified military bases, 33 lookout posts, daily helicopter patrols, road-blocks and where new fortifications are still being built."

And what of comments made in the past three weeks?

"We see this as yet another treaty broken by your country . . . Perfidious Albion has done it again. You change the bloody rules when it suits you . . . How would you feel if somebody came into your parliament and said that because of the behaviour of certain of your constituents, we are going to remove your government? Why can't people understand what a fantastic achievement two-and-a-half years of ceasefire has been, given the ceaseless provocation? The guns are out of use and that is what matters. The unionist veto is alive and well. Do you wonder we feel aggrieved?"

Yet how to solve the irreconcilable impasse on decommissioning? There is a risk that the republican movement will now split in a hideous echo of 1921. As one put it last week: "The lunatics will soon take over the asylum, and then what? We have done all we can, I promise you."

The republican movement has accepted participation in a devolved assembly in a partitioned island under British rule. To push them on decommissioning would be to remove any chance of it happening in the foreseeable future. The weapons issue should therefore be removed from the equation and returned to the independent international commission on decommissioning.

An anonymous 16th-century civil servant wrote that the war in Ireland ". . . would always continue without God set in men's [hearts] to find some new remedy that never was found before." That remedy surely lies within the hearts of people in Ireland, but we are all concerned, and the beginning is to understand the pain which we have caused the people there.

Cardinal Cahal Daly believes deliberate effort is required to reach out to others across religious and political divides, making friends with old enemies and changing bitter words and feelings into words of peace, forgiveness and love. Let it begin with me.

webTitle: Harland & Wolff locks horns with DTI

fields.headline: Harland & Wolff locks horns with DTI
fields.standfirst:
Anger and recriminations in Belfast after Queen Mary 2 order lost to a French shipyard

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Harland & Wolff and the government were locked in a furious war of words yesterday after the Belfast shipbuilder lost out on a make or break £400m contract to build the passenger ship Queen Mary II, virtually sealing the 139-year-old yard's demise.
fields.body:
Harland & Wolff and the government were locked in a furious war of words yesterday after the Belfast shipbuilder lost out on a make or break £400m contract to build the passenger ship Queen Mary II, virtually sealing the 139-year-old yard's demise.

Cunard announced it was awarding the contract for the 150,000-tonne ocean liner to Alstom Chantiere de L'Altantique, the successful French operation, despite the department of trade and industry's last-minute package of financial guarantees.

The pledges amounted to a grant of £38m and a loan of more than £380m.

But Harland & Wolff, with no cash reserves, blamed politicians for coming up with too little, too late.

It is believed to have been unhappy at government reluctance to pay all of the £38m grant up front and its decision to attach undisclosed conditions to the loan.

But sources at the DTI and the Northern Ireland office say they had too little time to put together a deal which would completely satisfy Cunard. They criticised the business plan of Harland & Wolff for being "incomplete".

Tony Blair yesterday insisted the government had done all it could. It had offered the maximum grant allowable under European Union rules, equal to 9% of the contract, as well as the full loan which Harland & Wolff had sought.

The loan, under the shipping mortgage scheme, equalled 80% of the contract's value. That, too, was the largest allowed in the EU.

Unless the world-famous yard is able to attract alternative work immediately it will begin laying off its 1,785 workers in June, when it is due to complete work on two oil drilling vessels. Its shipbuilding operations would then close for good in September.

That would be a devastating blow to the Northern Ireland economy, particularly in the deprived loyalist heartland of east Belfast.

Estimates yesterday indicated another 2,000 local jobs could also go.

East Belfast MP Peter Robinson, the deputy leader of the Democratic Unionist party, said there was no time to lose on recriminations. The imperative was to find new contracts immediately.

Mr Robinson said: "There is no point in a post mortem when there is not yet a corpse.

"We must concentrate now on building this yard up from the dire situation it now finds itself in."

Ulster Unionist Sir Reg Empey, trade and industry minister in Northern Ireland until Stormont was suspended last month, demanded that the ministry of defence look favourably on Harland & Wolff for forthcoming contracts.

It requires two aircraft carriers, 12 type 45 destroyers and six roll-on, roll-off ferries.

But Harland & Wolff is thought to have a realistic chance only of two advance landing ships for the MoD. That would be worth £130m.

The MoD is due to put the vessels out to tender later in the year. But unless it accedes to calls to bring the process forward, Harland & Wolff is scheduled already to have closed by that time. Downing Street yesterday appeared to rule out any change in the planned timetable.

Sir Reg suggested that Cunard may have been stringing along Harland & Wolff, which has no recent history in building ocean liners. He believed the firm may have used the yard's bid to put pressure on the French company.

Workers were also angry about conflicting signals this week from Cunard, owned by Miami-based Carnival Corporation. It indicated only on Thursday that it would take until next month to make up its mind - but instead released its decision hours later.

They also fear that Fred Olsen, the company's owner, may be more interested in the yard's 300-acre site for property development than in retaining shipbuilding in Belfast. They complain that the firm has mishandled its recent financial problems.

The Belfast yard last built an ocean liner, the Canberra, in 1961, but Alstom Chantiere de L'Atlantique is recognised as a world leader in constructing such vessels. It employs 4,000 at the Breton port of Saint-Nazaire, and at present has a full order book.

But Harland & Wolff workers believed a successful attempt against the odds to build the Queen Mary II would have opened up a new and growing market.

It would also have guaranteed the shipyard's future until 2003.

Bobby Moore, the senior shops stewards' committee chariman, captured the mood of despair yesterday. He said the workforce was shattered.

Mr Moore said: "It is an absolutely devastating blow to me and my family and all the workers and all their families. We have been hoping against hope that we would get the order for the Queen Mary."

George Matchett, of the confederation of shipbuilding and engineering unions, wondered if Cunard - which had said it was keen to emphasise the British nature of the project - would now rename the ship.

He said: "Perhaps they will now call it Marie Antoinette."

webTitle: Murder case solved but killings go on

fields.headline: Murder case solved but killings go on
fields.standfirst: Theories are rife about the deaths of 200 women in one Mexican city
fields.trailText: Women's bodies are once again appearing in the desert hinterland of Juarez, ending an eight-month respite from a murder spree which has claimed the lives of 200 women since 1993.
fields.body:
Women's bodies are once again appearing in the desert hinterland of Juarez, ending an eight-month respite from a murder spree which has claimed the lives of 200 women since 1993.

The respite followed claims by the Mexican authorities that they had solved the mystery of the murders. But while the latest discoveries are prompting renewed fear, few people seem surprised - the residents of this booming border city have seen it all before.

"I felt so bad about the latest girls to fall," says Irma Perez during a poorly attended demonstration called to demand an end to the violence. Her daughter's scarcely recognisable body was found in the desert in 1995, a month after she disappeared.

Many of the 200 victims were young, poor migrants from the south, drawn to this gritty city of 1.3m just over the Rio Bravo from Texas, by offers of work in its mushrooming export assembly industry.

The murder figures are not disputed, but there are wildly conflicting reports of the way the women died. Some people claim all the bodies were found with signs of sexual abuse. But the authorities say only 64 showed definite signs of sexual abuse, with a further 21 bodies too decomposed to make a definite assessment.

"I understand the panic at the beginning about a serial killer, but there are different kinds of murders. There are those of a sick psychopath, and those for diverse motives," says Suly Ponce, the special investigator for murders of women.

Ms Ponce took up the post after a new government took office in Chihuahua state in 1998. Her appointment was made at a time of intense political pressure for action to stop the murders. Mexican feminists allege that she is more concerned to question the reputations of the victims than to search for their killers.

The previous administration had arrested an Egyptian-born chemist, Omar Latif Sharif, in 1995 in connection with several killings, but bodies had continued to turn up.

In 1996 a gang of petty criminals was arrested and accused of committing murders at Sharif's behest. It was claimed the murders were part of his strategy to make it appear that the real killer remained at large. But still the killings continued.

Last May the authorities announced they had definitively cracked the case. They arrested a group of bus drivers who, they claimed, were paid $1,200 (£760) by Sharif to kill two women every month. The murders then stopped until this year.

Ms Ponce scribbles down figures showing a dramatic drop in the number of murders recorded since her appointment. She says the latest deaths do not appear to be related to the earlier serial killings, and is convinced the right men are in jail.

"Sharif is a psychopath," she says, after insisting that Egyptians are well known for their scant respect for women's rights. "The others are just multi-murderers."

Although the elaborate story spun around Sharif - who was given a 30-year jail term last year for the murder of a 17-year-old girl - has failed to convince many, his record of sexual crime in the United States, and the sudden halt to the murders in 1999, have won him few defenders.

But one woman campaigns in his name. "He is an ideal scapegoat: a foreigner, alone and with a criminal record," says Irene Blanco, his legal representative.

Ms Blanco promises a book later this year detailing how the real murderers are linked to the Juarez drug cartel and protected by the authorities.

"They say that I am crazy, but they don't say why," says this wealthy mother of two who claims a gangland-style attack on her son last year was a direct result of the case.

"All they say is that Irene is in love with Sharif, but so what if I am? I don't claim he's innocent because he's gentle or attractive. I say it's an absurd story ... It's absurd to say he wanted to buy his freedom by paying people to murder, when it would make so much more sense to just buy off the judge."

Esther Chavez, who spearheaded the movement that forced the creation of the special investigator post, says that, while she believes Sharif is a rapist, she thinks he was jailed primarily to defuse the pressure to find the killer.

"The impunity has created a situation in which anybody can kill women," says Ms Chavez, who last year opened a women's crisis centre and says she quit the fight to clear up the murders "to look after the survivors".

She now believes the killers are many, nurtured by a macho backlash against working women."At the centre we see so many women and children abused in so many horrible ways, why not kill them too."

Ms Perez is one of only a handful of victims' relatives still focused on the murders. She says she does not know whether Sharif is guilty, but she does know that the investigation into her daughter's death has gone nowhere.

"Every day I get disappointed, but I never give up," she says. But most of the other relatives, and the city's population, appear to have done just that.

webTitle: Indonesian army drives rich region into rebels' arms

fields.headline: Indonesian army drives rich region into rebels' arms
fields.standfirst:
Aceh might well decide against independence if only the military stopped terrorising people

Indonesia and East Timor: special report
fields.trailText: When Mohammed Assegaf and his two friends finished describing how Indonesian soldiers had killed some people and terrorised dozens of others in their part of Aceh province during the past two months, they slipped out of the café's back door, across the paddy fields, and away.
fields.byline: John Aglionby  in Kembang Tanjung, Aceh, Indonesia
fields.body:
When Mohammed Assegaf and his two friends finished describing how Indonesian soldiers had killed some people and terrorised dozens of others in their part of Aceh province during the past two months, they slipped out of the café's back door, across the paddy fields, and away.

Outside the front door were three heavily armed plainclothes policemen demanding to know what was going on.

People active in criticising the authorities or promoting the idea that Aceh - and its natural wealth - should break away from Indonesia risk arrest, or worse. Such intimidation is commonplace now in this resource-rich province at the north-western tip of Sumatra.

According to independence supporters and human rights workers, troops have killed more than 200 civilians and burned hundreds of homes since January in what army commanders describe as their latest operation to defeat the Free Aceh Movement (GAM), a guerrilla group that has been waging an armed independence struggle since 1976.

The GAM is contributing to the latest violence, but human rights activists say the army's aim is much broader than the defeat of a rebel group. They suspect the aim is to crush the apparent desire of the majority of Aceh's 4m people for an East Timor-style referendum on the province's status. This became manifest at the end of last year in rallies across the province.

"The government became very scared when it saw how much momentum the referendum campaign was developing," said Mohammed Nazar, the coordinator of the campaign for a ballot on independence from Jakarta. "It responded in the only way it knows."

Not only are civilians being killed, he and others say, but human rights workers, students and journalists are being prevented from reaching affected areas.

"We no longer dare man posts where people can report atrocities to us," said Muliadi, a student in the town of Lhokseumawe. "Too many people have been beaten up, arrested or detained without reason."

"Five death threats a day is nothing out of the ordinary now," according to Hamdani Rukiah, the bureau chief in the Aceh town of Lhokseumawe for the main daily newspaper in the province, Serambi Indonesia.

There are dozens of checkpoints and roadblocks on the main roads through the province. A lecturer at a university in the provincial capital, Banda Aceh, said he was on a bus journey recently where all the men were ordered off in three different towns and strip searched. He called this "pure terror tactics".

Independence activists also say people are losing out financially. The February coffee crop in the central highlands was 40% down on last year's, according to them, because people were too scared to be in the fields in the crucial weeks before the harvest.

Such local informants say the repression is worse than in the 1990s, when several thousand people were killed in nine years of similar operations, and it worries them that this seems to be condoned internationally.

When Tony Blair met President Abdurrahman Wahid in February, he pledged British support for Indonesia's territorial integrity. Other foreign leaders, including Bill Clinton, have done likewise.

The GAM is far from blameless in the current violence. Many village heads have reported repeated intimidation by its members. "They regularly extort money, demand the use of cars and motorbikes and steal food," said Suraiya Kamaruzzaman, the executive director of Flower Aceh, a group seeking to promote women's rights in rural Aceh. "Anyone who refuses to help is at great risk of being attacked."

Exacerbating the situation is the presence of other armed groups. They are among the elements becoming bolder in Indonesia now that Jakarta's dictatorship is gone.

In the past few months in Aceh young men, known as "atoms", who lost their fathers in the early 1990s terror have started a chaotic revenge cam paign. "They get hold of guns and then attack police and military posts without thinking about the consequences," said one analyst who asked not to be named.

Mafias from Medan, the city just south of Aceh, have also begun operating this year. "They mainly steal cars, motorbikes and electronic goods," said the analyst. "But they are creating massive fear and panic among the people."

Human rights workers believe that - caught between such groups, the GAM and the military - most of Aceh's people would probably be satisfied to stick with the federal government, if Jakarta would only offer as much carrot as it is doling out stick.

"People still want a referendum because they have lost all confidence in the central government," said Maimul Fidar, the head of a group called Coalition for Human Rights. "If the government treated the people with respect then it would probably win a vote."

This is borne out by people in villages who see independence as "peace", "an end to the violence", "no more terror" and "withdrawing all the soldiers".

But while the central government, which took more than 99% of Aceh's resource revenue until last year, has started investing more in the province, the perception is still widespread that Jakarta does not care. "All we see is the pain of being part of Indonesia and none of the benefits," said Mr Nazar. "The government is not being serious with us."

He points to the constant delay of the first trial of military human rights violators as a case in point. It was due to begin last month but is unlikely to get under way until April at the earliest; the government's latest excuse is that it cannot find the £42,000 needed to stage it.

Moderates in Aceh believe the best way forward is for President Wahid to offer a referendum in several years, halt the repression and work hard to win the people's hearts and minds.

"Such tactics have a great chance of success," said Muhammad Yus, the speaker of the provincial legislature. "We would then have a firm bargaining position with GAM, and once peace is established most people will be happy.

"The government has to take the first step but it seems incapable of doing so. It does not seem to realise that it cannot win over the Acehnese through force."

webTitle: Film directors strip award of link to Klan epic

fields.headline: Film directors strip award of link to Klan epic
fields.standfirst:
Film Unlimited
Directors' Guild of America
"Greatest Films" review of The Birth of a Nation
fields.trailText: Steven Spielberg is to receive a prestigious award for his film-making at a ceremony in Los Angeles tonight.
fields.body:
Steven Spielberg is to receive a prestigious award for his film-making at a ceremony in Los Angeles tonight.

But the award - which until now bore the name of the legendary director DW Griffith - has been renamed owing to protests over Griffith's 1915 film, The Birth of a Nation, which portrayed the Ku Klux Klan in a heroic light.

Critics claim the film, which has often been hailed as the first American epic, promoted racism and caricatured black people.

The controversy within the film industry over the name change is reminiscent of the arguments prompted by last year's lifetime achievement Oscar for the director Elia Kazan, which was awarded despite his having named names to the House Un-American Activities Committee in the 1950s.

While some argue that Griffith was operating in a different time and climate, others say that to keep his name on the prize would be a continuing insult to African-Americans and a comfort to racists.

The Directors Guild of America's award for lifetime achievement is handed out sparingly. Its recipients have included Orson Welles, Frank Capra, Cecil B deMille and Alfred Hitchcock.

Tonight one of its past winners, Francis Ford Coppola, will present the award to Spielberg. But for the first time since the award began in 1953, Griffith's name will not be associated with the prize; it will now be called the DGA Lifetime Achievement award.

Griffith, who died in 1948, came from a southern Confederate family and is described by the filmographer Ephraim Katz as "the single most important figure in the history of American film".

The Oscar-winning film- maker William Friedkin, who directed The French Connection and The Exorcist, has called Griffith, who died a pauper, "arguably the greatest name in American film".

The Birth of a Nation, a three-hour silent movie, was set during the civil war and based on the Rev Thomas Dixon's book The Clansman.

The Klan members are shown as heroic figures and the African-Americans as debauched and savage creatures. In one famous scene a young white woman jumps to her death over a cliff to escape rape by a black man.

Even at the time, the film, which starred Lillian Gish, caused great controversy, with some all-white audiences giving it standing ovations and calls by black groups and white liberals to ban it.

Its technical brilliance has not been disputed but it is equally clear that the KKK experienced a surge in support on the back of the film. The Klan has a long and bloody history of lynching black people and the film was seen as pandering to those tendencies.

Last year a number of African-American directors told the president of the DGA, Jack Shea, that there was much unhappiness about Griffith's name still being attached to the award. It was put to him that black directors, who are slowly growing in number, might not be able to accept the award.

After consultations with surviving recipients, a proposal was made that the name be dropped - a move passed unanimously by the 44-strong national board of the guild.

But the decision has provoked criticism. The National Society of Film Critics called it "a depressing example of 'political correctness'".

Friedkin has also attacked the decision, saying it should have been debated by the membership beforehand.

The National Association for the Advancement of Coloured People (NAACP) was one of the earliest groups to speak out against the film and its acceptance as a "classic".

Yesterday the NAACP's western regional director, Frank Berry, welcomed the decision to remove Griffith's name. "It's been a long time coming," said Mr Berry, who added that many people were puzzled that it had taken the DGA so long.

"I'm happy that they're finally doing it," Mr Berry added. "It is obviously a step in the right direction to stop glorifying people who have done such tremendous injustice."

webTitle: 18 schoolgirls die in locked dorm blaze

fields.headline: 18 schoolgirls die in locked dorm blaze
fields.trailText: Eighteen schoolgirls and their supervisor were killed when a fire swept through a locked dormitory at a school in the south Pacific country of Tuvalu, government officials said yesterday.
fields.body:
Eighteen schoolgirls and their supervisor were killed when a fire swept through a locked dormitory at a school in the south Pacific country of Tuvalu, government officials said yesterday.

The Thursday night fire on the the remote coral atoll of Vaitupu, 620 miles north of Fiji, was believed to have been caused by a pupil's candle. The dormitory's door had been fastened shut and its open windows were covered in wire mesh. The dead students were aged between 14 and 17, and the supervisor died as she attempted to rescue them, Diana Semi, a local radio reporter, said. - AP, Tuvalu

fields.headline: Images of war
fields.standfirst: Legacy of photographers who died
fields.trailText: A collection of Vietnam war photographs went on show in Hanoi yesterday, giving Vietnamese the opportunity to see more than 300 images taken by photographers who died in the war 25 years ago.
fields.body:
A collection of Vietnam war photographs went on show in Hanoi yesterday, giving Vietnamese the opportunity to see more than 300 images taken by photographers who died in the war 25 years ago.

The exhibition pays tribute to all 135 photojournalists - including Vietnamese - who died or disappeared during the wars in Vietnam and neighbouring countries.

Entitled Requiem: The Vietnam Collection, the photographs came from a book compiled by photojournalists Horst Faas and Tim Page, both of whom covered the war.

What began as Mr Page's memorial to two friends - Dana Stone and Sean Flynn, who died in Cambodia - expanded to collect the works of all photojournalists who died in the line of fire.

The book, Requiem: By the Photographers Who Died in Vietnam and Indochina, was published in 1997.

"Tim and I felt that these pictures were taken in Vietnam by photographers who were in love with Vietnam. In a way, these photos are now coming home," Mr Faas said. - AP, Hanoi

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Bomb blast kills 18 in Colombo
fields.body:
Bomb blast kills 18 in Colombo

A bomb explosion on a Colombo street killed at least 18 people and wounded more than 40 during the evening rush hour yesterday, Sri Lankan police and hospital sources said. Many of the injured were in critical condition in hospital and fatalities were likely to rise.

Initial reports said a vehicle had exploded, but some witnesses said there could have been two explosions - triggered by suspected Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam suicide bombers. Three policemen were reported to have been killed by the blast, and witnesses said they heard gunfire.

The attack occurred in the Borella area on a route to parliament, where MPs were meeting for a monthly vote on extending the national state of emergency and to discuss the defence ministry budget.

The government and main opposition party are discussing constitutional proposals to put to the Tamil separatists on ending the war. The deputy defence minister, Anuruddha Ratwatte, who is a prime target of the rebels, was in parliament at the time of the explosion. Reuters, Colombo

Swiss look into Bedie's accounts

Swiss authorities said yesterday they had frozen accounts in the name of the deposed Ivory Coast president, Henri Konan Bedie, and other former government officials.

Switzerland's federal office for police affairs said it had no details so far of the sums frozen in the accounts, blocked in nine banks in Geneva, Zurich and Lugano.

The block was ordered on Wednesday after a request from authorities in the west African country, the office said. All are suspected in Ivory Coast of "having enriched themselves illegally while in office", it added.

General Robert Guei, who took power from Mr Bedie in a Christmas Eve coup, accused the ousted government of plundering state coffers. Mr Bedie arrived in Paris in January and was granted a renewable resident visa. - Reuters, Bern

Cancer specialist discredited

Professor Werner Bezwoda, one of South Africa's leading cancer specialists, was cast into the scientific wilderness yesterday when US scientists discredited his research, which had been thought to offer hope to women with advanced breast cancer.

US specialists conducted a review of Prof Bezwoda's work at Witwatersrand university, which had been launched at an international conference in the US in May to some acclaim. The professor has since admitted "a serious breach of scientific honesty and integrity" - he invented results to support his thesis - and been fired.

The US specialists found discrepancies between his claims and his documentation. Although Prof Bezwoda had stated that 154 patients were in the study to assess the regime of high-dose chemotherapy and stem cell transplants which he claimed saved lives, the US team were given records for only 58, of whom nine they considered not eligible. All 58 were on the therapy. At least seven patients probably died of advanced cancer, in addition to the eight deaths Prof Bezwoda reported. Furthermore, the reviewers saw no signed consent, and the university's institutional review committee had no record of having approved the study. - Sarah Boseley, Health Correspondent

Japan to think twice on reactors

The Japanese government announced a complete rethink of the country's energy policy yesterday in a move that is expected to result in the scrapping of plans for up to seven new atomic reactors.

The rethink, forced by a sea-change in public opinion since the country's worst nuclear accident in September, will make it difficult for Japan to attain its commitment to reduce greenhouse gases. It could also cut into the potential reprocessing market for British Nuclear Fuels.

Japan relies on its 51 atomic plants to supply about a third of its electricity. The government had hoped to increase this proportion by building between 16 and 20 new facilities by 2010. Yesterday it admitted this goal was impossible in the face of growing hostility to nuclear power.

"I have doubts about hitting our target," said Takashi Fukaya, the trade and industry minister, who announced a one-year review, starting in April, which local media reports said would focus on cutting the number of new plants to 13.

According to Mr Fukaya, the shift was prompted by a decline in energy consumption and fears about safety after last year's uncontrolled chain reaction at a processing plant in Tokaimura. One worker died, another is in critical condition and more than 400 people were exposed to radiation by that accident, caused by sloppy safety standards and a lack of supervision by the authorities. - Jonathan Watts, Tokyo

Road rage dog killing angers US

No road rage incident of recent years has so animated California as one in which a man reached into the car of a woman driver, grabbed her small dog and threw it in front of oncoming traffic. The man, whose car had Virginia number plates, then drove off, and police are now searching for him.

A reward of $50,000 (£31,000) has been offered by dog lovers to catch the driver. Sympathetic animal lovers can visit the dead dog's personal website.

The incident took place in San Jose on February 11 when Sara McBurnett, who lives near Lake Tahoe, was driving near the local airport and became involved in an altercation with a male driver, who reached into the car and grabbed her dog.

Since then Ms McBurnett has appeared on phone-in programmes to discuss the incident, but some callers are questioning the attention generated by the incident in comparison to widespread indifference towards some 13 deaths of children by firearms each day in the US. - Duncan Campbell, Los Angeles

webTitle: Vote a test of how socialist Spain is

fields.headline: Vote a test of how socialist Spain is
fields.trailText: Under the shadow of Basque separatist violence, Spain goes to the polls tomorrow with the centre-right prime minister, Jose Maria Aznar, battling allegations of cronyism while trying to draw support from powerful regional parties.
fields.body:
Under the shadow of Basque separatist violence, Spain goes to the polls tomorrow with the centre-right prime minister, Jose Maria Aznar, battling allegations of cronyism while trying to draw support from powerful regional parties.

Ahead in the polls but afraid that Spain still leans to the left, Mr Aznar holds only a slim lead of 4-5 percentage points despite the fact that Spain is growing faster and creating three times as many jobs as any other European country.

"We're on track. Let's stay there," says Mr Aznar, who promises growth, jobs, tax cuts and a chance to push Spain into the top tier of EU countries.

"Not good enough," argues the Socialist leader, Joaquin Almunia, a lawyer aged 51 who concedes that the economy is racing ahead, but accuses the government of cronyism and capitalism. These, he claims, have grossly enriched personal friends of the prime minister put in charge of privatised state concerns while overall standards of living have declined.

Mr Almunia's main task is to convince sceptics on the left that his electoral alliance with the communist-led United Left really is "the start of a beautiful friendship" and not just a marriage of convenience that could easily fall apart.

Voters know that Mr Aznar delivers. Few rated his chances of survival when he won the last election with a smattering of votes, and he had to bury the right's centralising tradition and reach an agreement whereby Catalans and Basque nationalists supported his People's Party in parliament.

A former tax inspector, Mr Aznar, 47, is efficient and industrious but lacks personal appeal. In recent days his attractive wife has been pitched into the spotlight to add warmth and glamour and appeal to women voters.

The campaign has taken place amid Basque violence, after well over a year of peace thanks to a ceasefire. Three terrorist attacks by the Basque separatist group ETA ended a 14-month ceasefire definitively, and Mr Aznar's tough stance on terrorism goes down well with many voters outside the region.

These, he claims, have grossly enriched personal friends of the prime minister put in charge of privatised state concerns while overall standards of living have declined. Mr Almunia's main task is to convince sceptics on the left that his electoral alliance with the communist-led United Left really is "the start of a beautiful friendship" and not just a marriage of convenience that could easily fall apart. Voters know that Mr Aznar delivers. Few rated his chances of survival when he won the last election with a smattering of votes, and he had to bury the right's centralising tradition and reach an agreement whereby Catalans and Basque nationalists supported his People's Party in parliament. A former tax inspector, Mr Aznar, 47, is efficient and industrious but lacks personal appeal. In recent days his attractive wife has been pitched into the spotlight to add warmth and glamour and appeal to women voters. The campaign has taken place amid Basque violence, after well over a year of peace thanks to a ceasefire. Three terrorist attacks by the Basque separatist group ETA ended a 14-month ceasefire definitively, and Mr Aznar's tough stance on terrorism goes down well with many voters outside the region.

fields.headline: Capital letters
fields.standfirst: Dogs have their day as heirs to revolt sniff at rule-makers
fields.trailText: Lola is seven years old. She adores puppies and has a weakness for chocolate. She has huge brown eyes and a flirtatious manner. Her nose is stippled and she is covered in short, dense hair.
fields.body:
Lola is seven years old. She adores puppies and has a weakness for chocolate. She has huge brown eyes and a flirtatious manner. Her nose is stippled and she is covered in short, dense hair.

Lola is a dog. My dog.

When I first came to Berlin, I found it hard to see how anyone could keep a dog in trim. Every park I saw had a notice at the entrance warning that leads had to be be used at all times and listing stiff penalties awaiting owners who defied the bylaws.

In the woodland which surrounds the city, there was an even more alarming sign, which showed a startled dog being tusked into the air. The forests of Berlin are alive with wild boar.

Yet dogs are as common as house flies. There are more in Berlin than in most of Germany's other big cities put together. And an astonishing number can be found off their leads, not just rambling in the parks, but ambling along pavements, lounging in cafes and bars, and even in restaurants and clubs.

Even members of the most popular breed, the pit bull terrier, roam about unhindered, along with rottweilers, dobermans and other dogs that look as if they eat a poodle or two for breakfast.

A history professor, Wolfgang Wippermann, who has written a book about the Germans and their dogs, has unearthed municipal edicts, some dating back to the 18th century, with which the authorities had tried, with a uniform lack of success, to get the Berliners to put their dogs on leads.

The other thing you notice is that there are no cats. Or at least not in sight. For a while, I thought they had been hunted to extinction by the dogs. But there is a law which says they have to be kept in, and this is respected. It is one of the very few laws that the Berliners do obey.

This is the capital of Germany. Everywhere you look, there are reminders of the grim discipline which has been imposed from this city: Nazi ministries, Stasi barracks.

There is respect for order to be found here, certainly. As is the case throughout Germany, pedestrians wait at crossings for the red man to turn green, even when there is no traffic to be seen.

But there is a streak of indifference to authority in the Berliners that would do credit to a Neapolitan. It has its roots in the city's history.

Berlin was the scene of one of the most vigorous and temporarily successful of Europe's 1848 revolutions. In the 1890s, the city, by that time a major industrial centre, was a stronghold of the then radical Social Democrats. Until Hitler came to power, the capital was Rotes Berlin - Red Berlin.

Even now that grey-suited officials and diplomats have flooded in from Bonn, the collar-and-tie quotient on the streets is minimal.

A few weeks ago, I happened to notice no less than three men on a U-bahn platform wearing suits. One of them was standing by a no-smoking sign. Lighting up a cigarette.
