webTitle: Germany woos computer specialists from abroad

fields.headline: Germany woos computer specialists from abroad
fields.trailText: The German government yesterday announced controversial plans to recruit up to 30,000 computer specialists from outside the European Union to meet a drastic shortage of qualified workers in Germany's information technology industry.
fields.byline: Tony Paterson  in Berlin and Jamie Wilson
fields.body:
The German government yesterday announced controversial plans to recruit up to 30,000 computer specialists from outside the European Union to meet a drastic shortage of qualified workers in Germany's information technology industry.

Under the scheme, which has been compared to America's green card system, Germany's strict immigration controls will be waived to allow an initial 10,000 non-EU computer and hi-tech specialists to enter the country this year.

Last night IT recruitment specialists in the UK called for the government to introduce a similar scheme to stop British industry falling behind.

"If the Germans are going to introduce a scheme like this, why don't we? We have just as big a shortage in this area as anybody; there are always more jobs than suitable candidates," said John Ford, who runs an IT recruitment company in north London.

"We have a very considerable number of applicants from the Indian subcontinent every week for positions that we simply cannot fill, but because of the rules governing work permits we have to turn them down."

Although the project faces opposition from German trade unions, government sources yesterday confirmed that plans to recruit a further 20,000 foreign computer experts would be discussed by the Social Democrat-Green coalition of the chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, at the end of the year.

The measures are part of a personal initiative by Mr Schröder aimed at overcoming a shortage of more than 75,000 qualified workers in the computer and hi-tech branch. The government also plans to increase the number of computer training opportunities from 14,000 to 40,000.

But in an attempt to counter critics who claim that the intitiative is a back door to permanent immigration, the government has stipulated that its work permit system - unlike America's - will be limited to a maximum of five years.

According to German press reports, suggestions that the government was about to open the way for a non-EU computer expert recruitment drive have already prompted German headhunters to seek staff in the Indian hi-tech cities of Bangalore and Hyderbad.

The moves are a response to growing complaints from business and industry that Germany slept while its EU partners invested heavily in turning out qualified hi-tech workers.

The recruitment drive amounts to a radical departure from the policies of the former chancellor Helmut Kohl's previous conservative government.

Throughout its 16-year tenure, his Christian Democrat-led coalition rejected the idea of immigration quotas or importing non-EU labour despite the country's plunging birthrate.

However, after initially opposing the idea, the conservatives have joined Germany's other main parties in supporting the recruitment drive.

India's talent waiting in wings

John Cassy

India's software and information technology experts are so prized because they meet the global industry's two key requirements: they are highly educated and mostly English speaking.

Their reputation for dedication is another bonus.

Microsoft chairman Bill Gates was so impressed by the Indian pool in 1997 that he predicted the country would become a software superpower and then awarded the first Microsoft professorship outside the US to Delhi's Indian Institute of Technology.

Bangalore is India's computer capital, a Silicon Val ley for the Indian sub-continent.

Ten miles outside town is Electronic City, home to 80 mostly international companies like Oracle and NTT, and the centre of the fast-emerging sector.

In export terms, the industry will be worth £2.5bn this year and as much as £12.5bn in three years, according to estimates.

Wages of around £300 a month are nearly 10 times the average Indian's income but tiny by Western standards.

Their European peers often earn six-figure annual packages. For skilled operators the lure of Germany could be strong.

webTitle: Border TV braces for Scottish Radio bid

fields.headline: Border TV braces for Scottish Radio bid
fields.trailText: Border Television, one of only two remaining independent ITV companies in Britain, could find itself at the centre of a bidding war after Scottish Radio Holdings last night admitted it was preparing an offer for the group.
fields.body:
Border Television, one of only two remaining independent ITV companies in Britain, could find itself at the centre of a bidding war after Scottish Radio Holdings last night admitted it was preparing an offer for the group.

The takeover panel forced Scottish Radio's hand after a day in which shares in Border rose sharply over speculation that a bid was imminent. Border closed 32% higher at £10.50, valuing the company at £113m.

The brief statement from Scottish Radio said it had retained financial adviser Investec Henderson Crosthwaite and was considering a bid but warned the price would not be at a significant premium to the present value.

Talks between Scottish Radio and Border faltered two years ago on the then price on offer of £4 a share.

Border chief executive Paul Corley expressed surprise at the new overtures and said there had been no recent contact between the companies.

"The board is fully committed to remaining independent and growing the business and we have big plans. But of course it is the duty to our shareholders that we listen to what Scottish Radio has to say," he said.

Border is increasingly viewed as attractive because of its radio assets which deliv ered almost 40% of group revenues last year. The biggest, Century North West covers 5.5m people including the populations of Liverpool and Manchester and is the largest franchise area outside London.

The company is also bidding for licences in Birmingham and Yorkshire and is part of a consortium for the second London digital licence, which would use the Century brand if successful.

Analysts said the statement could prompt other bidders to emerge. "Border is on everyone's forward planning list because everyone is expecting it to fall victim to consolidation," one analyst noted. The only other independent ITV company extant is Ulster TV.

Potential bidders could include Capital Radio, Chrysalis or Granada, which recently said it would consider a bid for either of its two big rivals in ITV - United News & Media or Carlton.

Guardian Media Group, which publishes the Guardian newspaper, hopes to build a radio portfolio and is also widely rumoured to be circling Border.

Scottish Radio has about 16 radio services including the flagship Radio Clyde. It also has 40 local weekly newspapers and is the fourth largest billboard owner in the country.

In January, the company raised £75m for acquisitions through a rights issue.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Stakeholder rules eased
fields.body:
Stakeholder rules eased

Social security secretary Alistair Darling yesterday bowed to pressure from life insurance companies and allowed traditional with-profits funds to join the forthcoming stakeholder pensions regime.

Until yesterday the government had favoured index funds over with-profits funds, which are a mix of shares, bonds and properties, widely regarded as difficult for savers to understand.

However, the DSS refused to relax the maximum 1% annual charge on stakeholder pensions, which will prevent many small with-profits funds from participating.

Mice Group takes to the net

Mice Group, the exhibitions contractor, intends to build "virtual visitors' centres" for clients through a tie-up with an internet company.

The group, which helped build two zones in the Millennium Dome, will initially invest £200,000 in Birmingham-based WebXpress but said its web technology spending could reach £5m.

The firm's annual results yesterday showed a 65% surge in pre-tax profits to £4.2m.

DT pressed to seek merger

Deutsche Telekom is likely to come under increasing pressure from investors to buy an overseas company after the breakdown of its latest talks with Qwest and US West, two American rivals.

The company is understood to have pulled back from a proposed $100bn-plus (£63bn) takeover of the two companies after rejecting the terms laid down by US West. Analysts believe that the battle has highlighted Deutsche Telekom's need to do a deal.

John Slack, an analyst at stockbroker PaineWebber, said the group's soaring share price - it has risen almost 50% this year - gives it the currency to buy a global rival in the US or elsewhere. "They have a chance for a once in a lifetime deal."

Coke reacts to race protest

Douglas Daft, the recently appointed chief executive of Coca-Cola, moved to head off further criticism of the US drinks group's race policies by linking his own pay to the promotion of minorities.

The decision to set a series of targets to "achieve diversity" over the next few months comes as the group faces a lawsuit from former and current employees which alleges discrimination. Mr Daft, who announced some 6,000 job cuts last month, also announced the appointment of a director of diversity strategies.

Co-op calls for Link action

Co-operative Bank yesterday claimed the government had failed to go far enough in protecting bank customers from excessive cash machine charges. The bank called on ministers to highlight the profits some banks will continue to make from the fees.

It said the 30p cost of a transaction on the Link ATM network was covered by the interchange fees banks pay each other. "To charge any more would be gross profiteering."

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.trailText: Tafraoute, Morocco
fields.body:
Tafraoute, Morocco

This area is famous for its almond trees, cultivated and wild. Blossom, a scented celebration of winter's close departure, is followed by soft new leaves of spring and in the Ameln valley there are villages with water springs.

We walked to Aguiz where a small boy guided us to La Source. First we saw the huge cistern where the water is gathered before the women open and close different channels to allow equal irrigation. Here we saw argan trees at their best. Peculiar to Morocco the smaller ones might be mistaken for olives, but once they have grown to their full girth they acquire the statuesque presence suitable for a tree that provides fruits whose different parts feed animals, light fires and provide oil for cooking or beauty.

Goats enjoy climbing and munching in them. In other parts we have seen how argan forests are disappearing under the pressures of overuse. Here they are majestic. As we followed the water channel upwards we saw fish and frogs in the sunlit waters and dragonflies above, some flaunting crimson bodies, others very like our beautiful demoiselle.

We passed terraces where wild boar had been breeding before the villagers smoked them out, frightened of their proximity. Climbing higher we finally approached the spring itself. Towering granite rocks were producing a steady stream of clear water. In a country afflicted by dryness it felt like a miracle. Maidenhair ferns tumbled around it. Bulbuls bellowed, little warblers called and twittered, butterflies flitted by, one of them looking like our orange tip.

A scramble around the side brought us to the boys' swimming pool with flickering fish and ambient rocks. We walked away past small fields of beans in flower, whose scent filled the air. The next village had a spring in the middle with women filling water pots and lower down doing the washing, before the vital resource is channeled off towards the crops.

Back in Tafraoute we looked up during breakfast and saw two Bonelli's eagles moving slowly through the thermals, their eyes probably strong enough to see the dark brown wild bees clustered on our jam. They circled round and drifted off, effortlessly.

webTitle: Singer sells brokerages before bubble bursts

fields.headline: Singer sells brokerages before bubble bursts
fields.trailText: Independent merchant bank Singer & Friedlander plans to sell off its stockbroking outfits before the share bubble bursts.
fields.body:
Independent merchant bank Singer & Friedlander plans to sell off its stockbroking outfits before the share bubble bursts.

The bank, which has been cited as a takeover target for its rival Close Brothers, is expected to use the proceeds of the sales of Collins Stewart in the UK and Carnegie in Scandinavia to boost its fund management operation.

Michael Gibbins, chief operating officer, said yesterday the bank was in the advanced stages of talks with the management of Collins Stewart after they made an approach to buy the company back after 10 years.

He refused to disclose the price although analysts suggested it might raise £100m for the bank.

The move by the management of Collins Stewart had prompted Singer & Friedlander to review its 55% stake in Carnegie although it was unclear last night whether the group was planning to sell out its shares entirely. Reporting a 50% rise in pre-tax profits to £81.8m, the bank admitted the two broking businesses accounted for £63.4m of the overall figure, generated by the explosion in the demand for share trading.

In part, the decision to sell was motivated by a need to improve its stock market rating which was held back by the volatility of returns in the broking businesses.

In its core merchant banking business, Singer & Friedlander had boosted its fees from clients by taking stock options.

Mr Gibbins used an arrangement struck with Affinity, floated on the stock market last year, in which it owns stock options worth £25m, in addition to £6m already realised, as an illustration of the new payment method.

The bank, which has been cited as a takeover target for its rival Close Brothers, is expected to use the proceeds of the sales of Collins Stewart in the UK and Carnegie in Scandinavia to boost its fund management operation. Michael Gibbins, chief operating officer, said yesterday the bank was in the advanced stages of talks with the management of Collins Stewart after they made an approach to buy the company back after 10 years. He refused to disclose the price although analysts suggested it might raise £100m for the bank. The move by the management of Collins Stewart had prompted Singer & Friedlander to review its 55% stake in Carnegie although it was unclear last night whether the group was planning to sell out its shares entirely. Reporting a 50% rise in pre-tax profits to £81.8m, the bank admitted the two broking businesses accounted for £63.4m of the overall figure, generated by the explosion in the demand for share trading. Mr Gibbins used an arrangement struck with Affinity, floated on the stock market last year, in which it owns stock options worth £25m, in addition to £6m already realised, as an illustration of the new payment method. fields.headline: Sign of the times
fields.standfirst: Rolex guns for Lancashire jeweller
fields.trailText: Rolex, the watchmaker, is threatening a Lancashire jeweller with the full weight of the law in a dispute over the use of trade names on the internet.
fields.body:
Rolex, the watchmaker, is threatening a Lancashire jeweller with the full weight of the law in a dispute over the use of trade names on the internet.

Brittons of Nelson - with a total staff of six - could be bankrupted by its stand against the Swiss company.

Central to the dispute are two internet domain names. Rolex has hired Clifford Chance, the City's largest law firm, to bring Brittons into line.

The jeweller, founded in 1971, specialises in second-hand watches, and has a number of internet names registered, covering makes such as Omega and Cartier. "Nobody else has bothered us at all," said Philip Walden, a partner at Brittons.

He said his own legal advice was that Rolex did not have a case, and it seems no legal precedents exist. But Mr Walden said "we can't afford to fight Rolex".

Clifford Chance said: "The position of our client Rolex is that it objects to third parties registering domain names which in clude the Rolex trade mark as part of the name."

The firm added: "We have been instructed by Rolex to write to Brittons requiring that they transfer and/or cancel the domain names." Mr Walden said: "We're not a big business, we're a quality business and we can't afford to fight Rolex".

fields.headline: Oftel squeezes local loop timetable
fields.trailText: Oftel director-general David Edmonds yesterday held out the hope that "local loop" competition could start ahead of schedule in some areas.
fields.body:
Oftel director-general David Edmonds yesterday held out the hope that "local loop" competition could start ahead of schedule in some areas.

The deadline for unbundling the so-called last mile - the stretch of line between BT's local exchanges and subscribers' premises - has been set for July next year, though the government would like it to happen earlier.

Mr Edmonds said yesterday that he was encouraged by the commitment shown by BT and the rest of the industry to the programme, adding: "Progress is at a very good rate. If this continues it should be possible to achieve some initial roll-out prior to the full launch.

"Oftel will continue to work with BT to see if the timetable can be improved."

However, BT was more cautious. A spokesman said much work needed to be done. "You can't make assumptions at this early stage. What must not be allowed to happen is for local loop unbundling not to work. It must work, otherwise everyone loses."

Unbundling will give other service providers access to the "last mile", enabling them to offer services to customers without having to install their own cables. They will also be able to install high-speed digital subscriber line technology which can carry services such as video-on-demand and always-on internet access.

BT shares continued their recent recovery yesterday, adding 34p to 1,355p as the City digested its latest internet initiatives.

Morgan Stanley Dean Witter raised the shares to "outperform" and set a target of 1,580p. Earlier Lehman Brothers had raised its BT target price to 1,590p.

BT's plans for unmetered internet access, which have been criticised by some providers as too expensive, yesterday won the backing of PlusNet Technologies, which said it would sign up for the SurfTime scheme.

PlusNet's operations director, Michael Naylor, said the company was discussing how much it would charge on top of the connection fees announced by BT on Wednesday.

"We think its a good product, we don't think the price point is too high," Mr Naylor said.

fields.headline: Deutsche prepares golden handcuffs
fields.trailText: Two German banks involved in a groundbreaking £50bn merger are considering a plan to apply "golden handcuffs" to key investment bank staff who are based in the City of London.
fields.body:
Two German banks involved in a groundbreaking £50bn merger are considering a plan to apply "golden handcuffs" to key investment bank staff who are based in the City of London.

The retention bonuses are being considered for some members of Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, the investment banking arm of Dresdner Bank which on Thursday announced a merger with its larger rival Deutsche.

While a spokesman for Dresdner refused to comment, speculation mounted yesterday that management of the bank was looking at ways of preventing prized staff from being poached by rivals.

"All the talk is that they will be working on retention bonuses this weekend," one banker said.

Bankers are regularly poached by rivals, particularly during takeovers when uncertainty makes it easier to persuade people to leave.

The City still expects Dresdner Kleinwort Benson to bear the brunt of the pain which will result from the unit merging with Deutsche's investment bank in London.

The worries have persisted even though Rolf Breuer, joint chief executive of the merged bank, was at pains this week to described the operation as a "jewel" which would not be closed.

He admitted that 1,600 investment banking jobs were likely to be lost but refused to indicate how many of them would be in London where the combined groups employ more than 12,000.

The merged bank, to be known as Deutsche Bank, is anxious to expand its mergers and acquisitions capabilities. However, this is an area in which Dresdner Kleinwort Benson is regarded by some rivals as being stronger than Deutsche.

Deutsche is said to have more focus on bonds and equities after last year's acquisition of Bankers Trust of the US, which involved 5,500 job cuts on both sides of the Atlantic.

webTitle: TransTec receiver backs Statesman web page

fields.headline: TransTec receiver backs Statesman web page
fields.trailText: Andersen, the accounting and consulting group, is sponsoring the New Statesman's web page despite its role as receiver of TransTec, the engineering group founded by the magazine's publisher, Geoffrey Robinson.
fields.body:
Andersen, the accounting and consulting group, is sponsoring the New Statesman's web page despite its role as receiver of TransTec, the engineering group founded by the magazine's publisher, Geoffrey Robinson.

The sponsorship will raise questions about Andersen's role in handling what assets remain for creditors after the collapse last December of the former treasury minister's Midlands engineering group.

TransTec is being investigated by the department of trade and industry and west midlands police over allegations that it hid liabilities in 1998/99 and fraudulently applied for government grants in the late 1980s.

Arthur Andersen, the accounting wing of the Andersen group, was appointed receiver in December, after banker HSBC found TransTec had concealed a £12m liability to its client Ford, the car maker. Losses at the company are expected to top £200m.

Mr Robinson, who had resigned from the government a year earlier over the £375,000 mortgage he made available to the then trade and industry secretary, Peter Mandelson, had left the company before the Ford liability surfaced.

He has denied any knowledge of Ford's demand for compensation for late deliveries from TransTec's plant in Campsie, Northern Ireland.

Andersen Consulting is in the process of splitting from Arthur Andersen.

webTitle: UK backs German in IMF contest

fields.headline: UK backs German in IMF contest
fields.trailText: Britain yesterday gave its backing to the German candidate for the top job at the International Monetary Fund, after several days of intensive diplomatic arm twisting.
fields.body:
Britain yesterday gave its backing to the German candidate for the top job at the International Monetary Fund, after several days of intensive diplomatic arm twisting.

A spokesman for prime minister Tony Blair said Britain would throw its weight behind Horst Köhler, the head of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

The treasury added its endorsement, saying Mr Köhler was "a serious figure with experience in the international financial community". Behind the scenes both Downing Street and the treasury are believed to have preferred Giuliano Amato, the Italian finance minister and former prime minister, but Mr Blair was keen to foster better Anglo-German relations by supporting Berlin.

With the UK falling into line, there are expected to be no further obstacles to Mr Köhler winning the European Union nomination for the job as early as this Monday, at a meeting of EU finance ministers. But Mr Köhler has still to secure the crucial backing of the US treasury which effectively vetoed Germany's first nominee for the job, Caio Koch-Weser.

US secretary of state Madeleine Albright reiterated during a visit to Brussels yesterday that the US would support a European for the job but wanted "a strong head of the IMF" with the right qualifications. She declined to name Mr Köhler.

In Berlin a government spokesman said the non-com mittal US position reflected the fact there still was no formal European candidate and insisted support for Mr Köhler was firming ahead of Monday's talks.

By tradition, the head of the IMF is always a European, while the US chooses the head of the fund's sister organisation, the World Bank. However, after the diplomatic embarrassment to Berlin of having its first choice rejected, the EU's grip on the appointment procedure appears to be slipping.

Two non-European candidates have been nominated and are still officially in the running, even after a straw poll last week at the fund showed neither commanding sufficient support. Yesterday, the Japanese candidate, Eisuke Sakakibara, admitted he was unlikely to win, but called for the selection procedure to be reformed.

"Anybody who is qualified for that job, regardless of their nationality, should get that position. In that sense, my candidacy is quite symbolic," he said.

Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa said yesterday that Japan had no plans to withdraw Sakakibara, a former deputy finance minister known as "Mr Yen" for his clout in currency markets, as its candidate for the top job at the IMF.

The third candidate, Stanley Fischer, a Zambian born, naturalised American, has strong support from some developing countries, but is thought unlikely to be a serious contender because the US would not risk further diplomatic tensions with the EU by nominating one of its own citizens.

webTitle: Ayling forgot business life's little essentials

fields.headline: Ayling forgot business life's little essentials
fields.standfirst:
BA jobs will go

British Airways
fields.trailText: Notebook; BA jobs will go & Y2K bugged
fields.body:
W e will attempt to spare you the "ailing boss being ejected from an airline in a spin" stuff. But as the headhunters are scrambled at British Airways, it is worth reflecting on the reason for Bob Ayling's departure as chief executive - and the timing.

There are various schools of thought. The sympathetic line says Mr Ayling is another victim of the extraordinary state of convulsion shaking just about every type and size of business.

It says that the 40% fall in BA's share price over the last four years in large part reflects the fickle nature of the markets, with the airline caught by the huge asset switch out of "senior" business and into youthful, technology-led enterprise.

At the same time the global trend towards both price deflation and competition over service levels put the squeeze on BA with a violence that no manger could have been expected to predict or respond to.

In any case, following in the footsteps of predecessors such as Lord King was never going to be easy.

Mr Ayling was perhaps just a little unlucky: if he had only managed to get those first class "flying beds" installed on transatlantic routes earlier his major shareholders would at least have had somewhere to lie down while their feelings of nausea passed.

An alternate line says Mr Ayling should have been ousted many months ago. Here is a man who took over a business making £500m a year at the pre-tax level and is leaving it four years later set on a course to lose around £250m. Bizarrely, he has managed to increase the staff count by 20% in that time and simultaneously destroyed BA's enviable reputation for quality service.

With hindsight, Mr Ayling - like Dino Adriano, the deposed boss of J Sainsbury - was failing from the outset.

He had set his heart on the merger with American Airlines, he got bogged down in the "slot wars" at Heathrow and the cabin crew strike did him no favours whatsoever.

Mr Ayling seemed to presume the underlying business would run on auto pilot - forgetting all those crucial aspects of top management such as making sure that the staff feel proud and act loyally.

All those tales about Mr Ayling not being like Lord King, "who used to come round and say hello to everyone", were illustrative rather than facile.

From here the company faces a long haul. Competitive conditions in the industry are not about ease, and regardless of yesterday's statements grinding on about how the board is fully committed to the airline's present strategy, the lopsided focus on pandering to premium passengers at the expense of the baggage class needs to be reviewed.

On top of this, whoever Lord Marshall brings in will have to produce quick, visible action to jolt the City's negative mindset - if only to ward off potential foreign predators.

One can almost visualise Lord Marshall's memo to headhunters, begging for someone like Peter Davis, who made his mark at J Sainsbury on day one by sacking a couple of top managers.

But in BA's case the job will involve putting rather more people out of work.

Y2K bugged

When one of the world's biggest metals traders starts blaming the millennium bug it is time either to reassess one's Y2K cynicism or to have a long, hard think about the company concerned.

On the face of it the latter option has to be more attractive.

One year ago, we were told that, post-recession in the commodities markets, investors were simply gagging to get hold of a piece of Metallgesellchaft's about to be spun-off, London-based dealing unit - given the sporty name of MG. Then came the flotation last September, when MG's shares dropped 14% below the issue price.

Yesterday MG said its profits since the start of its financial year in October were "below expectations". The shares tanked by about 20% as MG suggested: "The Y2K issue impacted overall market activity in the months surrounding the end of calendar year 1999."

Quite how bug problems may or may not "impact" the demand for the basest of base metals is unclear, but the impartial judge - aware of the likelihood of the world needing aluminium and copper long after it has found some new way to replicate the services of Lastminute.com - may still give MG the benefit of the doubt.

As we said at the time of the float, MG is no ordinary company, and it did last September persuade the City to buy 51% of an entity that has no equivalent; there are no independently quoted traders in either Europe or the US, and its rivals are inside either big commodity houses or mining companies.

Those with steady nerves may well give MG the benefit of the doubt.

Those without may indeed conclude that the millennium bug is the last refuge of the scoundrel.

fields.headline: The mother of reinvention
fields.standfirst: Interview - Hilary Cropper, chairman, FI Group
fields.trailText: In this industry you've really got to reinvent yourself, says Hilary Cropper, executive chairman of IT outsourcing and management consultancy group FI. "I joined at an early stage and it's gone on changing at such a rate of knots it's never gone stale and, frankly, we've not seen anything yet.
fields.body:
In this industry you've really got to reinvent yourself, says Hilary Cropper, executive chairman of IT outsourcing and management consultancy group FI. "I joined at an early stage and it's gone on changing at such a rate of knots it's never gone stale and, frankly, we've not seen anything yet.

"The next 20 years will be even more exciting than the last 20 and you're constantly refreshed in your thinking."

At 59, Cropper could be excused for thinking of retirement to the Dorset farm her husband, Peter, recently bought after reinventing himself following a parallel career in IT. But she isn't: she originally planned to step down as chairman next year but now talks of carrying on for three years or more.

The reason, you surmise, is that Cropper wants to help guide a company that has grown exponentially in the past two years through a corporate landscape where the advent of e-commerce will create such seismic changes many companies will be left in the craters. And her company, based on an exceptional business philosophy, faces exceptional challenges.

FI, originally known as Freelancers International, is certainly an unusual company though you would not think so from its bog-standard headquarters on a business park in Hemel Hempstead. Essentially, it is run by women - Cropper and her long-standing colleague, Jo Connell, group managing director.

Intellectual capital

But the times and culture have changed since it was founded in 1962 by Steve Shirley, a German-born Jewish woman, who ran it with an initial £6 and a kitchen table for her office. Until the sex discrimination act of the mid-1970s FI employed only women.

Cropper, who joined the computer software group as managing director in 1985, gives off little sense of the crusading feminist spirit that motivated its founder and dismisses any suggestion that a commercial outfit run by women is, well, more cooperative, collaborative and less cut-throat competitive.

In fact, the corporate culture at FI is highly collaborative. But Cropper says: "Maggie [Thatcher] was not a great collaborator. I have no idea whether it's to do with women: I've seen plenty of situations where women have done the opposite of what we're talking about. And I was educated in a convent and I don't remember much cooperation among the nuns."

Her own business culture owes a great deal to her experiences working in large computing firms. "I had seen - though I worked for outfits which treated me well - such a waste of human intellectual capital.

"I know I came here with a view that this thing was small enough to mould [it had sales of £7m] and I was most definitely going to create a culture where that kind of near-repression simply didn't happen. It's still true and all the newcomers, to a man or woman, say it's the least political organisation they've ever come across."

A defining moment came when Dame Steve Shirley, who became life president in 1989, handed over the reins to Cropper as chief executive and Sir Peter Thompson as chairman. The founder, influenced by Quaker ideas, wanted to turn the company into a trust but Cropper and Thompson, who led the buyout at the National Freight Corporation, embraced the idea of employee share ownership and managed an employee buyout in 1991.

Today, even after a series of acquisitions - the OSI business consulting group last year, the Indian computer group IIS Infotech in 1998 and January's £763m takeover of Druid, the management consultancy group - around a third of the enlarged group is owned by the workforce and employee benefit trusts. After buying Druid the group has 5,000 staff, compared with 500 in 1991 when Steve Shirley sold a block of her shares to the workforce.

Cropper, who made £6.5m from a board sale of some of their own holdings a year ago, is wedded to employee ownership. "If you've got a massive vote that your workforce control you can't pull the wool over their eyes. I actually think I work for them," she says.

IIS Infotech has embraced the culture and employee share ownership scheme. It affects the entire group, Cropper says.

FI's workforce influence, she adds, is much greater than the size of its proxy votes. "It doesn't stop you being tough: there could be job cuts but that doesn't stop you. Anyway, we have always kept a high degree of variable cost in our base; of the 5,000 staff around 1,000 are contractors or freelancers and if there's any slack you take it out of there rather than cutting back on employees."

Cropper sees FI emerging as a powerhouse in the e-commerce world of constant reinvention. "We have got all the elements to help customers through business change which is technology-driven. We are not selling these services independently but as a total package or solution." E-commerce consultancy provided 10% of turnover in the six months to October 31 last year and FI wants to boost this to at least 30% in the coming years.

But Cropper has set her sights wider. "The international operation provides 17% of turnover and we are going to move it significantly. We will certainly be a multinational company in the next few years.

"I'm a great believer in organic growth because that way you tend to create more shareholder value. Equally, you've got to do acquisitions if you want to remain independent - which we do."

There are plenty of bumps and dents in the landscape to be navigated. Reading-based Druid came with a profits warning because of IT spending postponed due to the millennium bug. It is not expected to return to the black until next year.

Cropper is sanguine. "The atmosphere is hugely volatile but I don't worry about it. The market simply doesn't see the potential growth we see."

But, she admits, many of FI's customers have simply put off change and there's been a limbo. "Everybody knows it will get back to normal. We've also effectively told the analysts Druid will get back into profit but don't push your expectations too high; it's the year after they'll make a significant contribution."

Career moves

Then there's the little matter of the euro and the UK's readiness to join - another source of lucrative business for FI that has been on hold for some time. Cropper doesn't blame the government's dithering and expects a genuine lift in contract work once the single currency is circulating as notes and coins in 2002.

"This will be a very big piece of work, bigger than Y2K. Two years ago, it looked as if work on the euro and the bug would dovetail but it didn't."

After a lifetime's reinvention Cropper will probably retire when Britain joins the euro but who knows? Certainly not she. The 200 acres her husband farms are clearly his domain; FI and its wider interests hers.

"There were plenty of times when his career was jumping way ahead of mine and now it's the opposite. There were tensions, of course, when the children were smaller. If you're going to have a career and a family you've got to compromise your career up to a point because you've got to support each other through it.

webTitle: Blue blood of America's motorbike snobbery

fields.headline: Blue blood of America's motorbike snobbery
fields.standfirst: Brand values - Harley-Davidson
fields.trailText: Peter Fonda rode one in Easy Rider. So did Dennis Hopper. They saw early action as American troops scrapped with Pancho Villa in the 1900s along the Mexican border and rather more in subsequent wars.
fields.body:
Peter Fonda rode one in Easy Rider. So did Dennis Hopper. They saw early action as American troops scrapped with Pancho Villa in the 1900s along the Mexican border and rather more in subsequent wars.

But these days still the figure in crash helmet and leathers on a Harley-Davidson is more likely to be a married man of middle years than a serving soldier or a romantic rebel in search of a cause.

For a company close to celebrating its centenary, Harley-Davidson has a snappy summary of its history. It "began in a shed, went to war, became the symbol of American individualism and ended up king of the road".

These days the shed is distant history - although there is no lack of pretenders to the bikers' crown, and Harley-Davidson still retains an idiosyncratic approach which might be thought to reinforce its claim as a flag carrier of individuality.

Take, for instance, its attitude to the internet. Harley-Davidson has its own comprehensive website, but while some of its rivals see the internet as a crucial selling tool, Milwaukee's motorbike maker will have none of it.

If you want to buy a Harley-Davidson then you have to go to a dealer.

"Besides, it might do you some good to get away from your computer and see the real world, maybe even do a little shopping," says the company.

As for chat rooms they are, according to Harley-Davidson: "for people who drive cars. We prefer to chat in the middle of a national park".

But for all its folksy approach - Harley-Davidson was not called Davidson-Harley because the four founders were three Davidsons but only one Harley and it was apparently seen as the gentlemanly thing to put his name first - the firm has not survived into the 21st century by being a corporate pushover.

The depression in the 1930s decimated the American motorcycle industry. Only two manufacturers survived the slump, Harley-Davidson and Indian - the former on the back of its police and military orders, exports and a "conservative business management". Twenty years later, and the two were down to one.

For a while it was full throttle on the open road towards a Wall Street flotation in 1965. Within four years it had merged with the American Machine and Foundary Company. Money was poured into expanding production.

Then the Japanese arrived. Market share fell sharply. With a little help from Washington, however, and new models like the Electra Glide ($20,000 for the ultraclassic) Harley-Davidson weathered the storm.

Ronald Reagan hailed the group as an "American success story" - despite which the company has continued to flourish. Indeed its shares hit an all-time peak this month.

But quite what turned the company from a mere manufacturer of motorbikes into an American icon is not easy to pin down. Maybe it was the contribution to the American effort in the second world war, or perhaps its rugged battle for survival during the 1970s and early 1980s.

Or maybe it was the 1950s, with the Sportster superbike and a generation with a taste for customising which encap sulated a post-war craving for individuality. "We could talk about that for hours over several beers," said spokesman Steve Piehl. Therein lies another conundrum. For all its cult status Harley-Davidson is not what made Milwaukee famous. That accolade belongs to the beer, not the bike.

fields.headline: Small wonder
fields.standfirst: As a teenager, she volunteered to help concentration camp survivors and the experience changed her life. Today she works with victims of torture and helps them overcome unimaginable horrors.  Simon Hattenstone on the tireless compassion of an 'ordinary woman with extraordinary talents'
fields.trailText: As a teenager, she volunteered to help concentration camp survivors and the experience changed her life. Today she works with victims of torture and helps them overcome unimaginable horrors. Simon Hattenstone on the tireless compassion of an 'ordinary woman with extraordinary talents'
fields.body:
In 1945 Helen Bamber made the decision that was to shape her life. She was 19 years old, still a girl, when she told her parents that she was going to Belsen with the Jewish Relief Unit. She didn't quite know why she felt compelled to see, to smell, to understand the dreadful aftermath of Nazism, but she knew she had to. It was in Germany that Bamber decided the world was divided into two camps: bystanders and witnesses. Bystanders see what they want, turn away when it suits them, deny the evidence if necessary. Witnesses have a duty to observe and report truthfully.

Now, 55 years on, Bamber still divides the world into bystanders and witnesses. As founder and director of the Medical Foundation for the Care of Victims of Torture, she has borne witness to myriad horror stories. At the foundation, she works as a psychotherapist, listening to clients for as long as they wish or can bear to talk. And when she's not listening, she is tending the foundation's ever expanding bureaucracy or travelling the world to discover the most repugnant details of the world's most oppressive regimes. The title of Neil Belton's recent biography of her, The Good Listener (Phoenix, £7.99), is a perfect summation of her life and work: understated, to the point, practical - rather like the foundation itself.

"Helen is not an extraordinary person in many respects," says Sherman Carroll, her director of public affairs at the foundation. "She's not an intellectual, she's not terribly well educated with a fancy degree, she's not a lawyer, not a doctor. She's an ordinary woman who has committed her life to good works. So in that sense she's amazing ... but ordinary."

John McCarthy, the broadcaster and former hostage, remembers being as intrigued as he was impressed the first time he met her. "She's tiny. She'll come to slightly above your waist," he says. "Yet as you talk to her you realise there's a great deal of not just energy but power. She is an interesting mix - so caring and compassionate, but also direct and determined."

When you enter the foundation you walk past a room full of disparate people, of all colours and nationalities. Many faces are marked with the lines and scars of struggle. One woman is laughing with a friend; one man holds the weight of his head - the world - in his hands; a couple of children run about the waiting room. You can't help wondering about their history. Where are they from? How did they offend their home state? Were they psychologically tortured, starved, beaten, locked in solitary? Can they ever be happy again?

Helen Bamber, 74, seems even tinier than John McCarthy suggests. She's wearing a glistening white shirt that is buried inside a smart blue cardigan which trails down to her ankles. Her lips are glossed, her nails varnished in a transparent silver. Any number of bracelets dance up her arms. The foundation has just heard that General Pinochet will be returned to Chile, and she can't hide her despondency. She questions the value of the British medical reports and says she would be happy if the Chilean authorities disregarded them .

She speaks softly and slowly, slightly pedantically. It's a lovely voice - ebbing and flowing, massaging. She gestures emphatically as she talks, and when this is pointed out she is a little embarrassed and defensive. "So many of my clients put their hand on their heart when they want to express something. It's a language of the body."

A conversation with Bamber soon turns to Belsen. She talks about how inexperienced she was, how she had to learn quickly. "I realised after a time that I couldn't take away their suffering, or their images or their losses, or their terrible sense of unresolved grief. People would tell you their story and it would spill out like a kind of vomit. They would go on talking, talking, talking ..." You can hear their despair in her voice. "And what they were telling you was sometimes quite dreadful. After a while I began to realise the most important role for me there was to bear witness. Bearing witness to the vulnerability of humanity."

She stops herself. "It sounds a very pompous phrase doesn't it? But the evil that can be done to human beings is something that I suppose has dominated my life."

Did her parents support her when she went to Germany? "My father accepted it, almost with a shrug of resignation. I think it was something about repaying a debt. I was aware that if the Nazis had succceeded in invading England, we would have been the victims."

Bamber grew up with a sense of persecution. Her father, Louis Balmuth, was born in New York, but his family returned to the Poland of the pogroms before emigrating to England in 1895 when he was nine. He was in his late 30s when he married Marie Bader, who had been born in Britain of Polish extraction. Bamber's first memories are of a huge house in north London's Amhurst Park that she shared with her extended family, a "splendid house" with its own billiards room.

Louis was an accountant by day and a philosopher/scribbler/ mathematician by night. Marie was a singer and pianist who hoped that Helen would realise the dreams she had had for herself and become a celebrated performer. The house was owned by the mysterious Uncle Michael, who had made a fortune as a "merchant", though what he sold no one seemed to know. The Balmuths were clever, multilingual and argumentative, and unsympathetic to the ways and needs of children. Before long, the Depression swallowed up Michael's money, and Helen and her parents found themselves relegated to a much smaller home in nearby Stamford Hill.

Fascism and its attendant fears were a backdrop to daily life. An educated pessimist, Louis Balmuth seemed to regard extermination as an inevitability. As the second world war scoured Europe, he listened to broadcasts by Goebbels, read young Helen extracts from Hitler's treatise Mein Kampf, and told her exactly what the Nazi leader was doing and where it would all end. Balmuth lived petrified by the past and in fear of the future.

Bamber had initially been sent to a private Jewish school in London. But when her parents began to struggle financially she was switched to a multi-denominational primary, from where she won a scholarship to high school in Tottenham. This is where a teacher bawled her out for not knowing the second verse of the national anthem and told her that of all parents, the parents of Jewish children had a particular duty to make sure their children knew the anthem.

She says her real education happened at home in early childhood. Bamber was a sick girl who spent much of her childhood bedridden with an illness that was probably TB. Relatives and refugee friends of her parents used to visit her, talk to her as if she were an adult and deliver bedside chats that could go on for days. She recalls a man who sat by her side explaining the first world war, and how the punitive settlement led to the rise of Hitler.

Bamber didn't go to Belsen with a sense of mission, but with foreboding. "I felt I had to face something, the fear in myself. I had to understand other people's fear, and I had to understand something about overcoming fear_ living. How does one live with the knowledge of atrocity?"

Henry Lunzer, her boss in the Jewish Relief Unit, still thinks of her as a "lovely, vivacious little girl". She was also a natural organiser. "Helen just took charge of headquarters, administered the whole thing," says Lunzer. "It was amazing at that age. God only knows what made her so efficient!" When we talk about Lunzer, Bamber smiles abstractedly. He was "quite a guy", she says, "looked very handsome in uniform, but then everyone looked good in uniform". She pulls herself up abruptly: "That's a stupid thing to say."

Bamber founded the the Medical Foundation for the Care of Victims of Torture in 1985. She had spent three decades campaigning for the human rights organisation Amnesty International, where she had started a group to help torture victims. Amnesty leaders decided that treating torture victims as well as campaigning against the regimes that abused them was too broad a remit, which spurred her to start the foundation. Today there are 85 paid staff and 110 volunteers.

Although never formally trained, Bamber says she has no qualms about calling herself a psychotherapist - she has earned the title, having trained on the job for most of her life. Sheila Melzak, head of child and adolescent psychotherapy, at the foundation says she doesn't know how Bamber does it, but somehow people just open up to her. "She's very moth erly, maternal, but not in a pampering way. All sorts of people feel safe with her, especially those who have missed out on parenting. They'll talk to her about the most private experiences." She says no level of training could equip someone with this skill, and suggests that it is down to Bamber's own childhood experiences.

"I do think it's because of her own lack of parenting in her childhood. Her father was passionate about human rights. Fixated. So she was taught from a very early age about repression and about how other people may challenge that. But as parents they were not particularly good at parenting."

Bamber believes torture is a political act, but she says she must be careful here - the foundation is a charity, and it is important for it not to be perceived as politically motivated. "For me, torture is about total helplessness and total power, the deliberate destruction of people. It often can be at the instigation of the government, carried out by their henchmen. It is about the destruction of human beings, often while keeping them alive. Torture has been described as the attempt to kill a person without their dying."

The foundation exists to help people like Luis Muñoz who was tortured by Pinochet's henchmen. In 1974 his wife, a journalist who had written a book about Chile's ruling class, disappeared and he never saw her again. He was 26, she was 23. Muñoz was then thrown into a torture centre. He was beaten, kicked, forced to hang by his arms. His torturers attached electrodes to his mouth, his ears his eyes, his penis, his anus and his toes. They applied a soldering iron to his testicles. "They thought I was going to die, but they didn't want me dead yet, so they stopped the shock treatment and put me in a wooden box and deprived me of sleep, food and hygiene. There was a little hole for ventilation. They put me in there to drive me mad."

After three months in the torture centre, he was put in solitary confinement for another couple of months before being transferred to a concentration camp. On the way, the guards tormented him with a mock execution. Muñoz pleaded with them to kill him. "I thought I'd be better off dead, I'd given up."

When he arrived in Britain in 1977 he suffered depression, panic attacks and guilt, in addition to considerable physical pain. He first met Bamber when he and fellow Chilean refugees were on a 16-day hunger strike protesting against Pinochet. He discovered that Bamber, like him, lived in London's Muswell Hill, and after that they kept bumping into each other on the 43 bus. "She was very concerned about me. She knew more about my physical and mental health than I did at the time." Bamber told him he looked terrible, broken, that he needed help. "She doesn't let go. You can't evade her. She's very persistent. If you keep stuff from her, she won't give up."

He started going to Bamber for therapy. "For a long time I thought that if you talk about what happened to you, you'll hurt the person; you think it's too much for anyone else to bear. But Helen can contain you. She enables you to cry."

Luis Muñoz is what Bamber would call a creative survivor. She says there is so much rubbish talked about survivors and victims, as if survival itself is enough. But people have to be shown how to live again. She cites the strongest she found at Belsen - those who formed political committees, held religious meetings, started a theatre, forced themselves into being more than helpless victims. In a strange way the culture that grew out of concentration camps like Belsen become a template for the foundation. It is not simply a clinic where victims come to unveil themselves of their histories, but a cultural centre with allotments, holiday clubs, chess groups and drawing classes.

Creative survival is also about allowing people to grieve. Bamber talks about the Jews who came to Britain after the Holocaust and found themselves in a new world where they had to put their past behind them because it was not acknowledged, a world where they had to make do and get on. Many Jewish people did get on, but without an emotional release some imploded.

"That is something I feel so strongly about here. How do you retrieve their memory of somebody so you can bury them in an appropriate way, and not be fixed on their grotesque way of dying? I think many of us have found ways of sitting with people and retrieving that young man or woman by talking about the way they looked, the way they dressed, the way they smoked, and their irritating ways. You can bring the person back as they were in the best of memories, and you then see it's time to bury them." She apologises for her bluntness.

Soon after returning from Belsen she married Rudi Bamberger, who changed his named to the more British Bamber. He had escaped from Germany and the thugs who destroyed his parents' house and beat his father to death with fists and truncheons. There was tenderness and love in their relationship, but it was doomed. Like her father, Rudi was a terminal pessimist. He was drowning in his own darkness, and Bamber couldn't cope. Although her father had been more articulate about his helplessness, they shared the same quietness, the sense of having withdrawn from life. Living with victims is a very different matter to working with them, says Bamber. They divorced after 23 years together.

"It's not that one doesn't have affections or love, but very often somebody who has survived becomes disassociated from themselves as well as other people." She is almost whispering. "That was quite hard to live with - someone who was cut off from communication. You couldn't have spontaneity or celebration."

She says it would have been easier to divorce if they had simply not liked each other. "I was very sad for a long time. I think I'm still very sad." For many years she has lived by herself in Muswell Hill. Life was tough after they split up. She worked as a medical secretary at St George's hospital in east London, but was always broke. Their two sons Jonathan (now a physicist), and David (a sculptor whose work often alludes to the Holocaust), attended separate schools, she didn't have a car, the house they lived in was condemned.

John Rundle, a doctor who has known Bamber for 30 years and now works at the foundation, thinks struggle has made her what she is today. "If you're capable of dealing with the sorts of people we get here I don't think you could come from a jolly-hockey-sticks, wonderfully protective background. Helen has been fighting adversity ever since she was at Belsen. I don't think life has left her much room for personal comforts."

In some ways the breakdown of her marriage was liberating. Because she was short of money she rented rooms to foreign students. Suddenly her morose, dilapidated home was transformed by youth and optimism. "I suppose I began to laugh a lot when they were around. We had fun, we danced, we cooked, I used to book the entire launderette on a Sunday afternoon. There were six or seven students at a time, every nationality under the sun, and there would be great battles or debates about the virtues of eating rhinoceros. There hadn't been much laughter in my parents' home or in my married life."

Bamber has a lovely girlish giggle, and can extract humour from the grimmest situations. She says the ability to laugh is terribly important, especially in someone so prone to crying. Does she cry at work? "No. I can listen to the most appalling stories that people tell me, I can bear it." She says the one thing she can't cope with is hearing people sing. "We used to hold a music group downstairs. And sometimes there would be singing, and this I could hardly bear. We had a terribly sad woman from Iran who used to sit there and do very little, and then she sang, and I had to leave the room. There's something about the human voice; seeing what capacity people have for creativity and what's denied them. Perhaps it's about what people might be if left alone."

Bamber has a famously tough exterior - the woman who gets things done. When asked for five words to describe his mother, Jonathan Bamber chooses: "Driven, focused, dedicated, slightly obsessive . . . She has an unimaginable amount of energy, disappearing off to Uganda, to Kosovo, to the West Bank, all of the most horrible, devastated places in the world. It can drive people mad." Sheila Melzak says that she is finally learning to let go a bit, to delegate, though she's still reluctant to cede control. . "But recently, more and more, I've seen she can have fun."

She talks about how she felt sorry for her parents, their sense of failure and unhappiness, and how she never wanted anyone to feel sorry for her. I get irritated with myself, so it's not surprising others do."

It has been suggested there is a masochistic streak in Bamber that forces her to go on, but Rundle disagrees. "I don't think it's obsessional or pathological. I think it's that she's been challenged. She knows the evil of mankind, and she won't put up with it. It's a crusade if you like. But it's not done as a zealot, it's done as a human being."

While much of Bamber's early middle age was devoted to the domestic, bringing up Jonathan and David, she also managed to hold down a series of demanding jobs - acting almoner (social worker) at Middlesex Hospital, administrator at the Middlesex and personal assistant to the brilliant orthopaedic surgeon Sir Herbert Seddon. For many years she couldn't see a pattern to her life. It's only recently that she has begun to realise it has all been of a piece - from her father; to Belsen; to Rudi, her husband; to Amnesty; to the foundation.

There was also her work with Dr Maurice Pappworth, a much-loved and vilified campaigner against the abuses that go on in the name of medical experimentation. Bamber met Pappworth at St George's where he was a consultant. Bamber would help him with his administration, and they would talk in his rooms for hours about the overuse of drugs, unnecessary surgery, the Nazi doctors' malign experimentation. Bamber says Pappworth educated her about medical ethics. "He was as preoccupied as I was with this question of total power, total helplessness." Together they compiled an archive of abuses. John Rundle, who was taught by Pappworth, describes him as the greatest doctor he met. "Like a lot of very clever people he was succinct and simple because he grasped all the underlying principles, and Helen's very much the same. She tends to be a person of few words, straight to the point."

Bamber is fidgeting again, desperate to get back to work. "It's like sitting here when Rome is burning." The therapists at the foundation see their own therapists, or supervisors, to make sure they are still up to the job. Her supervisor gives her a hard time for over-working. Is she right? "I don't think I'm terribly good at taking care of myself." Perhaps work is her way of looking after herself? "I think it is. I think it gives me a lot of hope, a lot of personal help. I get a lot back from the people we treat in terms of seeing them grow and develop and overcome."

Neil Belton talks about the paradox of the carer. "You can get a lot of satisfaction from being an omnipotent carer. There's a little bit of God that attaches to it, the way people come to rely on her. She is aware of that element."

Does she think there is a danger of playing God? She doesn't answer directly. "You have to be clear that you have tremendous limitations in this work; you know you're going to lose some along the line."

Belton spent three years writing The Good Listener. He says: "Helen remains an enigma to me. Most activists I've known don't retain the humour and human sympathy she brings to her work, the ability to focus on individuals. There's a side that's just the grimly dedicated campaigner, but another that brings a great deal of joy and light."

Earlier this year, the government introduced its immigration and asylum act, which has resulted in asylum seekers living off vouchers instead of real money while being banned from earning their own. Families have been dispersed across the country. "At least when Jewish people came to Britain after the war, they were allowed to live in communities," says Bamber. "I feel so ashamed of the situation."

John McCarthy says: "She starts from the basic premise of right and wrong. You need a fair degree of anger to do her work." Bamber agrees. She says that anger can be a tremendous creative driving force, that without it none of the world's most pernicious regimes would have been defeated.

I know we did try to protect them from the full knowledge of what had happened, and I don't know that I blame myself for that.

"When one of my sons was very young he asked me whether his grandfather had been shot, and I said 'yes', which was a lie, because he was beaten to death in front of his family. At what age do you say that to a child? I suppose I didn't want them to have the same knowledge that I had when I was growing up" - the knowledge she desperately sought out. Bamber never attempts to reconcile her contradictions.

She offers a cigarette from a dusty box. She likes seeing people smoke, she says: it reminds her of the war. She is stroking the hair of a beautifully dressed soft doll that Chilean clients have made to raise money. She is talking about the disappointments in her life; how this fiercely independent woman had always aspired to Sunday-lunch domesticity. "I never quite pulled it off. fields.bodyText: In 1945 Helen Bamber made the decision that was to shape her life. She was 19 years old, still a girl, when she told her parents that she was going to Belsen with the Jewish Relief Unit. She didn't quite know why she felt compelled to see, to smell, to understand the dreadful aftermath of Nazism, but she knew she had to. It was in Germany that Bamber decided the world was divided into two camps: bystanders and witnesses. Bystanders see what they want, turn away when it suits them, deny the evidence if necessary. Witnesses have a duty to observe and report truthfully. Now, 55 years on, Bamber still divides the world into bystanders and witnesses. As founder and director of the Medical Foundation for the Care of Victims of Torture, she has borne witness to myriad horror stories. At the foundation, she works as a psychotherapist, listening to clients for as long as they wish or can bear to talk. And when she's not listening, she is tending the foundation's ever expanding bureaucracy or travelling the world to discover the most repugnant details of the world's most oppressive regimes. The title of Neil Belton's recent biography of her, The Good Listener (Phoenix, £7.99), is a perfect summation of her life and work: understated, to the point, practical - rather like the foundation itself. "Helen is not an extraordinary person in many respects," says Sherman Carroll, her director of public affairs at the foundation. "She's not an intellectual, she's not terribly well educated with a fancy degree, she's not a lawyer, not a doctor. She's an ordinary woman who has committed her life to good works. So in that sense she's amazing ... but ordinary." John McCarthy, the broadcaster and former hostage, remembers being as intrigued as he was impressed the first time he met her. "She's tiny. She'll come to slightly above your waist," he says. "Yet as you talk to her you realise there's a great deal of not just energy but power. She is an interesting mix - so caring and compassionate, but also direct and determined." When you enter the foundation you walk past a room full of disparate people, of all colours and nationalities. Many faces are marked with the lines and scars of struggle. One woman is laughing with a friend; one man holds the weight of his head - the world - in his hands; a couple of children run about the waiting room. You can't help wondering about their history. Where are they from? How did they offend their home state? Were they psychologically tortured, starved, beaten, locked in solitary? Can they ever be happy again? Helen Bamber, 74, seems even tinier than John McCarthy suggests. She's wearing a glistening white shirt that is buried inside a smart blue cardigan which trails down to her ankles. Her lips are glossed, her nails varnished in a transparent silver. Any number of bracelets dance up her arms. The foundation has just heard that General Pinochet will be returned to Chile, and she can't hide her despondency. She questions the value of the British medical reports and says she would be happy if the Chilean authorities disregarded them . She speaks softly and slowly, slightly pedantically. It's a lovely voice - ebbing and flowing, massaging. She gestures emphatically as she talks, and when this is pointed out she is a little embarrassed and defensive. "So many of my clients put their hand on their heart when they want to express something. It's a language of the body." A conversation with Bamber soon turns to Belsen. She talks about how inexperienced she was, how she had to learn quickly. "I realised after a time that I couldn't take away their suffering, or their images or their losses, or their terrible sense of unresolved grief. People would tell you their story and it would spill out like a kind of vomit. They would go on talking, talking, talking ..." You can hear their despair in her voice. "And what they were telling you was sometimes quite dreadful. After a while I began to realise the most important role for me there was to bear witness. Bearing witness to the vulnerability of humanity." She stops herself. "It sounds a very pompous phrase doesn't it? But the evil that can be done to human beings is something that I suppose has dominated my life." Did her parents support her when she went to Germany? "My father accepted it, almost with a shrug of resignation. I think it was something about repaying a debt. I was aware that if the Nazis had succceeded in invading England, we would have been the victims." Bamber grew up with a sense of persecution. Her father, Louis Balmuth, was born in New York, but his family returned to the Poland of the pogroms before emigrating to England in 1895 when he was nine. He was in his late 30s when he married Marie Bader, who had been born in Britain of Polish extraction. Bamber's first memories are of a huge house in north London's Amhurst Park that she shared with her extended family, a "splendid house" with its own billiards room. Louis was an accountant by day and a philosopher/scribbler/ mathematician by night. Marie was a singer and pianist who hoped that Helen would realise the dreams she had had for herself and become a celebrated performer. The house was owned by the mysterious Uncle Michael, who had made a fortune as a "merchant", though what he sold no one seemed to know. The Balmuths were clever, multilingual and argumentative, and unsympathetic to the ways and needs of children. Before long, the Depression swallowed up Michael's money, and Helen and her parents found themselves relegated to a much smaller home in nearby Stamford Hill. Fascism and its attendant fears were a backdrop to daily life. An educated pessimist, Louis Balmuth seemed to regard extermination as an inevitability. As the second world war scoured Europe, he listened to broadcasts by Goebbels, read young Helen extracts from Hitler's treatise Mein Kampf, and told her exactly what the Nazi leader was doing and where it would all end. Balmuth lived petrified by the past and in fear of the future. Bamber had initially been sent to a private Jewish school in London. But when her parents began to struggle financially she was switched to a multi-denominational primary, from where she won a scholarship to high school in Tottenham. This is where a teacher bawled her out for not knowing the second verse of the national anthem and told her that of all parents, the parents of Jewish children had a particular duty to make sure their children knew the anthem. She says her real education happened at home in early childhood. Bamber was a sick girl who spent much of her childhood bedridden with an illness that was probably TB. Relatives and refugee friends of her parents used to visit her, talk to her as if she were an adult and deliver bedside chats that could go on for days. She recalls a man who sat by her side explaining the first world war, and how the punitive settlement led to the rise of Hitler. Bamber didn't go to Belsen with a sense of mission, but with foreboding. "I felt I had to face something, the fear in myself. I had to understand other people's fear, and I had to understand something about overcoming fear_ living. How does one live with the knowledge of atrocity?" Henry Lunzer, her boss in the Jewish Relief Unit, still thinks of her as a "lovely, vivacious little girl". She was also a natural organiser. "Helen just took charge of headquarters, administered the whole thing," says Lunzer. "It was amazing at that age. God only knows what made her so efficient!" When we talk about Lunzer, Bamber smiles abstractedly. He was "quite a guy", she says, "looked very handsome in uniform, but then everyone looked good in uniform". She pulls herself up abruptly: "That's a stupid thing to say." Bamber founded the the Medical Foundation for the Care of Victims of Torture in 1985. She had spent three decades campaigning for the human rights organisation Amnesty International, where she had started a group to help torture victims. Amnesty leaders decided that treating torture victims as well as campaigning against the regimes that abused them was too broad a remit, which spurred her to start the foundation. Today there are 85 paid staff and 110 volunteers. Although never formally trained, Bamber says she has no qualms about calling herself a psychotherapist - she has earned the title, having trained on the job for most of her life. Sheila Melzak, head of child and adolescent psychotherapy, at the foundation says she doesn't know how Bamber does it, but somehow people just open up to her. "She's very moth erly, maternal, but not in a pampering way. All sorts of people feel safe with her, especially those who have missed out on parenting. They'll talk to her about the most private experiences." She says no level of training could equip someone with this skill, and suggests that it is down to Bamber's own childhood experiences. "I do think it's because of her own lack of parenting in her childhood. Her father was passionate about human rights. Fixated. Bamber believes torture is a political act, but she says she must be careful here - the foundation is a charity, and it is important for it not to be perceived as politically motivated. "For me, torture is about total helplessness and total power, the deliberate destruction of people. It often can be at the instigation of the government, carried out by their henchmen. The foundation exists to help people like Luis Muñoz who was tortured by Pinochet's henchmen. In 1974 his wife, a journalist who had written a book about Chile's ruling class, disappeared and he never saw her again. He was 26, she was 23. Muñoz was then thrown into a torture centre. He was beaten, kicked, forced to hang by his arms. His torturers attached electrodes to his mouth, his ears his eyes, his penis, his anus and his toes. They applied a soldering iron to his testicles. "They thought I was going to die, but they didn't want me dead yet, so they stopped the shock treatment and put me in a wooden box and deprived me of sleep, food and hygiene. There was a little hole for ventilation. They put me in there to drive me mad." After three months in the torture centre, he was put in solitary confinement for another couple of months before being transferred to a concentration camp. On the way, the guards tormented him with a mock execution. Muñoz pleaded with them to kill him. "I thought I'd be better off dead, I'd given up." When he arrived in Britain in 1977 he suffered depression, panic attacks and guilt, in addition to considerable physical pain. He first met Bamber when he and fellow Chilean refugees were on a 16-day hunger strike protesting against Pinochet. He discovered that Bamber, like him, lived in London's Muswell Hill, and after that they kept bumping into each other on the 43 bus. "She was very concerned about me. "For a long time I thought that if you talk about what happened to you, you'll hurt the person; you think it's too much for anyone else to bear. But Helen can contain you. She enables you to cry." Luis Muñoz is what Bamber would call a creative survivor. She says there is so much rubbish talked about survivors and victims, as if survival itself is enough. But people have to be shown how to live again. She cites the strongest she found at Belsen - those who formed political committees, held religious meetings, started a theatre, forced themselves into being more than helpless victims. In a strange way the culture that grew out of concentration camps like Belsen become a template for the foundation. It is not simply a clinic where victims come to unveil themselves of their histories, but a cultural centre with allotments, holiday clubs, chess groups and drawing classes. Creative survival is also about allowing people to grieve. Bamber talks about the Jews who came to Britain after the Holocaust and found themselves in a new world where they had to put their past behind them because it was not acknowledged, a world where they had to make do and get on. Although her father had been more articulate about his helplessness, they shared the same quietness, the sense of having withdrawn from life. Living with victims is a very different matter to working with them, says Bamber. They divorced after 23 years together.
