webTitle: Dresdner counts human cost of merger

fields.headline: Dresdner counts human cost of merger
fields.trailText: Day after day. Deal after deal. The vast majority pass across the screen arousing varying degrees of interest but precious little emotion. Just occasionally one, such as the Deutsche-Dresdner merger, causes a flutter of the heart.
fields.body:
Day after day. Deal after deal. The vast majority pass across the screen arousing varying degrees of interest but precious little emotion. Just occasionally one, such as the Deutsche-Dresdner merger, causes a flutter of the heart.

Nine months ago I helped turn out the lights on BT Alex Brown's European equities business as our parent, Bankers Trust, disappeared into the Deutsche Bank machine. Four years earlier at Kleinwort Benson I waved a wary flag of welcome for our new parent, Dresdner Bank. You could say I've had my fill of German banking mergers.

Thursday's press release from Deutsche and Dresdner trumpeted a "merger of equals". This would be funny were its human costs not so sad. Deutsche's shareholders will end up with at least 60% of the combined business, its executives will be in a major ity on the interim board of managing directors and, in London at least, it is the Dresdner staff who will bear the brunt of redundancies.

One wonders whether Deutsche has learned the PR lessons from its bungled handling of the Bankers Trust acquisition. Then Rolf Breuer, its chief executive, boasted of a "best of breed" approach to integration. Our gallows humourists at BT Alex. Brown made much of the teutonic undertones in this remark, especially once its emptiness became apparent. The Deutsche approach was more dog's breakfast than Cruft's.

Most galling of all, at the time, was the stupefyingly large retention package used to neuter Bankers Trust's much-criticised chairman, Frank Newman, until after the merger had been completed. Needless to say, he was then swiftly cast (much wealthier) into oblivion. One suspects that the co-operative approach to managing the new Deutsche bank AG will prove just as temporary.

Dresdner's chief executive officer Bernhard Walter is cited in the press release as stressing that "the merger would be equally favourable for clients, shareholders, em ployment and the financial market in Germany". Leaving Walter's own job prospects aside, it is difficult to see how he can make this claim about employment with a straight face. Shareholders will only benefit because 16,000 jobs are to go over three years, many in Frankfurt where the erstwhile rivals' HQs tower over the peep shows and dis carded syringes of the red light district.

Of the 16,000 redundancies, many will be in investment banking, and many of these in the City of London where Deutsche and Dresdner Kleinwort Benson compete head-to-head for the same territory. If history is any guide, Deutsche management will seek to confine the pain to only one of the two investment banks, hooking out a few star bankers and reducing the rest to rubble.

A rumour ran around Dresdner's Fenchurch Street offices on Wednesday - as details of the merger began to leak - that Deutsche would look to sell DrKB as a going concern. While this has not been ruled out, the rumour always felt like wishful thinking.

Why would Deutsche want to set a rival up in business in the lucrative European capital markets? The value to Deutsche of removing DrKB as a competitor (even after closure costs) must outweigh its sale value to a third party, particularly when Deutsche can pick through the rubble to augment its existing business.

This approach certainly worked for Swiss bank UBS when it combined the Warburg and UBS investment banking businesses in 1998. UBS's refugees scattered to the corners of the City, providing a modest boost for a number of investment banks, but a quantum leap for none.

The merger process will take months. Extraordinary general meetings of the two banks have been slated for November. DrKB faces a steady attrition of clients and staff, slow and humiliating death for a merchant bank with 200 years of history.

It deserved better but there is much to admire in the ruthlessness of Deutsche's approach to takeovers. It may not build perfect businesses, but it creates strong ones. Deutsche's investment bank has flourished in Europe post the Bankers Trust acquisition. In backing its existing culture and jettisoning "best of breed" rhetoric it has at least emerged as a thoroughbred.

Whether Deutsche has the staying power to win the investment banking race, however, is another matter. And, on the back of this merger, only first is likely to be good enough. But right now my sympathies are for those dodging falling masonry in Fenchurch Street.

fields.headline: In a tailspin
fields.standfirst:
£60m PR disaster
British Airways
fields.trailText: It was meant to signify BA's new global vision - a fresh look to dispel the airline's image as the stuffy preserve of the business travelling elite. But those notorious tailfins spun BA into a PR disaster and forced Bob Ayling into an embarrassing climbdown.
fields.body:
It was meant to signify BA's new global vision - a fresh look to dispel the airline's image as the stuffy preserve of the business travelling elite. But those notorious tailfins spun BA into a PR disaster and forced Bob Ayling into an embarrassing climbdown.

He was convinced that to modernise its image, BA had to drop its red, white and blue union flag-based design in favour of "world" colours. Designs from around the globe were introduced to aircraft tails as part of the £60m rebranding.

But the reaction was universally derisive. Lady Thatcher indicated her disapproval by dropping a handkerchief over the "awful" tailfin of a model plane at a Tory party conference.

Richard Branson's Virgin airline, still smarting from the "dirty tricks" campaign waged under a previous regime at BA - though while Ayling was a senior executive - reacted by introducing the union flag to its own aircraft.

Eventually, customer reaction forced BA into a rethink and in June last year the design was changed again. The union flag was back.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: Leading shares ended the week on a positive note, although there was widespread disappointment in the Square Mile that the FTSE 100 failed to hold above 6,600 - seen as a key psychological level. Still, with the Footsie finishing 36.6 points higher at 6,568.7 over the session, this marked the highest level since mid-January.
fields.body:
Leading shares ended the week on a positive note, although there was widespread disappointment in the Square Mile that the FTSE 100 failed to hold above 6,600 - seen as a key psychological level. Still, with the Footsie finishing 36.6 points higher at 6,568.7 over the session, this marked the highest level since mid-January.

Heavyweights moving higher again included British Telecom , which electrified the market on Thursday and then scored another 36p rise to £13.51 yesterday.

But much of the real interest rested in the drugs sector, where AstraZeneca rallied from £23.26 to £24.86, Glaxo Wellcome put on 48p to £16.12 and SmithKline Beecham added 30p to 739p.

Dealers said the sector was simply recovering from the midweek shock of the profit warning from Procter & Gamble in the US.

All the broader indices closed higher, with the Techmark 100 once again standing out - up 119.8 at 5,719.

J Sainsbury topped the Footsie leaderboard, adding 23p to 262p as the supermarket group announced the departure of recent recruit David Bremner, who was in charge of supermarkets. New chief executive Peter Davis will take day-to-day control of the supermarket chain.

British Airways was also in demand on news of the departure of its chief executive, Bob Ayling, adding 6p to 299p.

Other prominent risers included Lloyds TSB , up 34p at 551p after analysts Warburg Dillon Read upgraded the stock to "buy" from "hold" in a review of the banking sector.

Meanwhile, over in the general retailing sector, Kingfisher put on 8p to 523p ahead of next week's initial public offering for French internet provider LibertySurf SA, with analysts valuing Kingfisher's stake in the venture at anywhere between £720m and £2.8bn.

Elsewhere, airports operator TBI fell 11p to 59p after the group warned of poor trading at a number of its airports.

A tweak to the FTSE indicies rules has allowed Israeli high-tech companies Geo Interactive and BATM Advanced Communications to join the Mid 250 indicator. The news saw Geo surge 955p to £35.00, while BATM jumped from £52.50 to £62.85.

webTitle: The man who fell to earth

fields.headline: The man who fell to earth
fields.standfirst:
After a series of misjudgments, BA chief was left to rely on a wing and a prayer
British Airways
fields.trailText: Whenever Tony Blair passed through the British Airways VIP lounge at Heathrow, Bob Ayling always managed to clear a window in his busy schedule to check the peanut bowls were plentifully stacked. After waving Tony and Cherie off on another official tour, he could repair to his open-plan office, gaze out over the newly laid cobbles and carefully placed water features, and bask in his privileged position as a favoured square mile neo-socialist.
fields.byline: Matt Wells, Keith Harper  and Kevin Maguire
fields.body:
Whenever Tony Blair passed through the British Airways VIP lounge at Heathrow, Bob Ayling always managed to clear a window in his busy schedule to check the peanut bowls were plentifully stacked. After waving Tony and Cherie off on another official tour, he could repair to his open-plan office, gaze out over the newly laid cobbles and carefully placed water features, and bask in his privileged position as a favoured square mile neo-socialist.

But the hotline to Downing Street would not save the share price, and when profits tumbled and the shareholders bayed for blood, even Mr Ayling could not survive the storm. When the BA chief executive took another spin in the London Eye this week, he already knew his time was up. "Life is full of risks and some of them pay off in a big way," he told reporters gathered for the wheel's official opening. The decision to sponsor the Eye now seems a risk worth taking: his strategy to turn round BA, unfortunately, does not.

A few months after the former lawyer and civil servant succeeded Sir (now Lord) Colin Marshall at the helm of BA on January 1 1996, the airline announced record pre-tax profits of £474m. A lucrative alliance with American Airlines was in the offing, and Mr Ayling had embarked upon an ambitious £1bn cost-cutting programme. Even after privatisation, BA was still a national institution: the UK's unchallenged flag carrier.

But in four years staff morale hit rock bottom with his inept handling of a cabin crew strike; the airline's new tailfin design became a national joke, and a proposed tie-up with American Airlines became bogged down in regulatory disputes. Attempts to cut staff failed - the BA payroll now stands at more than 63,000 - and most humiliating of all, the stock market is bracing itself for losses that might top £200m. "First we had King, then we had Marshall - now we are just Ayling," the graffiti at BA headquarters read.

Some analysts wonder how he survived so long.

Certainly, Mr Ayling is naturally resilient. He was forced to leave King's school, Wimbledon, at 16 when his father's retail business went bankrupt. He took a job in a law firm and ended up a partner at 24. His family commitments are as demanding as his professional life: he and his wife have three children, two boys and a girl the eldest son, aged 25, has Down's syndrome.

And it is clear that Mr Ayling's association with new Labour did him no harm - in the beginning, at least. He held a joint 50th birthday bash with Jack Straw, the home secretary, after the pair discovered they were both born on August 3 1946; Mike Craven, a former aide to John Prescott, advises the airline on its PR strategy.

The strength of the relationship was underlined when BA was persuaded to help bail out the millennium dome at a time when it had few friends and even fewer financial backers. Ever-reliable BA agreed to become a £6m co-sponsor.

When Jennie Page was sacked as dome chief executive in January, ministers might have taken the flak publicly but journalists were left in no doubt that Mr Ayling had called the shot. It was a handy way of sharing the blame.

In turn, Mr Blair demonstrated his gratitude 18 months ago by stopping off in Toulouse when BA took delivery of £2bn worth of Airbus planes. Mr Blair and his team have worked hard to build up the relationship - the BA champagne party at Labour's annual conference is a must.

Only last October, Mr Ayling said he planned to confound his critics by seeing out the seven remaining years of his contract.

He described the criticisms levelled at him as "malicious" and spoke in enthusiastic terms of "the excellent new, young management team" over which he was presiding. In reality, Mr Ayling was facing mounting pressure to go.

While the tailfin controversy earned Mr Ayling the derision of the travelling public - with Lady Thatcher leading the catcalls - it was two business misjudgments that caused more nervousness on the stock market floor.

The staff overhaul and the proposed tie-up with American Airlines were part of Mr Ayling's strategy to modernise the airline's image and business practices. But both turned into expensive disasters which took up much of his time and, according to some analysts, drew his eye from the ball.

The 1997 industrial dispute was BA's most expensive mistake of the decade. Directors sought to slash costs at a time when BA was the most profitable airline in the industry: flight attendants reacted angrily against the imposition of new rosters and working practices. In a staggering display of corporate arrogance, managers threatened to sack - and even sue - the striking flight attendants. The three-day dispute cost BA £125m, and the trust of its staff.

It also probably cost Mr Ayling a peerage. He was frozen out of the New Labour circle and friends whispered that he felt "snubbed and humiliated". But there was universal agreement that BA's handling of the dispute was inept, and a dismayed Downing Street saw it as a throwback to the 1970s.

Mr Ayling struggled hard to rebuild staff morale. He attempted to be seen more on the shop floor, but did not share the gregariousness of his predecessors and never felt at ease with the trolley girls and boys.

On an inaugural flight from London to Denver, the 747's in-flight entertainment system failed: but the harassed cabin crew battled to keep the VIPs smiling alone. The populist boss of a certain rival airline, you might imagine, would have been plying the aisles signing free flight vouchers; instead, Mr Ayling sat firm in first class.

Indeed, it was the United States which proved to be his undoing. BA's much-lauded link with American Airlines would have created one of the world's biggest carriers. But the deal fell foul of regulators: the European Commission ruled that BA would have to give up 267 landing and take-off slots to rivals, more than half of the airline's market share on some transatlantic routes.

The United States justice department came out against the deal and BA was eventually forced to settle for a humiliating compromise, joining a loose partnership of five international carriers, including AA. Some observers feel that Mr Ayling devoted far too much of his time to this protracted wrangle and failed to notice the where things were going wrong at the airline's core.

There were many successes, including the launch of a cut-price airline, Go, in the face of stiff opposition from rivals. But Mr Ayling's latest plan to woo the high-paying business class passengers has been widely criticised, and in the end, he could not resist the pressure to go.

Juggling the toughest job in the airline industry with a time-consuming family life must take its toll, even of the toughest shopkeeper's son.

fields.headline: Call centre management
fields.standfirst: Catherine Clayton, operations manager at First Direct, talks to Miles Brignall
fields.trailText: I studied Arabic and management at university and although I haven't used the Arabic yet, all the management stuff has been hugely useful. I'm responsible for just over 100 staff processing new account applications - half deal with telephone enquires, the others input new customers' details.
fields.body:
I studied Arabic and management at university and although I haven't used the Arabic yet, all the management stuff has been hugely useful. I'm responsible for just over 100 staff processing new account applications - half deal with telephone enquires, the others input new customers' details.

A lot of the data work isn't particularly interesting and so an important part of my job is motivating those doing it.

The department is split into teams of around 25 and we sit in a big open plan office dealing with completed application forms, either on paper or via the internet.

Because we never see our customers, all our focus is on providing the best possible service down the telephone line. As a result we monitor each employee's performance for both speed and accuracy and we know how much work everyone's doing - you'd be surprised how much it varies. Where a member of staff is falling short of what's expected, I'll organise support and training to get them up to speed. It's not our style, or in our interest to get rid of people and we haven't had to sack anyone yet.

Motivation comes in the form of planned bonuses topped up with incentives - won either by individuals or as a department. I'm always trying to think up new ways of encouraging those that are hitting their targets like giving away holidays or electrical items or putting money towards a departmental night out.

Because the company has set months in which it heavily markets the service we have very busy periods. A lot of my job is predicting when we'll be working at full stretch and bringing in extra staff as required. Because the department is open from 7am to 10pm and we work shifts, we try to be as flexible as possible and try to help those with children. Accommodating things like school holidays all has to be managed.

My other main area of responsibility is to represent the department to the rest of the company. I sit in a lot of meetings discussing future plans and I will have to agree whether, as a department, we can deliver what is being proposed and whether it's practical. In turn, I have to take back any changes and explain what their impact will be on the department.

I get my satisfaction from watching it all running smoothly and love the fact that we generate genuine enthusiasm and a good team spirit.

I studied at Leeds University and decided to stay in the city when I left. I started out as someone taking the calls, was promoted to team leader and on to my current position.

fields.headline: Tip of the week
fields.standfirst: Count the days
fields.trailText: Count the days
fields.body:
Well done, you've got the job! But you can forget about a honeymoon. "Companies used to have what they loosely called a 90-day probation period," says executive coach Linda Seale. "Now they can't spare more than 60 days. At some companies, you're lucky to get even that." The biggest mistake that a new recruit can make is to lose a sense of urgency, says Seale.

"Time slides by, and before you know it, you're stuck with whatever impression you may have haphazardly left for others to see. The combination of your performance and your personality will determine how you're viewed."

Status: Managing director of internet price comparison service Shopgenie

Past: Degree in computer science, artificial intelligence and psychology from Nottingham University. Joined Perot Systems - IT company created by Texan billionaire Ross Perot - but quit after just six months. "I got tired of developing other people's ideas."

Present: Created Shopgenie last May. Type in the book, CD or software you want to buy and Shopgenie scours 30 online stores for the best price. Expects workforce to double to 20 within next eight weeks.

Future: Relaunching the site this month to include new features. Planning to introduce more product categories and move into areas such as financial services. "We'll go to market when the time is right."

Strengths: "I'm very creative and pretty dynamic ."

Weaknesses:"I lack patience. I want everything done now."

Wisdom: "If you can articulate your ideas clearly, you'll always find people who can help you."

webTitle: An ABC guide to ... settling into your new job

fields.headline: An ABC guide to ... settling into your new job
fields.trailText: A House rules
fields.body:
A House rules

Learning through mistakes doesn't do much for your confidence during the first days of a new job. What you could use is an alternative employee handbook containing details of whose gossip to listen to, whose stapler not to borrow and an outline of current involvement or animosity between individuals. What you have to make do with is discovering all the taboos without breaking too many of them.

B Ask nicely

During the inevitable period of mutual sizing up you're expected to make blunders. Try not to be embarrassed by them. Always apologise, but avoid grovelling or appearing insensitive - the way you handle early errors can have a lasting effect on how people react to you. Asking about every small detail makes you appear fussy and uncertain. Spread your questions around and supplement them with observation. Listen to gossip - but don't take it seriously or contribute until you know who you can trust.

C Curiosity value

Don't resent the curiosity of others; you've come into their world and they need to know what effect you'll have on it. Enjoy the attention while it lasts, but unfold slowly. Preserve some mystery until you work out how much you should reveal and to whom. Don't rush into relationships, alliances or reforms. One common unwritten rule is that the newcomer should not be cocky, bossy or critical. If you want to do things differently be subtle and give it time.

Taking place in London on Saturday, March 18 and costing £65, the workshop will help you generate and research new career ideas and options. Call 020 7554 4555 for further details.
fields.body:
 Working weekend: Step By Step is the latest in a series of one day workshops organised by our friends at C2, the "graduate careers shop". Taking place in London on Saturday, March 18 and costing £65, the workshop will help you generate and research new career ideas and options. Call 020 7554 4555 for further details.

 Books of the week: Kick-start your career in fashion, accountancy or the media with Kogan Page's new series of Careers in ... guides. Packed full of advice and info on the qualifications and skills you'll need, each book offers names and contact details of potential employers. Priced £8.99 each, the books can be ordered from our Cultureshop. Ring 0800 316 6102.

 Don't be shy: Do you lack confidence at work? You're not alone. A study by the Shyness Research Institute at Indiana University has found that the number of people claiming to be shy has risen from 40% to 48% during the last 15 years. The advent of email and mobile phones has only made it easier for the shy to be bullied warns the study.

 You've got fe-male: The internet is helping to further equality in the workplace. Women held top management posts in 45% of internet companies that venture capital firms financed during 1999 - up dramatically from 1998, when women accounted for just 21% of senior management positions, according to VentureOne, a research firm in San Francisco.

 Inviting the grown-ups: If you still get embarassed by your mum and dad, you probably won't be interested in the latest family-friendly initiative to sweep the US: Bring Your Parents To Work Day. At New York web design firm Organic, for example, 125 parents spent half a day learning what their kids actually do for a living before breaking for pizza.

 Heading for the exit: Companies reward their MBA-qualified staff with an immediate salary rise of 25% and then fail to make use of their newly acquired skills, according to an Association of MBAs survey. Within one year of graduation, one in three has moved on.

fields.headline: Paperback non-fiction, 11 March
fields.trailText:
We wish to inform you...
by Philip Gourevitch
(Picador, £6.99)
Buy it from BOL
fields.body:
We wish to inform you...
by Philip Gourevitch
(Picador, £6.99)
Buy it from BOL

Awards and encomiums went to this because it was the first - make that the only - attempt to report the 1994 Rwandan decimation (it's a measure of the scrupulousness of Gourevitch that he uses "decimation" in its exact sense: the death of one-tenth). No excitement in the bodycount; no easy emoting; just the most accurate record he could compile, true to tone as well as to fact. He has done the murdered the courtesy of not simplifying their lives or their deaths, and he has set down calmly the testimony of the escaped. Here is a real place in its full ambiguity and complexity. A hard book to read because you cannot, you must not, put it out of mind.

Voltaire's Coconuts
by Ian Buruma
(Phoenix, £7.99)
Buy it from BOL

We've always trusted Buruma's cross-cultural perceptions - his understanding of the fantasies that motivate Japan, for example. So we were uncomfortable with this study of European Anglomania, because of the awkwardness of its transitions between family biography and the history of ideas. Juxtaposing refugees in Buruma households and a movie definition of Englishness in The Scarlet Pimpernel comes off - Hungarian actor Leslie Howard embodies a Hungarian novelist's romance with England; and so does the chapter on Dr Pevsner (classifier of parish churches, etc). But in earlier centuries and in the final summary we wished Buruma had had the nerve to settle for the personal and footnoted the political. Or the other way about.

fields.headline: Audio, 11 March
fields.trailText:
Robert, My Father
written and read by Sheridan Morley
(ABM, £8.99, 165 mn)
fields.body:
Robert, My Father
written and read by Sheridan Morley
(ABM, £8.99, 165 mn)

"Move the fat boy" was the first and hardly most auspicious stage direction yelled about the youth who was to become one of Britain's most loved character actors. His son gives an affectionate, admiring and honest appraisal of his father's remarkable career, which began shakily at RADA, after a hopeless public-school stint spent largely in the sick bay to avoid games. The first word of his solemn audition piece provoked an instant guffaw, but RADA admitted him - partly, says Sheridan, because there was a shortage of male applicants in the 1920s. Morley père was to appear in 50 plays and twice as many films, in between prolific bursts of playwriting and journalism. Sheridan delivers his homage at a cracking lick: presumably drama critics develop a horror of dawdling, having sat through so much of it. It is an evident labour of love and altogether makes heart-warming and delightful listening.

fields.headline: Paperback fiction, 11 March
fields.trailText:
Our Fathers
by Andrew O'Hagan
(Faber, £6.99)
Buy it from BOL
fields.body:
Our Fathers
by Andrew O'Hagan
(Faber, £6.99)
Buy it from BOL

O'Hagan's debut novel is a hymn to Scotland the angry, the defiant and the misunderstood. Jamie Bawn grows up in the shadow of his father - fired by drink, violence and despair - and his grandfather, a devout socialist who plans to sweep away slums and replace them with palaces in the sky. Both are indelibly Scottish - reflections of their country's post-war dreams and post-industrial decay. Yet until Jamie returns to look after his dying grandfather, the pieces of his family jigsaw fail to fit. O'Hagan is a master of epiphany: in his hands the slightest incident acquires significance. At times he overplays his gift for description, but Our Fathers is a compelling book.

The Vintner's Luck
by Elizabeth Knox
(Vintage, £6.99)
Buy it from BOL

A chronicle of the life and times of a French vintner in the first half of the 19th century with the addition of annual angelic visitations, The Vintner's Luck is a mixture of the prosaic and the mysterious. Through her hero, Sobran Jodeau, Knox tells of vendanges, wars, progress, passion and death in a small Burgundy village. Jodeau's midsummer trysts with Xas, all pale skin and expressive wings, cause Jodeau spiritual headaches as well as an urge to sin. There is only one possible conclusion - a fall from grace. Despite its angelic writing and inspired structure, however, the divine and the everyday do not quite mesh into a satisfying whole.

Midwinter Of The Spirit
by Phil Rickman
(Pan, £5.99)
Buy it from BOL

If it weren't for the profession of its heroine, Rickman's Hereford-set thriller would be a dead cert for Sunday evening television. But it's not just that Merrily Watkins is a heavy-smoking female vicar who swears like a trooper on occasion. She also runs the diocesan "deliverance ministry" - that's exorcism to lay folk. Even before she gets a flash office under the nose of her trendy bishop boss, things start going bump all over the county and Merrily has to calm spirits both quick and dead. Rickman does the supernatural stuff with élan and builds around his heroine a rich hinterland of politicking clerics and mother-daughter growing pains - all of which makes for an entertaining read, with shivers.

Stolen Marches
by David Crackanthorpe
(Review, £6.99)
Buy it from BOL

A wartime thriller with a human face, Crackanthorpe's debut deals with the reckonings which come at war's end. Stephen Seagrove is estranged from his family and from England. His war has been spent with the resistance in southern France harrying the occupiers and preparing for the revolution which will surely come after liberation. A chance photograph taken of a Frenchman watching the deportation of French Jews and his personal quest to find Ida, his gypsy lover, ensure that for Seagrove peace is more deadly than war. Crackanthorpe, a first-time novelist at 71, weaves a complicated plotline around his romantic hero - more Wordsworthian than Byronic - but his laconic prose sidesteps both sentimentality and derring-do.

webTitle: Home and The Long Room Gallery

fields.headline: Home and The Long Room Gallery
fields.trailText: Home
fields.body:
Home

The Illinois sunrise demonstrates
exactly what an alien you are
in your car on the prairie
heading north to Chicago
where some Irish guy
aimed a hundred years ago.
That's why you're going there
instead of somewhere else.
He is controlling your life
and the direction of your auto.
If he had decided on Boston -
you'd be driving there instead.
Funny how we let this geezer
place us here and give us an accent,
expecting us to live surrounded
by corn and soybean fields.
In a booth at the Dixie Truck Stop
you drink your bottomless coffee
and figure how the rustics to your left
and the military personnel to the rear
were similarly plonked down
in the middle of nowhere.
Simple souls that we are
we now call this region "Home".

The Long Room Gallery (Trinity College Dublin)

There is nothing to breathe
here in the Gallery
except old years.
The air from today
goes in one lung
and 1783 comes out the other.
As for spirits,
stand perfectly still
and you will feel them
carousing near your ear.
Tourists down below
think they've seen a ghost
when they spot you
floating through the bookcases
over their heads.
On a creaky wooden balcony
you tunnel through centuries,
mountains of books
rising into the cumulus.
You could scale a ladder
up the rockface of knowledge
or search the little white slips
stuck in books
for a personal message
from Swift.
Ancient oxygen,
antique dust particles, petrified wood...
Who are you kidding?
You belong down there:
baseball caps, chewing gum, videos.

fields.headline: The sisters of southern gothic
fields.trailText: Rebecca Wells's second novel, Divine Secrets of the Ya-Ya Sisterhood , has become one of those success stories that less fortunate writers rock themselves to sleep with. It is set in her native Louisiana, and tells the story of four Southern belles, born in the 30s, who grow up together: from childhood, through hellraising adolescence, to motherhood, middle-age and grey feistiness. When the daughter of one of them tells a newspaper interviewer there was maternal violence in her childhood, her enraged mother disinherits her. But thanks to the sisterhood of the Ya-Yas, they come to understand and forgive each other.
fields.body:
Rebecca Wells's second novel, Divine Secrets of the Ya-Ya Sisterhood , has become one of those success stories that less fortunate writers rock themselves to sleep with. It is set in her native Louisiana, and tells the story of four Southern belles, born in the 30s, who grow up together: from childhood, through hellraising adolescence, to motherhood, middle-age and grey feistiness. When the daughter of one of them tells a newspaper interviewer there was maternal violence in her childhood, her enraged mother disinherits her. But thanks to the sisterhood of the Ya-Yas, they come to understand and forgive each other.

Not merely is the book a commercial success (selling four million copies in the US), but for its fans it has become a lifestyle. Fifty-three Ya-Ya Sisterhood "chapters" have sprung up in the US, with two more in England and one in Cork. There is a Ya-Ya website, written in a Ya-Ya drawl and featuring pictures of "Rebecca with lilly on her porch" (sic), or Rebecca with girlfriends, plus musings on the "joy of inter dependence", the importance of privacy to famous writers in small towns, or the charm of her Ya-Ya soul-sisters.

"In Knoxville, Tennessee," she writes. "I was swept into a gold 1966 GTO convertible with a gang of passionate readers who'd had an initiation ceremony à la Ya-Ya, and taken on tribal names like Baroness of Benevolence and Duchess of Divine Decadence and, my personal favorite, The Mistress of Farts - a reference to an important (and all too public) bonding event which cemented the Ya-Yas' friendship at the age of eight."

Does this mean that all Ya-Yas are insane? "Oh, no!" says Wells emphatically. She met the the San Francisco group last year and they were "powerful, literate" women.

Perhaps Wells has hit a nerve, because she taps into a mass craving for idealised Ya-Ya friendship - girls together with their secrets, breaking rules and baling each other out at times of crisis. But there is also much to identify with in the book's darker theme - the agonising and often unspoken territory of mother/daughter relationships, caught for ever between love and hatred.

"I like to write books that are like beautiful cakes with files inside - the get-out-of-jail kind of file," says Wells, whose first novel Little Altars Everywhere , was a thinner, darker book. The cake metaphor is particularly apt for Divine Secrets , which has a candied fluffiness and touchy-feely sentimentality that threatens to swamp the dark emotions buried inside.

So powerful is the evocation of the mother/daughter crossfire that one can't help feeling it's autobiographical, but Wells insists it's not. In fact, she is outraged by a trend she identifies as "sidelining fictive narrative with memoir or romans-à-clef." She says: "We want to assume that fiction is a reflection of the writer's life. It reduces the imagination. My work is the result of my imagination dancing a psycho-spiritual tango."

She says the only autobiographical element in the book is the oddly named dog Hueylene, based on her own dog. The love interest - a handsome, intelligent fiancé who understands a Ya-Ya's troubled soul - is certainly not modelled on the man with whom she lives, an artist.

Success hasn't arrived early to Wells (she won't disclose her age, but says she is old enough to have studied with Allen Ginsberg). She began writing novels, after her career as an actress /playwright was stalled by an accident. "I was playing a New Orleans erotic dancer in a play I had written, and as I came down from a burlesque flight in five-inch heels, I cracked my left foot." It was during her convalescence that she "gave herself permission" to write.

A graduate of Louisiana State University and the University of Georgia, Wells also studied with a Tibetan Buddhist teacher whom she cites as her creative influence, along with Jung and gospel, "and the more feminine aspects of Catholicism - cowgirl Catholicism I call it, but no dogma. I have my bones to pick with the Vatican."

It took her four years to write the Ya-Yas; her best time, she says, is 4.30am - before her dream consciousness is disturbed by the racket of Seattle, where she now lives. At one point, when she was writing, she found herself leading a back-to-front life, writing by night and sleeping by day. Writing still doesn't come easily to her: "I doubt myself every day, but you have to move on with faith in the power of the imagination, character and narrative even when your confidence lies shattered."

The actress in her won't let her take the frustrations of her new life sitting down. When she finds herself getting restless she dances to "Swamp pop": Louisiana R&B. What next? She's working on something but it's still, she says - with a swoop into French that is part of the strange, camp Ya-Ya lingo - "a bébé ". She doesn't yet want to speak about it, she's superstitious, it's in gestation. Have the Ya-Yas made her rich? "I was raised to consider it très gauche to talk about money - am I mega-rich? No. The sales are a complete shock to me. I've lived a bohemian-artist life, but now I don't have to drive my 25-year-old Impala, I have a Honda Accord."

 Divine Secrets of the Ya-Ya Sisterhood is published by Pan at £5.99.

Success hasn't arrived early to Wells (she won't disclose her age, but says she is old enough to have studied with Allen Ginsberg). She began writing novels, after her career as an actress /playwright was stalled by an accident. "I was playing a New Orleans erotic dancer in a play I had written, and as I came down from a burlesque flight in five-inch heels, I cracked my left foot." It was during her convalescence that she "gave herself permission" to write. A graduate of Louisiana State University and the University of Georgia, Wells also studied with a Tibetan Buddhist teacher whom she cites as her creative influence, along with Jung and gospel, "and the more feminine aspects of Catholicism - cowgirl Catholicism I call it, but no dogma. I have my bones to pick with the Vatican." It took her four years to write the Ya-Yas; her best time, she says, is 4.30am - before her dream consciousness is disturbed by the racket of Seattle, where she now lives. At one point, when she was writing, she found herself leading a back-to-front life, writing by night and sleeping by day. Writing still doesn't come easily to her: "I doubt myself every day, but you have to move on with faith in the power of the imagination, character and narrative even when your confidence lies shattered." The actress in her won't let her take the frustrations of her new life sitting down. When she finds herself getting restless she dances to "Swamp pop": Louisiana R&B. What next? She's working on something but it's still, she says - with a swoop into French that is part of the strange, camp Ya-Ya lingo - "a bébé ". She doesn't yet want to speak about it, she's superstitious, it's in gestation. Have the Ya-Yas made her rich? "I was raised to consider it très gauche to talk about money - am I mega-rich? No. The sales are a complete shock to me. I've lived a bohemian-artist life, but now I don't have to drive my 25-year-old Impala, I have a Honda Accord."  Divine Secrets of the Ya-Ya Sisterhood is published by Pan at £5.99.

fields.headline: Wag tales
fields.standfirst:
Comedy? Metafiction? Shaggy dog story? Alex Clark enjoys Kate Atkinson's Emotionally Weird
Kate Atkinson's Top Ten books
fields.trailText: Comedy? Metafiction? Shaggy dog story? Alex Clark enjoys the ride
fields.body:
Emotionally Weird
by Kate Atkinson
345pp, Doubleday, £16.99

Literary theory, it might fairly be said, is something of a closed book to anyone outside its seething cloisters: a nightmare of lofty pronouncements wagging an excluding finger at those who wouldn't know the difference between langue and parole if it bit them on the bum. Its pompous opacity makes it a nice subject for gentle satire, especially given that its proponents generally operate in the infinitely send-uppable world of academia. Both David Lodge and Malcolm Bradbury have made a second, and far more profitable, living out of poking fun at their colleagues' perennial obsession with the difference between reality and make-believe, while firmly holding on to their university posts.

In her third novel, Kate Atkinson has a crack at the none-too-subtle business of metafiction. Emotionally Weird - an unexplained and inexplicably grotty title that suggests a rather different kind of book - is teeming with various fictions; the book itself boasts a bewildering array of typefaces. A more insidious by-product of this carnival of confabulation is that, after a while, the reader has no idea what's true and what isn't. By that point, Atkinson is relying, rather too heavily at times, on the fact that we won't care, so beguiled are we by her narrative exuberance and comic invention.

The thrust of the novel takes place in two main fonts. The first, a no-nonsense sans serif, maroons us on a bleak, wind-lashed island, "a speck of peat and heather pricked with thistles", where Euphemia Stuart-Murray - Effie for short, luckily - and her mother Nora are telling each other stories to while away the austere hours. Effie's story, which takes up by far the bigger portion of the book, focuses on her days as an English student at the University of Dundee in the early 70s, and is thoroughly, deliberately inconsequential. It is almost literally a shaggy dog story - great chunks of it revolve around the proprietorship of a stray canine - its utter unimportance in inverse proportion to its narrator's garrulousness. The novel also exploits the convention that the story less told is the one we want to hear more of, so that while Effie's account of her student days proliferates wildly, her mother's story - concerned with Effie's mysterious parentage - sputters out painfully and haltingly, keeping us, for the most part, in the dark.

Of the other typefaces, a typewriter-style font brings us instalments of student Effie's assignment for her creative-writing course, a seaside thriller; a crazy gothic number signals the Middle Earthish fantasies of one of Effie's classmates; pseudo-handwriting gives away a would-be Mills & Boon romance called The Wards of Love ; and a tellingly hard-to-read face alerts us to The Expanding Prism of J , the magnum opus of Effie's theory-mad tutor.

Everybody in Emotionally Weird is trying to write, and most of them are dreadful at it. For Effie, however, the matter is doubly pressing. In her account of her undergraduate days, life is a fast-enclosing crisis of unmet deadlines, in which she is pursued with dream-like intensity for her detective story, her essay on George Eliot and her dissertation, "Henry James - Man or Maze?". On the island hideout it is her mother who constantly prompts and provokes her to further excesses of storytelling, while simultaneously chiding her for her inability to sustain plot development or character. "It's been nothing but ringing telephones and boiling kettles, doorbells and toilets, since you began," she remarks querulously, but not altogether unjustly.

Much of Atkinson's strength as a writer lies in her talent for observational humour. It's hard not to laugh at her Scottish faculty life 70s-style, which at times combines the savagery of The History Man with the surrealism of A Very Peculiar Practice . Effie's tuned-out boyfriend Bob puzzling over predicate logic while watching Star Trek , a community of hessian-clad hippies trying ineptly to slaughter a goat, a Marxist structuralist lecturer bludgeoning the finer points of Derrida and Barthes into a group of largely unconcerned teenagers - all these are woven into a comic caper with an impressive cast of private dicks, OAPs on the run and precocious children.

Up against this determinedly whimsical competition, Atkinson's second story fares badly, and she never manages to establish the vexed relationship between Nora and Effie, ostensibly the more interesting tale, as a going concern. As for any comment on the nature of what we might call intertextuality, forget it. One suspects Atkinson herself is well aware that she's much better performing a funny turn than telling us anything serious; Emotionally Weird is firmly subtitled "A Comic Novel". Take out the typefaces and banish the overly ponderous outer reaches of this book and it's just a series of gags; but they're pretty good gags, and it's none the worse for that.

fields.headline: Foot notes
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Lezard  on  Roy Porter and GS Rousseau's history of medicine's most ludic disease - Gout: the Patrician Malady
fields.trailText: Nicholas Lezard on Roy Porter and GS Rousseau's history of medicine's most ludic disease - Gout: the Patrician Malady
fields.body:
Gout: the Patrician Malady,
by Roy Porter and GS Rousseau (Yale University Press, £13.95)

When my friend Adam Beck told me he was suffering from gout, I sniggered. As did all his other friends when he told them. For, although he is in just about all other respects a recognisably contemporary human being, the disease made us think of him in another light: that there was, forsooth, something of the 18th century about him, now we thought of it, and we imagined him with his bandaged foot resting on a stool as he looked forlornly at the decanter of port and table of rich viands he was now having to forego. Arf, arf!

"You bastards," he said, "it really hurts" - and yet we did not listen, or care; but here is a 17th-century description of the affliction from Thomas Sydenham, who wrote a treatise on it in 1683 and was the first to provide a full clinical and diagnostic picture of it in any language: "The pain resembles that of a dislocated bone . . . grow[ing] gradually more violent every hour . . . the parts affected . . . become so exquisitely painful as not to endure the weight of the clothes nor the shaking of the room from a person's walking briskly therein." After that, things worsen. Sydney Smith said it was "like walking on my eyeballs".

So this is the thing about gout: it is an intensely painful condition, something like having kidney stones in your feet, and yet people smirk when mentioned. We entertain dim memories of a hundred prints by Rowlandson or Gillray or Hogarth, the gouty foot as the stooge of clumsy fate, to be bumped and knocked and jostled into by the clumsy nemeses of the sufferer's own self-indulgence. No other disease is as ludic; not even the clap.

For it is also aristocratic: it may not be invariably connected to a rich diet, an easy lifestyle, but that is the way it is perceived. Gout is, in Porter's and Rousseau's typically striking formulation, "the condition par excellence signalling excess and guaranteeing isolation"; the 17th-century Lord Warwick's gout lasted for nearly 20 years, driving him so insane with irritability that he forbade anyone to touch or speak to him.

Which was not an entirely bad thing in itself. Not only was gout meant to protect one from more dangerous ailments; it engendered virtue in itself. According to one encomium, gout is chaste, as it does not like even to be touched; it is "majestic": "One lies in bed like a king on his throne, one goes to meet no one, one arises for no one, one accompanies no one, and one finally visits no one, even when one has been visited."

Yes, you may ask, but why is this Pick of the Week? Because this is a work of the most astonishingly focused scholarship and insight. Although not a conventional popular-science book, "this will be for many years the definitive treatment of the topic", said the distinguished Pat Rogers in the TLS, which is that publication's equivalent of the five-star review.

The research is both so dense and wide at the same time that it is awe-inspiring, humbling even. This isn't exactly a light read, to be soaking up sun-block and ice-cream splashes on beaches worldwide this summer (although that is a great fantasy). But you will learn so much, in passing, of literary and medical history (the history, you come to realise, of plausible theories) that you will emerge from it significantly enriched. How we come to terms with our suffering is one of the narratives of humanism: and this book, as one such tale, is supremely eminent.

fields.headline: I turned down Monroe
fields.standfirst: Richard Boston  hears Colin Clark's boastful tale in My Week With Marilyn
fields.trailText: Richard Boston hears Colin Clark's boastful tale in My Week With Marilyn
fields.body:
My Week With Marilyn
by Colin Clark
192pp, HarperCollins £14.99

Colin Clark's father was the art historian Kenneth Clark; his more famous brother was the politician, diarist and bounder, the late Alan Clark. In 1956, fresh from Eton, Oxford and national service, Clark worked on the set of The Prince and the Showgirl , starring Laurence Olivier and Marilyn Monroe. When his diary of that time was published a few years ago, nine days were missing; a gap now filled by My Week with Marilyn .

Not that this is a diary, even if it looks like one. Rather it is, he says at the outset, a fairy story, an interlude, a few days when a dream came true. You can see what he means when you find that he went to bed with Marilyn Monroe. They slept together. Quite soundly. And that was it. Marilyn did suggest they make love, but Clark said no. He was 26, had "a bit of a reputation for chasing the ladies"; he was in bed with Marilyn Monroe, she suggested they make love and he said no. Sounds incredible, doesn't it? Fairy stories often do.

At times this book is artless to the point of naivety; at others you get the feeling that the author is a very artful dodger indeed. Who does he think he's taking in - us or himself? What fairy tale are we being told? Part of the fun of this often ill-written book is in trying to unravel the facts from the numerous stories tangled together.

Laurence Olivier is the fairytale ogre, coming across as a foul-mouthed bully. When Marilyn first hears him say "fuck" she says "Gee, do they have that word in England too?" Being American she says "gee" a lot, as in "Gee, Colin, you really care, don't you? What are we going to do?" There are whole pages of this stuff, often hilariously (though unintentionally) funny.

Olivier is almost a good guy compared with the real villain, Arthur Miller. Clark dislikes him intensely, finding the brainy dramatist vain, smug and superior. He admits Miller has never actually been rude to him but, much worse, "he has ignored me completely". Most inexcus ably, he's married to Marilyn Monroe: in fact, they're honeymooning while Marilyn films. There are rows and Miller pushes off to Paris.

Marilyn's entourage consists of a number of people who, Clark does not fail to point out, are not only Americans but also Jews, as is Arthur Miller and Marilyn's drama coach, the fairy story's "witch". Colin is third assistant director on the film; he tells us this countless times, endlessly repeating that he is "very unimportant", "the lowest of the low". Such Uriah Heepish self- deprecation is usually a form of boasting, and this is no exception. Clark comes across as opinionated, patrician, arrogant and quite a bore. Ever so modestly, he lets it slip that, humble as he is, he drives a Lancia and can fly a fighter jet. Marilyn is frightfully impressed.

And then she kisses him, and the frog becomes a prince and rescues the damsel in distress by becoming masterful and giving her morale-boosting pep talks - at which point I realised we had gone from panto to Hollywood. As for Marilyn, "this heavenly creature", self-obsessed, tiresome beyond measure, she hasn't a clue who she is. The most extraordinary moment comes when she and Clark meet a crowd of fans outside the fairy castle (Windsor, actually). Marilyn says "Shall I be 'her'?" and promptly strikes a pose. "Her hip went out, her shoulders went back, her famous bosom was thrust forward." Marilyn Monroe, in public, acts the part of Marilyn Monroe on screen. No wonder she has an identity problem.

fields.headline: The wars of remembrance
fields.standfirst: From silent taboo to modern obsession:  Eva Figes  on two very different Holocaust histories of the past and present: Peter Novick's The Holocaust and Collective Memory and Louise London's Whitehall and the Jews 1933-1948
fields.trailText: From silent taboo to modern obsession: Eva Figes on two very different Holocaust histories of the past and present: Peter Novick's The Holocaust and Collective Memory and Louise London's Whitehall and the Jews 1933-1948
fields.body:
The Holocaust and Collective Memory: The American Experience
by Peter Novick
373pp, Bloomsbury, £18.99
Buy it from BOL

Whitehall and the Jews 1933-1948: British Immigration Policy and the Holocaust
by Louise London
313pp, Cambridge, £30
Buy it from BOL

For anyone old enough to remember the second world war, the fairly recent explosion of interest in the Holocaust is astonishing. For decades after 1945, the systematic murder of Europe's Jews was subjected to a silence which almost amounted to a taboo. It was an obscenity that could not be mentioned, should not be thought about. Survivors were told to forget, relatives of victims pretended their loved ones had died in obscure circumstances. How to explain the shift from virtual silence to obsession? Peter Novick sets out to give some answers, dismissing early on the Freudian theory of repression of trauma leading to problems at a later date. He is considering collective rather than personal memory; his subject is America, and more particularly American Jewry, who, he points out, have always seen themselves as far removed from the Europe their grandfathers left a century ago.

Although Novick is writing about the US, much that he has to say is relevant for this country too. We read the same books, see the same films, have begun to memorise the event and its victims in the same way. Primo Levi, first published in obscurity, is now famous. Novick puts much of this in historical perspective: he begins by reminding his readers that the truth of the death camps emerged at the end of a war which had killed between 50 and 60 million people, and that a few months after the camps were liberated came Hiroshima, which, in the years to follow, loomed much larger in the popular imagination, since it represented the future rather than the past. Nazi Germany was finished; a nuclear standoff was the new threat and the USSR the new ogre. In addition, the immediate post-war years were upbeat and optimistic. The Allies had won the war and the emphasis now was on looking to the future, on the task of reconstruction. And, I might add, no one had a greater need to rebuild their lives than Jews directly affected by the Holocaust. Nobody wanted to look back.

Two factors loom large in Novick's analysis of American Jewry's changing perception of the Holocaust. One is the existence of Israel and the continuing problems of the Middle East, and the other is a significant change in the US itself. In the immediate post-war years America had an integrationist ethic: everyone was first and foremost an American. In recent years people have begun to regard themselves primarily as Hispanics, blacks, Irish American or whatever. American Jews, for so long assimilationist and often totally secular, began to identify with their distant relatives across the seas.

With this new concern over ethnic roots has come a culture of victimhood which, in the US, goes along with a competition between ethnic groups, women and gays - what Novick calls the "Victimisation Olympics". American blacks in particular suffer from "Holocaust envy", which is distasteful and can surface in the most unlikely places. The dedication to Toni Morrison's Beloved , a novel about slavery, reads "60 million and more", a figure clearly picked out of the air but not at random. That such a cheap jibe should come from a writer of her quality is shocking.

Novick also points to a growing paranoia among American Jews, who in fact have never had it so good. They now regard themselves as the perpetual victims of history, and worry about what will happen to them "next time". This helps to bolster Israel's cause. In fact, American Jewry is the most successful socioeconomic group; this is very galling to American blacks, who have lost their martyr's crown to a group infinitely better off than themselves. Novick stops short of saying so, but it is among blacks that anti-Semitism is most virulent.

Post-war Americans believed in heroism; so did Israelis in the early years. The supposed passive victimhood of European Jews was regarded as shameful. Early Zionists had seen Hitler's persecution of the Jews as a great opportunity to promote their cause - a benevolent catastrophe - and even refused to divert funds earmarked for buying Arab land to the rescue of Jews. The mood changed markedly from the time of the Yom Kippur war, when Israel's difficulties grew and she often found herself isolated, criticised even by her cold-war ally. From now on the Holocaust was increasingly invoked to rally international (particularly American) support, and the "myth", as Novick calls it, grew that Israel had been created as a consequence of Allied guilt at failing to rescue Europe's Jews. In fact, he writes, no guilt was felt - rather a considerable sympathy for the survivors (known as "displaced persons") - and the creation of Israel was the cheapest way of dealing with them.

Invocation of the Holocaust by pro-Israelis could be blatant. In 1981 Hyman Bookbinder wrote to the German Ambassador to the US, saying that plans for the Washington Holocaust Museum were now being developed. "How Germany will be treated in that museum," he wrote, "will be affected by the decision you make pertaining to the sale of arms to Saudi Arabia."

Novick's analysis is lively, cool-headed and balanced, but I think that he does on occasion over- simplify. For instance, he points out that in the immediate post-war period the murder of Europe's Jews was seen as only part of Nazi barbarism; it took 20 years for the term "Holocaust" to come into common usage, and with it the notion that it was a unique event. British self-interest was predominant in the selection procedure, and nobody was admitted without a financial guarantor. Single women and girls were almost always admitted provided they agreed to do domestic work, since British women had rebelled against servitude and there was a shortage of housemaids. Thousands of highly educated women now found themselves learning to wield a duster.

The home office studiously avoided keeping statistics on Jewish immigration, thus avoiding the need to answer embarrassing questions in the House of Commons. Refugees were admitted on a temporary basis - officially "in transit" - even though it became increasingly obvious that there was nowhere for them to go. Yet as the persecution of the Jews grew more vicious there was genuine public indignation, and with it came demands for more help to be given.

Chamberlain, who himself accepted anti-Semitic stereotypes, was appalled by the barbarity of Kristallnacht, which undoubtedly helped to speed up immigration procedures. (No sense of public outrage figures in Novick's account.) Thousands of unaccompanied children were brought out of Germany. Money and offers of help began to pour in from non-Jewish sources, especially after Baldwin made a broadcast appeal. A story of British compromise and fudge, then, but also of decency and kindness.

fields.headline: Chop chop!
fields.standfirst: John Mullan  on losing your head in The Who's Who of British Beheadings by Geoffrey Abbott
fields.trailText: John Mullan on losing your head in The Who's Who of British Beheadings by Geoffrey Abbott
fields.body:
The Who's Who of British Beheadings
by Geoffrey Abbott
244pp, André Deutsch, £12.99

Keep your head. Stick your neck out. My head's on the block. You're for the chop . . . Our language retains a grimly jocular folk memory of a terrible and instructive spectacle: the beheading. Geoffrey Abbott, who has compiled 100 case histories of "selected victims", has his own attachment to this history, as a Beefeater at the Tower of London. The Tower was long associated with the business of execution: Tower Hill was the most frequent site of beheadings, and many a victim was interred within its walls.

Decapitation was the punishment preserved for the gravest or noblest offenders, and the last to die by beheading was Simon, Lord Lovat, one of the leaders of Bonnie Prince Charlie's Jacobite Rebellion, in 1747. As he waited for the axe he saw one of the spectators' stands collapse, killing many. "The more mischief, the better sport," he remarked. In 1817 the odious Prince Regent insisted that three radical republicans be publicly beheaded after death: death alone was inadequate for enemies of the state. One is reminded of Oliver Cromwell, his rotted corpse dug up after the Restoration to be hanged at Tyburn, then decapitated.

For centuries, Londoners were made aware every day of the fate of "traitors". The heads of those who had been hanged, drawn and quartered were put on show, most commonly on pikes on London Bridge. This grisly tradition began in 1305 with the head of William Wallace - "Braveheart" himself - which became one of the sights of London. Cromwell's head spent 40 years on a spike outside Westminster Hall, until blown off in the Great Storm of 1703.

As if this were not enough, the quarters of the torso were also variously displayed. The Earl of Carlisle had his head mounted on London Bridge, but his quarters dispatched around the country; the Gunpowder Plotters had theirs displayed over the city gates. In the cases of Catholic priests executed during the reigns of Elizabeth and James I, the ritual savagery inadvertently produced sacred relics. Some of the book's strangest stories are of the migrations of victims' heads: Sir Thomas More's found its way from a pole on London Bridge to St Dunstan's Church, Canterbury; the head of Archbishop Oliver Plunkett ended up in an ebony casket in an Irish convent.

As Abbott explains, the operation was messy and often botched. Before he was beheaded for leading a rebellion against James II, the Duke of Monmouth complained to infamous executioner Jack Ketch that the axe was not sharp enough. Despite Ketch's professional reassurance, the first blow inflicted only a flesh wound, causing the victim to raise his head with "a reproachful stare". According to eyewitnesses, it took four more strokes before "the botcherly dog" managed his job.

Beheading was usually a public spectacle. Thus the many eyewitness accounts of the extraordinary stoicism or spirit of victims, their pious or defiant last words, the ghastly protocols: victims offering the executioner forgiveness, and often giving the signal for the axe to fall. As intended, these events had a horrible life in popular recollection. Here comes a candle to light you to bed. Here comes a chopper to chop off your head.

fields.headline: Bought for a button
fields.standfirst: Katy Emck  on the 'savage' stolen away to England to meet the Queen in  Nick Hazlewood's Savage: The Life and Times of Jemmy Button
fields.trailText: Katy Emck on the 'savage' stolen away to England to meet the Queen in Nick Hazlewood's Savage: The Life and Times of Jemmy Button
fields.body:
Savage: The Life and Times of Jemmy Button
by Nick Hazlewood
359pp, Hodder , £12.99

In 1947 there were only 150 pure-blooded Indians left in Tierra del Fuego; when James Fitzroy first encountered them in the 1830s there were probably 9,000. The mournful tale of Europeans' influence on the Indians of this South American region comes through magnificently in Nick Hazlewood's Savage , which exposes the clumsiness of the English and the tragic innocence of the Fuegians in a credible, sympathetic style which also makes for extremely poignant reading.

Hazlewood's peg for his history is the life of one Jemmy Button, a boy who was abducted in 1830 and taken to England, where he was trained in Victorian values before being returned to his own country as a torchbearer for civilisation. This criminal action in the service of a "higher purpose" was typical of English attitudes to the Fuegians.

The bald facts of Jemmy Button's abduction are that Captain Fitzroy of HMS Beagle was bartering with some Yamana Indians when he invited the youngest of them on his boat, throwing a button to the other natives before taking the boy away - hence the name. The Captain was motivated by a weird mix of vengefulness and lofty purpose. His idea was to educate the Indians out of their irritating bad habits, and he didn't much care if the means of persuasion were unethical.

Eventually, Fitzroy returned with three amenable Fuegians to Walthamstow, where they were taught Victorian manners and the English language, treated kindly and given an audience with the King and Queen. Jemmy's famil iarity with the English seems to have stranded him between absurd pride and abject shame. He became dandyish and vain while in England, and, when he was rediscovered naked and dirty after his return to Tierra del Fuego, his embarrassment at his altered state was, wrote Charles Darwin, "quite painful to behold".

Darwin was a young naturalist when in 1831 he accompanied Fitzroy on his return to Tierra del Fuego on the Beagle , describing the native Indians as "the most abject and miserable creatures I anywhere beheld". This inability to recognise the Fuegians' dignity and intelligence foreordained the failure of Fitzroy's attempt to civilise them. When the Beagle returned to Tierra del Fuego, capacious but impractically chilly wigwams were built, clothes provided and European crops planted, so that Jemmy might by example lead his tribe away from nomadism. But the clothes and tools were nicked and redistributed amongst a people for whom property was meaningless, and Jemmy himself soon returned to Fuegian ways.

This was by no means the end of it, however; 22 years later, Jemmy was once again requisitioned, when the Patagonian Missionary Society persuaded him to bring Fuegians to a new missionary settlement in the Falklands. Although he greeted the incomers with eagerness and showed nostalgia at mementoes of England, Jemmy made it clear that he did not want to leave his home again.

One member of the Missionary Society, Captain Snow, realised in disgust that to take uncomprehending Fuegians hundreds of miles from home in order to inculcate them in a new way of life was immoral, and he returned to England to publish a stream of tirades against the Society. Snow's pet hate was George Packenham Despard, who browbeat and bribed Jemmy to go to Keppel Island along with four of his family, and was soon sending idyllic reports of the Buttons' table manners, cleanliness and general progress back home.

However, Jemmy became homesick and resentful, and was rightly anxious that the missionaries wanted to take his children away from him. When, after five months, the Buttons were returned home, the missionaries proceeded to woo a new set of Fuegians with food and presents so as to get them to the settlement on Keppel IsIand. Although nine natives eventually capitulated, it seems they had no clear idea of where they were being taken and why. For nine months on Keppel lsland the Fuegians soaped themselves, did their English lessons, sang hymns and worked at painting, building and basket-making.

But the optimistic reports sent home by the missionaries glossed over their own discontent with the Fuegians and the brewing dissatisfaction of the Fuegians themselves, who had not only been coerced into leaving their homeland but were subjected to the indignity of being repeatedly searched for stolen objects.

A week or so after the ship had returned to Tierra del Fuego, eight missionaries were massacred. It is unclear who the perpetrators were, but it is certain that Jemmy Button joined in the looting. Nevertheless, it was Jemmy and his family who helped the ship's one survivor, feeding him on shellfish for four months before rescue came.

When the story came out in England, little sympathy was shown towards the Patagonian Missionary Society. One Under-Secretary of State even went so far as to write, "If the Chief Missionary kidnapped natives, and then kept them to forced labour, it is not surprising that murder should follow." Hazlewood's dissection of the conflicting evidence about the massacre is both full and fair, and his conclusion convincing: the missionaries, with their routine use of bribery, "had contributed to an atmosphere of greed that contributed to their downfall".

fields.headline: Big in thrillers
fields.trailText: The TV hit The Sopranos showed how it no longer suffices to serve a straight mafia sandwich. There it was mafia'n'shrink; here mafia'n' haute cuisine. Anthony Bourdain's Bone in the Throat (Canongate, £10), predating The Sopranos but published here for the first time, mixes sous chefs with wise guys using the restaurant kitchen out of hours to turn men into meat, ho ho. Chefs and murder normally spells bad camp and a surfeit of culinary metaphors; then there's the further problem of the author being a professional New York chef himself, given that there are far too many chefs and comedians in this world, especially those who feel compelled to write. The TV hit The Sopranos showed how it no longer suffices to serve a straight mafia sandwich. There it was mafia'n'shrink; here mafia'n' haute cuisine. Anthony Bourdain's Bone in the Throat (Canongate, £10), predating The Sopranos but published here for the first time, mixes sous chefs with wise guys using the restaurant kitchen out of hours to turn men into meat, ho ho. Chefs and murder normally spells bad camp and a surfeit of culinary metaphors; then there's the further problem of the author being a professional New York chef himself, given that there are far too many chefs and comedians in this world, especially those who feel compelled to write. So, surprise: Bourdain plays his funny straight for the most part, knows his street moves and can do the wise-guy dialogue that has, in its way, grown as precise as Jane Austen. The joke here is that unshowy mob nephew Tommy, trying to take the honest path, is deeply embarrassed by dated wise-guy taste, a source of general snickers.

Buy Bone in the Throat from BOL

Daniel Woodrell - a name here since the release of the Civil War picture Ride With the Devil , based on his book - gets rentaquotes on Tomato Red (No Exit Press, £6.99) from literary stars Roddy Doyle and E Annie Proulx ("reaming the language with a dry corncob"). Woodrell can indeed write'n'ream, but therein could lie the problem: does the material require such abrasive treatment? His territory is by nature that of thousands of dashed-off country songs - backwoods American white trash, rich dreams and impoverished reality, jukebox sentiment, sexual voracity, booze and intolerance. A punk thief, passing through the Ozarks, falls in with a bizarre brother and sister with dangerous social aspirations and sexual proclivities. Woodrell is full of clever slants and literary smarts, but blessing his protagonist with such a uniquely calculated voice leaves you wondering why the boy is still paddling around the lowlifes and not involved in creative writing classes with E Annie Proulx.

Buy Tomato Red from BOL

Irresistible by Ethan Black (Headline, £17.99) lets loose in New York a female stalker/serial killer who compiles dossiers on her victims before performing radical post-coital surgery. Less radical is what follows. The investigating cop is a Jaguar-driving millionaire, which prompts the unanswered question: why bother turning up to work? Surface-clever, Irresistible becomes more like clunky Brian De Palma as increasing amounts of old chestnuts get dug up.

Buy Irresistible from BOL

Witch's Cradle by Gillian White (Bantam, £9.99) works on the cusp between tabloid and broadsheet, picking up on the latter's growing appetite for conspiracy and hysteria. What begins as a loose update of Cathy Come Home and a satire on media voracity (docusoap series lets smug middle-class crew exploit dirt-poor but charismatic tower-block couple for the entertainment of a watching nation) is then treated to a double twist. Targets are kept large and the characters diagrammatic, buttons get pushed, but the slide away from reality is done with confidence.

Buy Witch's Cradle from BOL

Deadline by Campbell Armstrong (Doubleday, £9.99) offers a wobbly update of the Hitchcock I Confess riff, with the sanctity of the confessional replaced by the shrink's couch. Shrink finds himself under pressure when an ex-client's records are of wider relevance, as she is about to become Attorney-General. Armstrong chucks in everything to varying effect, too often sub-Hitchcockian - wife kidnapping, orchestrated surveillance, split-second timing and mounting paranoia - but this does at least have the effect of leaving the shrink interestingly isolated.

Buy Deadline from BOL

For once comparisons are merited: mention of Jon A Jackson - published in the UK for the first time - in the same sentence as the late Charles Willeford is deserved. Willeford stills knocks most writers into a cocked hat (Leonard, Hiaasen, you name them), and Jackson shares Willeford's ability to trust the tale and relish its telling with the aid of some properly mordant humour, here involving a Detroit mafia turf war that draws in cops and the mob's own investigator. Where several of the above books make their moves ponderously, Jackson makes even his minor ones with grace, and Hit on the House (Canongate, £10) runs on an effortless but fiendish ingenuity.

Buy Hit on the House from BOL

The same can't be said for Bill Newton Dunn's The Devil Knew Not (Allendale, £5), a thriller written by a Euro MP about the European Parliament, which, though hopeless in terms of the usual virtues, does offer useful anecdotal material on the European process, should you want to know. But you probably don't.

fields.headline: In vino veritas
fields.standfirst: Helen Falconer  is intoxicated by a narrator with a lot of bottle in Joanne Harris' Blackberry Wine
fields.trailText: Helen Falconer is intoxicated by a narrator with a lot of bottle in Joanne Harris' Blackberry Wine
fields.body:
Blackberry Wine
by Joanne Harris
419pp, Doubleday, £12.99

Being more of an alcohol buff than a confectionery lover, I was drawn to Blackberry Wine with much more instinctive enthusiasm than to its predecessor, the international bestseller Chocolat (shortlisted for the 1999 Whitbread Novel of the Year award).

So, after having recovered from the unexpected shock of being addressed directly by a bottle of wine (not the cheeky home-made plonk of the title, which obviously couldn't be trusted to tell a straight tale, but a rather more dignified if somewhat garrulous 1962 Fleurie), I slurped down Joanne Harris's new novel with easy enjoyment.

Harris draws on her French and Yorkshire backgrounds, setting her tale partly in the north of England and partly in the archetypal village of Lansquenet, already familiar to Chocolat enthusiasts. Her chosen literary territory is again that of magical realism. You might think this would sit oddly in down-to-earth Yorkshire and provincial France - and it is a genre that can irritate - yet Harris accomplishes it remarkably smoothly, without ever getting cute or unlikely, even when indulging in astral travel and chatty vintages. Belief is most pleasurably suspended, much as after a few glasses of decent hock.

Jay Mackintosh, owner of the articulate Fleurie that narrates the tale, was once a saddened, disillusioned child; struck down by boarding school and his parents' divorce, but then happily restored by the magic of retired miner Joe Cox. The old man teaches him the secrets of gardens and growth, of spells and potions, and, most importantly, of powerful home-made wines which "unleash the tongue" and "speak of great things". When Joe moves on without leaving a forwarding address, the angry, deserted teenage Jay rejects all things magical. Yet in later life, now a fatally blocked author, he discovers a crate of Joe's special wines and finds his way to a new home in France, where Joe's astral form guides him to self-discovery (and a new, improved love interest).

Oddly enough, the strands of this novel that jar the reader into disbelief are not the magical-realist ones but some of the supposedly true-to-life characters, whose stories raised my eyebrows in mean-minded suspicion, while only a few pages previously I'd downed the herbal potion for invisibility without a murmur of protest.

Witchcraft aside, Harris is at her best when detailing the sensual pleasures of taste and smell. As chocoholics stand advised to stock up on some of their favourite bars before biting into Chocolat , so boozers everywhere should get a couple of bottles in before opening Blackberry Wine . It even made me nostalgic for those disgusting sugary home-made vintages that country-dwelling folk love to brain you with at every opportunity.
