fields.headline: To thrill - a mockingbird
fields.standfirst: James Wood  hails the tart comic vision and sharp style of Anne Enright, who once again proves with her new book, What Are You Like?, that she is a highly original writer
fields.trailText: James Wood hails the tart comic vision and sharp style of Anne Enright, who once again proves with her new book, What Are You Like?, that she is a highly original writer
fields.body:
What Are You Like? by Anne Enright
259pp, Cape, £10

Since it is by definition not imitative of anyone else, an original style has only itself to imitate; it is its own mockingbird. And the risk genuinely original writing runs is that a distinctive style can come to seem, in its very individuality, unnaturally sealed off from the ordinary, rather unoriginal world we inhabit.

Anne Enright is a very original writer - a spry surrealist who challenges the world with extraordinary, lancing sentences. She is indeed a kind of mockingbird: she and her characters see life with a tart comedy which is briskly ascetic, sourly lucid and never quite accountable. It is partly that Enright uses words you do not expect her to use; more than this, she speeds up the connections between thoughts (one of Bergson's definitions of the comic) and between the sensations her unhappy characters experience.

Thus the people in her fiction are always simultaneously quicker and more confused than those in more ordinary novels: they are cognitive zealots. For instance, one of the heroines of her new novel, Maria , visits a family farm as an unhappy adolescent. She hates her time there and, to make things worse, is made to act as waitress to her various adult cousins. Enright offers these compact sentences: "She picked up the jug. She poured, and the milk smelt of everything." A second sentence perfect in its simplicity and its complexity, exactly catching the limitlessness of a child's rage.

The danger is that Enright's curious characters will seem not only zealots but neurasthenic clowns, rushing between various mental junctions. Yet Enright's brittle, sometimes artificial style finds its proper counterpart in the two strange and brittle heroines at the heart of her fine novel. Maria and Rose are twins, separated at birth when their mother died in the hospital. Maria stayed with her father in Dublin, and Rose was adopted by an English couple in Surrey. Until late in the novel neither is sure of the other's existence, feeling it only as a dumb severance. Both are deeply unhappy in similar ways, and the novel's narration bounces between parallel accounts of their separate unhappinesses. We see Maria's childhood in Ireland and glimpse the frozen misery of her father's marriage to his second wife (wonderfully summarised as a woman with "a big anxious head and smug little feet"). At 20, Maria goes to New York, and some of the novel's most affecting writing evokes that city surreally, as a kind of Circumlocution Office of lost souls - of people suing or arbitrarily having sex with each other. Maria works as a cleaning lady for wealthy Upper West Siders; she feels that "she looks like a perfect stranger, like a girl you would pass on the street".

Meanwhile Rose, back in England, pities and despises her unobservant, bien-pensant parents, who are forever taking in abandoned children and stray cats. Like Maria she feels unmoored, alien to herself, and like Maria she specialises in self-destruction. Her relationships with men are lumpy and doomed; though a talented violinist, she summarily abandons the instrument because she feels she is not good enough. The novel gradually drives these two spiky, miserable mates together, but its quality lies not in their eventual recognition of and reconciliation with each other, but rather in the portrait it offers of two people filled with lack. Each is gnawed at by absence and each, though peculiar in her sadness, has a youthful, bitter confusion that is likely to speak universally to any reader whose growing up was jagged.

Enright is so intelligent and so controlled that she doubtless knows already the risks her style poses. At times her choice of adjectives - particularly when in unexpected combinations - can seem over-deliberate, almost a kind of knowingness. When she describes Maria's farming cousins at table, "their movements obliged and tragic", one feels that she has got ahead of her characters - that she is condescending to them a little, sealing them off from the reader in fancy words.

The bold confidence of Enright's style, and its tendency to break into tight, perfect paragraphs, can occasionally waver on the border of flippancy. I don't believe her, for instance, when she tells me that Maria's stepmother married her husband because he sleeps so soundly at night: "It was for this she married him, for his ability to sleep." At such moments, Enright wants her characters to seem confident in their own sadness - to be decisive fatalists - yet it seems to be only the author being confident on behalf of her characters.

But such fractures are very rare. Much more common - indeed, overwhelmingly, redeemingly common - are moments and whole passages when Enright captures something subterranean with a strange flick of her marvellous insight. Maria's unconfident father, for example, kisses a woman at work, and is unsure: "He had never kissed the mouth of a woman who smoked . . . it gave him the uncomfortable feeling that he might be kissing a man." Or there's Maria's stepmother, trying on dresses in a shop and disliking "a gathered floral thing that made her look like an alcoholic". Or this perfect comic devastation of the pretensions of Manhattan sandwiches: "Genoa salami, mortadella, Black Forest ham, provolone, balsamic vinegar and olive oil. It looked like a dinner party slapped on a slice of bread." Maria has to turn to a different, calmer sandwich: "It was not a sandwich you had to dress up for."

Elsewhere, a drunk is seen, "his face working in slow motion, as though every emotion was a puzzle to him, and the solution was a surprise . . ." And, most beautifully: "The Shannon has burst its banks and spread like a mirror around Athlone. The fields are full of sky, pierced with grass like frozen, upside-down rain. She sees a swan sailing into the dark mouth of a shed, and the sun comes out at Ballinasloe."

But another distinctive stylist, Virginia Woolf, argued that writers should be praised not for sentences but for chapters - for the accumulation of their lustres. Anne Enright practises a kind of emotional cubism, using her characters to piece together the world in strange combinations with perfect, sharp little sentences. As a way of constructing a novel, rather than short stories (Jane Bowles and Flannery O' Connor come to mind), it is a risky procedure. But in the end this novel is more than a style; it is a style that turns itself into a world, a world of sad comedy, securely if gradually located in the distressed hearts of Enright's moving heroines, twins whose anxious solitude the reader comes to know and share.

fields.headline: All animals are equal
fields.trailText: • We at the Guardian don't like to let a day pass without some comment on the immensely exciting mayoral race, even in the absence of Matthew Norman. This time, Austin Mitchell, MP, raconteur and panel-game veteran, has been musing on the parallels between Animal Farm and the recent difficulties. "We all know who Napoleon is," he comments, "but who's the Ken Livingstone character?" Suggestions on a postcard, please, but no prizes for identifying Squealer, heard here reassuring the unruly animals: "No one believes more firmly than Comrade Napoleon that all animals are equal. He would be only too happy to let you make your decisions for yourself. But sometimes you might make the wrong decisions, comrades, and then where should we be?"
fields.body:
 We at the Guardian don't like to let a day pass without some comment on the immensely exciting mayoral race, even in the absence of Matthew Norman. This time, Austin Mitchell, MP, raconteur and panel-game veteran, has been musing on the parallels between Animal Farm and the recent difficulties. "We all know who Napoleon is," he comments, "but who's the Ken Livingstone character?" Suggestions on a postcard, please, but no prizes for identifying Squealer, heard here reassuring the unruly animals: "No one believes more firmly than Comrade Napoleon that all animals are equal. He would be only too happy to let you make your decisions for yourself. But sometimes you might make the wrong decisions, comrades, and then where should we be?"

 Women are an equivocal bunch, according to an unusual piece of reader-response criticism undertaken by Germaine Greer. She - or, ahem, someone - asked 500 women for their thoughts on her book The Whole Woman. Not as in "Did you like it?" or "Is there an unbroken thread of intellectual inquiry running through Greer's oeuvre?"; no, questions were far more specific than that. Respondents were invited to agree and disagree, in various degrees of intensity, with statements from"Men don't shop, even for their own underpants" to "Men don't care one way or the other about what becomes of their sperm". Lo and behold, 8.6% strongly agreed with the shopping proposition, while 6.8% strongly disagreed, with a pretty even split on whether "women are driven through the health system like sheep through a dip". Whether or not this generous exercise in audience participation will signal a rush on the paperback of TWW - oddly enough, out this week - the Loafer could neither strongly predict nor strongly doubt.

 WG Sebald is off to Penguin for his next three books, courtesy of the Wylie Agency, whose bid for world domination knows no bounds. One theory circulating around cowed editors is that Wylie's band model themselves on the agents from The Matrix. You know, the ones that dress in black, change shape and can dodge bullets. Andrew Wylie himself, who's a little tired of the sobriquet The Jackal, might prefer this more up-to-date homage.

 And now a despatch from Washington, where our man in Barnes & Noble reports that a new novel by Eric Tarloff is fast heading for cult status. Face Time is, on the surface, just your run-of-the-mill sex-in-the-White-House story, but includes a seedy and cynical Guardian correspondent. Eager scandalmongers have it that the character is based on Christopher Hitchens rather than our own Martin Kettle, but it would be impolitic, not to say a little incestuous, to comment further.

Respondents were invited to agree and disagree, in various degrees of intensity, with statements from"Men don't shop, even for their own underpants" to "Men don't care one way or the other about what becomes of their sperm". Lo and behold, 8.6% strongly agreed with the shopping proposition, while 6.8% strongly disagreed, with a pretty even split on whether "women are driven through the health system like sheep through a dip". Whether or not this generous exercise in audience participation will signal a rush on the paperback of TWW - oddly enough, out this week - the Loafer could neither strongly predict nor strongly doubt.  WG Sebald is off to Penguin for his next three books, courtesy of the Wylie Agency, whose bid for world domination knows no bounds. One theory circulating around cowed editors is that Wylie's band model themselves on the agents from The Matrix. You know, the ones that dress in black, change shape and can dodge bullets. Andrew Wylie himself, who's a little tired of the sobriquet The Jackal, might prefer this more up-to-date homage.  And now a despatch from Washington, where our man in Barnes & Noble reports that a new novel by Eric Tarloff is fast heading for cult status. Face Time is, on the surface, just your run-of-the-mill sex-in-the-White-House story, but includes a seedy and cynical Guardian correspondent. Eager scandalmongers have it that the character is based on Christopher Hitchens rather than our own Martin Kettle, but it would be impolitic, not to say a little incestuous, to comment further.

fields.headline: Poetry
fields.trailText: Poets are a civilised lot, so they tell us, which is remarkable considering how little hard cash they garner from their efforts. We would expect Seamus Heaney, riding high in hard covers at the top of the poetry league table, to be quite comfortable - his Whitbread-winning version of Beowulf is the twelfth best-selling title on amazon.co.uk. But go further down the charts and the poets begin to look a little less prosperous, with TS Eliot prizewinner Hugo Williams, for example, a frequent contributor to the TLS on the subject of the precariousness of freelance life.

fields.headline: Changes of mind
fields.standfirst: Andrew Rissik  on Philip Terry's Ovid Metamorphosed and our eternal fascination with Ovid's painful hedonism
fields.trailText: Andrew Rissik on Philip Terry's Ovid Metamorphosed and our eternal fascination with Ovid's painful hedonism
fields.body:
Ovid Metamorphosed
ed. Philip Terry
250pp, Chatto & Windus, £14.99

Ovid was perhaps the greatest of the Roman poets, and his influence on Western literature is unique. While the marks left by other ostensibly more monumental figures from Roman antiquity (Lucretius, Virgil, Horace) have faded into a kind of quiet scholar's obscurity, Ovid's work -which, to his contemporaries, was sexy, funny, graceful and true, but not especially "serious" - continues to demonstrate a remarkable imaginative staying power. Now the facts of Ovid's life and the themes of his work are glanced at, toyed with, reinterpreted and sometimes explicitly described in a new collection of essays and short stories edited by Philip Terry, Ovid Metamorphosed . What is the cause of this persistent fascination?

Ovid was born shortly after Julius Caesar's assassination, and died before Christ grew to manhood. He was too young fully to appreciate the peace and stability which the emperor Augustus wrested from the war-torn ruins of the old Republic. He made his name not with epic flattery of the vanities of the regime, like Virgil, or graceful, moralising essays, like Horace, but with two notorious poems devoted to seduction and adultery, the Amores and the Ars Amatoria , which preached that sex was the only thing really worth doing and poked malicious fun at the plain-living Roman values of military achievement and chastity within marriage promoted by the emperor.

Yet though he lived as a sensualist, he was centred as a poet by his knowledge of what it is like to suffer - to be helplessly, ferociously in the grip of some frustrated or denied emotional need. In the Heroides , a book of imaginary letters from famous heroines to their lovers, he took the monologue out of classical drama and made it lyrical and contemporary, creating a form - the unhappy woman alone, analysing her feelings - which has conditioned literature and art ever since.

In his greatest work, the Metamorphoses , he writes of shape- changing and transformation; but the stories he tells are interesting less for their eye-catching fairytale magic - the necromantic element rendered so well by Hughes - than for Ovid's hypnotic understanding of the vulnerability of human emotions. His spirit was vivacious, sceptical, hedonistic, but shot through with pain. He lived when the old certainties were dying but a new era of faith had not yet taken hold, and the stoic darkness of a godless world - one without pity or consolation - always lay threateningly close.

Ovid had no literal belief in gods, but he retained a deep respect for the powers which they embodied - for the anarchy and cruelty of lust, the mania of love and the fateful violence which could strike down the arrogant and overweening. Although his enemies disparaged him as a frivolous boudoir cynic, he treated the fickleness of male desire and the wounded extremes of misplaced female trust and hope with a depth of sympathy that has remained "modern" for 2,000 years. It was a passion with him - as Chaucer, Dante, Shakespeare and Goethe knew - to get inside the skin, to enter the soul of the victim.

He became one himself in the end, sent to live in conditions of near-Siberian harshness in what is now Romania after becoming involved in some scandal involving the Emperor's promiscuous grand-daughter, Julia. The reversal of fortune broke him completely. Like Oscar Wilde centuries later, he was pathetically out of his depth in a world where sophistication meant nothing; and the brutality of exile left him howling with self-pity.

Appropriately, the stories in Ovid Metamorphosed jangle with discordance. Sometimes they echo closely the sinuous, erotic violence in Ovid's own writing - MJ Fitzgerald gives us a retelling of the story of Tereus and Philomel in hard, brutal prose which is part translation, part something more immediate - or venture along the inviting pathways of biographical speculation. Paul West's sane and funny "Nightfall on the Romanian Coast" sees Ovid looking back, in contemporary language and from the standpoint of our present age, on a life that went wrong for reasons that Meyerhold or Shostakovich might have understood. "I was a snob," says West's Ovid. "I refused to come up with tractor poems, paeans to hydroelectric stations, to the rustic rabble and the proles of Rome."

The list of contributors is impressive - Marina Warner, Margaret Atwood, Michele Roberts among them - and few of the stories lack their own particular narrative skills or effects of atmosphere. Yet there's a sense of strain, clutter, ingenuity prevailing over creativity, in much of the writing. The world created here is coldly nightmarish rather than dreamlike, and to a large extent - many of the contributors are women - in revolt against or embarrassed by male values.

It is also heavy with psycho- analytical hindsight. Nicole Ward Jouve reconstructs Ovid's Narcissus as a self-regarding academic-cum-artist, interested only in seeing herself reflected in the praise of her acolytes; Joyce Carol Oates turns Actaeon, who was torn apart by hounds, into a drunken patriarchal brute from Nova Scotia who humiliates his wife in public and is then gleefully dismembered by his children; Philip Terry depicts a magazine attracting protest after it starts to print politically incorrect sex tips filched from the Ars Amatoria in its agony column.

What these too-metaphorical reinterpretations cannot convey is the wonderful transfiguring romanticism of Ovid's own tale-spinning - the sheer literal beauty of his images. Perhaps this is why the two most impressive pieces in the book - AS Byatt's "Arachne" and "Heart's Wing" by Gabriel Josipovici - are not stories but essays, distinguished pieces of imaginative criticism which successfully express the vital resonance at the heart of Ovid's masterpiece, the idea that human feelings can be so strong, so intense, that the laws of nature bend beneath them.

Josipovici's "Heart's Wing" is a meditation upon Ovid's tale of Alcyone, who was so wracked with grief at the death of her husband in a shipwreck that the gods turned them both into kingfishers. It is also an elegy to his mother, the translator Sacha Rabinovitch, and an attempt to understand why the story had meant so much to her. Simply and eloquently, he traces this back to lived experience: "Her husband's abandonment of her, pregnant and with a two-month-old child . . . and the subsequent death of her second child . . . must have convinced her at some inarticulate level that nothing she loved could be held for long." He surmises that, in Ovid's tale, "she found her pain renewed and at the same time made bearable".

Freud thought that the process of mourning had not been com pleted until whatever had been lost was restored to life within the heart or the ego of the mourner. This weaved-up mystery lies at the heart of the Metamorphoses and helps to explain its extraordinary continuing appeal. Unlike Ted Hughes, I don't believe Ovid's tales are about the supernatural, or at least not in any sense that matters. The transformations are metaphors - beautiful, resonant, pain-resolving - like the stage miracle of Hermione's resurrection at the end of Shakespeare's Winter's Tale , or the last-minute off-stage divine redemption of Gretchen in Goethe's Faust .

There is also a voice in Ovid's work that prose cannot capture, but which was caught, clearly and gracefully, by the poet Jamie McKendrick in a passage from the anthology After Ovid . It's a contemporary voice, but also very ancient, the voice not only of Ovid's Polyphemus but of Shakespeare's Caliban and of song itself, eternally yearning, eternally unfulfilled:

"I'd dig rare gems out of the mountainside

With strange faults of fire like constellations

And fashion a necklace of dragonflies

And teach two tame owls to sing for you . . ."

Ovid's many metamorphoses

Tales From Ovid, by Ted Hughes (Faber, £8.99)

Hughes's dark, incandescent and eminently page-turnable Tales From Ovid was one of the publishing successes of 1997.

After Ovid, ed. Michael Hoffman (Faber, £8.99)

Hughes's interest grew from this earlier, more experimental volume, in which many different poets - the best-known being Hughes and Heaney - tried their hands at individual sections of the Metamorphoses .

An Imaginary Life, by David Malouf (Vintage, £6.99)

A fable of spiritual rebirth, constructed from the circumstances of Ovid's banishment to the shores of the Black Sea, and written with severity and grace.

Metamorphoses, ed. EJ Kenney (Oxford, £7.99)

Modern, unacademic translation.

fields.headline: Floating points
fields.standfirst: Ros Taylor dips into the best sites on boating
fields.trailText: Ros Taylor dips into the best sites on boating
fields.body:
Messing about in boats isn't just an occasional holiday extra. When your boat doubles as self-catering accommodation, you can be virtually self-sufficient and never grow tired of staying in one place.

Canal Junction
If travelling at only four miles an hour, taking turns to man the tiller, regularly negotiating locks and sleeping in cabins sounds like fun, then head for Canal Junction which offers some basic narrowboat history, suggested cruises and a directory of boat-hire companies.

British Waterways
There are more than 2,000 miles of canal in England and Wales, and the organisation responsible for maintaining it is British Waterways, who run a very useful site. Visitors can plan their route with the interactive maps and research the attractions on the way - which is very important when you don't have a car and must plan stops carefully.

Blakes cruisers
Blakes cruisers plies the Thames, Lake Windermere and the Norfolk Broads as well as canal routes. These cruisers can sleep up to 12 people and tend to offer more privacy than barges.

According to Blakes, they are also easy to sail; yachts require slightly more practice. If enough people share a boat and you are able to economise by self-catering, this can also be a very cheap holiday. Hire, insurance and fuel can cost less than £100 per person at certain times of the year.

Norfolk Broads
The Norfolk Broads, incidentally, has its own website, with a special section on boating.

Royal Yachting Association
If you want to learn how to sail - which opens up any number of holidays, from enjoying the coast of St Tropez to competitive racing - the Royal Yachting Association has a good list of training contacts. Look here, too, if you are interested in windsurfing or powerboat racing.

British Canoe Union
Paddling your own canoe, or kayaking, is covered by the British Canoe Union. However, you often need a licence to use British rivers and canals.

GORP
If kayaking abroad sounds more exciting, try the Great Outdoor Recreation Pages, where the sport is called "paddling". It favours North American destinations, but with the continuing fall in airfares to the States and the high safety standards there - not to mention some breathtaking rivers - you might want to leave Britain behind.

webTitle: Relief is in sight for mis-selling victims

fields.headline: Relief is in sight for mis-selling victims
fields.standfirst: The millions of people facing endowment mortgage shortfalls are to get FSA protection against being hurt again as they receive letters giving a fair and unbiased list of their options. Tony Levene reports
fields.trailText: The millions of people facing endowment mortgage shortfalls are to get FSA protection against being hurt again as they receive letters giving a fair and unbiased list of their options.
fields.body:
Endowment mortgage shortfall victims will get protection against losing out a second time. Consumer money watchdog the Financial Services Authority has ordered life insurance companies to give homebuyers whose endowments are no longer on track to repay their loans a fair and unbiased list of options in letters to be sent to five million homebuyers from early next month.

The letters result from an FSA decision that insurers should come clean on endowment progress by re-quoting likely results using a 6% annual growth rate. This is designed to help prevent victims being sold expensive top-up plans which benefit sellers more than buyers.

Companies will also be banned from using the endowment "re-projection letters" for sending out mail shots or using them for "selling activity." The personal letters will calculate how much of the mortgage will be paid off when the policy matures assuming a 6 % annual growth rate - half the annual increase used in many original quotations before the early 90s.

But the new letters will ban life companies from suggesting how much extra a month would be needed to put the plan back on track. Until now, many life offices had tried to earn more from shortfall customers by encouraging them to top up endowments with extra payments. They presented this as the first choice, relegating other possibilities to a "fact sheet."

A Legal & General mortgage review letter sent out three months ago mentioned a leaflet Your Options Explained, but then detailed the one option guaranteed to bring in more cash to the life company - extra premiums.

The FSA feels that stressing additional premiums over other choices such as adjusting the mortgage or saving through an Isa gives it a "default option" status.

Legal & General does not charge up-front fees on extra payments which then attract a low 0.2% annual charge. But with some companies, such as Allied Dunbar, opting for a policy top-up produces a further commission-earning opportunity, so less of the extra premiums go into making good the shortfall.

Some five million letters will be sent out with a "traffic lights" range of possibilities, although these will not be printed in different colours. Around two million will receive a "green" letter - the draft letter is addressed to Mr and Mrs Grass. The "Grasses" are told: "Based on your plan update, we are pleased to confirm that we believe your plan is currently projected to repay the target amount when it matures. It is unlikely that you need to take any action now."

Life is green for the Grasses. They should be able repay their loan and earn a tax-free bonus at 6, although there will be a shortfall if the 4% projection holds true. But life is not so good for the Ashers and the Reeds, fictional recipients of "amber" and "red" missives respectively.

The Ashers will be told the insurer thinks "it is possible that your plan may not pay out enough." They have a potential shortfall at the 6% rate but if that were to prove pessimistic, they could end up with a small surplus if their endowment hits 8% growth a year - the top rate allowed under present rules.

The Ashers are given five options:

 Increase monthly savings

 Extend the mortgage

 Repay part of the loan with a lump sum from elsewhere

 Change part of the loan from an endowment to a repayment mortgage

 Wait and see - the "do-nothing" option for those who hope investment returns will increase.

But the "do-nothing" choice is not offered to the Reeds, whose household is set to suffer real misery.

Here the red letter warns: "There is now a high risk that your plan may not pay out enough." The Reeds are told that even if the investment grew at 8%, the top rate allowed for projections, they would still face a shortfall.

The Reeds may have forgotten how optimistic salespeople used rates well in excess of 8% for projections used when the plan was sold. They will not be reminded.

As part of the bargaining the original assumed growth rate, which was to have been part of the policy information, has been deleted. But the FSA has demanded plain English and a large typeface.The Reeds could claim they had been mis-sold the policy; that the original rate shown was wildly optimistic or that they were not warned it could go down.

Insurers have four weeks to reply to a complaint. They can reject it with reasons or accept it and offer redress or ask for an extension of a further four weeks. If there is no progress after eight weeks, the policyholder can complain to the ombudsman or give the company more time.

But if the Reeds bought their policy before April 29, 1988 - the date the Financial Services Act came into force - they could be out of luck with a mis-selling claim. The FSA says that companies have no obligation to look at policies bought before that date, although some have voluntarily agreed to do so.

Companies will also be banned from using the endowment "re-projection letters" for sending out mail shots or using them for "selling activity." The personal letters will calculate how much of the mortgage will be paid off when the policy matures assuming a 6 % annual growth rate - half the annual increase used in many original quotations before the early 90s. But the new letters will ban life companies from suggesting how much extra a month would be needed to put the plan back on track. Until now, many life offices had tried to earn more from shortfall customers by encouraging them to top up endowments with extra payments. They presented this as the first choice, relegating other possibilities to a "fact sheet." A Legal & General mortgage review letter sent out three months ago mentioned a leaflet Your Options Explained, but then detailed the one option guaranteed to bring in more cash to the life company - extra premiums. The FSA feels that stressing additional premiums over other choices such as adjusting the mortgage or saving through an Isa gives it a "default option" status. Legal & General does not charge up-front fees on extra payments which then attract a low 0.2% annual charge. But with some companies, such as Allied Dunbar, opting for a policy top-up produces a further commission-earning opportunity, so less of the extra premiums go into making good the shortfall. Some five million letters will be sent out with a "traffic lights" range of possibilities, although these will not be printed in different colours. Around two million will receive a "green" letter - the draft letter is addressed to Mr and Mrs Grass. The "Grasses" are told: "Based on your plan update, we are pleased to confirm that we believe your plan is currently projected to repay the target amount when it matures. It is unlikely that you need to take any action now." Life is green for the Grasses. They should be able repay their loan and earn a tax-free bonus at 6, although there will be a shortfall if the 4% projection holds true. But life is not so good for the Ashers and the Reeds, fictional recipients of "amber" and "red" missives respectively. The Ashers will be told the insurer thinks "it is possible that your plan may not pay out enough." They have a potential shortfall at the 6% rate but if that were to prove pessimistic, they could end up with a small surplus if their endowment hits 8% growth a year - the top rate allowed under present rules. The Ashers are given five options:  Increase monthly savings  Extend the mortgage  Repay part of the loan with a lump sum from elsewhere  Change part of the loan from an endowment to a repayment mortgage  Wait and see - the "do-nothing" option for those who hope investment returns will increase. But the "do-nothing" choice is not offered to the Reeds, whose household is set to suffer real misery. Here the red letter warns: "There is now a high risk that your plan may not pay out enough." The Reeds are told that even if the investment grew at 8%, the top rate allowed for projections, they would still face a shortfall. The Reeds may have forgotten how optimistic salespeople used rates well in excess of 8% for projections used when the plan was sold. They will not be reminded. As part of the bargaining the original assumed growth rate, which was to have been part of the policy information, has been deleted. But the FSA has demanded plain English and a large typeface.The Reeds could claim they had been mis-sold the policy; that the original rate shown was wildly optimistic or that they were not warned it could go down. Insurers have four weeks to reply to a complaint. They can reject it with reasons or accept it and offer redress or ask for an extension of a further four weeks. If there is no progress after eight weeks, the policyholder can complain to the ombudsman or give the company more time. But if the Reeds bought their policy before April 29, 1988 - the date the Financial Services Act came into force - they could be out of luck with a mis-selling claim. The FSA says that companies have no obligation to look at policies bought before that date, although some have voluntarily agreed to do so.

fields.headline: Ayling and 6,000 jobs axed
fields.standfirst: British Airways
fields.trailText: More than 6,000 jobs will be axed and a new raft of financial savings at British Airways are expected to be announced next week in the wake of the sudden departure of Bob Ayling, its beleaguered chief executive, yesterday.
fields.body:
More than 6,000 jobs will be axed and a new raft of financial savings at British Airways are expected to be announced next week in the wake of the sudden departure of Bob Ayling, its beleaguered chief executive, yesterday.

The crucial decision to sack the £500,000-a-year boss, who could receive a final payoff of at least £2m, was made earlier this week. But it was kept back until yesterday to allow Mr Ayling, a personal friend of the prime minister, the satisfaction of opening the London Eye, one of his few success stories since becoming chief executive four years ago.

Next year's budget, approved yesterday by the BA board, will be revealed to union officials over the next few days. It calls for staff cuts and efficiencies to offset BA's expected losses of up to £200m, and Lord Marshall, BA's chairman, felt that it was finally time for Mr Ayling, 54, to go.

The company said yesterday that Mr Ayling's final package was still being negotiated. He is on a rolling two-year contract, renewable until he is 60.

Mr Ayling's demise had been widely predicted for the past two years, but it was felt that he would hold on until the summer. But board members, led by BA's deputy chairman, Sir Michael Angus, finally prevailed over Lord Marshall, who regarded Mr Ayling as his prodigy.

Lord Marshall will take over as caretaker chief executive until a successor is found. BA said he would stay in post "for as long as it takes", indicating that there is nobody immediately earmarked for the job.

Mr Ayling, said to be out of the country yesterday, said job demands had taken a toll on his home life and it was time "for a new executive to take up the challenge".

Mr Ayling, who will stay on as chairman of the dome organisers, the New Millennium Experience Company, said he would have a rest. He has experienced a mounting barrage of criticism since the collapse of BA's share price last summer.

He said the company had faced unprecedented pressures from its competitors during his stewardship, but the past four years had been "tough and stimulating" and he was proud of his achievements.

BA insiders said his final mistake last week was to create the misleading impression that the company's "flat beds project" in business class was generally available. But it is not being introduced on Heathrow to New York flights until the summer, and then throughout the rest of the airline over the next three years.

Among possible successors being mentioned last night, the person with the best credentials is James Strong, chief executive of Qantas, the Australian carrier, in which BA has a 25% share. Qantas carries all BA's traffic into Australia and New Zealand after it reaches Singapore.

Possible insiders are Barbara Cassani, who heads BA's low- cost carrier Go, although it is still not in profit, and Carl Michel, BA's commercial director, brought in recently by Mr Ayling after running the German subidiary of BA.

Tony Blair refused to comment on Mr Ayling's departure, saying that it was a commercial decision for the company. But he praised Mr Ayling for a "fantastic job" on the millennium celebrations and the dome, and might offer him a job with a business background.

Mr Ayling's bitter business rival, Sir Richard Branson, chairman of Virgin Atlantic, who clashed with BA over its "dirty tricks" campaign, wished him "the best of luck".

fields.headline: Point of departure
fields.standfirst:
Véronique Gens/ Roger Vignoles
Wigmore Hall, London
***
fields.trailText: A concert consisting entirely of French song in the mezzo soprano range was something of a departure from the norm for Véronique Gens, a singer who has made her name as an interpreter of Baroque music and a Mozart soprano. The fiery nobility she brings to Mozart's Fiordiligi was left at home during this concert, in favour of a more relaxed delivery. Her programme was attractive but not very varied, and at times one longed for some good old soprano neurosis to break through all the languid Gallic sensuality.
fields.body:
A concert consisting entirely of French song in the mezzo soprano range was something of a departure from the norm for Véronique Gens, a singer who has made her name as an interpreter of Baroque music and a Mozart soprano. The fiery nobility she brings to Mozart's Fiordiligi was left at home during this concert, in favour of a more relaxed delivery. Her programme was attractive but not very varied, and at times one longed for some good old soprano neurosis to break through all the languid Gallic sensuality.

Two songs from Berlioz's cycle Les Nuits d'été set the mood from the start. Gens sang with a clear, simple and lovely tone, free from affectation. Accompanying, Roger Vignoles was sensitive and responsive, playing with a deftness and lightness of touch that was an apt support to the long, sustained vocal lines. It didn't always seem easy for Gens to pass from mid-range to the high notes, but when she stayed in her higher range for more than a moment, as she did in Le Spectre de la Rose, the resulting phrase was full of richness and tantalisingly brief.

Fauré's earliest published work, Le Papillon et le Fleur, revealed that when the composer was a student he had already pinned down the gift for charming and evocative lyricism, which Gens amply conveyed in four of his other settings.

Four songs by Reynaldo Hahn (a French composer born in Venezuela in 1875) were more varied. Trois Jours de Vendange introduced a note of tragedy, while A Chloris owed more than a little debt to the Baroque airs of Handel and JS Bach.

Book I of Debussy's F tes Galantes and his Chansons de Bilitis raised Vignoles's role to that of duet partner. Gens was still communicative and natural but, as earlier, showed a tendency to let her tone slacken at the end of phrases, and her dynamic range remained largely unexplored.

She was more animated in Poulenc's Banalités, a cycle of sharply-observed settings of poetry by Apollinaire. The fast, almost schmaltzy waltz that is Voyage à Paris was sung with a broad smile, yet the next song, Sanglots (Sobs), was as intense and dark as its title suggests.

This programme explored one side of Gens's performing persona very thoroughly, yet she can do much more. It was a nice touch to throw in Purcell's Fairest Isle as an encore, a tribute to a British audience. A little more of such variety earlier on would have better highlighted her considerable skill.

webTitle: Discount deals flourish as Bank holds its hand on interest rates

fields.headline: Discount deals flourish as Bank holds its hand on interest rates
fields.standfirst: The issue explained: Setting Britain's interest rates
fields.trailText: Homebuyers are ditching fixed rate loans in favour of discount mortgages in the belief that, after this week's Bank of England decision to keep base rates on hold, interest rates will soon peak, then begin marching down again by 2002.
fields.body:
The fix has died, long live the discount. Homebuyers are ditching fixed rate loans in favour of discount mortgages in the belief that, after this week's Bank of England decision to keep base rates on hold, interest rates will soon peak, then begin marching down again by 2002.

Halifax has unveiled a new range of discount mortgages which brokers say are among the best currently available. For first time buyers able to stump up a 25% deposit, it is offering a two-year discount of 2.05% off its current standard variable rate of 7.74% to give a rate of 5.69%.

The smaller the deposit, the smaller the discount. For loans of up to 97% of the value of the house, the discount will be 1.99% for two years. Neither loan has lock-in penalties, which means that even if you quit during the discount period you won't face a repayment fee.

Note the 97% maximum. Only last week, Halifax raised its maximum "loan to value" from 95% to 97%, provoking concern that rising house prices plus competition among lenders is encouraging home buyers to stretch themselves to affordability limits.

The higher loan limits also come with a sting in the tail. Borrowers who put up a deposit smaller than 10% of the value of the house will usually have to pay a mortgage indemnity premium, which in the case of a £100,000 loan can cost around £1,700.

Abbey National also unveiled a 2% discount mortgage, giving an initial rate of 5.74% and no exit penalties if you pay a booking fee of £195. The minimum deposit, however, is 10%.

Siobahn Hotten of brokers John Charcol says homebuyers are spurning fixed rate deals in favour of discount loans. "In some ways it's quite odd. Historically people have jumped into fixes when they expect rates to rise. But this time they're opting for discounts, partly because they don't have redemption penalties but mostly because the rates are so much better than the fixes now on offer."

For example, Halifax's current two-year fix is 6.19%, or nearly half a per cent above the discount rate, plus you have lock-in penalties during the term of the fix.

Of course, rates could shoot up, leaving all those on discounts wishing they had taken a fix. One way to avoid that problem is to take a "discount plus cap" loan, which limits the maximum rate that you will pay on the mortgage. John Charcol is offering a deal it has agreed with Yorkshire building society where the maximum interest rate charged will be 6.99% over the next five years.

Northern Rock is also offering a capped rate of 6.3% for two years with a £500 cashback. Redemption penalties apply in the first two years.

A further approach to second-guessing future moves in interest rates is to look at tracker mortgages.

These follow base rates up and down, usually in the form of base rate plus 0.5-1%. Understandably these have not been popular in recent months as rates have risen and are expected to go higher. But this week Legal & General issued a tracker which is charged at 0.79% over base rate, giving an initial pay rate of 6.79%, which is then further reduced by a two-year discount, taking the rate to just 6.09%.

The main advantage of the tracker concept is that you are guaranteed that when rates do start heading south, your lender will pass on the difference immediately rather than passing on just small cuts as happens frequently.

The only catch with the L&G loan is that you have to put up a 25% deposit. For deposits smaller than 25%, the start rate is 6.29%.

What do the experts predict will happen with interest rates? City investment bank Salomon Smith Barney this week said that it believes the prospect of the UK joining the euro is "receding to the distant horizon", so there is little chance of a lurch down to interest rates common among the European countries.

Its forecast is that base rate will rise from 6% to 7% by the end of this year and hit a peak of somewhere between 7% and 8% in 2001.

If so, that will result in a Halifax standard rate of 9.75%. So don't hang about - bag yourself a deal quick while the going is good.

webTitle: Low-cost plan may aid the rich

fields.headline: Low-cost plan may aid the rich
fields.standfirst: Relaxed rules for the stakeholder scheme could open the way for abuse writes Tony Levene
fields.trailText: Relaxed rules for the stakeholder scheme could open the way for abuse
fields.body:
Stakeholder pensions are set to be wide open to manipulation by wealthy tax avoiders - the very antithesis of the group that the low cost pensions should appeal to.

Although there is a £3,600 limit on annual contributions, pensions experts say the Inland Revenue has no method of preventing plan buyers purchasing more than the upper yearly ceiling by going to more than one pensions company.

One said that the system - due in April 2001 - would be impossible to monitor. A second believes that "they are more likely to find a market among the well off and their tax advisers than among the poor for whom stakeholder is intended".

Stakeholder pensions have been designed to "make pension provision available to millions of people who have previously not been able to save into a pension". It was envisaged that most buyers would be in the £9,000 to £18,000 annual income band. The plans will replace personal pensions for most - providing better value with their low costs.

But for the well off involved in tax planning, the biggest advantage of stakeholder is the ability for all the family to have one. Only those in final salary based company plans will be banned.

Personal pensions apply only to "net relevant earnings" - money from work rather than capital gains, dividend income or interest. And they are linked to earnings levels - the maximum percentage retirement income savers can put in varies according to age. For those up to 35, the upper limit is 17.5% of net relevant earnings while for the 60 plus purchaser, the ceiling is 40%.

But those links are broken by stakeholder. Anyone will be able to pay in up to £3,600 a year, irrespective of earnings. On top of that, contributions are paid net of basic rate income tax so, assuming the April 2001 tax rate is 22%, plan holders need pay only £78 for each £100 in pension. There is no need to fill in a tax rebate form as the tax is deducted at source. Higher rate taxpayers will be able to reclaim the difference between the two levels.

Within the rules, a better off person could put in £3,600 and the same amount again for a partner, children, and anyone else under 75 in the family. The absence of an earnings link makes investment for everyone much easier.

Each £3,600 invested will bring tax relief of £792, while the fund will grow free of income and capital taxes. Under present rules, stakeholder buyers will be able to take out 25% of their final pension pool as tax free cash and defer buying an annuity until they are 75. But with compulsory annuities under fire, few believe the system will stay unchanged over the next decades so it could be worthwhile investing in the new system for children.

The Inland Revenue limited the number of plans any one could take out to one a year for a general Pep, and to one every five years for Tessa. It used national insurance numbers to check on those buying over the limit.

It has had more consumer confusion with Isas where up to three can be held in any one tax year, but it still uses national insurance numbers as a check.

However, with stakeholder, there is no limit on how many plans can be opened in one year, providing each is at least £20 and the total does not top £3,600. Pensions specialists say you could have 180 plans a year and stay within the rules. So it is far easier to go over the limit inadvertently or to top the ceiling on purpose.

The ability to buy a stakeholder for babes in arms removes the national insurance number check. NI numbers are given out only as teenagers approach their 16th birthday.

Going over the £3,600 limit could help someone hit by the "pension cap" - the upper earnings limit for pensions contributions, currently £90,600.

But groups like Scottish Life have warned that at the other end of the earnings scale, the least well off might do better spending their money rather than putting it into a pension - and then applying for means-tested income support on retirement.

A £20 a month payment for someone now 20 years away from retirement is unlikely to produce an annuity of much more than £10 to £12 a week.

The Inland Revenue concedes that it is easier to go over the top - inadvertently or otherwise - than under the present personal pensions rules. It hopes to control purchases by the wealthy by asking them to list plans on self assessment tax returns. But it says it has no firm plans at present.

"We don't think there will be much abuse. But we are consulting pension providers," a spokesperson says.

webTitle: The eagle lands a direct hit

fields.headline: The eagle lands a direct hit
fields.trailText: You've got to hand it to Barclays - when it comes to dropping the smelly stuff on customers from a great height, the big blue eagle really did itself proud this week.
fields.body:
You've got to hand it to Barclays - when it comes to dropping the smelly stuff on customers from a great height, the big blue eagle really did itself proud this week.

On Wednesday, Barclays stressed its determination to press ahead with its proposal to charge non-customers who use its cash machines - a plan which it presumably believes every other bank should put in place too.

On the very same day it emerged that it is shutting more than 170 branches all on the same date - April 7. Around 90 of these are the last remaining or only banks in their communities, according to the Campaign for Community Banking Services.So it is leaving many thousands of its customers high, dry and bankless, yet is pushing for a system that means that if they have the temerity to get money out of another institution's cashpoint, they get clobbered.

So the great cash machines saga trundles on, with no consumer-friendly solution in sight. In an attempt to extricate some answers from the industry, trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers called representatives of the Link network and leading banks and building societies in for a meeting where he told them they "should not underestimate the feeling of anger amongst their customers" as a result of their decision to introduce a surcharge. He would not hesitate to throw the book at them if they went ahead with unreasonable charges.

As a result, it now looks virtually certain that no cash machine user will be double-charged for taking out their own money. Link chairman John Hardy emerged from the meeting to say that its members were set to ban double charging, where someone using another bank's machine is hit with both a disloyalty charge from their own bank and a surcharge from the bank owning the ATM. This puts an end to the threat that customers might be charged £2.50 for taking out £10 or £20.

But this comes as scant consolation when nobody knows just how much these single charges are going to be. Apart from Barclays, which says £1, banks have failed to give any indication of how much non-customers will have to pay from January next year. Mr Hardy says this will remain the domain of each individual institution.

Meanwhile, the anti-charges protest is gathering momentum. Yorkshire Building Society, which is running a "Stop the Charges" campaign, says it has received more than 13,000 signatures in just two days. It has put petitions in all its branches and is also inviting people to register their displeasure by logging on to its website (www.ybs.co.uk) or phoning a cheap-rate phone line, 0870-1200-803, and leaving their name and address.

People who do still end up facing an exorbitant cash machine penalty will soon be able to get money at their local pub. Scottish & Newcastle Retail this week announced it is extending its cashback facility to more than 2,000 of its pubs and pub restaurants by the end of this year.

Those selected to offer up to £50 cashback will include country pubs some distance from a cashpoint. You won't have to pay any charges but you'll need to spend £2 or more at the pub to use the facility.

webTitle: Target Europe as your pet project

fields.headline: Target Europe as your pet project
fields.standfirst: With the right skills and qualifications, you're hot to trot
fields.trailText: With the right skills and qualifications, you're hot to trot
fields.body:
Do you want to be a good European and work in Europe? If your answer is yes, then the good news is that opportunities have never been greater, with the most sought-after graduates being those with IT, engineering and language skills.

There are a number of ways to scoop a dream job in Europe. If you're adventurous you may want to jet off to your chosen destination, find a relatively unskilled job when you arrive and network your way to the top.

The more conventional route, however, is to work for a company that also has offices on the continent. Some of the UK's top companies have several European locations, including oil giant Shell and consultants Cap Gemini and Andersen Consulting.

Claire Simpson, a senior programmer with Cap Gemini opted for this career path. "One of the reasons I joined Cap Gemini was because it had offices all over Europe and I wanted to see the world within my job," explains Claire, a Sussex University graduate. Last year she worked in Switzerland for just over three months.

She speaks French, but didn't get to use the language much as her colleagues spoke a Franco-German dialect. Claire hopes to continue working abroad, but only on short term stints.

For final-year students with their sights set on getting their first graduate job in Europe, help is at hand.

EMDS is one of a growing number of international recruitment consultancies which target multi-lingual final year students and graduates with up to five years experience.

Twice a year EMDS sends up to 1,000 applicants to meet between 25 and 60 companies at a recruitment fair in Brussels. Candidates invited to the fair are guaranteed an interview and more than 50% receive at least one job offer. The next event is on April 28 2000.

Though it is possible to obtain a graduate job in Europe straight after university, some careers advisers suggest that you get at least one or two years experience first in a UK-based job.

"Job hunters at graduate level in Europe are much older than British graduates and a lot of them have done work experience," says Andrew Whitmore, a senior careers adviser at Manchester University and UMIST.

"A 21 or 22-year-old may be considered too inexperienced and too young."

Your starting point in finding a job in Europe is to work out exactly what you want to do and in which country.

Begin by looking in the UK broadsheets which regularly advertise a number of professional and executive positions in Europe. It is worth getting hold of foreign newspapers, which are sold in larger newsagents. You could even place your own ad in the "situations wanted" section - a popular route for finding a job in Germany, for example.

Trade and professional publications are also useful, as are specialist titles such as Home and Away and Overseas Jobs Express. The Overseas Placing Unit which is linked to job centres can also inform you about job opportunities in Europe.

But this method of job hunting has a number of limitations: in many cases the vacancies may be ones that are difficult to fill locally. "The system is best suited to those who have a sought-after skill or experience to offer," says Mark Hempshell writing in Getting a job in Europe (How To Books).

"Even then the chances of being offered a job are minimal. It is essential to have language ability in the country in question and the OPU cannot help with arranging interviews, contracts and permits."

If possible use the state employment service of the relevant country and private employment agencies in the UK and Europe. Finally, try contacting embassies, professional associations and chambers of commerce for details of employers to whom you can send speculative letters.

Some good news on this front if you happen to be looking for a job in France - 78% of French employers recruit from speculative applications, compared with just 64% who advertise in the press.

 Working in Europe is by the Association of Graduate Careers Advisory and published by CSU publications.

Working Abroad by Jonathan Golding is published by International Venture Handbooks.

For the Overseas Placing Unit telephone 0114 259 6051.

Useful websites

www.emdsnet.com

www.eurograduate.com

www.eurojobs.com

fields.headline: Top rung/Bottom Rung
fields.trailText: Two employees of the TGWU share their thoughts of life at the top and the bottom of the organisation
fields.body:
Margaret Prosser
Aged 62
Deputy general secretary TGWU

Margaret Prosser, now her union's no 2, admits that her rise was a stroke of luck. "It was the 80s and while the industrial officers were dealing with redundancies and tumbling union membership, I was working in a field (women's issues) whose time had come," she explains.

CV to date: Margaret joined the TGWU in the mid-70s and within four years was on the women's advisory committees. By 1983 she was a full-time official in the public services sector and in 1992 became the union's national organiser. She was elected deputy general secretary in 1998.

Union stats: The TGWU is Britain's second largest union with 850,000 members ranging from airline cabin crews to public sector employees. The union has a growing presence in high street retailing.

In her present role, Margaret deputises for the general secretary and, day to day, co-ordinates the union's political activities. She is also treasurer of the Labour Party.

What's the buzz? "Making a difference for members by improving their situation. For example, education gives ordinary people the confidence to go forward."

Graduate opportunities? The TGWU recruits college leavers for research and policy work.

Bottom Rung</B

Sharon Graham
Aged 31
National youth and development officer TGWU

Sharon Graham arrived at the union via the TUC's organising academy which fast-tracks young talent. She was one of 33 - from 4,000 appilcants - selected for the first intake to undergo 12 months training.

While at the academy, trainees learn to organise campaigns through central tuition and on-the-job placements.

Dream job? "I originally wanted to be a journalist. But when I worked in an estate agents as a secretary I joined the TGWU and, having had the support of the union, I decided I wanted to be part of it."

Current tasks: Sharon is involved with the organisation of young members and recruitment of potential members. It includes workplace campaigns around th country.

"Graduates can be recruited directly as researchers or via the TUC's academy which is in its third year and proving a great success. The union stereotype is breaking down and its image has definitely improved."

Next move: "It's a massive job to develop young workers. And I see myself involved in this for a long time to come."

Final thought: "It's hard work but very rewarding."

For more details visit the TGWU website: www.tgwu.org.uk

fields.headline: Trouble at t'mall
fields.standfirst:
Candide 2000
Tramway @ Old Fruitmarket, Glasgow
****
fields.trailText: The best of all possible worlds versus a normal amount of unhappiness: this is the drama at the heart of Voltaire's wicked, funny and silly satire, Candide. While the details change, this core philosophical tussle remains in Suspect Culture's wise yet wild modern-day adaptation. In purely theatrical terms, this is much closer to the best of all possible worlds than the mundanely miserable alternative.
fields.body:
The best of all possible worlds versus a normal amount of unhappiness: this is the drama at the heart of Voltaire's wicked, funny and silly satire, Candide. While the details change, this core philosophical tussle remains in Suspect Culture's wise yet wild modern-day adaptation. In purely theatrical terms, this is much closer to the best of all possible worlds than the mundanely miserable alternative.

The setting is a mammoth shopping centre called Clearwater, perfect just now for a spot of existential angst. Here gather a posse of disaffected teenagers (superbly played by local teens - the first time I've seen this done minus the cringe factor), a few grown-ups disenchanted with life and a band playing Pulp-like accompaniments to the action.

Colin (Colin McCredie) starts out happy, an employee of Fiesta Mexico, a foul fakery like all the other food outlets, but learns the hard way to distrust the empowering self-help corporate-speak spouted by his boss. He falls in love, falls into a living Hell, falls into an Edenic paradise on Earth ("that's not a landscaped car park, it's a landscape!") and by the end, falls out of them all into his own reconciliation with reality. The story we know, but it's the way this ver sion tells it that matters ultimately.

Thirty pieces of theatre - slivers of narrative for an attention-deficient culture - are delivered within the space of the shopping mall, as if it's the limits of our collective imagination. This structuring works emphatically to bring the point home: we have more than ever before, we have more choice than ever before, but we are also more restless, more disappointed with ourselves, than ever before. And therein lies the limits of this otherwise hugely engaging production: we already know that. Ours is a hard time to satire because we know the vacuity of our deepest and yet most shallow pleasures even as we indulge them.

The same is true of the self-help-speak satirically targeted throughout. Bridget Jones has already been there, done that, so it hardly feels cutting edge. What does is the set (it's the mall but it also looks like those bridges over busy roads, always home to bored adolescents), the music, the writing (David Greig, yet again) and the timeless observations that still feel just like now. "You hate us because we're different; we hate you because you're all the same." Teenage kicks in this instance, but true to Voltaire, too. That takes some doing.

 Ends tonight, then touring to Newcastle, Aberdeen, Inverness and Edinburgh; tour details: 0141-248 8052.

webTitle: Help: I'm not being taxed enough!

fields.headline: Help: I'm not being taxed enough!
fields.trailText:
I haven't enough to do - I'm bored witless but don't want to draw attention to it and put myself out of a job.
Janina S, marketing data analyst, Norwich
fields.body:
I haven't enough to do - I'm bored witless but don't want to draw attention to it and put myself out of a job.
Janina S, marketing data analyst, Norwich

Quite right too. Complaining about this will show you've either no initiative or that you're superfluous. Although being under-occupied can be stressful, it's easily remedied. Take a closer look at those around you. If they're genuinely busy, make everyone happy by offering to take over some of their work.

If they're all underemployed, they'll have developed strategies to hide it and conduct a pleasant existence. There's much you can learn

from them. A job that's unable to keep you fully occupied leaves a lot of scope for personal development, just use your imagination. It's not unknown for people to write novels in order to compensate for the strain of being paid to do less than they're comfortable with.

Easier to justify if questioned are activities that appear work-related. Improve your internet techniques by undertaking some web based research; increase your job knowledge by reading related periodicals, going to conferences or arranging visits to clients or suppliers. Fine tune your communication skills by having lengthy conversations with your colleagues, or spending hours on the phone.

You may have stumbled across one of the few remaining sanctuaries of pressure free work - count yourself lucky. If you can't enjoy this rare and endangered environment, leave it unharmed for others who will appreciate the tranquillity it offers. Remove yourself quietly. You'll have no trouble finding activity, stress and overwork elsewhere.

Email Irene Krechowieka at ijk@excite.com

webTitle: How to ... handle colleagues who covet your job

fields.headline: How to ... handle colleagues who covet your job
fields.standfirst: There is room for both of you to shine
fields.trailText: There is room for both of you to shine
fields.body:
You have to feel sorry for William Hague. No, really. Not content with leading one of the most shambolic political parties in living memory, he is now consistently under threat from the gleamingly ambitious Michael Portillo. For Hague, anxieties about his performance as leader can only be exacerbated by the knowledge that the malevolent Michael is constantly leering over his shoulder.

"I know just how he feels and its not pleasant," admits Ian Sharpe, who works as a design editor on a glossy magazine.

"For six months my picture editor, David, made it clear he wanted my job - he thought he could do it better than me, that my ideas were old-fashioned and dull. He was always schmoozing to the managing editor and at strategy meetings, although he would never criticise me directly, he would always gently criticise my ideas."

Feeling threatened by a colleague can cause all sorts of problems - and it's important to establish just why you think this way about them. "I think the first thing you need to ask yourself is why you are being so paranoid," says Mark Hastings, head of policy at the Institute of Management.

"What areas of your job are you not doing well in, or do you feel anxious about? You must have some insecurities, or you wouldn't feel threatened. It's important to establish what these areas are, and make some changes."

Ian Sharpe agrees: "Although I was right about him wanting my job - a couple of colleagues confirmed he had admitted it over a few beers in the pub - I was surprised to find how much his attitude worried me. Instead of dismissing the whole thing, I became very worried about my position - and I had to ask myself why.

"I realised that I was concerned he was better than me - that I wasn't innovative enough, that I had 'lost my edge', so to speak. If I had felt more confident about my ability to do the job, I know I would have coped with the situation better."

"What is dangerous with this sort of situation is that it can become a downward spiral," says business consultant Robert Kayler. "You feel threatened by a colleague so you feel more insecure, then more threatened. As soon as you start to feel anxious about a situation like this, it's important to take action.

"Take the person out for lunch or coffee, so you can get a better idea of what areas of responsibility they are looking for. And reassure yourself of your own abilities - make a list of successes that you have had, problems you have solved - and feel good about your achievements."

In theory, it all sounds easy, but professional confidence can be a precarious thing - and the best way to avoid becoming increasingly insecure is to take control of the situation. "A while ago I had a senior buyer, Gina, working for me who was hugely driven," says Claire Franksome, head of buying for a large store.

"She was always in the office before me, stayed after I left, constantly bursting with new ideas. I felt so threatened by her that I didn't really encourage her. Her reaction was to go the MD and announce that she felt I was holding her back and not giving her enough responsibility."

"It is important not to fear someone else's ambition - but instead see it as a bonus," says Mark Hastings. "Try and empower them - give them a project of their own, something to make them feel that their talents are being utilised. And try and learn from them. What talents do they have that make you insecure? And how can you improve your own talents in that area?"

Claire needed the reassurance of her boss before she could really got to grips with the situation. "I had a meeting with the MD who told me what Gina had said, and suggested that I give her more responsibility.

"He also made clear how happy he was with the job I was doing which made me feel a million times better. After that I tried to see Gina as a positive asset to the team and increased her areas of responsibility. I still had the odd twinge of anxiety, but trying to see her as an ally, rather than an enemy, made things much, much easier."

If you don't remember anything else, remember this ...

If you're worried about the ambition of others, you're probably more worried about yourself. Don't transfer your anxieties - face them - polish up your skills, feel proud of your talents and remember that there's room for both of you to shine.

"A while ago I had a senior buyer, Gina, working for me who was hugely driven," says Claire Franksome, head of buying for a large store. "She was always in the office before me, stayed after I left, constantly bursting with new ideas. I felt so threatened by her that I didn't really encourage her. Her reaction was to go the MD and announce that she felt I was holding her back and not giving her enough responsibility." "It is important not to fear someone else's ambition - but instead see it as a bonus," says Mark Hastings. "Try and empower them - give them a project of their own, something to make them feel that their talents are being utilised. And try and learn from them. What talents do they have that make you insecure? And how can you improve your own talents in that area?" Claire needed the reassurance of her boss before she could really got to grips with the situation. "I had a meeting with the MD who told me what Gina had said, and suggested that I give her more responsibility. "He also made clear how happy he was with the job I was doing which made me feel a million times better. After that I tried to see Gina as a positive asset to the team and increased her areas of responsibility. I still had the odd twinge of anxiety, but trying to see her as an ally, rather than an enemy, made things much, much easier." If you don't remember anything else, remember this ... If you're worried about the ambition of others, you're probably more worried about yourself. Don't transfer your anxieties - face them - polish up your skills, feel proud of your talents and remember that there's room for both of you to shine.

webTitle: Don't go overboard on travel insurance

fields.headline: Don't go overboard on travel insurance
fields.standfirst: Agents and insurers go for a hard sell but it makes sense to tailor your spending to the level of risk you face, says Richard Colbey
fields.trailText: It seems to be taken for granted that anyone travelling abroad needs insurance. But the enthusiasm with which travel agents and insurance companies push this "product" reflects its profitability rather than travellers' needs.
fields.body:
It seems to be taken for granted that anyone travelling abroad needs insurance. But the enthusiasm with which travel agents and insurance companies push this "product" reflects its profitability rather than travellers' needs.

Indeed, so great are the margins on some policies, that in 1998 regulations were introduced banning tie-ins between holiday offers and insurance. While the market has become more competitive, this is largely because the majority who go on low-risk beach or city holidays subsidise the few who prefer more hazardous activities.

It is perhaps, then, disappointing to hear the Consumers' Association unquestioningly assert in the latest edition of Which?: "Whether you plan to trek in Nepal or sun yourself in Spain, proper travel insurance is vital."

It is hard to see how insurance against anything except medical emergencies can ever be vital. Other losses, such as stolen baggage or cancellation, covered by insurance rarely exceed £1,000. Many people would prefer to bear that risk rather than pay for disproportionately expensive insurance.

Indeed, typical policies only allow £250 cover for valuables - less than the cost of a decent camera. Baggage cover is normally £2,000 but unless one opts for the few (and expensive) policies offering new for old, the pay-out, based on second-hand values, will be a pittance if a suitcase of clothes is stolen.

Which? points out that if baggage is lost by an airline, its liability is restricted to around £14 per kilo. This only applies to checked-in baggage and even then is not, strictly speaking, accurate, as the airline will be required to pay the full amount if the loss was caused through its recklessness. While this would not always be easy to prove, airlines often accept the greater liability rather than risk bad publicity. The £14 is likely to be as much as an insurance company would pay anyway.

Travel insurance usually covers against claims by third parties if there is an accident, but this won't extend to liability when driving. Most household insurance policies provide this protection anyway. Except when doing something inherently hazardous like driving or boating, it would not occur to most people to seek out liability insurance at home. There is no greater need for it on holiday.

Insuring against medical bills is another matter. Simply getting a broken leg set in America is likely to cost more than £2,000, while surgery and a lengthy stay in hospital there will consume the life savings of all but the very rich. In developing countries treatment may be relatively cheap, but most hospitals lack facilities.

Having an insurance company to arrange and pay for transport to a major hospital in a capital city or for a flight home could be, literally, a life saver. For the £30 or so three weeks' cover costs, only the foolhardy would visit America or a developing country uninsured.

Throughout the EU medical cover is available free or cheaply, as it is in Australia and New Zealand. The form E111 available from Post Offices should be carried, though some continental hospitals won't actually want to see it. Even after producing the form, some fees may be payable, though these are unlikely to be ruinous. What will not be covered is the cost of getting home by air ambulance if you are seriously ill or likely to be incapacitated for a long time.

A Consumer' Association spokeswoman said travel insurance was vital "because it gives peace of mind". However, the Association of British Insurers takes a more pragmatic stance. Its spokeswoman said: "Whether or not to insure on holidays is purely a matter of personal preference.

"Different holidays in the same country have different risks. If you went pony trekking in the Pyrenees, you would be at much greater risk than if you are just going to lie on a Spanish beach." She, like the CA, emphasised the importance of shopping around and investigating whether one is already covered through, for instance, a bank or credit card.

There are no statistics about what proportion of travel insurance premiums is actually paid out to claimants, but the cost of advertising and brokers' commission as well as 4% tax, on top of the insurers' own profits, mean that it is perhaps around 75%.

Those who buy insurance, then simply sit on a Spanish beach, are inevitably paying a high price for the peace of mind that the CA considers so essential.

 Richard Colbey is a barrister
