webTitle: Small investors cash in on the net

fields.headline: Small investors cash in on the net
fields.standfirst:
A treasure trove of free and up-to-date information can give your amateur portfolio that professional edge, reports Rupert Jones

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The growth of the internet means the small private investor now has access to a wealth of information and tools that, up until a few years ago, were strictly the preserve of the professionals.
fields.body:
The growth of the internet means the small private investor now has access to a wealth of information and tools that, up until a few years ago, were strictly the preserve of the professionals.

Not only has the net forced sharedealing costs down - it also means the world is your oyster. You can research companies in Seattle, Stuttgart or anywhere in between, find out how stock markets across the globe are performing and call up the latest investment news all at the click of a mouse.

The internet has also made it much easier to monitor how your shares and other investments are doing.

But the sheer volume of material in cyberspace can produce that "I don't know where to start" feeling. That's where personal finance sites such as MoneyWorld (www.moneyworld.co.uk), Interactive Investor International (www.iii.co.uk) and the Guardian's moneyUnlimited (www.moneyunlimited.co.uk) come in.

These three, and a number of other sites, all offer "portfolio management services", which let you track the performance of a whole range of investments, from shares and products such as personal equity plans and individual savings accounts, to pensions and offshore funds.

With most of the sites, the service is free. You can have as many or as few investments in your portfolio as you like, and amend it as you wish. You can view the latest share prices, call up historical performance data, and measure the performance of your imvestments against the various indices, and display this in graph form. You can even set up some systems to notify you when a share you are interested in hits a certain price.

If you're wondering what's in it for the websites, the answer is that these services are a very good way of getting people to come back time and time again, explains John Blowers at Interactive Investor International. They are all desperate to build up user loyalty - the more page views they get and the higher the number of regular users, the more they can charge advertisers.

"There's a battle of the portfolio tracking services going on out there," says Danny Bowers, editor of MoneyWorld.

Between them, MoneyWorld and Interactive Investor International have close to 400,000 people using their portfolio services. This number is growing all the time. This week, another investor website, Sharepages.com, entered the fray, launching its own portfolio tool.

So what sort of people make use of these services - hardcore investors dabbling in the latest internet stocks or cautious types checking on their pension?

Well, almost nine out of 10 are male; some log on to their portfolios as often as 500 times a day, and contrary to what you might expect, the shares people are tracking are predominantly blue chip demutualisation and privatisation stocks, rather than racy technology shares.

These are just some of the findings of an analysis of MoneyWorld's database of portfolio service users carried out for Jobs & Money. MoneyWorld has 171,000 people using its facility, who between them have a total of 280,000 portfolios.

 The average user has 10 shares and two funds of some sort in their portfolio(s).

 60% of users are aged 26 to 45, and 86% are male.

 More than a seventh (15%) work in finance, while another 17% are employed in IT.

 70% earn more than £20,000 a year, while 19% earn £50,000-plus.

 The most popular share held is BT, followed by, in order: British Airways, Halifax, Marks & Spencer, Vodafone AirTouch, Lloyds TSB, Abbey National and Norwich Union. Surprisingly, the highest-ranking hi-tech stock is Pacific Media, which is the 20th most-held share, while ARM Holdings, the computer chip manufacturer, comes in at number 24.

 The most popular unit trusts are, in order: M&G UK Equity, Aberdeen Technology, Jupiter European, INVESCO GT European Growth, and Virgin UK Index Tracker.

 The majority of users have just one portfolio but a few have 10 or more, and three have at least 50.

 Four in 10 users log on to their portfolio either once a day, every other day or once a week. Almost 15% have logged on only once so far, which suggests that for many of these people, the portfolio service is a novelty that has failed to grab them. At the other end of the spectrum, five users log on an average of 50 times a day to see how their investments are doing, while one person taps into his/her portfolio a staggering 500 times a day - that's every three minutes. Far be it for us to point the finger, but that sounds suspiciously like a day trader type, sitting behind a terminal all day frantically buying and selling volatile net stocks.

Mr Bowers says that a good portfolio facility should be very fast to load on to the screen, and should enable the user to quickly configure exactly what he or she wants to view. "Some users are only interested in seeing a share's mid-price. Others want to see the opening, the high for the day, the low, the close, the spread and the trading volume. And users tell us time and time again that they want to see graphs - they want the flexibility to compare on a graph the share price performance of, say, BT, Cable & Wireless and the FTSE 100."

Some websites have subscription products aimed at the really serious investor. For example, Interactive Investor International has a "premium" service where, for £15 a month, users can enjoy real-time share price updates.

Sharepages.com's new portfolio management service is available to all internet users but will probably appeal to the seasoned investor more than the amateur.

It has less of the general information and more of the hard facts. As with other sites, it is free, with Sharepages.com making its money through advertising. Because it offers more specialised information, the site is also used by some fund managers.

Meanwhile, the Motley Fool personal finance website (www.fool.co.uk) is marketing itself as an education site and, as such, hopes to attract investment beginners who are looking in the first instance for information and in the second for money management services.

As well as setting up a real portfolio, the site lets you create a virtual one where you can experiment. Users can try a variety of different shares and find out if they have the aptitude for investing in this way before they commit any of their money.

The site as a whole has around 100,000 users, less than 50,000 of whom are thought to be users of the portfolio management service which, again, is free.

webTitle: Playtime as Microsoft enters games console market

fields.headline: Playtime as Microsoft enters games console market
fields.standfirst: The future of Microsoft - special report
fields.trailText: Parents beware. The games console market is set to become even more crowded from next year with the arrival of a console from Microsoft.
fields.body:
Parents beware. The games console market is set to become even more crowded from next year with the arrival of a console from Microsoft.

The X-Box unveiled yesterday in California by Bill Gates, Microsoft's chairman, brings the world's largest software manufacturer into the console market for the first time as a challenger to the established manufacturers Sony, Sega and Nintendo.

The X-Box, which Microsoft promises will be three times more powerful than Sony's PlayStation 2, will be launched in the US in the autumn of next year and is expected to be available in Britain by Christmas 2001.

The announcement was welcomed by UK game developers. Jez San, chief executive of Argonaut Games plc, said: "It's very good for the entire industry. It will enlarge the video game business."

Like PlayStation 2, the X-Box can be connected to modems, giving access to the internet.

According to indepen dent industry analysts Datamonitor, consoles have the potential to become the sole conduit into the home for digital entertainment such as games, internet access, music CDs and DVD movies.

"Microsoft has realised that the personal computer, its traditional home ground, is increasingly threatened in its role as the dominant gateway to the internet by devices such as mobile phones, set-top boxes and gaming consoles," said a spokesman.

"The arrival of the X-Box will be Microsoft's Trojan horse into the living room."

The global video game market is worth £12.6bn annually. The games market is worth £1bn in Britain, and is expected to generate more money than the music industry this year.

The X-Box is expected to retail for less than £300. It will contain two hugely powerful chips equivalent to the power of two PCs, and Microsoft said it would deliver movie-quality graphics and better, faster games.

fields.bylineHtml: Paul Kelso and Jack Schofield

fields.headline: Hold the joy and pain
fields.standfirst:
Shola Ama
Jazz Cafe, London
***
fields.trailText: The story goes that west London teenager Shola Ama was singing to herself at Hammersmith tube station one day when, in true pop-legend fashion, a record company scout happened by. Taken by her vampish soul style, he signed her up - and by the age of 18 she'd achieved a platinum-selling album and a Brit award. But this serendipitous good fortune is offset by what some might call a manifest lack of charisma - she's got the voice, the looks and the Rodney Jerkins-produced new LP, In Return, but she hasn't got the presence that might redeem a show that started 90 minutes late.
fields.body:
The story goes that west London teenager Shola Ama was singing to herself at Hammersmith tube station one day when, in true pop-legend fashion, a record company scout happened by. Taken by her vampish soul style, he signed her up - and by the age of 18 she'd achieved a platinum-selling album and a Brit award. But this serendipitous good fortune is offset by what some might call a manifest lack of charisma - she's got the voice, the looks and the Rodney Jerkins-produced new LP, In Return, but she hasn't got the presence that might redeem a show that started 90 minutes late.

Much is made of the fact that Ama is only 20, but this is one of those instances when youth has little to recommend it. Maybe by the time she's her heroine Aretha Franklin's age, she'll have enough experience under her gold silk belt to instil real joy and pain into her sumptuous songs. At the Jazz Cafe, she relied on Live & Kicking bubbliness ("Thanks, guys, and you'll probably know this next one"), technical skills and an impeccable band, but all of these were as nothing against the gig's lack of star quality.

There's an R&B subspecies called the slow jam that increasingly has cropped up at gigs. It's a groove-based meander that can go on for up to 10 minutes without reaching resolution or even chorus, giving the artist the chance to wander in and out of the song in patented "soulful" manner. Even the burningly charismatic Lauryn Hill has a hard time making them interesting, so what possessed Ama to base the majority of her set on them? They sedated the audience into head-nodding slumber from which they failed to wake even when the guitarist asked us to sing happy birthday to Shola.

The hits You Might Need Somebody and You're the One I Love produced a livelier response, due both to their brevity and Ama's rousing herself to deliver spirited versions that displayed her elastic range. This is where she should be heading, toward the mainstream regions where Whitney Houston flourishes. And if a little of Houston's imperious-diva attitude rubs off, so much the better.

fields.headline: Sainsbury sacks deputies
fields.standfirst: Payoffs could cost £1.5m but City rewards 'decisive Davis' with share price rise
fields.trailText: Sir Peter Davis, the new chief executive of Sainsbury, sacked two of his key deputies yesterday in a move that could cost the supermarket group up to £1.5m in payoffs.
fields.body:
Sir Peter Davis, the new chief executive of Sainsbury, sacked two of his key deputies yesterday in a move that could cost the supermarket group up to £1.5m in payoffs.

Sir Peter, who moved into Sainsbury only eight days ago, asked David Bremner, managing director of the ailing chain, and stores director Kevin McCarten to leave with immediate effect.

The City welcomed the decisive action and the shares climbed 21p, or 8.79%, to 260p, adding some £410m to the value of the group.

Sir Peter paid tribute to the two men - but pledged to fight any claims they might make for two year's money as compensation for loss of office.

The directors are in the middle of converting from two- year to one-year contracts, but the procedure had not been completed when Sir Peter made his move. Mr Bremner, 41, who has spent 15 years of his career with the Sainsbury group, could therefore be entitled to a payoff of up to £850,000 - twice his 1999 salary. Mr McCarten, also aged 41, earned £294,000 last year and could qualify for a £588,000 payout.

Yesterday Sir Peter said negotiations with the two men over their payoffs were under way but that he would seek to reduce their payoffs on the grounds that they were both likely to land new jobs quickly. "They are both exceedingly bright and young. We will argue very hard for mitigation on a two-year basis".

The management shake-up means that three of Sainsbury's top directors have been removed since the turn of the year. Chief executive Dino Adriano was asked to leave in January to make way for Sir Peter Davis.

The new chief executive, who was formerly at the Pru, was widely welcomed by investors and analysts. He had spent 10 years at Sainsbury between 1976 and 1986 and at the Pru he was credited with hauling the insurer back from the abyss of pensions misselling and masterminding the development of the much-admired Egg internet bank.

fields.headline: Davids trouncing Goliaths
fields.standfirst:
Banks which promised best ISA rates are lagging woefully behind the building societies. Jessica McCallin reports

www.leek-united.co.uk
www.dunfermline-bs.co.uk
www.smile.co.uk
fields.trailText: Banks which promised best ISA rates are lagging woefully behind the building societies
fields.body:
Abbey National and Halifax have fallen short of their promise to provide the best cash ISA products on the market, with competitors announcing much more attractive rates.

Building societies, including the little known Dunfermline and Leek United, are offering almost a whole percentage point more than the high street banks.

Dunfermline launched an ISA paying 7.5% last week and Leek United's rate has reached 7.25, rising 1% since its launch last April.

Coventry Building Society has also done well with rate increases of 0.5% to 7.05% since the New Year - 0.75% to 7.75% if you have been a member for five years.

And smile, the internet bank owned by the Co-op, is offering 7.25% on its ISA, having increased the rate by 0.25% on three different occasions since its launch in October 1999.

Halifax, on the other hand, has put its rates on a roller-coaster ride over the past year, resulting in minimal or non existent overall increases and comparatively low rates - usually less than one percentage point above the Bank of England's base rate.

A customer with less than £1,000 in a Halifax ISA will now be getting a rate which, at 4.15%, is just 0.15% higher than what was offered last April.

Balances between £1,000 and £2,999 are receiving the same 6% rate they got last April, and balances of over £3,000 will be getting 6.60%, just 0.10% more than the launch rate.

Abbey National's ISAs present a similar picture. Its rates have varied between 5.5% and 6.65%, at times dropping by as much as 0.5%.

The overall effect, however, is rates which more or less mimic those of last April. Customers with more than £3,000 in their ISA will now be receiving a rate of 6.65%, just 0.15% up on the launch rate and well below the rates offered by the building societies.

Customers with lower balances are not so lucky. Savings of between £100 and £2,999 are now being paid 6.15% interest, less than the 6.25% they received when the product was launched last April.

Customers with balances under £100 have seen rates go up and down throughout the year, but end up where they started at 6% - on par with the base rate.

Base rates dropped by a quarter of a percentage point to 5% last June, but have since been increased by a quarter of a percentage point on four different occasions. It now stands at 6%.

webTitle: Marriages made in heaven - and hell

fields.headline: Marriages made in heaven - and hell
fields.standfirst: A three-step plan to surviving a merger
fields.trailText: A three-step plan to surviving a merger
fields.body:
Mergers and acquisitions are back - big time. Judging from recent activity, companies in such industries as banking, insurance, telecomms and the media believe pairing off is the best way to grow and tap new markets.

But when companies join forces, every employee, from the chief exec to the still-wet-behind-the-ears graduate is affected.

Take the financial services industry as an example. Deutsche Bank, Germany's largest bank, and its rival Dresdner Bank announced this week that they were in talks that could create the world's biggest bank - and destroy 14,000 jobs.

The Brits don't like being outdone by the Germans, so the surrender of NatWest to the Royal Bank of Scotland is likely to cost 16,000. The proposed Norwich Union/CGU merger is small fry in comparison, able to muster only 4,000 job losses.

As it happens, evidence on the effectiveness of takeovers and mergers is inconclusive. If costs are slashed and disillusioned employees leave, service quality suffers, and customers depart.

But are the shareholders and board of directors going to listen to you? Are they heck.

And even if you are lucky enough to survive the inevitable cull, don't expect the transition to be smooth. You'll have to contend with organisational chaos and much uncertainty.

Yet if you play your cards right, a merger or acquisition could provide you with an early break.

Step one: Develop a plan.

You'll weather the transition better if you have a strategy for managing your career. Your plan should include goals for long-term career success and short-term job survival.

"Work out what your personal values are, which will help you when deciding whether you want to be part of the new organisation or not," says leadership development consultant and coach Valerie Waters. "Evaluate your strengths and what's special about you - this will help you to know your own value when it comes to considering options."

Don't be a victim - take personal control of your career path. You may be worried about a job or position change, but you don't have to feel demoralised. Toughen up mentally and make positive things happen by taking advantage of new opportunities that can often come as a result of mergers and takeovers.

Above all, don't panic. Some things never change. Mission statements and job descriptions come and go, but what's required of a good employee remains constant. Companies - even mega ones - need capable professionals like you to handle challenges, save time and improve efficiency. So if you're interested in being a survivor, show your new employer your willingness to help.

Step two: Get networking

Mergers test work relationships, especially those with colleagues whose jobs may be phased out. Your dealings with the people around you will take on a new dimension as job descriptions change and layoffs are announced. Your position may survive, but a colleague's might not. You'll need to listen and be empathetic to their plight. Offer encouragement and suggestions, and minimise your feeling of relief so you don't seem oblivious to their pain and worry.

At the same time accelerate your networking activities. Helping colleagues in both companies will be as important as gaining their assistance.

Many employees will lose jobs because of overlapping job descriptions and new priorities, not because they're incompetent. Be aware of openings and refer others whenever possible. By being helpful, you'll receive assistance when you need it.

"Speak to people in the other organisation to find out about culture rather than just listening to the myths and rumours," says Valerie. "Talk to friends and associates who have lived through a merger - ask them how they now view their experience and what they learned.

"And if the other organisation is one that you've worked for before - an increasingly common occurrence - find out who is still there that you know."

Step three: Remain vigilant

Recognise danger signals at work. These might include being left out of the loop or passed over for choice assignments, poor performance reviews, negative grapevine rumours or feeling uneasy around your boss.

But if you do happen to be one of those who fails to find a chair when the merger music stops, try to keep a sense of perspective, says Valerie. In today's working environment, most people's career paths will include umpteen jobs, several redundancies, and maybe even a couple of changes in vocation. "Mergers are just part of a bigger pattern," she says.

webTitle: Boards all set for rebel moves as D day looms

fields.headline: Boards all set for rebel moves as D day looms
fields.standfirst: Voting on the future of the Norwich Union and two building societies takes place soon. Tony Levene assesses the prospects
fields.trailText: It's make up your mind time for millions holding shares in Norwich Union and for members of the Skipton and Chelsea building societies. At stake is the future of these financial companies
fields.body:
It's make up your mind time for millions holding shares in Norwich Union and for members of the Skipton and Chelsea building societies. At stake is the future of these financial companies.

Norwich Union shareholders are being asked to vote their company into a merger with rival CGU to create the tongue-twisting CGNU, while savers and borrowers of the two building societies have to decide whether to continue backing their boards' pro-mutuality stances.

Even though the boards of all three organisations are pushing their own lines, all could receive a nasty jolt from rebel shareholders and members.

Norwich Union shareholders are being sent more than 300 pages of documentation. It details how they will receive 48 new CGNU shares for every 100 Norwich Union shares now held and how NU investors will collectively own 41.5% of the new company.

But nowhere is there any space devoted to those who might wish to vote against the marriage. All the reasoning is positive. Nor is there anything to help the many shareholders who are with-profits policy owners.

John Piaseycki, from Berkshire, says he is far more concerned about his endowment than his shares. "My policy is worth many times more. But there's no guidance as to how the merger will affect the with-profits fund other than saying shareholders could get their hands on some of the money. They don't seem to care about us as customers."

Norwich Union admits it is in a "Catch 22" position. It says it cannot legally answer with-profits queries until the merger is completed although it is aware that many regard these as central to deciding on the deal.

There is a voting slip should investors wish to disagree with the proposed £20bn union. Ballots must be returned by March 29 - unless shareholders turn up at the Wembley Conference Centre meeting on March 31.

Shareholders are being persuaded to vote in favour of the merger - technically a takeover by the larger CGU - with the carrots of a 30% higher dividend, cost savings of up to £250m a year (largely financed through redundancies), enhanced net asset value per share and an "improved strategic position".

And the merged group will have size - toppling the Prudential as Britain's biggest insurer and become a top five company in its sector in Europe. It will also have £200bn of assets under management with worldwide premium income and investment product sales topping £26bn.

One reason for voting against is the hope that another bidder will join the fray. For the merger presents no immediate takeover premium for stock holders in Norwich Union, which was demutualised in 1997. They are swapping their shares for no gain.

City analysts originally hoped for a counterbid from the likes of the French Axa, the German Allianz, the Dutch Aegon and the Italian Generali. But none of these European giants has shown the slightest interest so far.

The result is that all the big Norwich Union shareholders have lost interest and will vote in favour unless there is an eleventh hour change of mind. The Norwich Union share price which hit 500p last year, and stood at 460p after the deal was announced, has now slumped back to 400p indicating little chance of a hostile bid. And that's just 75p ahead of its first day's trading in June 1997.

But small investors, including disgruntled Norwich Union staff, who want to express displeasure at the way their company has been signed, sealed and delivered can still register a protest by voting against.

One angry Norwich Union shareholder, who posted a message on the Hemscott.Net bulletin board under, called the merger "rank bad value" and added: "There's no obvious benefit for shareholders and Norwich Union is not getting a great deal out of this merger."

The first hurdle for Norwich Union is to win acceptances from holders of 50.01% of shares - otherwise the deal falls. Individuals hold around 40% of the Norwich Union share base - mostly in small parcels averaging 300 shares currently worth about £1,200.

Were 25% to vote against, the group would be unable to pass certain resolutions at the extraordinary general meeting it has called. And if holders of more than 10% of the capital - one in four of the individual 1.2m shareholders - either vote against or abstain, Norwich Union will be unable to acquire outstanding shares compulsorily, although it will effectively be controlled by CGU.

Even if it gave up its official stock market quote, there could still be an unofficial market in the shares which would cause embarrassment to the combined CGNU board.

The two building societies are hoping to turn the tables on carpetbaggers by incorporating their resolutions. Members looking for a windfall are now suggesting voting against whatever the board recommends to register disapproval.

The Chelsea voting pack is being sent to members over the next two weeks.

This could produce bizarre results with carpetbaggers saying no to the first Chelsea resolution which invites the board to "consider the option of takeover or conversion." Chelsea says members should support this as it claims it does this every year as part of its essential planning.

The second supports the establishment of a charity to receive windfalls - again in line with Chelsea board thinking but one that will not be favoured by demutualisation supporters.

Chelsea ballots have to be returned by April 22 - unless members turn up at the annual meeting in Cheltenham on April 27.

The Skipton is fighting off its carpetbaggers with exactly the same tactics and with similarly-worded resolutions. Again, it expects members to vote for "considering changing the independent mutual status of the society" although it would not matter if they voted against.

The Skipton meeting is to be held in Skipton on April 26 - postal votes must arrive by April 20 while branch ballot boxes stay open until April 18.

The Portman pushed demutualisation off its agenda by throwing out members who supported a windfall resolution. Now savers and depositors who support a status change are being urged on the Carpetbagger.com site to vote against the re-election of directors.
